webTitle: Irish happy to be halfway there

fields.headline: Irish happy to be halfway there
fields.trailText: A good result tonight could see Ireland four points clear of the Dutch in Group Two.
fields.body:
By the halfway point of their Group Two campaign tonight the Republic of Ireland will expect their mid-term report to be adorned with gold stars. Defeat of Andorra at the Mini Estadi will leave Mick McCarthy's team in as healthy a position as they could have dared anticipate.

For a side who have already drawn in Holland and Portugal it is almost unthinkable that they will return from Spain without maximum points while Portugal and Holland slug it out in Lisbon.

"I would never be so arrogant or presumptuous to talk about the number of goals we could score. Talking like that is a sure-fire way to get a kick in the privates," said McCarthy.

"But yes, we have the incentive that if we win and Portugal gub Holland we will then be four points clear of the Dutch. Then Portugal would be coming to Dublin for a real showdown."

McCarthy has made two changes from Saturday's 4-0 win over Cyprus, with Blackburn's Damien Duff replacing his club-mate Jason McAteer and the Ipswich midfielder Matt Holland coming in for Charlton's Mark Kinsella.

Republic of Ireland (4-4-2): Given; G Kelly, Cunningham, Breen, Harte; Duff, Holland, Roy Keane, Kilbane; Robbie Keane, Connolly.

fields.headline: Hughes faces late test
fields.trailText: Aaron Hughes faces a late fitness test while Jim magilton's problems held up in training.
fields.body:
Aaron Hughes faces a fitness test this morning for a calf injury and some of his Northern Ireland team-mates were lucky not to join him on the treatment table after training on the rock-hard CSKA reserve pitch here ahead of tonight's Group Three game at Bulgarska Armia stadium.

But Jim Magilton, who has groin and hamstring problems, had no adverse reaction.

Bulgaria make no changes despite Biser Ivanov, Georgi Markov and Ilian Stoyanov arriving four hours late after a night on the town last Saturday.

Northern Ireland (probable; 4-4-1-1): Carroll (Wigan); A Hughes (Newcastle) or Nolan (Bradford), Williams (Wimbledon), Murdock (Preston), Griffin (Dundee Utd); Gillespie (Blackburn), Magilton (Ipswich), Lennon (Celtic), Elliott (Motherwell); M Hughes (Wimbledon); Healy (Preston).

webTitle: Giggs aims to find higher ground

fields.headline: Giggs aims to find higher ground
fields.trailText: Wales are hoping that Ryan Giggs' return will help inspire them to a first Group Five win.
fields.body:
Wales are hoping that Ryan Giggs' return will help inspire them to a first Group Five win this evening in Cardiff, where Ukraine are the visitors.

The Manchester United winger's availability after illness and injury is timely as Wales will miss John Robinson (suspended), Robbie Savage (knee) and Mark Pembridge, who injured a thigh in Saturday's 2-2 draw in Armenia.

"Ryan's like a lot of Welshman, myself included, who have had reasonably successful careers but have never played in a major finals for their country," said Mark Hughes, his national manager. "I'd like to achieve that now and I know Ryan desperately wants to show his talent on a world stage."

Matthew Jones of Leeds is expected to replace Pembridge while Giggs will step in for Robinson in an otherwise unchanged line-up. Savage was suspended for the draw in Yerevan.

Ukraine also have problems as Yuri Dmitrulin was carried off with a leg injury in Saturday's 0-0 home draw with Belarus, though Sergei Rebrov and Andriy Shevchenko will definitely feature along with Arsenal's Oleg Luzhny.

Wales (probable; 4-4-2): R Jones; Delaney, Page, Melville, Legg; Saunders, M Jones, Speed, Giggs; Hartson, Bellamy.

webTitle: Hoddle feels the pull of Spurs

fields.headline: Hoddle feels the pull of Spurs
fields.standfirst: Southampton manager meets Enic but Saints beg him to stay
fields.trailText: Glenn Hoddle was last night considering a return to his spiritual home as the new manager of Tottenham Hotspur, although Southampton are optimistic that he will stay on the south coast.
fields.body:
Glenn Hoddle was last night considering a return to his spiritual home as the new manager of Tottenham Hotspur. The former idol of White Hart Lane and odds-on favourite to replace the sacked George Graham was in surprise talks with the club yesterday immediately after returning from holiday in South Africa.

The Southampton manager and his agent Dennis Roach went straight from Heathrow to a secret London location for discussions with the Tottenham board about the vacancy, after Hoddle informed his current chairman Rupert Lowe of his intentions by phone from the airport at 8am.

The Tottenham chairman David Buchler has also just returned from South Africa after what he described as a "business weekend", prompting speculation that he had done the groundwork with Hoddle while out there.

The 43-year-old Hoddle, who played nearly 500 games for Spurs, will now return to Southampton, where Lowe will try to persuade him to stay. Privately Lowe is confident of winning the argument; Southampton are moving into a new 32,000-seat stadium next season, generating money for transfers as a result, and are still within sight of a European place through the Premiership.

Lowe has also just demonstrated the club's ambition by securing two of Southampton's most sought-after players, Dean Richards and James Beattie, on long-term contracts.

"We sincerely hope these discussions come to nothing and Glenn will stay at Southampton," he said. "But ultimately it will be one man and one man alone who makes the decision and that's Glenn Hoddle."

Hoddle's final decision will also be coloured by what he heard from Tottenham yester day. As well as discussing the size of his salary, he will want to know the size of his transfer kitty.

Although he built his reputation as a manager at clubs with limited budgets such as Swindon, Southampton and Chelsea before they opened the chequebook under Ruud Gullitt, he will not want to take on the task of turning Spurs into a major force with one hand tied behind his back.

Hoddle will only be too aware that it was Graham's public comments about the limited transfer funding available from Enic which led to the then manager being sacked this month. Tottenham's director of football David Pleat has been in temporary charge of the team as they approach two crucial games against Arsenal, one an FA Cup semi-final.

There was some initial anger at the Southampton end. The Spurs press officer John Fennelly announced yesterday afternoon: "We had permission from the Southampton chairman Rupert Lowe to stage talks." But Lowe initially denied this before, with an eye on persuading Hoddle to stay, he consented, saying: "I do not wish to jeopardise the excellent relationship I have with Glenn Hoddle."

Spurs said yesterday that they were looking at candidates other than Hoddle. Indeed Gullit claimed that he had also been approached but turned down the offer, saying: "I would prefer to stay here in Holland with all my friends and relatives."

The opinion of Southampton's players about Hoddle's likely decision was mixed. The captain Jason Dodd said: "Many of us thought he would speak to Spurs but that does not mean he will leave." But the midfielder Mark Draper was less optimistic: "He always told us he was happy here and I don't think he would be leaving for any other club except Spurs."

Hoddle would almost certainly take with him his assistant John Gorman, another former Spurs player. The favourites to replace Hoddle at Southampton include another former England coach in Kevin Keegan and the man Spurs have just sacked, George Graham.

webTitle: Hoddle is home banker for Spurs fans

fields.headline: Hoddle is home banker for Spurs fans
fields.standfirst: White Hart Lane awaits its favourite son, writes  Vivek Chaudhary
fields.trailText: There is little doubt at White Hart Lane that Hoddle will take the job. His appointment is imperative if the psychological and football damage inflicted on the club is to be repaired, writes Vivek Chaudhary.
fields.body:
Glenn Hoddle was giving nothing away at teatime yesterday as to when or whether he was taking the Tottenham manager's job, but there was no doubt among those connected with White Hart Lane.

"I think he'll take the job," the former Spurs player Graham Roberts declared. "I think Glenn wants to come home."

The words "Hoddle" and "home" and "Spurs" have become almost inseparable over the past few days, reports of his possible appointment being littered with football cliches about prodigal sons returning to spiritual homes.

Tottenham fans have always turned weak-kneed and misty-eyed at the memory of Hoddle waltzing over the White Hart Lane turf, majestically sidestepping tackles and sweeping the ball out to the corner of the pitch with dazzling poise and grace.

Even when he returned as manager of Chelsea and then Southampton, White Hart Lane would often echo to the sound of "Hod is the King of White Hart Lane" being sung to the tune of the First Noel, and for many at the Lane he is still referred to as "Hod the god".

But for Tottenham fans and former players, Enic's pursuit of Hoddle as manager is seen as much more than an attempt to hire the services of a talented former player who enjoys a special relationship with the fans. Indeed, his coming is being seen as instrumental in the attempt to heal the wounds that have beset White Hart Lane over the past few years and to unite the club after a period of uncertainty and turmoil.

The former Spurs captain Gary Mabbutt said: "There's no doubt that Glenn Hoddle is the biggest idol Spurs have ever had and in many ways he embodied as a player everything Tottenham are about.

"But the fans have needed Hoddle and his memory more than ever over the last few years because of the strong Arsenal connections that became associated with the club. No matter what George [Graham] did, the fans always felt that he would be more remembered for Arsenal.

"Hoddle is somebody who understands the traditions of Spurs and knows what is expected of the club. It's no surprise to me that Enic have said that he is top of their list."

Even during Graham's reign, which yielded one Worthington Cup triumph, most Spurs fans were still in favour of Hoddle taking over at the club.

After the anger and divisions caused by Alan Sugar's chairmanship, his lack of spending on big-name players, the appointment of Graham and the antics of Christian Gross which almost ended in relegation, Hoddle's possible arrival is viewed as an attempt to forge a new vision at Tottenham which is shared by all those involved with the club: fans, players, directors and back-room staff. Crucially he also has a Tottenham pedigree, something Graham conspicuously lacked.

If Enic's three- and five-year plan for Tottenham is to succeed then securing somebody such as Hoddle to orchestrate it is vital. His appointment is imperative if the psychological and football damage inflicted on the club is to be repaired.

The Tottenham players themselves sometimes hinted at their unhappiness under Graham's reign and the impact this was having within the club. It was well known at the club, for example, that Graham and the captain Sol Campbell had not talked for several weeks and that this might have had a significant impact on the defender's contract negotiations, which are currently under way with Enic. Other important players such as Les Ferdinand and Darren Anderton, who are also out of contract this summer, rarely spoke with Graham.

Two weeks before Graham's sacking the defender Stephen Carr captured the fans' mood when he said: "Some people seem certain that Glenn will leave Southampton and come to Spurs at the end of the season. I can see why Spurs fans would want to believe that, as the man was an exceptional player here for many years and has since been added to the folklore of the club."

Of course, Tottenham have been down the road of the return of the prodigal son once before when in 1993 Ossie Ardiles was appointed by Sugar in an attempt to placate the fans after Terry Venables left the club.

Ardiles's reign was a disaster, albeit an entertaining one, and almost ended in relegation as his team leaked goals.

Roberts said: "Ossie loved to play kamikaze football but I'm sure Glenn will not be like that. He is a very cautious manager; he does not like to concede goals. He's had a lot of experience and although he made some small mistakes with England I think he's learned from them.

"Ossie was also a great Spurs hero but there is something special about Glenn. He's the greatest player Spurs have ever had and as a player he captured the spirit of how a Tottenham team should play. I think the biggest problem is going to be how much money Enic are going to give him to spend."

Mabbutt said: "When Ossie was given the Spurs job many fans were happy to see him back. He is also a Tottenham legend. But I think Glenn will approach the Tottenham job in a completely different way. But that all depends on whether he is going to take it. That is still the main question."

Should Hoddle accept the challenge of turning Tottenham Hotspur around he is sure to be hailed as a messiah. Getting the club to the promised land, however, would be the biggest challenge he has ever faced.

webTitle: Easdaq deal aids Nasdaq advance into Europe

fields.headline: Easdaq deal aids Nasdaq advance into Europe
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Nasdaq, the US stock exchange, is seeking to force the pace of consolidation among Europe's equity markets through the purchase yesterday of a controlling stake in Easdaq.
fields.body:
Nasdaq, the US stock exchange, is seeking to force the pace of consolidation among Europe's equity markets through the purchase yesterday of a controlling stake in Easdaq.

The US group believes that market participants want "lower costs, more information, less fragmentation" in the European equity market. "If you stand in the way of this you will get buried," according to its chairman, Frank Zarb.

Europe's traditional exchanges have been making tentative progress towards the creation of a pan-European system but the structure of the industry remains largely nationally based.

The 70m euro (£44m) deal announced yesterday gives Nasdaq a 58% stake in Easdaq, a Brussels-based exchange that has sought to provide a pan-European option for investors but struggled to make headway in the face of competition from the likes of Germany's Neuer Markt.

Mr Zarb said that his exchange had discussed the deal with the leading European exchanges. "Ultimately we are looking for greater consolidation in Europe and we think that [this deal] can propel that further."

Describing the deal - only half jokingly - as the "fragmentation terminator", Mr Zarb said there was an element of "forcing a semblance of consolidation" in Europe.

To date there are just over 60 companies listed on Easdaq and Nasdaq is planning to expand its operations by attracting initial public offering and by encouraging the trading of leading US and European stocks on the exchange.

It will offer a hybrid trading model with a quote-driven market-maker operation sitting alongside a central order book as well as integration into a clearing and settlement system.

Mr Zarb said that a number of strategic investors would join the deal but he declined to give details.

Europe is a central factor in Nasdaq's ambitions to develop a global market place providing round-the-clock trading.

The exchange, the second largest in the US, has made several efforts to establish a significant presence in Europe.

Its first move was to set up its own organisation, Nasdaq Europe, then it joined the merger of the London and Frankfurt exchanges which subsequently fell through. It has also looked at the possibility of an alliance with the London exchange.

"The announcement demonstrates our commitment to become a major part of the European market place," Mr Zarb said.

"This agreement is one important step towards this objective while we continue to assess a wide range of possibilities with other European partners."

fields.headline: Stereophonics' thrashing, beefy rock
fields.standfirst:
Stereophonics
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London ***
fields.trailText:
Stereophonics
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London ***
fields.body:
If this were a meritocracy, the closest Stereophonics would ever get to a stadium stage would be row W. The question of them playing, let alone headlining, such places would never arise, because the attributes claimed for them by fans - that they are "hard working" and "unpretentious" - would count for little against the qualities they lack, namely genius and inspiration. Yet they are on their way to selling out mega-gigs at Donington and Chepstow racecourses in July, and this show, at the 1,200-capacity Empire, is deemed an intimate warm-up.

Saying that, the Welsh threesome make an evening pass more quickly than you'd expect. Kelly Jones, the pretty singer/writer, has mastered the craft of the fat, singalong anthem, and belts them with the fire of a Valleys Axl Rose. By the end of the opening, Mr Writer (theme: rock critics are friendless saddos), he has broken into a sweat. By the time he has thrashed the life out of another couple of songs from the new album, Just Enough Education to Perform, his voice is frayed, spurring him to greater heights of rasping. Behind him, Stuart Cable half-rises, curly mop quivering, to hit his drums with greater force. If exertion equalled record sales, Stereophonics would have more platinum discs than Elvis.

A surprising number of tunes are so familiar that Jones doesn't bother to introduce them. The first buzzing chords of Pick a Part That's New and I Wouldn't Believe Your Radio (theme: pop is rubbish, except ours) are all it takes to induce slam-dancing in the balconies. And justifiably: the songs may be as unsexy as the E Street Band without Springsteen but they rock, like it says on the tin. Jones even manages to make an acoustic interval sound beefy.

Emboldened, he tries a bit of wit, dedicating the improbable "lesbian" anthem The Bartender and the Thief to the Welsh-bashing Anne Robinson. That "lesbian" still passes for abuse in their part of the world tells you all you need to know about Stereophonics. Small wonder they play on a bare stage with no fripperies but a backdrop and a touch of strobe lighting. Anything fancier, any attempt to deviate from their menu of catchy bar-room rock, might imply that Kelly and the boys were . . . well . . . you know.

Don't hold your breath for the ambient bhangra album.
fields.bodyText: If this were a meritocracy, the closest Stereophonics would ever get to a stadium stage would be row W. The question of them playing, let alone headlining, such places would never arise, because the attributes claimed for them by fans - that they are "hard working" and "unpretentious" - would count for little against the qualities they lack, namely genius and inspiration. Yet they are on their way to selling out mega-gigs at Donington and Chepstow racecourses in July, and this show, at the 1,200-capacity Empire, is deemed an intimate warm-up. Saying that, the Welsh threesome make an evening pass more quickly than you'd expect. Kelly Jones, the pretty singer/writer, has mastered the craft of the fat, singalong anthem, and belts them with the fire of a Valleys Axl Rose. fields.headline: Kitemark sends clear digital signal
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The government yesterday stepped up its drive to encourage take-up of digital television with a labelling system designed to cut through the confusion at retail level.
fields.body:
The government yesterday stepped up its drive to encourage take-up of digital television with a labelling system designed to cut through the confusion at retail level.

The kitemark aims to distinguish digital TV sets from analogue sets boasting "digital features". The government wants to switch off the analogue signal between 2006 and 2010 but is concerned that many consumers are buying the wrong sets on bad advice.

All digital TVs will carry the Digital Video Broadcasting (DVB) logo from next month.

The initiative is the result of meetings between e-commerce minister Patricia Hewitt and TV manufacturers, retailers and broadcasters. British manufacturers and retailers are working together to ensure that all new digital sets carry the logo, and that sales staff understand and explain the advantages of digital TV sets.

Ms Hewitt said: "As a consumer myself, I know how confusing buying a new TV can be. Often the information consumers need is buried in the small print."

Digital TV sets can receive the existing five terrestrial stations as well as free-to-air digital channels such as BBC Choice, BBC Knowledge and ITV2.

Carlton and Granada, the two largest ITV franchise holders, are planning their own on-air promotional campaign to persuade the public to go digital.

The companies, which own ONdigital, are expected to run the campaign in the run-up to Easter.

A spokesman for the Consumers' Association welcomed the kitemark but said the government had not gone far enough. "Last week we published research which showed clearly that consumers were confused by the new digital offerings and many people were unaware of its benefits.

"The logo initiative is a useful first step, but it will only work as part of a wider digital information campaign led by the government."

fields.headline: Company executives fly into scandal
fields.trailText: There is something about corporate jets that seems inevitably to attract scandal.
fields.body:
There is something about corporate jets that seems inevitably to attract scandal.

Greg Hutchings found himself out of a job as chief executive of engineering group Tomkins following allegations that he had being using company jets for personal recreation.

More recently Scoot chief executive Robert Bonnier came under fire for making 88 flights in a private jet last year which were charged to the company.

The private aircraft cost about £850 an hour, but Mr Bonnier explained he billed the company at the same rate as a BA or Air France business class ticket and argues the aircraft is an essential "time management tool".

George Davies, former head of the Next clothes retail chain who now works with Marks & Spencer, would agree. He pilots his own private jet as does diamond dealer and Arsenal football club director Danny Fiszman.

In the cases of Tomkins and Scoot, investors privately admit they would only raise these kinds of issues where the shares have been performing badly.

It is not only in Britain that problems surround jets.

The Irish taoiseach, Bertie Ahern, and other Irish politicians have been in trouble for running up travel bills of £3m a year on a government Gulfstream aircraft whose destinations included race meetings.

In France Elf Aquitaine - now TotalFinaElf - has been at the centre of fraud investigations over allegations that former Gaullist interior minister Charles Pasqua travelled free on the company's planes.

The Pensions and Investment Research Consultants (Pirc), which specialises in corporate governance, says it sees nothing wrong with companies operating corporate jets, but it believes details of personal use by directors must always be properly included in the remuneration section of an annual report.

Stuart Bell, research director at Pirc, agrees that aircraft do set alarm bells ringing but only in the context of other abuses.

The internet boom has created a generation of super-wealthy businessmen who have turned to jets for business and pleasure. Larry Ellison, the head of software group Oracle, has not only a traditional executive jet but also a MiG fighter. He had to take the weapon systems off his purchase before the former symbol of Soviet military power was allowed into the US.

Corporate or executive jets are being used by companies more and more frequently especially by British executives who can no longer rely on British Airways or Air France for supersonic flights following the grounding of the Concorde fleet.

Virgin group underlined this at the weekend when it confirmed it was looking at establishing a corporate jet airline, Jetset, to cater for growing demand.

A recent survey by the National Business Aviation Association in the US suggested that 300 of the Fortune 500 companies owned a jet and 72% of company managers are using their own jets for business travel compared with 56% two years ago.

This might make shareholders more accepting of jets. It was not so for Robert Montague, former chief executive of trailer rental group Tiphook. He was one of the country's richest and successful executives of the 1980s with a fleet of luxury cars, a 139ft yacht and pedigree cattle.

When the business went pear-shaped attention centred on the private jet as an example of personal excess. Similarly Australian tycoon Alan Bond went to jail after running a highly successful business empire. He owned an entire Oxfordshire village but it was his aircraft that was seen as a symbol of misplaced opulence.

fields.headline: A novelist plays games with art
fields.standfirst:
Smallish
Greengrassi, London **
fields.trailText:
Smallish
Greengrassi, London **
fields.body:
Smallish is a smallish exhibition exploring relationships between adults and children, specifically men and boys. It is curated by the LA queer-punk novelist Dennis Cooper, author of Frisk, Period and other fictions that explore, with no holds barred, the nature of pornography.

When asked to comment on the recent row at the Saatchi Gallery, culture secretary Chris Smith said that he was more concerned about paedophile images on the internet. But the art scene will tend to go that bit further than you or I (or even the News of the World) thinks it would. Here, Cooper includes images downloaded from what he describes as "a now-defunct, legal paedophile news group called alt.binaries.boys.retromod". The pictures are of a boy fully clothed, asleep. The pictures, according to Cooper, were taken by a father who shared them with "the paedophiles who haunted that news group". Gulp.

Nearby is a piece by the LA sculptor Vincent Fecteau. It is a constellation of stickers - yellow, orange, green - clustered on two walls of a corner to create a three-dimensional cloud. This is as charming as the net pictures are creepy.

One of the points of light is a photograph of Fecteau's father, trimmed to just his head, smiling in heaven. The artist made this in 1994, just after his father died. It's a son's view of his father, one that is disruptively uninhibited, and the one piece that makes the show worthwhile.

Otherwise, this is strictly for Cooper fans. It is a novelist's show, playing games like those in Period, which deals with internet images, underground newsgroups and the power of art to resurrect a loved one. The climate of Cooper's books is of a bleached-out consumerist culture in which it appears that only the most violent convulsions of desire can make anyone feel real. But does art today have to touch on the most dangerous of images - sex and death in the raw - in order to make us feel anything?

It would be easier to answer yes or no if Cooper put things as bluntly as he does in his novels, but it seems that even he is wary of the image; we worry a lot less about what is on the page than what is in a gallery. John Williams's works - including a painting of an "evil boy", as seen by a shopping-mall surveillance camera - are so ordinary, the weight of the show rests on its flirtation with the extreme, a flirtation that feels cynical. This is a disappointment from a writer who seems in his books to be so moral in his courage.

 Until April 4. Details: 020-7387 8747

webTitle: More stock market turmoil to come, says Warren Buffett

fields.headline: More stock market turmoil to come, says Warren Buffett
fields.trailText: Warren Buffett, the US multi-billionaire widely regarded as one of the world's wisest investors, yesterday predicted more stock market turmoil to come and urged investors to go back to basics when considering buying shares.
fields.body:
Warren Buffett, the US multi-billionaire widely regarded as one of the world's wisest investors, yesterday predicted more stock market turmoil to come and urged investors to go back to basics when considering buying shares.

Mr Buffet, dubbed the Sage of Omaha, said he was not wading into the market, despite the recent gyrations in share prices. The FTSE-100 and Dow Jones, along with other world stock market indices, have posted big gains in the last three days after a huge sell-off last week. But Mr Buffet said he thought the roller-coaster ride for investors would continue: "I'd be surprised if it ends tomorrow".

Speaking in London on a tour of Europe to promote his executive jet company, Mr Buffet said: "We are buying more planes than stocks".

Mr Buffet, who claims he is a "lifelong technophobe" and who does not even accept e-mails because "I haven't made that much progress", says he is still not a buyer of bombed-out tech and telecom shares.

He urged investors to return to an old fashioned investment philosophy: "Just do what you understand. Don't just buy things because people say they are going up".

The time to buy, he said, was "when businesses sell in the market for less than they are worth"

Meanwhile US investors hoping for hints of future bor rowing cuts were disappointed yesterday when the Federal Reserve's chairman Alan Greenspan made no comment on the economy in a speech to businessmen.

New figures showed that confidence about the economic outlook in US households bounced back this month, after five successive months of decline.

DeAnne Julius, a dove on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, said Britain was much better placed than the US to weather any turbulence in the global economy. But if a slowdown in world growth were to drag down the UK, the Bank would be "duty bound" to reduce rates.

fields.headline: Ericsson shuts two British plants
fields.trailText: Swedish telecomunications equipment maker Ericsson announced yesterday that it is halting production of mobile phones at two British plants, threatening 1,200 jobs.
fields.body:
Swedish telecomunications equipment maker Ericsson announced yesterday that it is halting production of mobile phones at two British plants, threatening 1,200 jobs.

The group refused to rule out job losses among its other 2,000 UK employees when it announces more cost cuts next month.

Ericsson said that it was seeking buyers for the two plants, at Carlton, Nottinghamshire, which employs about 1,000 people, and Scunthorpe, Lincolnshire, where another 200 work. Production would cease during the third quarter of this year.

"It is a painful decision but this business is not profitable and we could not continue in an unprofitable way," a spokesman said.

The news was greeted with dismay locally. Bassetlaw district council, where the main Ericsson plant is located, said it was extremely concerned about the scale of the job losses.

The group announced that more than 2,000 jobs are to go in Sweden, including 600 at a mobile phone plant. Earlier this year Ericsson announced it was outsourcing mobile phone production to Flextronics of Singapore.

This month Ericsson announced that it would make a loss of up to SKr5bn (£343m) in the first three months of the year as the slowdown in global growth hit the unprofitable handset operation and the money-making networks division.

Yesterday Ericsson promised to squeeze another SKr20bn a year from its cost base, mainly in non-manufacturing areas.

fields.headline: Jet setting becomes time travel
fields.standfirst: The 'sage of Omaha', Warren Buffett, is bringing the timeshare business model to the rarefied world of corporate globe trotting, as Andrew Clark reports
fields.trailText: The 'sage of Omaha', Warren Buffett, is bringing the timeshare business model to the rarefied world of corporate globe trotting. Andrew Clark reports.
fields.body:
Warren Buffett spent Monday relaxing in the living room of his Boeing business jet, watching Tiger Woods' latest golf triumph by satellite relay on a 42-inch television screen as he crossed the Atlantic Ocean.

If he chose, America's second-richest man could have made a call on one of eight telephones, had a shower in one of two bathrooms, taken a snooze in a queen-size bed or held a meeting in the conference room.

The legendary financier, known, as the Sage of Omaha, likes to travel in comfort: he admits that he hardly ever slums it on commercial airlines. This week, he is on a three-day tour of seven European cities to promote NetJet, the corporate aircraft firm which his investment company, Berkshire Hathaway, bought for $725m (£500m) three years ago.

NetJet is one of the leaders in a rapidly growing market for executive jets. In the US, most top business people, sports stars and entertainers feel they need their own transport. Aircraft are still frowned upon in corporate Britain, as the engineering company Tomkins will bear witness, but Mr Buffett reckons they will soon take off on this side of the Atlantic: "I can't conceive of a Europe without thousands of owners 10 years from now."

Aunt Katie's share

NetJet, which has a fleet of 338 aircraft, has snapped up 40% of all the new corporate jets built over the past four years, largely because it offers "fractional ownership" - a kind of timeshare deal on private aircraft. Customers buy an eighth or a 16th of a jet, entitling them to a certain number of flying hours.

Fractional ownership appealed to Mr Buffett as soon as he encountered it. "I literally hadn't heard of it until six or seven years ago.

"Now both my sisters are in it and my kids are in it - although they've got very small shares."

Even Mr Buffett's 94-year-old Aunt Katie has a slice of ownership of a NetJet corporate jet. Other fans included Pete Sampras, Arnold Schwarzenegger and Martina Hingis, as well as companies such as General Electric, Gillette and Texaco. Timeshare on aircraft is becoming ever more popular as companies dispose of their own fleets because of uncertain economic conditions.

So sure is NetJet of the potential of its proposition that it is investing $400m in 50 new mid-range Citation aircraft. With 2,400 "owners" on its books worldwide, Netjet had aircraft allocated to 92 countries last year.

Mr Buffett reckons selling corporate planes is as promising in business terms as Coca-Cola. "Production of Coke started in Atlanta in 1884 and now it is in 200 countries, with 1.1bn servings sold per day. NetJet's somewhere on that scale, between 1bn and 1.1bn a day."

'Admiral's barge'

There are at present about 2,000 corporate jets in operation across Europe, although companies are shy of discussing the subject, fearing that will provoke the assumption that the aircraft are used for frivolous trips. Turkey farmer Bernard Matthews' ownership of two aircraft has raised eyebrows, but the aviation industry insists that management abuse is rare.

Graham Forbes, chief executive of the General Aviation Manufacturers and Traders Association, says: "The concept of the admiral's barge is dead. The idea that a chief executive would have a jet for his own use is pretty much gone."

He says corporate planes can actually make life tougher for employees, because companies allow them less travelling time: "I've heard of people being expected to go to South Africa and back in one day. The companies take the view that once you get on a private aircraft, it's just another office - it's working time."

One of the few British companies that is open about its aircraft ownership is BP, which says it has "a couple" of aircraft which it accidentally inherited when it bought the US group Amoco.

"With the acquisition of Amoco, we have a number of sites which are difficult to connect to each other, so we have kept a couple of their planes," a spokesman says.

One of BP's aircraft was damaged last year when it skidded off a runway in Cape Cod, careered across a four-lane highway and crashed into a wall. It was carrying the group's deputy chief executive, Rodney Chase, who was shaken but unhurt.

Brian Humphries, who runs Shell's fleet of corporate jets, says executives have to make a strong case for use of one of the oil company's aircraft. They are largely used for particularly tight schedules or for trips to places which are not accessible by commercial flights: "Shell has had corporate aircraft since 1927. We use them a lot now for going to places in the former Soviet Union."

Mr Humphries, who is also head of the European Business Aviation Association, says "break even" for a corporate aircraft usually occurs with four passengers on board; that number makes a private plane as cheap as business class commercial fares.

For pop stars and sports people the advantages of a small aircraft are privacy and security. There is also personal service: Tiger Woods likes a supply of Big Macs available to him when he flies with NetJet.

For companies, the issue is flexibility. Mr Forbes says: "Just imagine you've got to take a sales team to a particular place. If you're travelling on a scheduled flight, you've got a limited range of destinations - you may well have to change somewhere.

"On a scheduled flight, a great deal of time is taken up going through terminals. If you regard your sales team as a cost, it's better for them to waste less time and get on a smaller plane."

Stock market indicator

The aviation industry points out that in the US planes are considered no more unusual as business assets than computers and shredders. In Britain attitudes are beginning to soften. Even the government is beginning to take a different view. A report by the Department of Transport three years ago concluded that good access for business aircraft was one of the three most important factors in encouraging inward investments to a region, and airports such as Manchester and London City have been encouraged to open up to corporate customers.

NetJet's total revenue was $1.8bn last year. The company does not disclose its profits but for Mr Buffett the company has advantages other than financial returns. The billionaire financier jokes that the company acts as a great stock market indicator: "If any company cancels a plane and I find out about it early, I know it's a go

Other fans included Pete Sampras, Arnold Schwarzenegger and Martina Hingis, as well as companies such as General Electric, Gillette and Texaco. Timeshare on aircraft is becoming ever more popular as companies dispose of their own fleets because of uncertain economic conditions. So sure is NetJet of the potential of its proposition that it is investing $400m in 50 new mid-range Citation aircraft. With 2,400 "owners" on its books worldwide, Netjet had aircraft allocated to 92 countries last year. Mr Buffett reckons selling corporate planes is as promising in business terms as Coca-Cola. "Production of Coke started in Atlanta in 1884 and now it is in 200 countries, with 1.1bn servings sold per day. NetJet's somewhere on that scale, between 1bn and 1.1bn a day." 'Admiral's barge' There are at present about 2,000 corporate jets in operation across Europe, although companies are shy of discussing the subject, fearing that will provoke the assumption that the aircraft are used for frivolous trips. Turkey farmer Bernard Matthews' ownership of two aircraft has raised eyebrows, but the aviation industry insists that management abuse is rare. Graham Forbes, chief executive of the General Aviation Manufacturers and Traders Association, says: "The concept of the admiral's barge is dead. The idea that a chief executive would have a jet for his own use is pretty much gone." He says corporate planes can actually make life tougher for employees, because companies allow them less travelling time: "I've heard of people being expected to go to South Africa and back in one day. The companies take the view that once you get on a private aircraft, it's just another office - it's working time." One of the few British companies that is open about its aircraft ownership is BP, which says it has "a couple" of aircraft which it accidentally inherited when it bought the US group Amoco. "With the acquisition of Amoco, we have a number of sites which are difficult to connect to each other, so we have kept a couple of their planes," a spokesman says. One of BP's aircraft was damaged last year when it skidded off a runway in Cape Cod, careered across a four-lane highway and crashed into a wall. It was carrying the group's deputy chief executive, Rodney Chase, who was shaken but unhurt. Brian Humphries, who runs Shell's fleet of corporate jets, says executives have to make a strong case for use of one of the oil company's aircraft. They are largely used for particularly tight schedules or for trips to places which are not accessible by commercial flights: "Shell has had corporate aircraft since 1927. We use them a lot now for going to places in the former Soviet Union." Mr Humphries, who is also head of the European Business Aviation Association, says "break even" for a corporate aircraft usually occurs with four passengers on board; that number makes a private plane as cheap as business class commercial fares. For pop stars and sports people the advantages of a small aircraft are privacy and security. There is also personal service: Tiger Woods likes a supply of Big Macs available to him when he flies with NetJet. For companies, the issue is flexibility. Mr Forbes says: "Just imagine you've got to take a sales team to a particular place. If you're travelling on a scheduled flight, you've got a limited range of destinations - you may well have to change somewhere. "On a scheduled flight, a great deal of time is taken up going through terminals. If you regard your sales team as a cost, it's better for them to waste less time and get on a smaller plane." Stock market indicator The aviation industry points out that in the US planes are considered no more unusual as business assets than computers and shredders. In Britain attitudes are beginning to soften. Even the government is beginning to take a different view. A report by the Department of Transport three years ago concluded that good access for business aircraft was one of the three most important factors in encouraging inward investments to a region, and airports such as Manchester and London City have been encouraged to open up to corporate customers. NetJet's total revenue was $1.8bn last year. The company does not disclose its profits but for Mr Buffett the company has advantages other than financial returns. The billionaire financier jokes that the company acts as a great stock market indicator: "If any company cancels a plane and I find out about it early, I know it's a go

webTitle: World music review: Afel Bocoum, London

fields.headline: Afel Bocoum and the blues of Mali
fields.standfirst: Dingwalls, London ***
fields.trailText: Dingwalls, London ***
fields.body:
In the west African desert state of Mali there's the laid-back village of Niafunke. The local celebrity is the farmer and guitarist Ali Farka Toure, hailed as Mali's answer to John Lee Hooker, thanks to his gently intense playing and songs that make you believe that the blues must have originated in this part of Africa. Then there's his long-term sidekick, Afel Bocoum, who has played with Toure for 30 years but in all that time has produced just one solo album.

Toure has decided, not for the first time, that he wants to retire and use some of the earnings from his award-winning albums to help the local community, so now Bocoum has been sent out to tour in his place. At Dingwalls, he came on looking more like a Tibetan monk than a guitar hero, wearing a red robe and blue scarf and with cropped hair and rimless glasses. He was playing a lightly amplified acoustic guitar and was surrounded by a five-piece band, with a mixture of ancient and modern instruments. There was an electric guitar and bass, the njarka (the tiny traditional violin), the njunkle (the equally small Malian version of a guitar) and a percussionist (kneeling at Bocoum's feet and hidden from most of the audience) pounding a calabash.

Bocoum himself acted more as singer and band-leader than soloist, trying to match his master's skills. He introduced his songs of local Malian life and history partly in English, partly in French, sometimes slipping back and forward between the two within the same sentence. Then he launched into a bluesy guitar riff, with the violin joining in to bring a wailing, Arabic desert edge as the other musicians added to the gently chanted vocals.

They were a quiet band, considering their number, but their playing was rock-steady and mesmeric. Toure's pupil is like an African JJ Cale, exciting in the most relaxed way. There were passages of insistent, rhythmic, trance-like playing, with the guitars, old and new, weaving together against the solid beat of the calabash as the tempo gradually increased. By the end, Bocoum had put down his guitar, grabbed hold of his robes, dispensed with the electric guitars and danced to the sounds of the ancient instruments.

It was a gently rousing performance, especially for a man who has spent so many years acting as a backing musician, and the Dingwalls crowd was suitably impressed. Bocoum hasn't exactly rushed over here to promote his solo album, which has been on release for two years now, but he has emerged as a celebrity in his own right. Back in Niafunke, his old mentor would have been impressed.

webTitle: What happens when your boss sells the firm?

fields.headline: What happens when your boss sells the firm?
fields.standfirst: 28 March: My friend is worried he will lose his job and, as he works without a contract, will receive no compensation.
fields.trailText: The problem
fields.body:
The problem

My friend is a builder working for a small firm. He has not received a contract of employment during his two years with them. He now hears on the grapevine that the owner may be selling out to someone else.

Does he have any rights of compensation in the event that redundancy occurs? How can he set about making sure that he is not taken to the cleaners?

The solution

The Transfer of Undertakings Regulations 1981 stipulate that employees who are employed by the old employer at the time of transfer automatically become the employees of the new employer as if their contracts of employment were originally made with the new employer. In your friends' case, he does not have a contract of employment, but this should make little difference since it could be deemed that over two years a verbal contract has been established. The new employer should offer him a contract of employment based on this. As he has worked for the first employer for two years, he should receive redundancy payments if the new firm were to make his job redundant.

Your friend should really speak to ACAS (number in the phone book) to ensure that he is not "taken to the cleaners". It might be worthwhile, for example, asking for a contract from his current employer now, before any takeover. His best bet is to get all the advice he can to help him preempt any situation that might arise as best he can.


 Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

webTitle: Art review: William Tucker, Yorkshire Sculpture Park

fields.headline: The sculpture animals leave behind
fields.standfirst:
William Tucker
Yorkshire Sculpture Park, Wakefield ****
fields.trailText:
William Tucker
Yorkshire Sculpture Park, Wakefield ****
fields.body:
Bronze blobs that look like animals are something of a modernist cliche. Bronze blobs that look like something the animal left behind are something else. William Tucker presents both at the Yorkshire Sculpture Park. In the small Bothy Gallery, a series of folded and truncated forms suggests horse heads. Indeed, the titles tell you that's what they are, just in case you thought you were looking at bugs or grubs or casts of bent dough.

There is something about the subject of animals that has turned even the most adventurous sculptors of the past 100 years into self-parodying model-makers or mediocre public artists. To see Tucker working so often these days in semi-figurative clay modelling and bronze casting, not to mention charcoal drawing, comes as a surprise to those of us who recall his painted fibreglass abstractions of the late 1960s and early 1970s. After emerging as a key figure of the cool new generation of sculptors, Tucker moved to the US in the late 1970s, and that's the last many of us heard of him. There is a small retrospective display of work from all periods at Tate Liverpool, but it is with the recent work in the sculpture park's Pavilion Gallery and outdoor spaces that we see Tucker transforming himself into a sculptor of rare individuality and passion.

Scattered about the Park's hillside are the turd-like bronzes that offer an immediate and powerful affront to the eye. The semi-abstract references to recognisable animal appearance has been jettisoned. Here, Tucker is daring enough to leave raw matter to stand for itself. The clay has obviously been prodded, fingered and pummelled, but nothing familiar emerges from the mass.

These are models of almost primal unfamiliarity - 3D blots that evoke our most basic, sensuous ambivalence towards the organic nature of the world. Freudian-minded interpreters might have a field day with these works, but who cares? It's not easy to make such a wonderfully nauseous mess.

At last, here are sculptures that adequately disrupt the fake-modernist geometric banality of the park's per- manently displayed Barbara Hepworths. Tucker has adapted the gestural intensity of abstract expressionism to the creation of virtually indefinable things, things that look like they have come from some highly unfashionable, ageless other age - scatological masterpieces.

 Until May 20. Details: 01924 830302.

fields.headline: Share-shattered InterX thinks long term
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: InterX, the software group that has seen its share price shattered following the abrupt resignation of its highly regarded former chief executive, yesterday said it could survive on its £20m cash reserves for well over a year.
fields.body:
InterX, the software group that has seen its share price shattered following the abrupt resignation of its highly regarded former chief executive, yesterday said it could survive on its £20m cash reserves for well over a year.

Simon Barker, the new chief executive, said the costs that an extensive strategic review had taken out - including a quarter of its 120 staff sacked three weeks ago - would cut the cash going out of the business by 50%.

Mr Barker met his main shareholders to reassure them the drastic steps he is taking to return the loss-making business to profitability are the right ones. "I've told them I'm totally confident about our long-term prospects," he said. "But they've also been warned that they will have to wait six to nine months for the financial benefits."

Mr Barker and other directors may buy InterX shares to demonstrate their faith in the company. It has been among the worst performers on the London stock market this year, falling 80% after the February resignation of former chief Philip Crawford. He is thought to have disagreed on how the company was selling its main Bladerunner business software.

Mr Barker has decided to dismantle much of the direct sales force Mr Crawford had built up. InterX, which traded as high as £39 last year, closed yesterday at 91.5p, down 1.5p.

webTitle: Half the population tried the net

fields.headline: Web feat
fields.standfirst:
More net news
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: More than half of the population has now accessed the internet at some point, while just over one third of British people have access to the web at home, reports John Cassy.
fields.body:
More than half of the population has now accessed the internet at some point, while just over one third of British people now have access to the web at home, new figures show.

Around 23m people have now used the internet at some stage in their lives, and 80% of those people were online at least once in January, the month before the survey.

An average of 8.6m households are now connected to the web, according to the January 2001 national statistics omnibus survey.

That number is four times the level of two years ago. Some 57% of males have used the web compared to 45% of women.

Young people remain the most captivated by the medium with 85% of 16-24-year-olds having experienced it. Two thirds of adults who had accessed the web were aged 16-44, with internet cafes proving a popular way of getting online for those without a PC at home.

Wealth and social class continue to play a part in who has access to the net. Households headed by a professional are more than twice as likely to have used the web as those headed by an unskilled worker.

Personal computers remain the most popular way of getting online, accounting for 98% of users and underlining the limited impact Wap or internet enabled mobile phones have made.

Only 6% of those surveyed have gone online via an interactive digital TV platform such as BSkyB's Open or ONdigital's ONnet.

Email remains the most popular activity on the web for more than two thirds of people, although more than 50% of users also browse for information. Nearly a third said they had used the net to buy goods or services.

Of the people who have not tried the web 41% said they were not interested in it, 28% said they had no way of accessing it, 18% said they were not technically confident enough and 6% felt they were simply too old.

fields.headline: LSO/Davis, Barbican
fields.standfirst: Barbican, London  ****
fields.body:
Czech music continues to bloom in the London Symphony Orchestra's Bohemian Spring series. This concert of works by Dvorak and Janacek was divided with stubborn fairness between the composers - one choral and one orchestral work by each. It was an interesting programme that unearthed some rarities and found the orchestra responding as well as ever to their principal conductor Colin Davis. But it left one wishing for the impact that these forces might have generated with a really substantial symphonic work.

The Eternal Gospel, a "choral legend" based on the poet Vrchlicky's retelling of the words of a medieval prophet, was a departure for Janacek. Although combining lyrical and rousing episodes with an almost primeval feel, it remains an ungainly work. The relentless orations of the prophet didn't bring out the composer's most flowing music, yet the performers did their best to convince us otherwise. The prophet's words were declaimed with committed singing by Czech tenor Vladimir Dolezal, amply supported by the London Symphony Chorus on impressive form.

Gogol's Taras Bulba was another unlikely source of inspiration, but these gruesome tales of war, torture and filicide obviously struck a chord for Janacek, who used them as the basis for a three-movement orchestral rhapsody. Davis has a knackof finding the sharp edge of a piece of music and gently bringing it to the listener's attention; in this work he didn't have to dig too deep to find the foundations for an ominousatmosphere before stirring up a bitterly triumphal climax.

More surprisingly, Davis also managed to draw out an edge in Dvorak's Symphonic Variations, a showcase for the composer's techniques of orchestral invention. Musical undercurrents occasionally rippled the sweet, simple surface, before the main theme came scything through the orchestra as each instrument entered the fugal finale; the jaunty, tongue-in-cheek last page sounded as though Dvorak was having fun.

The Te Deum of 1892 found Dvorak at his most celebratory. The violins played their opening rustic melodies with vigour, preparing the way for some more strong singing from the choir. We had already heard the Slovakian soprano Andrea Dankova briefly in The Eternal Gospel; she brought a lustrous sheen to Te Deum, yet could have made a little more of her words. Fortissimo brass announced bass soloist Alastair Miles, who responded with resonant authority. Neither singer seemed to get under the skin of the work, but doubts were dispelled as Davis once again whipped up his forces into a jubilant close.

fields.headline: BCMG/Malkki
fields.standfirst: CBSO Centre, Birmingham ****
fields.trailText: CBSO Centre, Birmingham ****
fields.body:
Birmingham Contemporary Music Group's Sound Investment project was one of the brightest and most encouraging fund-raising ideas to come out of the new music scene in the 1990s. Members of the public are invited to contribute to the commissioning of a new work. In return they are informed of the work's progress, invited to rehearsals, presented with signed copies of the score and credited in the concert programmes.

Getting beyond the premiere is said to be the first big test of a contemporary work, and a surprisingly high number of these have passed - getting radio broadcasts and repeated performances, appearing at music festivals and being taken up by other groups.

This concert exhibited two commissions from the Sound Investment scheme - David Sawer's The Memory of Water and Bent Sorensen's Sinful Songs - plus a work written for the BCMG's composition workshop at Birmingham University, Disquiet by 21-year-old Claire Chipperfield.

The Memory of Water is typical of Sawer at his best: finely crafted, edgily rhythmic at first, poetic at its close. Sawer's writing for the strings (two solo violins and a chamber group) is, on the face of it, conventional, without clever, up-to-date techniques. But it has a highly personal atmosphere, alluring but faintly uneasy - the pathos of memory, perhaps. In Chipperfield's appropriately titled Disquiet, the sense of unease was more than faint and was well-sustained. Where Sawer avoided unusual techniques, Chipperfield embraced them, but the odd sounds - especially the brass players blowing tonelessly into their instruments - made sense. There was no suggestion of effects for effects' sake, though I did wonder why she had included the rare bass flute; from where I was sitting it was more or less inaudible.

I wish I could be as positive about Bent Sorensen's Sinful Songs. The basic idea was appealing: performers stationed in a semi-circle around the audience, with snatches of songs and dance tunes moving around the group at varying speeds. The effect, though, was of brief - too brief - flashes of interest amid stretches of neutral-sounding padding: not nearly sinful enough.

In compensation there were two great late-20th century works: Ligeti's breathtakingly inventive Chamber Concerto, and Sofia Gubaidulina's Seven Words - inspired by Christ's words to God from the cross - with its powerful solo writing for cello and accordion.

The young Finn Susanna Malkki conducted with quiet but firm control. Without drawing attention to herself she stamped her authority on everything - clearly a talent to watch.

Where Sawer avoided unusual techniques, Chipperfield embraced them, but the odd sounds - especially the brass players blowing tonelessly into their instruments - made sense. There was no suggestion of effects for effects' sake, though I did wonder why she had included the rare bass flute; from where I was sitting it was more or less inaudible. I wish I could be as positive about Bent Sorensen's Sinful Songs. The basic idea was appealing: performers stationed in a semi-circle around the audience, with snatches of songs and dance tunes moving around the group at varying speeds. The effect, though, was of brief - too brief - flashes of interest amid stretches of neutral-sounding padding: not nearly sinful enough. In compensation there were two great late-20th century works: Ligeti's breathtakingly inventive Chamber Concerto, and Sofia Gubaidulina's Seven Words - inspired by Christ's words to God from the cross - with its powerful solo writing for cello and accordion. The young Finn Susanna Malkki conducted with quiet but firm control. Without drawing attention to herself she stamped her authority on everything - clearly a talent to watch.

fields.headline: Big Air
fields.body:
It's not always the music that makes a gig stand out. Factors such as atmosphere also come into play - as they do at the Vortex, one of London's most popular sharp-end jazz and improv clubs. Certainly this packed house's reaction to the mixed American/British group Big Air was ecstatically noisy. But the group deserved it.

Big Air was the brainchild of former Loose Tubes trumpet/ sax duo Chris Batchelor and Steve Buckley. The group combines the duo's ragged-edged free-jazz virtuosity with the remarkable piano of American Myra Melford (a gifted descendant of the high-density Cecil Taylor school), the furiously inventive American drummer Jim Black (who can sometimes heard over here with Tim Berne) and Britain's Oren Marshall - the Jimi Hendrix of the riotously plugged tuba.

The band was performing Batchelor and Buckley's Ten Tall Tales, a Jazz on 3/Arts Council commission. The music is hard to define concisely - perhaps a stripped-down version of Charlie Haden's Liberation Music Orchestra with the Dirty Dozen Brass Band for a rhythm section, with Cecil Taylor appearing as featured soloist might get somewhere near it.

The Liberation Music aspect was recalled by the lurching, soaring trumpet/saxophone ensembles of The Wizard, Buckley's ethereal wails harmonising with Batchelor's bold, painterly trumpet lines. A total contrast usually followed such intense moments, like Buckley's innocently capering penny-whistle lines blending with Batchelor's muted effects, and Melford on minimalist harmonium. But then a long-lined, serpentine, post-boppish theme would sweep it all away, with Melford's chemistry of taut accuracy and blistering abstract arpeggios rising imperiously out of the mêlée.

It was fascinating to hear such a band within days of encountering Ornette Coleman at the Barbican - many of Big Air's mercurial, multi-rhythmic melodies come straight from the musical revolution Coleman initiated over 40 years ago.

The later stages of the gig moved through some unexpectedly forthright bluesy grooves, and close to the finale Marshall took off on an extraordinary odyssey of what you might call grunge-tuba, which sparked Jim Black into his idiosyncratic, dazzling combination of rhythmic looseness and quicksilver momentum.

Definitely a candidate for gig of the year.

 Big Air play the Wardrobe, Leeds (0113-274 2486), tonight.

fields.headline: Smith to stay at Derby
fields.trailText: Jim Smith has confirmed that he has no plans to hand over to Colin Todd but intends to see out the last year of his contract as Derby County's manager.
fields.body:
Jim Smith has confirmed that he has no plans to hand over to Colin Todd but intends to see out the last year of his contract as Derby County's manager.

Smith admitted that when the club were struggling back in November he did not wish to put his chairman and friend, Lionel Pickering, in the position of having to sack him.

The appointment of Todd as Smith's assistant had fuelled speculation that he was ready to stand down at the end of season and take on an advisory role. The revival in County's fortunes following Todd's arrival has also been seen as a signal that Smith was in his last season in charge.

Derby had taken only five points out of 33 before the former England defender resigned as Swindon's manager to move to Pride Park. They have since collected 30 from 57.

"I want to manage for at least another season," Smith said. "Colin Todd came here as my No2 and not as manager-in-waiting. He's happy doing that and that's how things will stay."

Smith's decision means that when his contract expires in 2002 he will have completed 30 years in club management, a stint that began at Colchester in 1972.

Swindon's chief executive Peter Rowe claims that the future of the club still hangs in the balance after a meeting with the town council failed to produce the written pledge the club need to develop a site for a new stadium.

Rowe had described as "dire" the possibility that the club's investors could pull out if an agreement over the new Farm Lane site was not reached. But after an emergency meeting of the directors, Swindon's backers have agreed to continue their support in the hope that a deal will be brokered soon.

fields.headline: Ranieri targets £20m Rangers pair
fields.trailText: Chelsea are ready to launch a summer spending spree by investing about £20m on the Rangers midfield pair of Barry Ferguson and Giovanni van Bronckhorst.
fields.body:
Despite a sharp drop in their share price yesterday Chelsea are ready to launch a summer spending spree by investing about £20m on the Rangers midfield pair of Barry Ferguson and Giovanni van Bronckhorst

Both players will almost certainly be auctioned off at the end of the season as the Glasgow club attempts to raise cash for an overhaul of a squad that has recently played second fiddle to Celtic.

The Chelsea coach Claudio Ranieri recently informed his chairman, Ken Bates, that he wished to dismantle and then reshape the squad he inherited from his predecessor at Stamford Bridge, Gianluca Vialli.

Having reached the conclusion that his first-team panel is not only ageing but seemingly incapable of realising their obvious potential, Ranieri has decided he wishes to move out the more obvious underachievers.

If, as is expected, Bates gives his consent to a cull of some of Chelsea's big earners, players such as Frank Leboeuf, Roberto di Matteo, Gus Poyet, Ed de Goey and even Dennis Wise could be offloaded to make way for fresh blood.

Van Bronckhorst, a Dutch international who is comfortable on either the left side of midfield or defence, is valued at around £11m and the central midfielder Ferguson, 23, is rated at £9m by the Rangers manager Dick Advocaat.

Chelsea are not the only Premiership club to admire Ferguson's combative style - Leeds United, Liverpool and Manchester United have closely monitored his progress over the past two seasons.

Had Ferguson been available for transfer 12 months ago the likelihood is that he would now be playing his football at Anfield. Informed that Ferguson was not for sale, the Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier reinforced his midfield with Nick Barmby, Igor Biscan and Gary McAllister instead.

Ferguson has been ruled out of tomorrow's World Cup qualifier against San Marino at Hampden Park because of a recurrence of a rib injury in the 2-2 draw with Belgium at the weekend.

Anderlecht have angrily denied reports that they are in talks with Chelsea over the transfer of the £12m-rated Czech striker Jan Koller.

The Belgian club's chairman Roger Vanden Stock was quoted at the weekend as saying the club had held talks with Chelsea about the striker. But yesterday Vanden Stock insisted: "We have not spoken to them [Chelsea] about Koller. I have no idea where they've got the story from."

Meanwhile, Arsenal are planning a £2m move this summer for Bordeaux's goalkeeper Ulrich Ramé. The 28-year-old stood in for Fabien Barthez in France's 5-0 win over Japan this week, earning his fifth cap.

webTitle: Injured Litmanen out for six weeks

fields.headline: Injured Litmanen out for six weeks
fields.trailText: Liverpool's three-pronged assault on cup success was dealt an untimely blow yesterday when Jari Litmanen was told that he may well be sidelined for the next six weeks.
fields.body:
Liverpool's three-pronged assault on cup success was dealt an untimely blow yesterday when Jari Litmanen was told that he may well be sidelined for the next six weeks.

Litmanen fractured a wrist while playing for Finland in the World Cup qualifying defeat by England at Anfield. Although he was able to finish the game after receiving treatment on the touchline, a second examination carried out yesterday has revealed the problem to be more serious than was first thought.

The Finn will miss both legs of Liverpool's Uefa Cup semi-final against his previous club, Barcelona, and also the FA Cup semi-final with Second Division Wycombe Wanderers.

"This really is a massive blow both for the club and for Jari himself," said Liverpool's assistant manager Phil Thompson. "We have some very important games coming up and we really do need all our players fit and available.

"He could be out for six weeks, which is very disappointing. I think that everyone can see what Jari offers to the team - he gives us so many different options.

"He will be very upset to have to sit out the two games against Barcelona because, obviously, he was really looking forward to them."

There was better news of Jamie Redknapp, who is close to a return after an absence of almost nine months. The England midfielder is almost fully recovered from a knee injury that threatened to end his career, and may play for the reserves within a fortnight.

"I'm now back in full training which, after everything I have been through, is good news," said Redknapp. "My knee does still feel sore sometimes, but I remain hopeful."

Fulham have confirmed that they will play at Craven Cottage next season even if, as is likely, they are promoted to the Premiership. The 20,000 capacity includes terraces for 14,000.

The club's managing director Michael Fiddy says that changes will be made only during the season after next. The club will then groundshare while the Cottage is redeveloped as an all-seat stadium.

fields.headline: Campbell hints at Spurs solution
fields.trailText: Sol Campbell has given the strongest hint yet that he will stay at Tottenham so long as the club's owner, Enic, displays enough ambition to win trophies.
fields.body:
Sol Campbell, shedding no tears over the sacking of George Graham, has given the strongest hint yet that he will stay at Tottenham so long as the club's owner, Enic, displays enough ambition to win trophies.

The England defender side-stepped a suggestion that his upbeat mood had anything to do with the departure of the former manager. But the pair were barely on speaking terms after a row over team selection, so Graham's exit will not prove to be a hindrance. Campbell now wants to know whether Enic's plans can persuade him to stay.

"I've been at Spurs for over 10 years now. I'm happy," said Campbell, who has been linked with moves to many of Europe's top clubs. "For me to do well at Spurs would mean everything. That's more important than any other offer. They [Spurs] have to convince me that they're as ambitious as I am. I want to stay."

Campbell, whose contract expires at the end of this season, says he does not need to know the identity of the next Spurs manager before committing himself.

Asked about the Scot's sudden dismissal, Campbell was anything but sympathetic. "That's football. You've got to move on," he said.

"You could tell by the performance against Coventry [the post-Graham game that they won 3-0] that we didn't want to allow ourselves to be distracted by it all," he added.

"We just want to move on. We can't stay in the past. The main thing is that we keep on winning and move up the league, and we've got the [FA Cup] semi-final as well.

"I wish George all the best, but at the end of the day we have to improve ourselves as players and as a team."

As for his own future, Campbell admitted: "I've had a couple of talks and we'll have one more meeting over the next two weeks to iron out a few situations. I'm all ears and I'm ready. We've got to talk and then see where we want to go as a club. As long as the club is healthy and have things in place, me and other players are going to want to join or continue with them.

"I want the club to do well; that's the main thing. I'm sure that if the club is in a situation where they want to do well, people are going to want to join in. That includes me.

"I'll give them time. I'm sure they've got a blueprint to get different players. But I've not spoken to anyone. I've stuck by my guns with Tottenham and been loyal to them.

"I want to see the blueprint first. I think every Tottenham fan and person dealing with them wants to see some kind of forward thinking. They're willing to get these plans out.

"For the fans, who want this club to do well, who are so desperate for that to happen - and I'm one of them - they've got to really do it. They've started, and I'm going to have some more meetings and we'll go from there."

Bayern Munich's midfielder Stefan Effenberg, meanwhile, is hoping for a move to north London. "Playing in England has always been in my thoughts; it's not Italy or Spain that is attractive to me," he said. "The club must be in London, Arsenal is a good club but Spurs have always fascinated me."

Wimbledon have been linked with a summer move for the Rangers striker Billy Dodds after club scouts saw him score twice for Scotland against Belgium on Saturday.

fields.headline: From Harrods to Halifax
fields.standfirst: Paul Bracewell has that sinking feeling, writes  Dominic Fifield
fields.trailText: Paul Bracewell has that sinking feeling as his Halifax prepare to meet fellow Division Three bottom-dwellers Carlisle.
fields.body:
From the bright lights of Fulham Road, pawing at the Premiership's coat-tails with complimentary Harrods account card in hand, to a sepulchral Shay among the league's dead men, Paul Bracewell has endured an eye-opening initiation into management.

A year ago his Fulham side perched 10th in the First Division, a footballing phenomenon swollen by Mohamed al Fayed's money and about to explode. Tonight Bracewell and Halifax Town, 91st in the league, host Carlisle United, a place and a point above them in the Third Division.

"One of the local radio stations described this as a nine-pointer," he smiles. "God knows what that means. Neither side's fate will be decided tonight, but it will go a long way towards it." Given Halifax's next three games are against promotion chasers, while they end their season at runaway leaders Chesterfield, the significance of the Cumbrians' visit is horribly plain.

Such desperate scraps are unfamiliar to Bracewell, the 38-year-old former Everton and England midfielder who cut his coaching teeth with Peter Reid at Sunderland and Kevin Keegan at Craven Cottage. When Keegan left for England, Bracewell steered the Londoners, newly promoted to the First Division, to within sight of the play-offs.

Most supporters were satisfied with the results; not so the chairman, who terminated the manager's contract two days shy of a year ago.

"Jean Tigana's done a tremendous job, but I always said it would take two years to get up. What more could I have done? Win promotion, I suppose, but I had a good relationship with Mr Al Fayed.

"It was a different world. I signed Lee Clark for £2.75m; here I've made one permanent signing and been out most nights scouting for players."

From Harrods to Halifax. Town had had a wretched start to the season, culminating in the dismissal of Mark Lillis in September, and their three-year sojourn back in the league was under threat.

"Most fans thought we'd never see a relegation fight again," says Paul Holroyd of the Halifax webzine Shaymenonline. "We have a squad of players who should be nowhere near the bottom."

After four points in four matches under the caretaker management of Tony Parks and Peter Butler, Bracewell raised eyebrows by taking up the reins of the league's bottom club and promptly lost his first five games.

"I wanted to have a good look at everybody," he says. "Getting beaten every week didn't help and we had to stop the rot. I inherited a club with history, a club who know what it's like to play non-league, but my aim was simple from the start - to keep us up."

The recovery saw six wins in 10, propelling Town into lower mid-table, only for a quartet of dire defeats this month to undermine their progress. "We won four games on the trot at one point, but we've been up and down, using loan players and constantly changing the personnel.

"It's been difficult and we've lacked consistency. Even so, it's not doom and gloom. We've created a good environment, a working atmosphere for people to enjoy."

On Saturday, such endeavour paid off. The Shaymen's early goal against Barnet provoked a barrage from the visitors that had the locals shivering in anticipation of another humbling defeat. Halifax took a battering but, with Craig Mawson saving a 57th-minute penalty, weathered the storm and prospered with two late goals. The win, which hoisted them off the bottom at Torquay's expense, owed much to the calming influence of the new player-coach and captain Neil Redfearn.

The 35-year-old, who arrived from Wigan on a free transfer, is best remembered for his barnstorming displays from midfield in Barnsley's memorable, if ultimately doomed, Premiership season in 1997-98.

"We've got a chance of staying up, but then so have all the sides in the bottom eight," he says. "If we stick to it we'll be all right. I don't think we'll struggle to score goals, but we've got to keep them out as well. The funny thing is it's an ambitious club and the future actually looks quite bright, as long as we stay up."

The re-development of the Shay proves as much, although a spanking new stand would serve little purpose in the Conference. For the moment, the supporters are praying it does not come to that.

"If you look hard enough you can see the scratch marks on the wall revealing how many times we've been down here before," adds Holroyd. "It's someone else's turn to taste failure. We've had 90 years of it and enough is enough."

A step from the basement

Defeat in tonight's Shay showdown could mean disaster for Paul Bracewell's Halifax or Ian Atkins' Carlisle. The two clubs sit precariously close to the Nationwide League's relegation trap door with just Torquay United below them in the table

Bottom three remaining fixtures

CARLISLE

Mar 27 Halifax (a); Mar 31 Macclesfield (h); Apr 7 Lincoln (a); Apr 14 Blackpool (h); Apr 16 Scunthorpe (a); Apr 21 Brighton (h); Apr 24 Rochdale (a); Apr 28 Southend (a); May 5 Hull (h).

HALIFAX

Mar 27 Carlisle (h); Mar 31 Hartlepool (a); Apr 4 Brighton (h); Apr 10 Blackpool (h); Apr 14 York (a); Apri 16 Macclesfield (h); Apr 21 Exeter (a); Apr 28 Darlington (h); May 1 Lincoln (a); May 5 Chesterfield (a).

TORQUAY

Mar 31 Hull (h); Apr 7 Cardiff (a); Apr 14 Mansfield (a); Apr 16 Shrewsbury (h); Apr 21 Plymouth (a); Apr 28 York (h); May 5 Barnet (a). TBA: Macclesfield (h), Darlington (h).
