Such desperate scraps are unfamiliar to Bracewell, the 38-year-old former Everton and England midfielder who cut his coaching teeth with Peter Reid at Sunderland and Kevin Keegan at Craven Cottage. When Keegan left for England, Bracewell steered the Londoners, newly promoted to the First Division, to within sight of the play-offs. Most supporters were satisfied with the results; not so the chairman, who terminated the manager's contract two days shy of a year ago. "Jean Tigana's done a tremendous job, but I always said it would take two years to get up. What more could I have done? Win promotion, I suppose, but I had a good relationship with Mr Al Fayed. "It was a different world. I signed Lee Clark for £2.75m; here I've made one permanent signing and been out most nights scouting for players." From Harrods to Halifax. Town had had a wretched start to the season, culminating in the dismissal of Mark Lillis in September, and their three-year sojourn back in the league was under threat. "Most fans thought we'd never see a relegation fight again," says Paul Holroyd of the Halifax webzine Shaymenonline. "We have a squad of players who should be nowhere near the bottom." After four points in four matches under the caretaker management of Tony Parks and Peter Butler, Bracewell raised eyebrows by taking up the reins of the league's bottom club and promptly lost his first five games. "I wanted to have a good look at everybody," he says. "Getting beaten every week didn't help and we had to stop the rot. I inherited a club with history, a club who know what it's like to play non-league, but my aim was simple from the start - to keep us up." The recovery saw six wins in 10, propelling Town into lower mid-table, only for a quartet of dire defeats this month to undermine their progress. "We won four games on the trot at one point, but we've been up and down, using loan players and constantly changing the personnel. "It's been difficult and we've lacked consistency. Even so, it's not doom and gloom. We've created a good environment, a working atmosphere for people to enjoy." On Saturday, such endeavour paid off. The Shaymen's early goal against Barnet provoked a barrage from the visitors that had the locals shivering in anticipation of another humbling defeat. Halifax took a battering but, with Craig Mawson saving a 57th-minute penalty, weathered the storm and prospered with two late goals. The win, which hoisted them off the bottom at Torquay's expense, owed much to the calming influence of the new player-coach and captain Neil Redfearn. The 35-year-old, who arrived from Wigan on a free transfer, is best remembered for his barnstorming displays from midfield in Barnsley's memorable, if ultimately doomed, Premiership season in 1997-98. "We've got a chance of staying up, but then so have all the sides in the bottom eight," he says. "If we stick to it we'll be all right. I don't think we'll struggle to score goals, but we've got to keep them out as well. The funny thing is it's an ambitious club and the future actually looks quite bright, as long as we stay up." The re-development of the Shay proves as much, although a spanking new stand would serve little purpose in the Conference. For the moment, the supporters are praying it does not come to that. "If you look hard enough you can see the scratch marks on the wall revealing how many times we've been down here before," adds Holroyd. "It's someone else's turn to taste failure. We've had 90 years of it and enough is enough." A step from the basement Defeat in tonight's Shay showdown could mean disaster for Paul Bracewell's Halifax or Ian Atkins' Carlisle. fields.headline: Emap axes UK staff as websites close
fields.trailText:
4.45pm: Emap Digital is closing around a dozen websites with the loss of at least 20 UK staff, writes Amy Vickers.

Mar 27: Emap cuts online operations

Click here for EMAP memo to staff
fields.body:
Emap Digital is to close around a dozen websites with the loss of at least 20 staff at its UK office.

In wide-ranging cutbacks at its internet operation, Emap is slashing its digital spend for the third time and said as many as 100 jobs could be lost from its worldwide total of around 400 Emap Digital staff.

Emap announced early last year that £250m would be spent on digital projects over three years, but in November the publisher said it was halving the funds available.

The latest cutback means Emap Digital's expenditure for 2001 will not exceed £25m - half what it spent on new media activities in 2000.

The cost of laying off staff and closing websites is expected to amount to £10m.

Websites for the chop include the online version of Screen International, Screendaily.co.uk; the website for advertising and film promotions magazine Shots; Motherandbaby.co.uk; and a number of outdoor websites such as anglingtimes.com, golferworld.com and salmonandtrout.com.

Other websites, such as the music and travel sites, could be affected in the longer-term.

So far Emap Digital's music arm has launched Q4music.com and Mojo4music.com but it is thought that it may to look to merge these and the four other planned individual music websites in a bid to cut costs.

Travel is another area where Emap Digital is seen as having a fragmented strategy and may look to consolidate.

However, a travel portal was pulled before Christmas with around 30 staff working on the project redeployed elsewhere within the division.

Emap Digital reiterated it would now concentrate on the "big eight", which is understood to include FHM, its music websites, Motorcyclenews, Maxpower, Construction News, its joint venture with Wanadoo in France, travel sites and Autolocate.

The restructure follows the company's recent closure of Slam, its internet joint venture with Channel 4 aimed at the teenage market.

Group chief executive Kevin Hand said changes would be phased in slowly, implying more cutbacks and website closures.

"We are committed to the digital business but it would be irresponsible to plough on with projects irrespective. We are taking action in a timely fashion," he said.

fields.headline: Emap memo to staff
fields.standfirst:
EMAP DIGITAL ANNOUNCEMENT

A RESTRUCTURE OF OUR UK DIGITAL BUSINESS
fields.trailText: Memo to staff:
fields.body:
Memo to staff:

Today's digital market is very different from a year ago.

The current climate is tough for everyone: advertising revenues are slower, e-commerce adoption is disappointing, business models are still evolving and straining under pressure.

We've learnt a lot about the digital market and about our business portfolio over the last 12 months. We continue to believe strongly in our digital business and our ability to succeed. However, given prevailing market conditions and volatility, we will be taking immediate steps to reduce our absolute level of exposure in the UK.

1. We intend to focus our investment and resources on a few strong, high value businesses: in short to back winners. This means closing some businesses and reorganising others.

The businesses we will be closing are:

a. anglingtimes.com, golferworld.co.uk, golfermagazine.com, grogro.com, countrywalking.com, trailmag.com, birdwatching.com, seaangler.com, troutandsalmon.com, b. screendaily.com, shots.net, c. motherandbaby.co.uk, d. theclickuk.com and associated sites

The businesses we will be restructuring are:

e. fhm.com, empireonline.co.uk, newwoman.co.uk, reddirect.co.uk, f. The Music portfolio, including q4music.com and mojo4music.com, g. hsj.co.uk, lgcnet.com, nursingtimes.net, therapy.co.uk.

We will continue to review the digital Slam, Travel and Produxion businesses.

The other businesses will largely be unaffected.

2. We intend to improve efficiencies and economies of scale across the business. This means restructuring a number of central functions.

We will be restructuring:

a. Commercial b. HR c. Marketing d. Central Business Management e. Business Development

3. We intend to apply more stringent disciplines to the way we continue to fund and manage the business. This means introducing new budgets, performance measures and risk management policies. Further details will be communicated in due course.

Our vision is to build a business that generates significant shareholder value by creating compelling digital experiences that entertain and inform, in so doing unlocking the full potential of EMAP assets.

fields.headline: Brown proposes pigswill ban
fields.standfirst:
• Outbreak pinned to Heddon-on-the-Wall
• Suggested ban on swill feeding
• Restrictions on herd movements
• Army to assist in slaughter

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Illegal foreign meat meant for the Chinese restaurant industry may have contaminated pigswill and triggered the foot and mouth disease outbreak, the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, said tonight.
fields.body:
Illegal foreign meat meant for the Chinese restaurant industry may have contaminated pigswill and triggered the foot and mouth disease outbreak, the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, said tonight.

Mr Brown told the Commons that he proposed to ban the use of pigswill as it seemed likely that an infected batch at a farm at Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland, may have caused the crisis, which has now spread to 669 premises.

He said: "I am today proposing a ban on the use of swill feeding in this country. I have concluded that the potential risk of swill feeding, introducing disease to livestock farms where swill is not used, and to the wider community, is now greater than the benefits to the relatively small number of premises which continue to adopt this practice."

Mr Brown acknowledged that the "unprecedented outbreak" had yet to reach its height. While he insisted the 24-hour period between diagnosis and slaughter was being rigorously pursued, he proposed further measures to tackle the spread.

Mr Brown outlined tighter restrictions on the movement of cattle, sheep and pigs to prevent any future outbreaks reaching such a large scale. He announced two consultation documents, one on banning pigswill and the other on a standstill of cattle movement for 20 days.

The agriculture minister added that consultations were continuing about the possibility of using vaccinations and preparation was being done, "so that it can be done immediately if we conclude it is the right course".

A container of suspect meat clearly labelled for a Chinese restaurant was reportedly found hidden inside a load of household goods after confirmation of the case in Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland.

The pig farmer at the centre of the crisis Bobby Waugh, who runs the Heddon-on-the-Wall farm said earlier today that the government was creating a "smokescreen" by suggesting swill could be behind the current crisis.

Speaking from his home in Sunderland, Mr Waugh, 55, who has a current Ministry of Agriculture licence to collect and process swill, said: "I am not responsible for this, despite suggestions of being the source, and have not even had any contact from Maff or Northumberland County Council regarding it."

To qualify for the pigswill licence farmers have to own processing equipment and boil swill for four hours at 93C to kill bacteria.

Mr Brown said 697,500 animals had been authorised for slaughter and that 423,000 had already been culled.

As the crisis continued to escalate, the Army said it was preparing to assist in the mass slaughter of healthy animals at burial sites in Cumbria, Dumfries and Anglesey. Mr Brown said that 780 soldiers were now helping fight the crisis. He said: "Their role is to assist in the disposal policies and their presence helps us free up our veterinary officers."

Meanwhile, the Northern Ireland livestock industry was today given the green light to resume exports to Europe after being granted regional status, the Province's agriculture minister, Mrs Brid Rodgers, announced.

webTitle: An exhausted generation finds its voice

fields.headline: An exhausted generation finds its voice
fields.standfirst: Last week's article on the stresses suffered by AS-level students prompted a huge response. Here is a selection of the letters we received.
fields.trailText: Last week's article on the stresses suffered by AS-level students prompted a huge response. Here is a selection of the letters we received.
fields.body:
We are a group of year 12s who have just read Phil Revell's article on Curriculum 2000 with interest (Generation exhausted, March 20). We'd like to say a huge thank you for pointing out our plight. We tried to be optimistic about the new system, hoping that it would help us not to specialise too early. But we found it hard to make an informed choice in year 11 as very few of the course details were available at the time.

It has also been very difficult for teachers to adapt to the new courses and to help us individually because a) they have not been informed completely, and b) we have much larger class sizes so there is no time.

Particularly annoying is the apparent lack of communication between the government, the universities and the schools/colleges as to what is required to secure a place in higher education.

The universities have taken no interest in the system and, so far, even the UCAS website has no details of how the new curriculum will affect entry requirements.

Meanwhile, the frankly farcical Key Skills insult our intelligence.

Thank you again for publicising how we feel. You have hit the nail on the head!

Helen Machin, Claire Childs, Laura Rayner, Bucks.

Congratulations to Phil Revell. As a private tutor I see lower sixth-form students under more pressure than upper sixth-formers, with no wider range of studies, no hope of learning as much as before since schools are only teaching about two-thirds of the year to lower sixth forms, corners being cut, especially as regards Key Skills, and a general sense that this has been a horribly backward step.

Personally, I have said that I will not take on new sixth-form students because the logic and philosophy of the new system eludes me.

My former colleagues have to soldier on, gloomily awaiting the next ill-planned change to the system, and my current students are deprived, or will be deprived, of the broader idea of education that used to be the virtue of our system.

David Drinkwater, Durham

Thank you Phil Revell. As a member of the lower sixth, it is nice to see somebody at last recognising what myself and the rest of my year are going through.

This year, after only half a term of four subjects, I had a complete nervous breakdown. As a result, I ended up dropping the fourth subject and now face real problems getting into a good university. I know that 95% of my year are also stressed out, even though the majority of them have not dropped a subject.

Few people have acknowledged what we are going through. Also, as Phil Revell pointed out, we have been the guinea pigs for practically every change implemented.

Can't somebody give us a break?!

Caroline Baker, by email

As a 16-year-old taking four AS-levels with general studies and Key Skills, I could not agree with Phil Revell more.

What I find particularly frustrating is the lack of time I have for other activities. I am finding it extremely difficult to do my extra-curricular Japanese course, which is important as I would like to do a Japanese studies degree.

All around me I see very able and enthusiastic students either leaving college or having to take only three AS-levels, because they cannot cope with the amount of work. I feel that real education has been sacrificed for the sake of pointless work such as Key Skills. Why did I work hard at GCSE simply to have to prove my competence in those areas all over again, via a variety of, frankly, insulting tasks?

Laura Berry, Birmingham

Out of 50 in my daughter's school who started doing four AS levels, only 12 are now still doing so - it is just too much work. It's nice to know we are not the only ones suffering.

Ruth Smith, Liverpool

Phil Revell reported on the AS choices of a student taking physics, biology, chemistry, mathematics, biology and geography in order to keep open his options for both medicine and geophysics.

A qualification in geology or geography is not a prerequisite for an application to read any form of geological sciences (often called Earth Sciences) at university, as the majority of courses assume no prior knowledge. The best preparation for geology or geophysics is maths, physics and chemistry.

At least one of the new AS syllabi in geology is carefully constituted to allow its being taught by geography teachers, while at the same time giving a lively introduction to the modern Earth Sciences. Such a course, taken in conjunction with maths, physics and chemistry, would be an ideal combination in year 12.

Phil England, professor of Geology, Department of Earth Sciences, Oxford

Maybe after "The School I'd Like" competition you should have "The Life I'd Like". I'd like some of my life back, please! I'm in the second term of AS-levels and averaging three to four hours homework a night during the week, with maybe six to seven hours total over the weekend.

And do you know what? I am just managing to keep up.

Caroline Costain, London

 To enter "The School I'd Like" competition, email education@theguardian.com (please remember to include a postal address) or write to Education Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER for an entry form. Closing date: March 30.

Letters on education are welcome and should be sent to Guardian Education, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, faxed to 020-7239 9933, or e-mailed to: education.letters@theguardian.com.

I'm in the second term of AS-levels and averaging three to four hours homework a night during the week, with maybe six to seven hours total over the weekend. And do you know what? I am just managing to keep up. fields.headline: NUS to campaign for means-testing
fields.trailText: The National Union of Students last night decided to campaign for means-tested grants for the poorest students, a result that was a victory for the current president, Owain James, over the union's left wing, which had campaigned for free education for all.
fields.body:
The National Union of Students last night decided to campaign for means-tested grants for the poorest students, a result that was a victory for the current president, Owain James, over the union's left wing, which had campaigned for free education for all.

At the end of a heated debate at Blackpool, 327 students voted to fight for free education, 407 voted against. Given that over 1,500 delegates are registered for NUS's annual conference, that total suggests over 700 student delegates failed to vote or did not turn up..

But Ben Monks, national secretary of the NUS, a member of the Labour Students, was happy with the result: "We beat the hard left in debate and maintained an all-important commitment to means testing, targeting resources at the poorest students. It's vitally important."

NUS president Owain James was also pleased: "It's the only workable strategy. If we went back to the worst of the factions, back to the hard left, and asked for £8,000 per student, we'd lose the support of the public and of other unions. I think that would be unachievable."

Mr James' opponent in this year's election for the NUS presidency, Helen Aspell rejected that argument: "I think a full grant is a realistic aim. Plus, you've got to campaign for what's right. You shouldn't go into negotiations saying, 'this is what we'll accept', you should demand what you want and then discuss."

webTitle: School sports culture leads to violence

fields.headline: School sports culture leads to violence
fields.standfirst: The godlike status afforded to student athletes in America has left the so-called 'nerds' and 'dweebs' feeling isolated and angry, writes Julian Borger
fields.trailText: The godlike status afforded to student athletes in America has left the so-called 'nerds' and 'dweebs' feeling isolated and angry, writes Julian Borger.
fields.body:
One of the highlights of the US sporting year is approaching its climax. It is known as "March Madness" - and with good reason. It pits basketball teams from across the country against each other in a knockout tournament that is watched by tens of thousands of fans in huge sporting arena and by tens of millions on television.

It is huge business, and the most extraordinary thing about it is that the players are all college students. The idea takes a little getting used to for an outsider.

I played some football (soccer in US terms) at university in Britain, and our maximum crowd numbered about a dozen. Even the good college teams would have near fainted at the idea of being on television.

The only college sports event with a mass audience is the annual Oxford-Cambridge boat race, and that owes much of its popularity to a national fondness for tradition.

The transatlantic difference is even more striking on the secondary school level. In small-town America, whole communities regularly turn out to watch the high-school team play baseball, or American football or basketball.

Schoolchildren can be heroes for the day. It is an all-encompassing social event of a kind rarely witnessed any more in English towns, and it is one where the focus of attention is exclusively on young people.

Nor is this school-age sporting culture confined to boys. Due to a piece of legislation called Title IX, passed in 1972 (at the height of the Nixon era of all times) girls are guaranteed equal spending and support in school sport, and parents appear to pay the game just as much respect. Girls' football (soccer) is even bigger than the boys' version, helped by the fact that the women's team won the last World Cup.

The downside to this phenomenon, however, is obvious and it is beginning to take its toll. If children who are good at sports are heroes, what does that make those who are not?

Underlying the recent spate of school shootings have been stories of bullying and exclusion of non-athletes by the school "jocks".

After a frustrated schoolboy shot two other students dead earlier this month in the Californian town of Santee, an entire subculture of bullying came to the surface.

An angry young reader wrote to the Los Angeles Times: "For school personnel to be at a loss as to the motives of the shootings at Santana High School is hypocritical. Anyone who has attended high school knows there is the "in crowd" made up of sports heroes, class officers and their entourage.

"To this group the teachers and administrators pander, allowing them to do pretty much as they please. Those not in the 'in group' become the subjects of bullying, taunting and ridicule. They are the nerds, dweebs etc."

The relentless rise of college sports has taken its toll in other ways. Many of the colleges have become addicted to the millions that their sports teams bring in, in the form of commercial sponsorship and ticket sales.

Increasingly they go out in search of young talents who have not finished secondary school. The academic role of these underage prodigies is often a polite pretence. In many of the big basketball playing colleges, the graduation rate among the players is well under 50%.

The term "student-athlete" rings hollow in what has largely become a training ground for the professional league, the NBA, and those who do not make the transition often end up with nothing to show for their years in college.

It is a high risk for a fleeting chance at stardom. It would have been nice to have a few more people turn up to watch us play football in our college days, but the most casual glance through the US daily press demonstrates there is a price to be paid for taking student sports too seriously.

fields.headline: Chaos theory
fields.standfirst: From 2002 university entrants will have an astonishing array of qualifications. And that, warns  Donald MacLeod, could throw admissions tutors into confusion
fields.trailText: From 2002 university entrants will have an astonishing array of qualifications. And that, warns Donald MacLeod, could throw admissions tutors into confusion
fields.body:
As a university admissions tutor remarked gloomily, "Any student who can understand this system deserves an offer." To which another tutor responded, "Any student who understands this system can have a job in my office any time."

Curriculum 2000, with its array of AS-levels, vocational A-levels and key skills on top of "normal" A-levels have been causing headaches in schools for months. But only now are universities waking up to the implications for their intake next year.

Should they make their 2002 offers to prospective students in the new mixed currency of qualifications or stick to "old money" A-levels?

This lack of clarity is putting an added strain on the current batch of 16- and 17-year-olds (and their teachers) in lower sixth who are already having to come to grips with new syllabuses. That is difficult enough, but now comes the added worry of what the new qualifications will be worth in the competition for places in higher education. Will my chosen university be impressed by a key skills certificate in application of number or IT, or should I concentrate on getting three good A-level grades?

It is just the latest trial for this guinea-pig generation in England and Wales, who have been the first to take Sats at ages 7, 11 and 14. (In Scotland the guinea pigs went through a year earlier and came disastrously unstuck when the Scottish Qualifications Authority was unable to deliver all the results.)

The admission tutors' exchange is reported by Brian Heap, who has made the first real attempt to find out what universities intend to do in 2002. For more than 30 years his Degree Course Offers has been essential reading for applicants, listing the A-level and Highers grades needed for entry to each university in all the main subjects.

But when he came to update his information for the next edition (due out in May) Heap encountered confusion. His 9,000 questionnaire returns included some who clearly did not understand the new points system devised by the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (Ucas). One physics course, for instance, proposed asking for 600 points - the equivalent of six A-levels at grade B. Another department muddled up A-levels and AS-levels.

Yesterday a Ucas survey found that 70% of A-level students in England, Wales and Northern Ireland will sit four new AS-levels this year, and 55% will be taking the new Key Skills qualifications - application of number, communications, IT, study skills, problem solving and working with others. This prompted chief executive Tony Higgins to declare: "The days of the traditional higher education applicant with three A-levels are gone." He said the challenge for universities and colleges now was to "recognise the wide variety of qualifications coming their way and to reflect this in their entry requirements."

If Heap's meticulous soundings among university admissions officers are right, a lot of this wide variety will simply be ignored. Tutors will certainly take the new AS-levels into account, as they look at the present A-level modules, but many say they will not consider vocational A-levels, key skills or the new general studies paper.

While Ucas has drawn up a table giving points scores for all qualifications, Heap feels this has not filtered through to every admissions tutor. One senior academic confided that the admissions tutors "paled visibly" when she explained to them what they were being asked to do.

But even when admissions tutors are aware of the Ucas equivalences, it is clear that they do not all believe them. A vocational A-level (formerly an advanced GNVQ) in health and social care is officially equal to two A-levels - say physics and chemistry. But as Heap points out, your chances of getting into medical school with a vocational A-level in health are pretty well nil.

The result is a split between universities that will accept the new Curriculum 2000 qualifications and those that won't - making a mockery of the government's grand reform. In general the older universities and the more sought after courses seem to be sticking to the "old money" until they get a better sense of the standards of the new AS-level, key skills and so on.

Brian Heap says: "Is it easier to get a grade B in a vocational A-level in art than a B in English A-level? Universities with competitive courses are probably sticking to the old grade system until they see the students coming through. It is very difficult for tutors to judge. It is probably going to take two or three years before the whole system settles down."

University College London is keen to encourage students to broaden their interests without being too prescriptive, explained Nigel Percival, head of the admissions office. That means three good A-level grades plus a fourth subject - either an AS-level or, for instance, a GCSE in Japanese.

UCL would not be using the Ucas points system, which he believes is unhelpful. Introducing key skills was a good idea but it was too early to judge the qualifications. Instead, students will be asked to show evidence of three out of the six skills, either by a certificate or something like a part-time job (showing their ability to work with others).

For any university course, in place of the simple A-level grades or the equivalent in points (10 for an A, eight for a B and so on) there will be a whole series of possible combinations that students will be able to offer. So in place of a course listed as requiring three Bs, for 2002 entry this will become 300 points achieved by BBC at A-level plus an AS-level; two Bs, plus a vocational A-level at B plus an AS-level; a vocational A-level plus a C at A-level and an AS-level. This by no means exhausts the possible combinations - some departments will accept key skills as part of the overall points score, some will not.

So complex have these combinations become that they would not fit in the encyclopaedic Big Guide that Ucas publishes. "It's not physically possible to get it into one book," said a spokesman. Instead, details of course offers will be in a CD-rom sold alongside the book. Publication has been delayed a month till mid-June.

Ucas concedes that the new curriculum poses a "big task" for the 330 universities and colleges involved in higher education: "We are giving a lot of help and support, but it is a major change in the qualifications people are going to be presenting for entry."

But when it comes to the value of the new qualifications, Ucas insists that universities can rely on the tariff it has worked out. A-levels (GCE) and vocational A-levels (VCE) are "on exactly equal footing", said a spokesman. "People may be studying different subjects but the results they will have are directly comparable and it should be possible for institutions to compare them. All of the institutions are aware that the previous curriculum no longer exists."

Yet a glance at the lists in the forthcoming Degree Course Offers tells a different story. In accountancy, entry requirements range from Southampton at the top asking 370 points to 140 points at Derby and Leeds Metropolitan. Southampton wants two grade As at A-level as part of that and will not include general studies. A lot of the other old universities like Queen's Belfast, Bath, Bristol, Edinburgh and London School of Economics specify A-levels, mostly ABB grades.

Less competitive courses at old and new universities tend to be more flexible - Aston will accept vocational A-levels in combination with A-levels or AS-levels and will include general studies; Kent simply states 260 points, Northumbria 240 points. The split is not just between old and new universities; Nottingham Trent specifies three Cs at A-level, while Aberystwyth requires 240 points (equivalent to three Cs but a lot more flexible if other qualifications are admitted).

Heap believes the new curriculum was brought in so quickly that examiners, teachers and admissions officers are all having difficulties - not to mention the unfortunate students.

 Degree Course Offers 2002 by Brian Heap is published by Trotman Publishing on May 16, rrp £21.99.

fields.headline: Robin Bagilhole
fields.trailText: Remarkable artist and teacher, over 25 years he taught at virtually every art and design school in England.
fields.body:
Robin Bagilhole, who has died of a heart attack aged 57, was a remarkable artist and teacher, one of the last of that breed of national diploma in design-trained artists. Over 25 years, he taught at virtually every art and design school in England. His silk screen and graphic works were exhibited and published through the Thumb and the Francis Kyle Galleries in London's Soho.

Educationally, he was associated with St Martin's School of Art from the mid-1970s until last year. Classes, marked by noise and laughter, were inspired by his quixotic sense of invention. Eighty students would enter a studio armed with a skip-load of cardboard and a hammer. Six hours later, an armada of Spanish galleons would sail out, props for his famous Hackney Empire St Martin's fashion shows.

Bagilhole was born in Wadebridge, Cornwall, the son of railway engineer; after leaving school at 14, he went to Redruth School of Art, where he completed his NDD. After a period as a long-distance lorry driver, chef and undertaker, he attended Nottingham College of Art, graduating in 1972, before going to the Royal College.

His reputation was founded on results. Some of his graduates now run television and film companies; others are animators, copywriters, designers, photographers, set-designers, printmakers, painters and a generation of art educationalists.

At the time of his death, he was about to publish A Year With Miss Jones, a series of lampoons mocking the hypocrisy of law, order and organised religion - a world of black wigs, carnal rumba and rolled trouser legs.

He is survived by the wife and two adult children of his first marriage, and Mariel, his second wife, and their two young children.

Robin Bagilhole, artist and teacher, born October 14 1944; died February 21 2001

fields.headline: Higher browsing
fields.trailText: The third degree | News: unemployment | Research news | Universe
fields.body:
The third degree

Solid reading matter on drop-outs (sorry, student retention) from the Commons education and employment committee's report last week, leavened by shameless point-scoring.

Professor Sir Howard Newby: "I do not think frankly any party is going to go into an election saying 'Vote for us and we will raise taxes so that we can give more money to higher education'."

Dr Evan Harris (Lib Dem): "Our policy at the last election was precisely that..." Chairman [Barry Sheerman]: "I think Howard said no major party."

Asked by Helen Jones (Labour) about progress on benchmarking and evaluation of academic staff, David Packham, registrar of Aston, replied: "There has been very measured progress really." "Is that a euphemism for slow?" "It has been quite slow, yes."

You have all heard of the academic transfer market, but did you realise that there is also a vibrant market in senior university administrators? Warwick University has found, to its annoyance, that it has become the UK's breeding ground for academic managers: other institutions have been poaching staff right left and centre.

The latest casulty is Dave Hall, the head of Warwick's research office, who is to become academic registrar at Birmingham University. Other former Warwick staff to leave in recent times include John Hogan, now registrar at Durham; David Holmes, registrar at Oxford; Tony Rich, registrar at Essex; Steve Cannon, university secretary at Aberdeen; John Gledhill, registrar at Coventry; Paul Bolton, vice-president, administration, at Hong Kong... and the list goes on. Perhaps it serves Warwick right for all those star academics it has poached over recent years.

News: unemployment

Early next month a government study will show that black and Asian graduates are up to three times as likely to be unemployed after university, even when they have the same grades in the same subjects as their white counterparts.

Detailed figures gaugeing the employability of graduates from different universities are being unveiled, and for the first time they take into account all the factors that determine a university leaver's job chances: degree classification; subject studied; class and school background; gender and age; even local employment conditions.

Female students are 50% more likely to secure a job six months after graduating than men, but this advantage disappears three years after graduation - suggesting women are less fussy about taking a lowly position for a first job.

A graduate's skin colour, however, dwarfs all other factors put together in determining the likelihood of employment. There is little variation in the figures for black Caribbean, black African, Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi or Chinese graduates. Where 6% of white graduates are still looking for jobs six months after university, as many as 15% of their black counterparts will be on the dole.

We'll check, mate

webTitle: George Eliot letters win export reprieve

fields.headline: George Eliot letters win export reprieve
fields.trailText: Admirers of the novelist George Eliot were yesterday given two months to start to raise nearly £18,000 to keep some of her most illuminating letters in Britain.
fields.body:
Admirers of the novelist George Eliot were yesterday given two months to start to raise nearly £18,000 to keep some of her most illuminating letters in Britain.

In one of these, the author writes: "The influence of one woman's life on the lot of other women is getting greater and greater, with the quickening spread of all influences".

Alan Howarth, the arts minister, said the letters expressed views central to her work and were of extensive literary significance.

As a "last chance" to keep them in the UK, he imposed a temporary bar on their export until May 26.

If a serious intention to buy them emerged he would extend the bar for a further two months, until July 26.

The 26 letters, dating from 1867 to 1879, cover the period when Eliot was finishing her masterpiece, Middlemarch. The culture department said the novel - televised in the 1990s - was acclaimed as possible the greatest work of realism in the English language.

Nearly all the letters were addressed to Jane Senior, a favourite on Eliot's "choice list of beloved 'Sisters'" in the movement for social reform.

Mrs Senior, noted also for her singing and beauty, appears to have been a dramatically more effective version of Dorothea, the idealistic heroine of Middlemarch.

A leading philanthropist, she was one of the first women appointed to a senior government position, as inspector of workhouses and pauper houses. One of Eliot's letters congratulates her on this post.

Others discuss their aspirations and ideas. Eliot writes: "One lives by faith in human goodness - the only guarantee that there could be any other source of Goodness in the universe."

Only three of the batch have been published before.

When Sotheby's of London sold them in December last year, it called them "the most important series of letters by George Eliot to appear at auction for many years".

They were then expected to fetch up to £34,600. The name of their overseas owner was not disclosed yesterday.

Mr Howarth's department said their "rich pattern of language, theme and tone reveals the development of a significant relationship over a sustained period of time".

fields.headline: Towns and a tapestry
fields.standfirst: Leek wants Reading's sewing
fields.trailText: The Nicholson Institute in Leek is a Grade II building dating from the 1880s which has recently been done up. What better way to celebrate its reopening, say the dignitaries of the Staffordshire town, than to repatriate the copy of the Bayeux tapestry which was made in the same decade. But for a century it has been on display in the Museum of Reading. And Reading has long made a fine home for it.
fields.body:
The Nicholson Institute in Leek is a Grade II building dating from the 1880s which houses travelling exhibitions, displays the work of local photographers and is home to a small permanent art collection. It has recently been done up (thanks to local rather than Lottery money) and is to be reopened this summer. What better way to celebrate the event, say the dignitaries of the Staffordshire town, than to repatriate the copy of the Bayeux tapestry which was made in the same decade as the institute.

But for a century it has been on display in the Museum of Reading, along with mosaics, ancient coins and an innovative machine invented by George Palmer and Thomas Huntley in the 1840s to stamp a name on biscuit dough. And Reading has long made a fine home for it.

The tapestry is a fine thing, a same-size reproduction of Bishop Odo's in Normandy, sewn at the inspiration of a Leek grande dame by the local embroidery society (who stitched britches on the naked Saxons for modesty's sake but otherwise plyed their needles with great accuracy). After touring abroad it was bought by a mayor of Reading who presented it as one of the first exhibits to the town's new art gallery in 1897.

We are not talking serious local pride here; this is not the the Elgin marbles. Town officials are in the business of boosting and conserving. Tourism, as the foot and mouth outbreak has shown, is big business. In the municipal power game, Reading has the muscle. It is now a "unitary" authority whereas Leek is a mere part of the Staffordshire Moorlands district. An amicable compromise ought to be arranged - an extended loan, say. Local museums are too often autarkies. If their collections were swopped and reformed - within obvious limits of cost - there might be gains all round. Maybe, in the spirit of true Europeanism, the real tapestry, currently in Bayeux but believed to have been made in Kent, should be part of the swapping deal as well.

fields.headline: A watchdog bitten
fields.standfirst: The plans to drastically cut the number of teaching assessments have infuriated student leaders, reports Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: The plans to drastically cut the number of teaching assessments have infuriated student leaders, reports Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
A huge bureaucratic weight was lifted from the shoulders of the English academic sector last week, when the government announced plans to dramatically reduce the number of teaching inspections in universities.

But the proposals, which will mean that 40% of university departments will avoid teaching assessments in the future, have attracted the wrath of student leaders, who argue that student applicants need all the information they can get when choosing degree courses.

Education secretary David Blunkett told MPs last week that departments awarded good teaching scores after previous inspections should be exempt from future assessments. This would mean that the teaching of whole universities such as Cambridge, York and Warwick would avoid departmental inspections altogether, although they would still face one overall institutional audit of their activities. Under the plans a few departments would also volunteer for inspections, in order to act as benchmarks for other courses.

Nothing boils the blood of academics more than teaching inspections, mainly because of the mountains of paperwork they require. "It's just an enormous amount of time," said Andrew Oswald, professor of economics at Warwick University. "If today's announcement actually happens, then it's very good news. It will save us a huge amount of wasteful paperwork."

The move represents a political coup for university leaders, who have been furiously lobbying behind the scenes to secure ministerial backing for the so-called "lighter touch" for teaching inspections. The Quality Assurance Agency, which carries out the inspections, had already agreed to reduce the bureaucratic burden of visits. But academics demanded further concessions.

Discussions between Universities UK, which represents academic leaders, and the quality watchdog chief John Randall, had ended in stalemate. But the chief executive of Universities UK, Diana Warwick, instead negotiated a deal with Sir Brian Fender, chief executive of the Higher Education Funding Council for England, which contracts QAA to carry out teaching inspections. At the same time UUK's president, Sir Howard Newby, bent the ears of the prime minister's education adviser Andrew Adonis. It is also understood that Cambridge and Oxford universities made direct representations to the prime minister. The teaching inspections have also been a burning topic of discussion during recent meetings of the Russell group, which brings together the heads of 20 large research universities. The Russell stand to benefit the most from the government's proposals, which would exempt any department scoring a minimum of 21 out of 24 in a previous inspection, as well as top grades in three of the six categories assessed.

Under pressure from Number 10, and briefed by the funding council, Blunkett made his announcement in parliament last Tuesday. It is also understood that Hefce officials have already drafted documents outlining funding cuts for the QAA as it moves to a less intrusive inspection regime after this autumn.

The move came as a revolt against the quality inspectors erupted among senior academics at the London School of Economics. The LSE board said it would "secede from engagements with the QAA". The funding council, however, can withdraw funds from any institution refusing to be inspected. Cambridge University also has previously delayed its own institutional audit by inspectors.

But what has been welcomed by the producers of higher education has only raised concern among students, the customers of universities. President of the National Union of Students Owain James said: "NUS is in favour of universities undergoing Teaching Quality Assessments because they give students clear and consistent external information on which to base their decisions when researching courses and colleges or universities.

"Student progression and achievement and student support and guidance are two of the six factors in the teaching and quality assessment. We are also disappointed that we have not been consulted by the DfEE in drawing up its 'lighter touch' proposals."

During their inquiry into student drop-out rates, MPs were told that students often use the teaching reports to inform their applications. Higher assessment scores were associated with departments with low drop-out rates. But in its report published last week the education committee also urges the QAA to publish guidelines to help reduce the burden of paperwork for academics and assessors.

fields.headline: Unreal world
fields.standfirst: Empirical research is more and more sidelined in favour of grand theory. Three Scottish academics show what can be done if you're prepared to examine the real world.  John Crace  reports
fields.trailText: Empirical research is more and more sidelined in favour of grand theory. Three Scottish academics show what can be done if you're prepared to examine the real world. John Crace reports
fields.body:
Just as the political apparatchiks are cranking themselves up for an imminent election, the fallout from another is about to begin. This week Philip Schlesinger, David Miller and William Dinan of the Stirling Media Research Institute (SMRI) publish Open Scotland?, a damning critique of political communications in Scotland, which alleges that the 1999 voter education campaign for the Scottish Parliament, which was co-ordinated by the Scottish Office in Westminster, was fatally flawed and that the main beneficiary of these errors was the Labour Party.

Empirical research into political trends has become unfashionable these days, Miller contends. "Many of the radicals of the 60s and 70s have drifted off into the arcane language game known as postmodernism or to other exotic theories from the left bank, in which nothing but language was real," says Miller. "As a result, not only did they not do empirical research on the real world, but some of them didn't even believe that there was a real world to research. With the abandonment of concepts of truth and reality, it became rather hard for researchers to point out the latest piece of government misinformation, secrecy or manipulation."

Miller is not alone in these beliefs. Rod Tiffen of the University of Sydney in Australia recently commented that it is "amazing how many media scholars there are, and how little work on some of the most basic and important trends". Ivor Gaber, emeritus professor of broadcast journalism at Goldsmiths College, University of London, said: "As a former university head of department, I recall with despair my attempts to persuade colleagues to consider undertaking research projects that either the Economic and Social Research Council or the media industries might want to fund."

Miller goes on to say that to many of the new breed of academics, whose desire to climb the greasy pole is matched only by their reluctance to rock the boat, the notion of independent research is anathema. It doesn't pay well, it's time-consuming and it's potentially controversial. None of which is exactly career-enhancing within the academic establishment. "You do get whispering campaigns," says Miller. "You hear that such and such a person is a trouble maker, and before long the gossip has become fact. No wonder so many academics are frightened of looking into areas where they're not wanted. Jobs are hard to come by, and the structures by which academic performance is measured are designed to favour consensus. The Research Assessment Exercise gives far greater reward to academics whose articles appear in international peer-reviewed journals, which research has shown are read by an average of between 1.5 to 6 people, than to those who are prepared to engage in a more public debate."

David Miller cites Anthony Giddens, the director of the London School of Economics, as the champion par excellence of the grand theorists. "He claims to be temperamentally unsuited to empirical research," says Miller, "but the result is that he is so little of a threat that he is welcome at Downing Street."

Giddens is not without his supporters, however, as some academics reject suggestions that researchers have become less critical of the government and argue that more academics should follow in Giddens' footsteps.

"My problem is that academics are too critical: they end up in carping mode," said Julian LeGrande, professor of public policy at the LSE, whose work influenced New Labour's health and welfare policies. "There are not enough people like Giddens looking at broad policy and having a positive impact on government. The RAE encourages researchers to be increasingly specialist, focusing on in-depth narrow topics, not broad policy sweeps."

Even so, three people who are almost certain to find themselves crossed off Tony and Cherie's guest list - assuming they were ever on it - are Schlesinger, Miller and Dinan, who compared the public pronouncements on the Scottish voter education campaign with what actually happened and found some disturbing discrepancies.

The elections for the new Scottish parliament were the first in Britain to introduce an element of proportionality into the voting system, in a bid to ensure that the voices of some of the smaller parties were heard. Each elector got two votes - the first was allocated on a first-past-the-post system, and the second on a proportional basis. It was a complicated system, but Donald Dewar, the then secretary of state for Scotland, stated in October 1998 that he wanted "to make sure that every individual understands the impact of the votes he or she casts".

In official documents, the rather more conservative aim of giving the voters "sufficient" information was put forward, but even by this lower standard the research team believes it is highly debatable whether the campaign met its aims.

"Six weeks after Donald Dewar made a statement pointedly giving examples where the SNP could lose out if its party's supporters cast their vote differently from the first one," says Miller, "the commitment to explain their voting system disappeared from internal campaign documents." Scottish Office officials, Miller claims, had anticipated that Labour would be the party which would most likely suffer the most if its own supporters voted differently. All that did appear by way of voter information was a largely unintelligible fact sheet that the government's own research shows was understood by very few.

One effect was that 112,586 Labour supporters in Glasgow alone wasted their second vote by voting Labour twice. "Labour had its full complement of representatives through the first ballot, so voting Labour twice was a waste of a second vote," says Miller. "It's possible that some voted Labour twice merely to keep another party out, but it is more likely they didn't understand the system. Research has also shown that when the system was explained to them, some respondents said they would have voted differently had they known. If only a proportion of Labour voters across areas of Scotland dominated by Labour had used their second vote differently, it is reasonable to conjecture that smaller parties like the Scottish Socialist Party and the Greens, as well as the Lib-Dems and SNP, could have gained a few extra MSPs. The ambition for proportionality was undermined. "The evidence suggests that something odd happened in the production of the campaign. We don't know if it was incompetence or deliberate, but the final campaign did not properly explain the voting system."

Not one to mince words, Miller argues that academics too often leave it to journalists to dig out political scandals; and that many of their peers have been neglecting their duties to the public in this area. "Academic salaries are paid for out of public funding," Miller points out. Theoretical research may still have a large part to play in the wider political and intellectual debates, but Miller believes that not enough academics are prepared to enter the political arena at a hands-on level.

The research team is now at the forefront of the campaign for the lobbying system in the new parliament to be regulated, and it has been critical of some journalists for offering ministers and civil servants media training. And while it may not always produce the results that the government has in mind, it still attracts kudos and respect for its independence. "We are consulted by government and other official bodies, who regard us as a source of relevant advice," says Schlesinger. "The key issue for me is that we're attempting to do some public policy research and present public interest arguments about devolution which seem not to be coming from anywhere else just now. This is a key role for academia. In my view it sets us apart from thinktanks, and because we have no-strings funding we can offer an honest view based on as exhaustive a research process as the constraints allow."

LeGrande concedes the point on think tanks. "There is some truth in the view that academics are becoming displaced by the think tanks as the architects of new ideas," he says. "the think tanks dominate discussion on policy because most academics are so specialised."

Miller would argue that the key issue is not specialisation so much as independence. And independence may not always bring its just rewards. Oxford is still paying for its refusal to grant Lady Thatcher an honorary degree, as millions of pounds from the Thatcher Foundation head east towards Cambridge, and many universities continue to measure their success by the research grants they can attract. Whether Stirling will welcome this latest publication is uncertain. But the Scottish electorate should be profoundly grateful.

 Open Scotland? is published by Polygon on March 28. Additional reporting by Lee Elliot Major

"Academic salaries are paid for out of public funding," Miller points out. Theoretical research may still have a large part to play in the wider political and intellectual debates, but Miller believes that not enough academics are prepared to enter the political arena at a hands-on level. The research team is now at the forefront of the campaign for the lobbying system in the new parliament to be regulated, and it has been critical of some journalists for offering ministers and civil servants media training. And while it may not always produce the results that the government has in mind, it still attracts kudos and respect for its independence. "We are consulted by government and other official bodies, who regard us as a source of relevant advice," says Schlesinger. "The key issue for me is that we're attempting to do some public policy research and present public interest arguments about devolution which seem not to be coming from anywhere else just now. This is a key role for academia. In my view it sets us apart from thinktanks, and because we have no-strings funding we can offer an honest view based on as exhaustive a research process as the constraints allow." LeGrande concedes the point on think tanks. "There is some truth in the view that academics are becoming displaced by the think tanks as the architects of new ideas," he says. "the think tanks dominate discussion on policy because most academics are so specialised." Miller would argue that the key issue is not specialisation so much as independence. And independence may not always bring its just rewards. Oxford is still paying for its refusal to grant Lady Thatcher an honorary degree, as millions of pounds from the Thatcher Foundation head east towards Cambridge, and many universities continue to measure their success by the research grants they can attract. Whether Stirling will welcome this latest publication is uncertain. But the Scottish electorate should be profoundly grateful.  Open Scotland? is published by Polygon on March 28. fields.headline: The tale of Anchor Cottage
fields.standfirst: When ex-students take out second mortgages to preserve a university amenity, it must be something special. Joe Plomin reports
fields.trailText: When ex-students take out second mortgages to preserve a university amenity, it must be something special. Joe Plomin reports
fields.body:
London's medical students are up in arms because a consortium of former students is being forced to buy a sailing cottage from their own university, Queen Mary, to keep the building in student hands. And it's not even certain that they will succeed, as they have to compete in the open market.

Thirty years ago, the London Hospital Medical College bought Anchor Cottage, in Burnham-on-Crouch, Essex, for its students to use for sailing. Although it became more run-down as the years went by, generations of London medics have enjoyed escaping from Whitechapel to the coast for odd weekends.

"There's a heartfelt commitment to the place. There's a girls' and a boys' bedroom, a nice patio and it's along the front of the river. It's right next to a nice little pub, you couldn't get a better position," said the captain of the sailing club, George Crowther, a second-year student.

Even after the college was amalgamated with two other institutions to form Queen Mary University, Anchor was safe for nearly four years. Before the transition, it had been listed as a "teaching facility", so that when it came under the new university's administration, the authorities did not realise they owned a prime piece of Essex property. That changed a year ago when Queen Mary received a letter asking if it would like to sell its riverside cottage.

Faced by finances in the red, the college decided to sell up and give the money to the students as the only way to renovate the main student union building, a project that was nearly on hold due to lack of money.

Queen Mary's financial position is difficult. It is £5m in debt and also £70,000 short on the money needed to renovate the union building. Even more crucially for the cottage, the university found a building in disrepair that needed a lot of work to bring it up to safety standards - work the college could not afford.

"They really gave us no choice. We know the college is in debt and does not have the money to refurbish Anchor, but everyone was really pissed off that they were linking one facility to another," said Tom Dolphin, the Medical and Dental Students' Association president. "It's not sustainable, you can't keep selling off one student facility to pay for another."

Angry students held an emergency general meeting, but decided they could do nothing - the cottage would have to go, or the union would not be refurbished.

The decision upset many students. "I've been going to the cottage since I was a young kid, because my sister was a medical student. It's like losing a part of the college," said Crowther.

Medical students moaned and complained, but lost hope until former medical students heard what had happened and breathed new life into the campaign."We started getting letters and emails from old boys to say how horrified they were. Several people have cancelled their alumni membership as a protest," said Dolphin.

Within the next few days, students hope a new bid will be announced, funded by former students, to buy the cottage a second time around. Professor Mark Cawfield, who studied at the London Hospital and now works there, has gathered a group willing to remortgage their homes for the sake of Anchor Cottage.

"We are not looking to make a profit, but to keep the cottage as an amenity for students. Most people will be borrowing against their homes to raise the money. It's not clear yet whether it's feasible," he said.

The university has delayed selling the cottage until it finds out if the old boys' bid is viable, but insists the cottage must be sold.

"The college decided to sell Anchor Cottage largely because of the cost of making it safe for continued use. No decision has been made on the sale and we are continuing to hold discussions with parties interested in purchasing the cottage," said Nigel Relph, Queen Mary's director of external relations.

The university says there is no acrimony between the students' association and the university and indeed everyone did agree to sell the cottage in the end.

But Tom Dolphin remembers frustration, if not outright acrimony. "It's been quite frustrating, they decided we couldn't attend lots of the meetings and had to write down our point of view. They then lost one of the bits of paper and it got confused. It was rushed through very quickly and wasn't satisfactory."

webTitle: British tourist industry counts foot and mouth cost

fields.headline: British tourist industry counts foot and mouth cost
fields.trailText: Government advertisements are urging people to go back to the countryside, but last weekend there was little evidence that anyone had listened
fields.body:
When foot and mouth disease struck, the government told people to stay out of rural areas. They did - and the tourist industry dried up.

Now government advertisements are urging people to go back to the countryside, but last weekend there was little evidence that anyone had listened. "The adverts have made absolutely no difference. We are still about 40% down on guests, particularly at the weekend," said Virginia Blackwell, who manages the 15th century Crown and Cushion inn in the Cotswolds. "Financially, it's devastating." The Cotswolds was formerly one of Britain's premier tourist areas, but at the Market House Restaurant, proprietor Aimee Wong has lost up to a third of her customers. "The ads came too late," said Mrs. Wong, whose business is her sole source of income. "People remember that the government told them not to visit rural areas, and they're staying away."

With more cases confirmed every day (the total has now topped 600, and is still rising) this scenario is being replicated in many areas that should now be playing host to their first spring visitors.

Tourist executives say that despite the advertising campaign - and new tax breaks for rural businesses - the industry is haemorrhaging £150m a week. "Although the effect is more acute in rural areas, there is clear evidence that towns and cities across the United Kingdom are suffering from cancelled bookings, and the cost is running into billions of pounds," said Conservative MP Peter Ainsworth on Monday.

Since it was first detected on Feb. 20, the disease has criss-crossed Britain and cases have been reported in France, the Netherlands and Ireland. Desperate to halt the contagion, British officials have closed walking paths and historic sites and cancelled sports fixtures, devastating a tourist industry worth around £96bn a year.

The government is now stressing that many facilities remain open, including pubs, restaurants and some theme parks. Between them, English Heritage and the National Trust plan to open 350 historic buildings as usual in the next few weeks, and some footpaths and canals in unaffected areas may reopen soon.

In the Lake District, which reported its first case of the disease at the weekend, officials fear for thousands of thoroughbred Herdwick sheep, a rare, indigenous breed that roams the hills. Chris Collier, chief executive of the Cumbria Tourist Board, said plans to reopen some hill areas to hikers have been delayed.

In Rochester, however, those who cater to tourists say business remains brisk. The nearest foot-and-mouth case is 15km north-east of Rochester in rural Kent, and the county has had relatively few outbreaks. "In fact, we have been busier than usual," said Matthew Luethi, proprietor of Mr. Tope's Bistro on the main street. "We have had a lot of Americans in the past few days - perhaps we are benefiting from problems in the rest of the country."

webTitle: Explore the creative potential of your mobile

fields.headline: Explore the creative potential of your mobile
fields.standfirst: SMS Poem Competition
fields.trailText: Unleash your hidden potential. This week the Guardian is launching the first interactive text message poetry competition.
fields.body:
Unleash your hidden potential. This week the Guardian is launching the first interactive text message poetry competition.

It is open to anyone, particularly those who have never thought of writing a poem before. It even offers the opportunity for mobile phones to be used legitimately in classrooms, since teachers can use the competition as the basis for a creative English lesson. The aim is to explore the creative potential of mobile phones. A prize of £1,000 will be given for the best entry, £500 for the second best and £100 for each of three runners-up. Entrants under the age of 16 will need the permission of a parent or guardian. Details of the competition, which is being done in association with Consult Hyperion (providers of the infrastructure) will be announced in the Guardian's Online section on Thursday and also on our website.

A period of two weeks, starting on Thursday March 29, will be given for writing the poems, which must contain a maximum of 160 characters, the limit for text messaging on today's mobile phones. This may seem restrictive but it still allows plenty of scope. For instance, "Shall I compare thee to a summer's day?" takes up 25% of the available capacity.

The competition will have a unique interactive feature, as the participants themselves will be sent the final shortlist so they can decide who the winners are (by texting back a mark out of ten to our central computer). The telephone number will be published on Thursday.

This is a new medium. There are no rules about how text poems should be constructed. They can be written in ordinary English, in text abbreviations, in the regional texting dialects that are starting to emerge (like "wid u" in the North) or in a combination of all three. But if they are to have any chance of success, they must be written in a way that judges can understand. If the abbreviations become so obscure that they look like a private language then it will be impossible to evaluate them. Thursday's Guardian will contain full details, including the telephone number to ring and instructions on how to text message for those people who haven't yet taken the plunge. There will also be an article advising participants on how to set about writing a text poem, together with samples of what text poems might look like. During the course of the competition, examples of poems that have been submitted will be displayed on our website.

webTitle: Pre-school groups to get star ratings

fields.headline: Pre-school groups to get star ratings
fields.standfirst:
Blair launches scheme to push up standards

Special report: New Labour in power
Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Parents will be able to choose nurseries and playgroups using a star rating system under a scheme unveiled yesterday by Tony Blair.
fields.body:
Parents will be able to choose nurseries and playgroups using a star rating system under a scheme unveiled yesterday by Tony Blair.

The prime minister, keen to stress the government's moves to help parents and children as the Conservatives push for the family vote with tax concessions, personally launched the Investors in Children initiative - with Cherie Blair as patron - at a Downing Street reception for childcare workers.

"Our scheme will help parents choose what's right for their children. It will be a practical guide on the facilities and quality of care and early education available," Mr Blair said.

"When a parent entrusts the care of their child to another they need to know that their child will receive high quality care."

Under the scheme, nurseries will be ranked under a standardised national system to highlight quality of education, care and facilities. Ministers hope the scheme will push up standards as nurseries improve their performance in or der to qualify for more stars.

The Conservatives, however, dismissed the initiative as a gimmick, arguing that national ratings could distance voluntary, charitable and independent providers. They would encourage flexibility "through the flowering of a diverse system of early years education", the party said.

Education ministers argue that a rating scheme is necessary to help push up standards for pre-school care and to help first-time parents, in particular, choose high quality care.

"The reality is that when parents are first looking for childcare, they often don't know exactly what to look for," said the employment and equal opportunities minister, Margaret Hodge. "This scheme will help guide their choice, and put parents in the driving seat."

The government has sought a substantial increase in childcare places - a "revolution in childcare" according to Mr Blair - to remedy the chronic shortage in Britain, where levels of provision are among the worst in Europe.

Additional pressures from schemes to encourage lone parents back to the workplace, together with the childcare tax credit, have revealed a severe shortfall in places, though the government says it has created 625,000 places since coming to power - more than the Tories achieved in 40 years.

Campaigners now stress the need to focus on the quality of expanded provision.

Currently, there are around 40 different quality assurance schemes for nurseries around the country, all of which will be subsumed under a new national quality standard. From September, the schools' inspectorate, Ofsted, is to start inspecting nurseries.

Mr Blair also announced that £15m will be spent on helping nurseries expand the services they offer and said the government had beaten its target for this year of increasing the number of free places for three-year-olds. There were 108,000 available, against a projection of 83,000, he added.

A further £4m will help playgroups expand their services to provide full day care, he said.

Anne Longfield, of the charity Kids Club Network, praised the star rating scheme, saying quality was a crucial factor in childcare.

fields.headline: My Inspiration
fields.standfirst: Al Alvarez
fields.trailText: Al Alvarez
fields.body:
Al Alvarez is a poet, critic and author. His latest book, Poker: Bets, Bluffs and Bad Bets, has just been published.

"My family have lived in London since the 1770s, but being a Sephardic Jew with a Spanish name, I have never felt altogether English. My parents came from a comfortable middle-class background. I was an afterthought; my sisters are eight and 10 years older than me and I suspect I was a big source of irritation to them. I was born with a growth on my ankle that required major surgery. There were fears it might have been cancerous; fortunately it turned out to be benign. Even so, it was a defining point in my life. An early childhood trauma can either make you retreat inside yourself or come out fighting. I did the latter and sports became the most important thing in my life.

"My first school, Peterborough Lodge, no longer exists and I remember very little about it. After that I was sent to The Hall in Hampstead where I remained throughout the Blitz. At 13, I was sent to Oundle, which was then a strenuissimo sports school, where you couldn't survive unless you were good at games. I entered the school an over-protected Jewish intellectual, like Franz Kafka, and came out with a big, thick neck.

"I was extremely lucky to have a wonderful English teacher, Hugo Caudwell. I took my higher certificates in French, Spanish and English and got into Oxford a year later, where I got a first. Throughout my academic career, I was aware of an anti-semitic culture. It wasn't until I went to the US in the 1950s that I really felt at home. There all the intellectuals were either Jewish, or pretending to be."

fields.headline: On the web
fields.trailText: Optics | Teeth
fields.body:
Optics

The Magic Factory
www.magic-factory.co.uk/
Suitable for KS2/3 teachers

Five games that help to reinforce ideas about reflection, refraction and colours. All require the Shockwave plug-in. The games are not particularly exciting, and the last one (on refraction) is wrong, but the teachers' notes are handy.

Light and colour
www.at-bristol.org.uk/Optical/default.htm
Suitable for KS2/3/4 pupils & teachers

The Exploratorium page is a little off-syllabus, but contains a number of excellent optical illusions with brief explanations. A student could enjoy leafing through them, or a teacher could use them as a basis for a class discussion.

Patterns in Nature
http://acept.la.asu.edu
Suitable for teachers

The main parts of this US site are not particularly easy to use, nor are the diagrams clear. But the section on optics in nature contains a very good description of how rainbows form.

Fun Science Gallery
www.funsci.com/texts/index_en.htm
Suitable for teachers

An old-fashioned site that shows how to make basic optical instruments such as telescopes and even a camera obscura. Diagrams are delightful and simple. It has a certain charm, but perhaps not wide appeal. The information reaches a good depth, though, and the site also contains some useful experiments.

The Teachers' Lab
www.learner.org/teacherslab/science/light/
Suitable for teachers, KS4 pupils

An excellent US site, covering shadows from multiple sources, coloured shadows, spectra and parallax, using a mixture of text and animation. The puzzles are quite demanding - for example, working out where a player is on a pitch by looking at the strength and shape of his shadows.

Compiled by Ken Zetie

Teeth

Dentists
www.kan.org/michael/dentist/toothcare.htm
Suitable for KS2 teachers & pupils

Set up by Susana Chai, a dentist. See its large colour diagram of a tooth with all the parts clearly labelled. Terms such as enamel, dentin, root, gum and pulp are explained.

EncartaBR> http://encarta.msn.com/find/searchasp?search=teeth
Suitable for KS1/2 teachers & KS2 pupils

Select "teeth" to find plenty of information about types of human teeth. Tooth disorders are also covered. There are links to sites covering care of teeth.

Discovery
http://health.discovery.com/diseasesandcond/encyclopedia/2284.htm
Suitable for KS1/2 teachers

Under "Dental care of the child", select the image for a high-quality enlargement with all parts labelled. The text pages provide advice about dental care for children.

Colgate
www.colgate.com
Suitable for KS1/2 teachers & pupils

In "Oral Care" you can ask how to brush or floss. Many juniors would be able to read the replies; infants will appreciate the illustrations. To enter Kids' World, use the password "mask" for a tooth-brushing chart, healthy snacks and a tooth fairy.

Dental defence
www.dentistry.com
Suitable for KS1/2 pupils

Enter the game room and select "Don't Let This Happen To You" - a Space Invaders-type game where participants must shoot foods that are bad for teeth and allow apples to fall through.

Healthy Teeth
www.healthyteeth.org
Suitable for KS1/2 teachers & pupils

This Canadian site is strong on illustrations. Useful options include teeth and gums, cavities, braces, experiments and activities.

A test
www.icteachers/resources/resources_science.htm#Biology
Suitable for KS2 teachers

Print out Keep Healthy, a test paper to assess pupils on this topic.
