fields.headline: Out in the cold
fields.standfirst: Nathan has been excluded from school. When asked why, his father, Michael, says simply: 'The easy way to improve results is to remove the kids with special needs.' Naive? Defensive? Not according to the findings of a new study. Simon Hattenstone reports
fields.trailText: Nathan has been excluded from school. When asked why, his father, Michael, says simply: 'The easy way to improve results is to remove the kids with special needs.' Naive? Defensive? Not according to the findings of a new study. Simon Hattenstone reports
fields.body:
Nathan Hancock is just home from college, and he's feeling good about life. He's only 15 years old, at least a year younger than his fellow students, but he's thinking about getting a job, and making something of himself. If you'd met him last year, he would have told you a very different story.

It was 1998 when Nathan's comprehensive school said they no longer wanted him there. At first they didn't officially exclude him; they simply told him not to bother coming in any more. There had been a fight between two other boys, and somehow Nathan ended up being blamed for it although he always said he'd been in the room next door. There had been earlier incidents at the school involving Nathan, but nothing serious.

Nathan has attention deficit disorder. Michael, his father, says what this means is that he's somewhat hyper, a bit of a fidget, but not malicious, not a bad boy. Nothing the teacher shouldn't be able to cope with. But, as with so many children who have special educational needs or emotional and behavioural difficulties, the teachers couldn't cope. A new report from the Children's Society reveals that a hugely disproportionate number of the children excluded from school have special needs. While 3% of schoolchildren are classed as having severe special needs, 40% of the 80 pupils surveyed for the report, Outside, Looking In, had such needs. A further 15% were on the code of practice, meaning some degree of special needs had been acknowledged.

Often, pupils only get a statement of special needs after their exclusion, which means their learning difficulties have gone unrecognised at school. It can be a vicious circle. If children with learning difficulties are not being looked after, their behaviour is likely to deteriorate, and when they are excluded their learning difficulties almost invariably increase.

Nathan was one of 10,400 young people excluded in England in 1998/99. Although figures have fallen from a 95/96 peak of 12,500, they are still almost four times what they were at the beginning of the 90s. Only 14% of those children permanently excluded were reinstated. Some 69% of exclusions were because of actual or threatened aggressive behaviour. While many of the exclusions concerned children with learning difficulties, some excluded young people were at the opposite end of the spectrum - they were so bright that school bored them and they became a nuisance. The report also shows that black pupils are about six times more likely to be excluded than white pupils - Afro-Caribbean boys are up to eight times more likely to be excluded. This disturbing statistic has been well documented previously.

Like many excluded children, the school labelled Nathan a bully while he said that actually he was the victim of bullying - not just by his peers, but by teachers as well. "The teachers would call me an idiot and say you need drugs because you can't control your temper." He was prescribed Ritalin. "And when I did need help with my work, when I couldn't understand it, they'd just say 'Go and take some pills, Nathan'."

Nathan was bigger than most of the lads at his school - at 15, he's already over 6ft. His dad says all the men in his family are big and broad. And that may be part of the problem. Nathan looks like a toughie. It's hard to believe that a boy-man like him could be bullied. But then you hear him speak and it's all too feasible. He talks in a soft Cornwall burr, and sounds so vulnerable. His dad calls him a gentle giant.

"It starts to get to you, and it makes you feel degraded, like you're not wanted," says Nathan. "It's horrible. I got depressed sometimes and felt, what's the point in going on? I'm going to be one of those people sleeping on the streets. No school, no job, no nothing." You can hear the hurt, and the fear, in his voice.

In the three years he has been away from school, Nathan has received around three hours a week of education. The school is supposed to ensure that excluded children receive 25 hours a week of education while away. On average, they get just four. "It was nothing," says Michael Hancock. "We did everything, sent letters to David Blunkett, but still there was nothing."

Both Michael and Nathan feel the exclusion was unfair and could have been avoided. Chris Osborne, the Children Society's programme manager for Right To Education, couldn't agree more."The whole process of exclusion leaves children and parents isolated. It isn't achieving anything for anyone. We are dealing with some of the most marginalised people in society; the more they are left out the more it leads to problems for these children and society."

The Children's Society has set up its Genesis project to help reduce the number of exclusions. The project works directly with schools (four, so far), and takes a long-term holistic approach because most of the problems, whether they have their roots in behaviour or learning difficulties or family background, are long-term.

Keith Ajebo, headteacher of Deptford Green, says his school has benefited hugely from the project. His school is in an area that has seen exclusions on a shocking scale. At Oliver Goldsmiths, the primary school Damilola Taylor attended before he was murdered last year, there were a reported 150 exclusions after a new headteacher took over. By contrast, Ajebo says Deptford Green excludes one or two kids a year. "We can pick up more of the people at the edges."

Ajebo says the project has enabled him to unite the disparate agencies there to help troubled children - drugs counsellors, truancy workers etc. "There are now six or seven professionals at the school who are not teachers, and staff can refer kids directly to them. Say if a pupil's mum had died, or they were a little wild, or they'd been chucked out of home, there is always someone here who can deal with it."

Ajebo believes a head must ultimately have the power to exclude. "When a child's presence is damaging the education of others you have to take that decision," he says. In 1999 it was made easier for heads to permanently exclude pupils and harder for parents to appeal against the decision.

Yet the government insists that cutting the number of exclusions is a priority. Something doesn't quite add up. Carol Hayden, co-author of Outside, Looking In, says there are conflicting aims. On one hand the government and many parents judge a school purely on its results, on the other schools are being asked to integrate children with severe behavioural and educational difficulties. "Schools are really valued on their ability to normalise behaviour," says Hayden. So when faced with children with real difficulties, it is easier to dismiss them as naughty. "The government assumes a middle-class consen sus about measuring intelligence and rewarding achievement while wanting to be inclusive."

Is that impossible? "No, it's not impossible. But we need a wider range of opportunities on offer. Ironically, we had this in schools before the national curriculum. It used to be much more about teaching children than teaching subjects. Many teachers would say that the national curriculum is the biggest restriction in managing different types of learning."

Perhaps the biggest problem is the underlying philosophy of exclusion - to punish rather than rehabilitate. "Just look at the word exclusion. It's horrible. If you were a parent and heard your child is too awful to be with other children you'd be devastated."

Michael Hancock is one of the roughly 70% of parents in the report convinced that young people with special needs are more likely to be excluded because of the pressure for results. "Even though money is set aside for special needs, they don't want special needs in schools. It's too much hard work. If you have 100 children and 25 are special needs, and are not going to achieve anything, you've automatically got a 25% failure rate from the start. The easy way to improve results is to remove these children."

The government is well aware of this. Last year it ruled that excluded pupils' results had to be included in its performance tables - to discourage schools from cynical exclusions. But the schools kicked up such a fuss that the government has reversed its decision.

In 1999 Nathan Hancock was readmitted to his old school. Within two days he was excluded after he hit another child (he was provoked, he says). Then there was a flare-up with an ancillary worker, which led to a 15-day exclusion. Before long the head banished him for ever.

Michael Hancock says it was virtually impossible for his son to be reintegrated into the school. First, there was so much hostility towards him and, second, he was always aware that he wasn't wanted. Hancock feels he is partly to blame for the exclusion. "Our ignorance of the system allowed us to be pushed around. It took me four years to get hold of his school records, and they're still reported inaccurately. I also discovered he was supposed to have anger management from the school and never received it."

Nathan is still bewildered about his exclusion. "I didn't do anything excludable," he says categorically. "I really did want to be there. All my friends were there. It was quite fun, and sometimes I was learning stuff. They didn't want me there, so they just ditched me."

It was only when his father began to exercise his rights that the council came up with a solution for Nathan. They have provided the cash for him to attend college three days a week. Here he is learning about building and computers, and he loves it. He says he's treated with respect and feels transformed by the experience. "They say if you fail once don't worry, try again. You can't go wrong with that, can you? I've got a lot of confidence in myself. I'm definitely going to get a job now."

 Outside, Looking In: Children's and Families' Experience of School Exclusion by Carol Hayden and Simon Dunne is published by the Children's Society, price £14.95 (plus £1.50 p&p).

fields.headline: On the board
fields.standfirst: The diary of a parent governor
fields.trailText: The diary of a parent governor
fields.body:
Two letters arrive from the school. The first is a notice of our next (extraordinary) governors' meeting whose business is strictly limited to the election of a chair and vice-chair.

The second is notice that I, personally, am in arrears with dinner money for Lucy (by £27.40). Oops. This is somewhat embarrassing, since it was only at the last meeting that a new strategy for tackling dinner money arrears was a major item for discussion. I must be one of the first parents to receive the new-style letter reminding us that the school office can provide free school dinner forms if required, but also warning that the dinner service will be swiftly withdrawn if the debt is not cancelled within three school days. Oh well, I think. At least it shows the school is using the new doctrine of tough love.

We're always meaning to start making packed lunches for Lucy. They would be more nourishing than the high-carb diet of chips and beans plus pudding.

One of the governors, Marcia Jameson, is a dinner lady. When the subject of school dinners arose at one meeting, she observed that the kitchen always provides vegetables, but that none of the kids ever accepts a portion by choice. Then I remember that I survived, it seemed, my entire school career chiefly by eating double portions of dessert - rather than the spam fritters deep-fried in what tasted like motor oil.

The last time school dinners was discussed at a governors' meeting a month or so ago, the head, Mr Richardson, said that he was considering raising the daily fee from £1.20 to £1.50 in order to finance a revolution in food quality. You could practically hear us middle-class parent-governors licking our lips. But, like many forms of gratification, further discussion of the replacement of chips 'n' beans by pasta 'n' pesto was deferred to a future meeting.

In the meantime, I am grateful that - the resignation of our chair of governors apart - life is fairly quiet and routine at our school.

And so we gather on Friday to elect, without controversy, a new chair. In his absence, but with his grudging consent, Mr Rothman (the architect) is duly elected to serve as chair for the remainder of the school year.

Nem con, as they say.

fields.headline: Reality television?
fields.standfirst: Another TV drama set in a school. Will this one manage to avoid the cliches?  John Crace  talks to teachers watching Teachers
fields.trailText: Another TV drama set in a school. Will this one manage to avoid the cliches? John Crace talks to teachers watching Teachers
fields.body:
Sex, drugs, booze, breaking and entering, swearing and turning up late. And that's just the staff at the fictional urban Summerdown Comprehensive in Channel 4's new midweek drama series, Teachers. TV companies like a winning formula, and ever since This Life captured millions of viewers with its edgy, well written soap of twentysomething lawyers, there has been a rash of look-a-likes. Teachers is the latest offering, even down to casting Andrew Lincoln, Egg in This Life, in the leading role of Simon. From the opening, jerkily filmed, sequences of a bunch of good-looking men and women arsing around and getting pissed, the viewer knows exactly what is in store.

Another bunch of twenty and thirtysomethings are sitting around the TV in a south London living room. They are also teachers, but unlike the ones on the TV, these are the real McCoy. They are all either currently working in London secondary schools, or have had recent experience of teaching, and are here to watch the first two episodes of the Channel 4 series. After an hour or so of animated conversation, the room goes quiet. At first, I mistake the silence for focused concentration and it's only after a few minutes that I realise two of the teachers have dozed off.

Here's the first point of departure from reality. While the Summerdown teachers seem to think nothing of going out and getting trashed every night of the week, our real ones are in a state of semi-permanent knackeredness. "They don't appear to spend any time marking or preparing their lessons," says Paul Jenkins, a music teacher. "Where's all the paperwork and the endless meetings," adds Cherry Tolcher.

Midway through the first episode, everyone begins to lose count of the factual inaccuracies. Health and safety issues are ignored, a male teacher spends time alone with a girl pupil, smokes dope with another pupil and generally pays no attention to the national curriculum. Even the staff room scenes come in for criticism. "The gossip is generally much less animated and far more trivial," smiles Elena Mauro, "such as who hasn't washed up the coffee mugs. There weren't enough weirdos in the staff room."

But it's not the litany of on-screen errors that the teachers find most depressing. It is the dull stereotypes that really rile them. "It's cliche after cliche," says Jenkins. "The two main pupils are the fat boy who wants to learn and the tarty teenaged girl," sighs Katherine Hodgkinson. Tolcher points out that the two main teachers are the diametrically opposed groovy young man whom everyone adores and the rather straight-laced serious woman, who is a total bore. It's script-writing by numbers.

The shadow of Dead Poets' Society hangs less heavily over Teachers than many classroom dramas. There is the implication that it is the supposedly charismatic Simon who will turn out to be the "teacher who makes a difference" as he wanders around the classroom declaiming grandly, but this is steadily undermined - either accidentally or deliberately - by his persistent rubbishing of the only boy in his class with any academic interest.

Paul Jenkins has some sympathy with the Simon character. "When I first qualified I didn't work that hard, and it took me a little time to find my feet," he says. "But I was nowhere near as lazy, nor did I party that hard." Hodgkinson says that most newly qualified teachers are incredibly hard-working these days. "Teacher training isn't a doddle, so most new teachers know exactly what is expected of them from the off."

No one would argue that a TV drama should be a recruitment video for the Department of Education, but all the teachers raised serious concerns about how their profession would be perceived by the public. Mike Kinsman believes people have very ambivalent feelings about teachers. "When I tell someone what I do, the first reaction is often, 'What a marvellous job you do, I couldn't possibly do that'," he says. "But it's almost always followed up by a general statement to the effect that 'most teachers need to buck their ideas up a bit'. When I first saw the billboard poster '30 Kids and a Hangover' for the programme, my heart sank. I thought, 'Here we go. Undermined again'."

Cherry Tolcher wonders what the effect on parents might be. "If any parent, whose child had just been offered a place at secondary school, happened to see this and thought this was the way the teaching staff behaved, they might seriously consider taking him or her out of school."

Lord Puttnam knows more than most about the dangers of portraying teachers on screen. "At the last NASUWT conference I showed a variety of clips from my own films, such as SWALK, P'tang Yang Kipperbang and War of the Buttons," he says. "It was my apologia as I realised that I had been as guilty as anyone of portraying stereotypes. There are many spectacular teachers doing spectacular work, but they are rarely mentioned. Teaching dramas have yet to reach the level of complexity of many hospital TV programmes, such as Casualty."

Teachers is no exception, with a leaden script and Andrew Lincoln, who played a thoroughly unsympathetic jerk in This Life, simply repeating his performance. But perhaps there is one convergence between drama and real life. If all the fictional teachers were forced to sit down and watch the first two episodes of Teachers back to back, maybe they would nod off, too.

 The second episode of Teachers is on Wednesday, Channel 4, 10pm.

Please Sir, no more

Goodbye, Mr Chips, 1939/1969

Misty-eyed slush in which shy schoolmaster meets music hall star, gets married and has 283 children.

The teacher's verdict: "Museum piece. Good for a wet Sunday afternoon."

To Sir With Love, 1967

Sidney Poitier plays a West Indian teacher going to work in an East End school. Fluffier, sentimental 1960s remake of The Blackboard Jungle.

The teacher's verdict: "It tries to get to grips with the real issues of multi-culturalism."

Mind Your Language, 1977

Racist sitcom about a night school TEFL teacher who specialised in patronising or flirting with his students.

The teacher's verdict: "This is the programme that Teachers most reminded me of. Except Mind Your Language probably has greater depth."

Hearts and Minds, 1995

Jimmy McGovern's diatribe against disillusioned, burnt-out teachers. Set in a tough Liverpool comprehensive, new teacher quickly gets the idealism kicked out of him. Often literally.

The teacher's verdict: "Who would want to be a teacher after seeing this?"

Hope and Glory, 1999

Lenny Henry rides into town as the new superhead of a failing comp. Full of teachers trying to do the right thing. The teachers' favourite.

The teacher's verdict: "Gives the lie to the Woodheadian view of educational incompetence."
fields.bodyText: Sex, drugs, booze, breaking and entering, swearing and turning up late. And that's just the staff at the fictional urban Summerdown Comprehensive in Channel 4's new midweek drama series, Teachers. TV companies like a winning formula, and ever since This Life captured millions of viewers with its edgy, well written soap of twentysomething lawyers, there has been a rash of look-a-likes. Teachers is the latest offering, even down to casting Andrew Lincoln, Egg in This Life, in the leading role of Simon. From the opening, jerkily filmed, sequences of a bunch of good-looking men and women arsing around and getting pissed, the viewer knows exactly what is in store. Another bunch of twenty and thirtysomethings are sitting around the TV in a south London living room. They are also teachers, but unlike the ones on the TV, these are the real McCoy. They are all either currently working in London secondary schools, or have had recent experience of teaching, and are here to watch the first two episodes of the Channel 4 series. After an hour or so of animated conversation, the room goes quiet. At first, I mistake the silence for focused concentration and it's only after a few minutes that I realise two of the teachers have dozed off. Here's the first point of departure from reality. While the Summerdown teachers seem to think nothing of going out and getting trashed every night of the week, our real ones are in a state of semi-permanent knackeredness. "They don't appear to spend any time marking or preparing their lessons," says Paul Jenkins, a music teacher. "Where's all the paperwork and the endless meetings," adds Cherry Tolcher. Midway through the first episode, everyone begins to lose count of the factual inaccuracies. Health and safety issues are ignored, a male teacher spends time alone with a girl pupil, smokes dope with another pupil and generally pays no attention to the national curriculum. Even the staff room scenes come in for criticism. "The gossip is generally much less animated and far more trivial," smiles Elena Mauro, "such as who hasn't washed up the coffee mugs. There weren't enough weirdos in the staff room." But it's not the litany of on-screen errors that the teachers find most depressing. It is the dull stereotypes that really rile them. "It's cliche after cliche," says Jenkins. "The two main pupils are the fat boy who wants to learn and the tarty teenaged girl," sighs Katherine Hodgkinson. Tolcher points out that the two main teachers are the diametrically opposed groovy young man whom everyone adores and the rather straight-laced serious woman, who is a total bore. It's script-writing by numbers. The shadow of Dead Poets' Society hangs less heavily over Teachers than many classroom dramas. There is the implication that it is the supposedly charismatic Simon who will turn out to be the "teacher who makes a difference" as he wanders around the classroom declaiming grandly, but this is steadily undermined - either accidentally or deliberately - by his persistent rubbishing of the only boy in his class with any academic interest. Paul Jenkins has some sympathy with the Simon character. "When I first qualified I didn't work that hard, and it took me a little time to find my feet," he says. "But I was nowhere near as lazy, nor did I party that hard." Hodgkinson says that most newly qualified teachers are incredibly hard-working these days. "Teacher training isn't a doddle, so most new teachers know exactly what is expected of them from the off." No one would argue that a TV drama should be a recruitment video for the Department of Education, but all the teachers raised serious concerns about how their profession would be perceived by the public. Mike Kinsman believes people have very ambivalent feelings about teachers. "When I tell someone what I do, the first reaction is often, 'What a marvellous job you do, I couldn't possibly do that'," he says. "But it's almost always followed up by a general statement to the effect that 'most teachers need to buck their ideas up a bit'. When I first saw the billboard poster '30 Kids and a Hangover' for the programme, my heart sank. I thought, 'Here we go. Undermined again'." Cherry Tolcher wonders what the effect on parents might be. "If any parent, whose child had just been offered a place at secondary school, happened to see this and thought this was the way the teaching staff behaved, they might seriously consider taking him or her out of school." Lord Puttnam knows more than most about the dangers of portraying teachers on screen. "At the last NASUWT conference I showed a variety of clips from my own films, such as SWALK, P'tang Yang Kipperbang and War of the Buttons," he says. "It was my apologia as I realised that I had been as guilty as anyone of portraying stereotypes. There are many spectacular teachers doing spectacular work, but they are rarely mentioned. Teaching dramas have yet to reach the level of complexity of many hospital TV programmes, such as Casualty." Teachers is no exception, with a leaden script and Andrew Lincoln, who played a thoroughly unsympathetic jerk in This Life, simply repeating his performance. But perhaps there is one convergence between drama and real life. If all the fictional teachers were forced to sit down and watch the first two episodes of Teachers back to back, maybe they would nod off, too.  The second episode of Teachers is on Wednesday, Channel 4, 10pm. Please Sir, no more Goodbye, Mr Chips, 1939/1969 Misty-eyed slush in which shy schoolmaster meets music hall star, gets married and has 283 children. The teacher's verdict: "Museum piece. Good for a wet Sunday afternoon." To Sir With Love, 1967 Sidney Poitier plays a West Indian teacher going to work in an East End school. Fluffier, sentimental 1960s remake of The Blackboard Jungle. The teacher's verdict: "It tries to get to grips with the real issues of multi-culturalism." The teacher's verdict: "This is the programme that Teachers most reminded me of. Except Mind Your Language probably has greater depth." Full of teachers trying to do the right thing. The teachers' favourite. The teacher's verdict: "Gives the lie to the Woodheadian view of educational incompetence."

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: My sister has bi-polar disorder (manic depression) and she is 13. She is worried about missing lots of school. My sister really needs private tuition but we don't know where to turn to inquire about it. I have asked my LEA but they said they don't do that. Is it possible?
fields.trailText: My sister has bi-polar disorder (manic depression) and she is 13. She is worried about missing lots of school. My sister really needs private tuition but we don't know where to turn to inquire about it. I have asked my LEA but they said they don't do that. Is it possible?
fields.body:
Clive Westwood, director of the Manic Depression Fellowship Wales

It is now generally accepted that adolescents can develop bi-polar disorder. Surveys show that some 10% of youngsters aged 13-19 have some form of depressive disorder. This may not be a comfort, but it does help to reduce the isolation felt by those involved.

My first message is one of hope. Many people with this condition live successful and fulfilling lives. Hundreds of people are benefiting from a self-management training programme developed by the Manic Depression Fellowship. This programme is designed to give participants a comprehensive understanding of the concepts and techniques involved in learning to manage mood swings. Knowledge is power and the better understanding your parents and your sister have of the condition, the more you will feel in control of the situation.

Second, ascertain how much awareness the school staff and students have of mental health issues. Armed with information, readily available from charities such as MDF, you will be able to explain the nature of the illness. Work as a team - child, family, school and health professionals - to create an accepting environment where adjustments to work and routine can be made to accommodate your sister's condition.

Third, for your parents: it is not their fault. They should not feel guilty. Your sister should meet others who have had the same experiences and learn at first hand how to deal with her feelings.

 Manic Depression Fellowship head office: Castle Works, 21 St George's Rd, London SE1 6ES, tel: 020-7793 2600.

 Manic Depression Fellowship Wales: 01633 244244.

Helen Kay, manager of the Bright Futures programme at the Mental Health Foundation

We promote mental health help for all children in schools and are advising the DfEE. The most important thing is for young people to be able to get help when they need it; we've interviewed young people who have found it difficult to access services when they had a crisis. One problem is that there isn't anything specifically for children. There's helpline in Manchester for young men that has been very successful and we would like to see many more helplines for young people. For worried parents, we recommend the Young Minds helpline, 0800 -018 2138. We have just obtained funding to employ four advocacy workers who will be developing new ways of helping young people access services; youngsters themselves will have a big part in the way this support is designed. Many said they wanted services that were less "bow-tie" and more youth worker.

The most successful help comes from workers who have time to listen.

 Mental Health Foundation: 020-7535 7400.

Mark Casserley, National Association for the Education of Sick Children

If a child is off school for a medical reason or because of exclusion, the LEA has legal requirements under section 19 of the Education Act 1996. This says that "each local education authority shall make arrangements for the provision of suitable education at school or otherwise than at school for those children of compulsory school age who by reason of illness, exclusion from school or otherwise may not for any period receive suitable education unless such arrangements are made for them".

Guidance has been issued in the form of a circular, number 12/94 - it's currently being revised, the consultation has been completed and the DfEE is considering the responses. The new version should be out in the summer, but in the meantime the current version stands. It recommends that for absences of up to four weeks, parents and school should be responsible for helping pupils keep up with work, though allowances are made for the likelihood of repeated time off due to illness. When it comes to the LEA's responsibility, normally this kind of help is run as a subsection of the local special needs department. If there's a big referral unit in the local hospital, there'll be a lot of hospital teaching going on, if there's no children's hospital ward locally there will be more home tuition. The NAESC keeps a directory of provision of this service.

 NAESC helpline: 0800 027 8525.

Coming next:

My youngest son has a September birthday. He is a very bright child and my concern is that he will be the oldest in a class of 30 children and will, therefore, be very bored. We can't afford private education. Is there anything I can do?

Do you have a problem with your child's education? Each week we ask leading experts to advise on a specific issue. Please send in your "problem" marked "If you ask me" to Guardian Education, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax them to 020-7239 9933 or email to education.letters@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Class notes
fields.trailText: Chief inspector of schools Mike Tomlinson gave a controlled if unexciting performance at his debut in front of the education select committee last week. But afterwards he revealed privately that his biggest fear was the prospect of his predecessor Chris Woodhead - now a scribbler for the Daily Telegraph - slipping into the room, notebook in hand.
fields.body:
Chief inspector of schools Mike Tomlinson gave a controlled if unexciting performance at his debut in front of the education select committee last week. But afterwards he revealed privately that his biggest fear was the prospect of his predecessor Chris Woodhead - now a scribbler for the Daily Telegraph - slipping into the room, notebook in hand.

But having breathed a big sigh of relief, the new chief inspector was suddenly pounced upon by a teacher and pupil from Summerhill, the unconventional independent school. Almost exactly a year to the day since the famous Suffolk site had the threat of closure dramatically lifted in high court settlement, the Summerhill Two travelled all the way to London to tackle Mr Tomlinson first hand about their treatment at the hands of Ofsted. A sweatshirt said it all: "Summerhill - probably the most inspected school in the world". Mr Tomlinson assured them on their specific concern that pupils were free to speak to inspectors during the inspection itself. So they know for next time then.

Eruptions in the exam world. The Scottish Qualifications Authority is behind schedule in preparing for dealing with this year's exams, and given that 17,000 pupils were last year sent results late, incomplete or just plain wrong, that's more than a worry. And exam board Edexcel has admitted more than 10,000 pupils were given the wrong results in new Key Skills tests in January because of a computer error. Some 3,705 who were told they passed the information technology test should have been failed, and 6,466 who were told they failed the communications and application of number tests should have passed. The chaos was caused by an examiner pressing the wrong button.

And the award for quote of last or any other week goes to Emma Darcy, who during a poetry class at Morpeth Secondary School in Bethnal Green, east London, found herself sitting next to the Queen, resplendent on a plastic chair. And Andrew Motion, the poet laureate, was sitting behind her. As Emma said: "It's not every day we get the Queen and the Poet Laureate in our class."

fields.headline: Every second counts
fields.standfirst: Last week, David Blunkett offered an independent review of teachers' workloads. So, what does a teacher do all day?  Matthew Keating finds out
fields.trailText: Last week, David Blunkett offered an independent review of teachers' workloads. So, what does a teacher do all day? Matthew Keating finds out.
fields.body:
Christopher Grey, 30, teaches year 1 (five- to six-year-olds) at Malorees Infant School in North London. He is also ICT co-ordinator for the school. Matthew Keating observed his every move last Thursday. It was, Christopher assures us, a typical day.

6.00am: Wakes. Straight to the kitchen to pour two tablespoons of coffee into a double size mug and spark up a Marlboro Light.

7.00am: Arrives at school.

7.02am: Tunes classroom radio to Kiss FM. The next two hours will be spent preparing lessons and trying to sort out the school computers.

7.07am: Logs on to the BBC website. Prints off worksheets for literacy hour.

7.12am: Discovers that the computer network isn't working properly.

7.15am: Sorts out classroom. "We're trying to teach them to clear up after themselves, but haven't got there yet."

7.28am: Makes a cup of coffee.

7.34am: Cuts A1 paper into halves with an old cutlery knife for children to draw on for the "how things grow" lesson.

7.50am: Lay outs the children's language exercise books.

7.55am: Talks to the head, Sin Davies. about sorting out the new computers, which are are still unpacked on the stage in the assembly hall.

7.58am: Fetches reading books from the library.

8.00am: Alters the weekly planning sheets which outline teaching objectives, group tasks etc. Does these a week ahead but usually ends up changing them: "Because I keep on thinking of better ways of teaching."

8.07am: School has bought some new computers. There is no computer suite, so Christopher starts to free up a computer trolley by putting the old ones on a table outside Red Class.

8.16am: Starts to type a letter to the suppliers of the network saying the governors want to review the contract, but keyboard doesn't work. Switches keyboards.

8.25am: Prints off letter to fax. "Our network bill was due in September. It's been four months since we asked them to send it. Now I have to fax, email and phone them every day."

8.27am: Discovers that school email isn't working properly.

8.35am: Moves to a different computer in the classroom to access email. "We've been having problems since installing new software last Friday."

8.46am: Telephones supplier. The man who deals with the school network is not in. "Last week I received a newsletter from them telling me how wonderful they were with a complimentary lollipop." Leaves a message for him to telephone back.

8.49am: Fills in certificates that will be presented to pupils at assembly.

8.55am: School bell sounds and the children start to pour in.

8.58am: Has a brief chat with Susan's mum.

8.59am: Most of the children are sitting on the carpet for registration. "Morning Mr Grey!"

9.00am: "Class, can I see three fingers. How about, four. How many fingers do we have? Good."

9.01am: Register. "Good morning Lucy." "Good morning Mr Grey." "How are you this morning?" "Er, very well." A child talks. "Antonia, would you like to take the register?"

9.05am: Yellow class is split into two for the literacy hour. Through fund-raising, Malorees has paid for another teacher to take one half.

9.06am: Each child is given either a white or pink page with a letter on and asks them to sound it aloud. "Ah, ah, ah, ah." "Buh, buh, buh, buh." Within a few seconds the class sound like mini Buddhist monks doing their daily incantations.

9.07am: "Everyone stop!" The children are paired off, white paper with pink. "Can anyone tell me what is special about the letters on the pink paper?" Hands shoot up. "Correct Susan, they're vowels. And the letters on the white paper?" "Consonants!" "Hand up first please."

9.10am: With their letters, the pairs take turns to hang them on the classroom's literacy washing line next to the letters "CK", to spell a word. Rack. Lock. Luck. Duck. Kick. "That's a word we had yesterday." Mock. C_ Nip in and swap Tim and Alexis's letters to prevent a Countdown mistake.

9.18am: Go through sentences prepared earlier containing works with CK at the end. "Read along with me."

9.23am: "I would now like you to make up your own five sentences." The class splits into their named groups - vans, rockets, giraffes, elephants, go-karts and dragonflies. Some do the sentences while others work on clock and spell worksheets. Moves about the classroom to work with the different groups.

9.30am: Tracy asks to go to the toilet. "Go straight there."

9.33am: "Can we quiet down please."

9.40am: John jumps up with a grin and heads for the toilets.

9.41am: Tries to get Steve to work by himself. "He's very bright but has behavioural problems so I have to devote a lot of time to him. I also have seven others with learning difficulties."

9.48am: Reads a story with one group on the carpet.

9.54am: "Everyone freeze, please. Everyone, hands on head and listen. I'm going to come around and look at the work you're doing."

9.56am: Two of the girls have mixed up their exercise books and written in each other's. Sorts out the muddle.

10.02am: "Can you all put your names on top of your work?"

10.03am: The rest of the class return from their literacy hour.

10.04am: A hive of activity, general murmur of little voices and tidying up.

10.06am: All the children are now sitting on the carpet. "Can anyone tell me a two-digit number." Hands up, the numeracy lesson starts.

10.14am: John asks if he can go to the water fountain.

10.23am: Comforts John, who is crying. Christopher is concerned: "He's been very tearful, recently."

10.29am: School bell sounds. "I'm a bit disappointed in Yellow Class. Being a bit noisy, not working hard. Let's start afresh after playtime."

10.30am: Class lines up and walks into assembly as Pastoral by Ernesto Bitetti plays on the music system.

10.42am: Sin Davies tells the school about the art project they are doing with artist Duncan Hoosan that will be ready after Easter.

10.45am: Playtime bell sounds. The children line up to get their coats.

10.50am: Nips to the toilet before tidying up the classroom.

11.07am: Yellow Class explore how things grow. Cross-legged on the carpet, Christopher explains with aid of a large picture book how to grow sunflowers. "You put the seed in the soil. What does the seed need?" "Er, water?" "Who has heard of nutrients?" Blank faces. "It is like food and the seed gets it from the soil."

11.25am: Armed with pencils, crayons and recycled paper, Yellow Class go forth and draw how sunflowers grow. "I wonder if I can give a star to everyone working quietly?"

11.29am: Reads with John, who is crying again.

11.34am: Works with all the groups while trying to fill in pupil assessment forms.

11.38am: "Can you label your pictures? The sun, the seedling, the tree."

11.40am: John goes up to the big book to see how to spell sunflower. Jay comes over to help him pointing to the word. "That's sunflower." "Thank you for assisting John, Jay."

11.45am: Tries to fill in assessment sheets again.

11.46am: "Freeze! Everyone put their names on top of their work and then sit on the carpet."

11.48am: "I've got stars for Omar's table who were working quietly." The four proud recipients stick them next to their name on the star chart.

11.52am: Plays I spy to settle the children. Tries to fill out assessment forms while supervising the game.

12.00noon: Lunch bell sounds.

12.04pm: Speaks to the nurse about one of the children.

12.11pm: Leaves the school premises for a three-cigarette break. "My main gripe is the new government initiative overload. Until recently I felt like I was constantly running and never satisfied with what I achieved."

12.30pm: Back to the staff room to make coffee.

12.31pm: Returns to the classroom to prepare the afternoon lesson.Tries telephoning the network supplier again. No joy.

1.00pm: Starts preparations for Art Week, cutting paper with the guillotine. "On Monday my class is working with Duncan Hoosan making clay tiles to jazz up the playground."

1.10pm: Puts out each child's handwriting book.

1.15pm: Speaks to Tony, the school handyman about liberating more trolleys for the new computers.

1.17pm: Loads the necessary programme on the class computer for this afternoon's mapping skills lesson.

1.25pm: Children return from lunch.

1.26pm: Begins afternoon register. "Good afternoon Tilly." "Good afternoon Mr Grey."

1.27pm: John is subdued. Samuel's hair is drenched in sweat. "You'll cool down if you take your jumper off."

1.31pm: Has to calm down Gabriel, who has come back from the playground cross.

1.35pm: "Fingers on lips to remind ourselves to be quiet." Starts the 15-minute handwriting lesson with joined-up Cs.

1.45pm: "Close your books. Leave them in the centre of the table. I'm going to look at them later."

1.46pm: Yellow Class return to sitting on the carpet. Reminds them of Duncan Hoosan's visit next week and explains, with the aid of pen and white board, that he wants them to draw a big face on paper. "With Duncan we are going to make faces in clay, which will be fired in a big oven called a kiln." "Think about the outline, the way your hair covers your ears."

1.58pm: Sin comes into the class to supervise so Christopher can talk to Tony about the new computers.

2.05pm: Collects handwriting books while the children work on their drawings.

2.07pm: "Can you all come to the carpet. Does anyone know why we've come to the carpet? Because we are being very noisy!"

2.10pm: "Duncan also wants you to think of some words to write which you associate with what you like at school." Hands go skyward. "Drawing." "Writing stories."

2.20pm: Has a quiet word with David and Tim about paying attention.

2.21pm: Thud. Francis falls off his chair. "This is what happens when you don't sit properly."

2.25pm: Moves around the class helping them with their drawings.

2.35pm: Helen has already finished and sits on the carpet reading a book from book corner below Enormous Watermelons mural.

2.38pm: "Can we all collect the pencils, put away our work and stand behind our chairs."

2.45pm: Bell for afternoon break. Yellow Class is held back for five minutes for misbehaving.

3.00pm: Cigarette break. Just one.

3.01pm: Children return for final half an hour for story reading and computer mapping skills.

3.25pm: Bell sounds for the end of school. Once the children leave, Christopher starts to tidy up.

3.45pm: Discusses ICT budget with Sin, and what to do with the old printers.

3.55pm: Returns to classroom to do assessment and planning sheets. "I can't work out why planning takes so much more time these days."

4.00pm: More lesson preparation. Sorts out lesson material for a supply teacher who is covering his class while Christopher is away on NOF training tomorrow. "We work long hours but if you did less when would you get to do the job? What would be helpful would be a half-day devoted to the paperwork and preparation."

5.30pm: Christopher finally leaves for home. He never did manage to speak to the man from the computer network supplier.

The names of the children in Yellow Class have been changed.
fields.bodyText: Christopher Grey, 30, teaches year 1 (five- to six-year-olds) at Malorees Infant School in North London. He is also ICT co-ordinator for the school. Matthew Keating observed his every move last Thursday. It was, Christopher assures us, a typical day. 6.00am: Wakes. Straight to the kitchen to pour two tablespoons of coffee into a double size mug and spark up a Marlboro Light. 7.00am: Arrives at school. 7.02am: Tunes classroom radio to Kiss FM. The next two hours will be spent preparing lessons and trying to sort out the school computers. 7.07am: Logs on to the BBC website. Prints off worksheets for literacy hour. 7.12am: Discovers that the computer network isn't working properly. 7.15am: Sorts out classroom. "We're trying to teach them to clear up after themselves, but haven't got there yet." 7.28am: Makes a cup of coffee. 7.34am: Cuts A1 paper into halves with an old cutlery knife for children to draw on for the "how things grow" lesson. 7.50am: Lay outs the children's language exercise books. 7.55am: Talks to the head, Sin Davies. about sorting out the new computers, which are are still unpacked on the stage in the assembly hall. 7.58am: Fetches reading books from the library. 8.00am: Alters the weekly planning sheets which outline teaching objectives, group tasks etc. Does these a week ahead but usually ends up changing them: "Because I keep on thinking of better ways of teaching." 8.07am: School has bought some new computers. There is no computer suite, so Christopher starts to free up a computer trolley by putting the old ones on a table outside Red Class. 8.16am: Starts to type a letter to the suppliers of the network saying the governors want to review the contract, but keyboard doesn't work. Switches keyboards. 8.25am: Prints off letter to fax. "Our network bill was due in September. It's been four months since we asked them to send it. Now I have to fax, email and phone them every day." 8.27am: Discovers that school email isn't working properly. 8.35am: Moves to a different computer in the classroom to access email. "We've been having problems since installing new software last Friday." 8.46am: Telephones supplier. The man who deals with the school network is not in. "Last week I received a newsletter from them telling me how wonderful they were with a complimentary lollipop." Leaves a message for him to telephone back. 8.49am: Fills in certificates that will be presented to pupils at assembly. 8.55am: School bell sounds and the children start to pour in. 8.58am: Has a brief chat with Susan's mum. 8.59am: Most of the children are sitting on the carpet for registration. "Morning Mr Grey!" 9.00am: "Class, can I see three fingers. How about, four. How many fingers do we have? Good." 9.01am: Register. "Good morning Lucy." "Good morning Mr Grey." "How are you this morning?" "Er, very well." A child talks. "Antonia, would you like to take the register?" 9.05am: Yellow class is split into two for the literacy hour. Through fund-raising, Malorees has paid for another teacher to take one half. 9.06am: Each child is given either a white or pink page with a letter on and asks them to sound it aloud. "Ah, ah, ah, ah." "Buh, buh, buh, buh." Within a few seconds the class sound like mini Buddhist monks doing their daily incantations. 9.07am: "Everyone stop!" The children are paired off, white paper with pink. "Can anyone tell me what is special about the letters on the pink paper?" Hands shoot up. "Correct Susan, they're vowels. And the letters on the white paper?" "Consonants!" "Hand up first please." 9.10am: With their letters, the pairs take turns to hang them on the classroom's literacy washing line next to the letters "CK", to spell a word. Rack. Lock. Luck. Duck. Kick. "That's a word we had yesterday." Mock. C_ Nip in and swap Tim and Alexis's letters to prevent a Countdown mistake. 9.18am: Go through sentences prepared earlier containing works with CK at the end. "Read along with me." 9.23am: "I would now like you to make up your own five sentences." The class splits into their named groups - vans, rockets, giraffes, elephants, go-karts and dragonflies. Some do the sentences while others work on clock and spell worksheets. Moves about the classroom to work with the different groups. 9.30am: Tracy asks to go to the toilet. "Go straight there." 9.33am: "Can we quiet down please." 9.40am: John jumps up with a grin and heads for the toilets. 9.41am: Tries to get Steve to work by himself. "He's very bright but has behavioural problems so I have to devote a lot of time to him. I also have seven others with learning difficulties." 9.48am: Reads a story with one group on the carpet. 9.54am: "Everyone freeze, please. Everyone, hands on head and listen. I'm going to come around and look at the work you're doing." 9.56am: Two of the girls have mixed up their exercise books and written in each other's. Sorts out the muddle. 10.02am: "Can you all put your names on top of your work?" 10.03am: The rest of the class return from their literacy hour. 10.04am: A hive of activity, general murmur of little voices and tidying up. 10.06am: All the children are now sitting on the carpet. "Can anyone tell me a two-digit number." Hands up, the numeracy lesson starts. 10.14am: John asks if he can go to the water fountain. 10.23am: Comforts John, who is crying. Christopher is concerned: "He's been very tearful, recently." 10.29am: School bell sounds. "I'm a bit disappointed in Yellow Class. Being a bit noisy, not working hard. Let's start afresh after playtime." 10.30am: Class lines up and walks into assembly as Pastoral by Ernesto Bitetti plays on the music system. 10.42am: Sin Davies tells the school about the art project they are doing with artist Duncan Hoosan that will be ready after Easter. 10.45am: Playtime bell sounds. The children line up to get their coats. 10.50am: Nips to the toilet before tidying up the classroom. 11.07am: Yellow Class explore how things grow. Cross-legged on the carpet, Christopher explains with aid of a large picture book how to grow sunflowers. "You put the seed in the soil. What does the seed need?" "Er, water?" "Who has heard of nutrients?" Blank faces. "It is like food and the seed gets it from the soil." 11.25am: Armed with pencils, crayons and recycled paper, Yellow Class go forth and draw how sunflowers grow. "I wonder if I can give a star to everyone working quietly?" 11.29am: Reads with John, who is crying again. 11.34am: Works with all the groups while trying to fill in pupil assessment forms. 11.38am: "Can you label your pictures? The sun, the seedling, the tree." 11.40am: John goes up to the big book to see how to spell sunflower. Jay comes over to help him pointing to the word. "That's sunflower." "Thank you for assisting John, Jay." 11.45am: Tries to fill in assessment sheets again. 11.46am: "Freeze! Everyone put their names on top of their work and then sit on the carpet." 11.48am: "I've got stars for Omar's table who were working quietly." The four proud recipients stick them next to their name on the star chart. 11.52am: Plays I spy to settle the children. Tries to fill out assessment forms while supervising the game. 12.00noon: Lunch bell sounds. 12.04pm: Speaks to the nurse about one of the children. 12.11pm: Leaves the school premises for a three-cigarette break. "My main gripe is the new government initiative overload. Until recently I felt like I was constantly running and never satisfied with what I achieved." 12.30pm: Back to the staff room to make coffee. 12.31pm: Returns to the classroom to prepare the afternoon lesson.Tries telephoning the network supplier again. No joy. 1.00pm: Starts preparations for Art Week, cutting paper with the guillotine. "On Monday my class is working with Duncan Hoosan making clay tiles to jazz up the playground." 1.10pm: Puts out each child's handwriting book. 1.15pm: Speaks to Tony, the school handyman about liberating more trolleys for the new computers. 1.17pm: Loads the necessary programme on the class computer for this afternoon's mapping skills lesson. 1.25pm: Children return from lunch. 1.26pm: Begins afternoon register. "Good afternoon Tilly." "Good afternoon Mr Grey." 1.27pm: John is subdued. Samuel's hair is drenched in sweat. "You'll cool down if you take your jumper off." 1.31pm: Has to calm down Gabriel, who has come back from the playground cross. 1.35pm: "Fingers on lips to remind ourselves to be quiet." Starts the 15-minute handwriting lesson with joined-up Cs. 1.45pm: "Close your books. Leave them in the centre of the table. I'm going to look at them later." 1.46pm: Yellow Class return to sitting on the carpet. Reminds them of Duncan Hoosan's visit next week and explains, with the aid of pen and white board, that he wants them to draw a big face on paper. "With Duncan we are going to make faces in clay, which will be fired in a big oven called a kiln." "Think about the outline, the way your hair covers your ears." 1.58pm: Sin comes into the class to supervise so Christopher can talk to Tony about the new computers. 2.05pm: Collects handwriting books while the children work on their drawings. 2.07pm: "Can you all come to the carpet. Does anyone know why we've come to the carpet? Because we are being very noisy!" 2.10pm: "Duncan also wants you to think of some words to write which you associate with what you like at school." Hands go skyward. "Drawing." "Writing stories." 2.20pm: Has a quiet word with David and Tim about paying attention. 2.21pm: Thud. Francis falls off his chair. "This is what happens when you don't sit properly." 2.25pm: Moves around the class helping them with their drawings. 2.35pm: Helen has already finished and sits on the carpet reading a book from book corner below Enormous Watermelons mural. 2.38pm: "Can we all collect the pencils, put away our work and stand behind our chairs." 2.45pm: Bell for afternoon break. Yellow Class is held back for five minutes for misbehaving. 3.00pm: Cigarette break. Just one. 3.01pm: Children return for final half an hour for story reading and computer mapping skills. 3.25pm: Bell sounds for the end of school. Once the children leave, Christopher starts to tidy up. 3.45pm: Discusses ICT budget with Sin, and what to do with the old printers. 3.55pm: Returns to classroom to do assessment and planning sheets. "I can't work out why planning takes so much more time these days." 4.00pm: More lesson preparation. Sorts out lesson material for a supply teacher who is covering his class while Christopher is away on NOF training tomorrow. "We work long hours but if you did less when would you get to do the job? What would be helpful would be a half-day devoted to the paperwork and preparation." 5.30pm: Christopher finally leaves for home. He never did manage to speak to the man from the computer network supplier. The names of the children in Yellow Class have been changed.

fields.headline: Computer Sound Morpher
fields.standfirst: Win a copy for your school
fields.trailText: Computer Sound Morpher
fields.body:
Intel Play Computer Sound Morpher
(Tag Learning, tel: 01474 537886, www.taglearning.com)

Price: £52.82 inc VAT

Age/ability range: KS1-4

The manufacturer says: "Create anything you want to hear! This is a high quality mobile sound recording and editing device for Windows computers."

Carolyn Bryan, technology coordinator, Springdale Junior School, Wolverhampton, says: "It's great fun - very colourful and sci-fi and made of see-through plastic. I spent about two hours getting to grips with it, but the kids took just 10 minutes! It's just right for 9- and 10-year-olds and also suits teenagers. We used it in a general activity lesson, but it would be great for looking at soundwaves in science and ideal for IT multimedia work. It ca n be used as a hand-held device, with four minutes' recording time available. We mainly downloaded sounds from the computer to morph. It could also be used for speech therapy with 7- and 8-year-olds. Although the instructions were a bit limited and lesson plans would have been helpful, this is a real novelty and very good value for money."

Curriculum links:

ICT: Primary unit 3B: manipulating sound; 3E: email; secondary unit 1: using ICT

Science: Primary unit 1F; secondary unit 8L: sound and hearing

Literacy: Creative writing and editing

fields.headline: Brave new era
fields.standfirst: The brave, new learning and skills era starts next week, says John Harwood
fields.trailText: The brave, new learning and skills era starts next week, says John Harwood
fields.body:
There was a time when most people left school at 15 or 16. If they continued learning it was in the university of life, or for those less fortunate, the school of hard knocks.

The problem we face today is that for too many families and communities this is still the norm. We cannot go on like this any longer. If we want to build a vibrant, successful modern economy for the 21st century we have to change our approach and crucially, attitude to learning.

The rest of the world has moved on. I have a chart on the wall above my desk. It shows the numbers of 17-year-olds who are engaged in learning or training in each of the industrialised nations of the world. We are doing better than Greece, Mexico and Turkey. Full stop.

For the last 20 to 30 years we have expanded provision and assumed that this was all we had to do to change people's expectations. We have seen a drastic increase in numbers staying on in education and training and very many people have worked hard to make this happen. But we have not really seen a dramatic change in our culture. Attitudes to learning and re-skilling in many parts of the country remain rooted in the past.

Hence the Learning and Skills Council. This new public body begins operation on 2 April. It will organise and fund all post-16 education in England - that includes further education colleges; school sixth forms; work-based training for young people; workforce development; adult and community learning; information, advice and guidance for adults; and education-business links. Basically, all adult education apart from that provided by the universities.

The Learning and Skills Council will manage the biggest ever investment in post-16 training and education, £5.5bn for the coming year, a 9% increase on what was previously made available.

But money is not the only issue. The Learning and Skills Council will help people from all walks of life find the kind of learning that is right for them, whether it is in IT, arts and crafts, retail, music or a variety of vocational subjects. It will also make sure that what is on offer is developed to meet their changing needs. Most importantly of all we will conduct a crusade to drive up standards by challenging and helping poor and coasting providers. We must all make the pledge that only the best will be good enough for our young people.

Importantly, the council will work with and through a wide range of other organisations, from the employment service and the trade unions to the Federation of Small Businesses. It is a national organisation with 47 local branches spread throughout England. Local learning and skills councils will work alongside local employers and training-related bodies. This is the best way to ensure that courses are structured to reflect the precise needs of any given community.

The Learning and Skills Council will be working to make sure those currently left behind by the system are included. It is a national disgrace that almost one in five people do not have the reading skills to find a plumber in the Yellow Pages. Widening and deepening participation will play a crucial role in helping communities develop the skills they need for regeneration and sustainable futures.

The success of the Learning and Skills Council will affect the success of the entire country. If a single course can improve the potential of one person, then thousands can improve the potential of the country. There are too many jobs currently available in the UK that cannot be filled for lack of skills. With hard work, proper co-ordination and the initiative of communities themselves, we can attack it with real purpose and make a real difference to the life chances of individuals and the future prosperity of our country.

 John Harwood is chief executive of the Learning and Skills Council.

webTitle: So you want to learn... language teaching

fields.headline: So you want to learn... language teaching
fields.standfirst: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.trailText: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.body:
Excuse me! En français, s'il vous plaît.

Quite. Can you direct me to registration, please? Dites-le-moi en français.

I just need the registration desk. Je n'ai pas compris. Repetez-le-moi en français.

Just tell me where it is! Bien sur. Mais posez la question en français.

Look, mate, I'm in a hurry! Je suis desolé mais...

Just tell me! Eeurgh! You're throttling me.

Ah! You do speak English. Of course I do.

So, why all the poncing about in French? I'm a languages teacher.

Just the chap I want. How did you get the job? Don't tell me you're looking for work?

Actually, I am. Well you need to speak a language first.

And then what? Well, you've got to pick a level. Do you want a bunch of lumpen 15-year-olds sniggering every time you say "oui, oui". Or the mature, respectful environment of the adult education evening class?

The latter! As a teacher for any age group you need to be patient, responsible and fair. Ideally, you should also have extensive knowledge of your subject.

Go on. It can be challenging work so you need bags of energy, a reasonable sense of humour and a bit of flair. Above all you need imagination.

You can't start making up words. No. Imagination with which to captivate and inspire your audience. You should expect to prepare your lessons and set and mark work. That's the case for whichever age group you teach. And you'll be expected to deal with a range of behaviour and possibly become involved with extra-curricular sport and social activities if you teach in a school. Aside from your normal working hours, you will also have to attend meetings and work out lesson plans.

What about entry requirements? It used to be qualified teacher status for schools and nothing for further education.

Just your genius. Quite. But that's all changing. From September, anyone wanting to come into further education teaching will also need a teaching qualification.

From where? I'm coming to that. It's complicated and it's still being worked out. Awarding bodies, such as Edexel and City & Guilds, are revising their further education teaching qualifications to satisfy Fento standards.

Fento? Sounds like a revolting fizzy drink. It's the Further Education National Training Organisation. Universities that offer further education teacher training are similarly revising their courses.

Sounds complicated. You said it. There'll be three basic packages depending on whether you want to teach full-time, part-time or as an occasional visitor.

Further Education National Training Organisation, 4th floor, 1-6 Ely Place, London, EC1N 6RY

Telephone: 020-7242 4662

Website:www.fento.org

Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (UCAS), Rosehill, New Barn Lane, Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, GL52 3LZ

Telephone: 01242-222444

Website: www.ucas.ac.uk

 Learning and Skills Development Agency, Unit 3, Citadel Place, Tinworth St, London SE11 5EH.

Telephone: 020-7840 5400

Website: www.feda.ac.uk

fields.headline: Final offer?
fields.standfirst: Will Blunkett's announcement on pay avert a strike, asks Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Will Blunkett's announcement on pay avert a strike, asks Peter Kingston
fields.body:
At Southwark cathedral, on the south bank of the Thames, the education secretary, David Blunkett, will tomorrow be aiming to pour oil on troubled water.

The one-time further education lecturer is hoping to announce a package which will avert the threatened May strike by Natfhe, the lecturers' union.

Blunkett will also be announcing more cash for the learning and skills system which wobbles to its feet next week. In the litany of largesse preceding the election, tomorrow is further education's day.

But the strike threat is his most pressing concern. Even though any industrial action is not now likely to start until after May 3, a probable general election date, ministers are nonetheless anxious to settle the claim.

According to Natfhe, that is going to take a considerable sum of money - more than the amounts being whispered. And the union stands firm in its insistence that it will not accept performance-related pay.

Natfe's interim claim for next year is for a £3,000 flat-rate pay rise for managers and lecturers. This is the first step in a staged award the union wants to be effected over the next four years to restore lecturers' pay-relativity with salaries in schools. Lecturers' pay has fallen by 10%-35% behind that of teachers.

Everybody apparently sees the strength of the lecturers' case. Natfhe's claim that few, if any, other workforces in the public sector have delivered the equivalent of a 70% growth in student numbers while seeing their pay levels fall steadily behind. It has been common for lecturers in some colleges to go for a couple of years without pay increases.

At the start of this month, a survey by the Association of Colleges showed that nearly a fifth of colleges had not paid this year's 3.3% pay settlement.

Lecturers' exasperation was further inflamed when they realised that schoolteachers would get a sum equivalent to 8% of their salary bill to implement a pay initiative, whereas the sum announced for them - £50m - represented 2% of their total bill.

In recognition of this inequity, the AoC last month told ministers they needed to find an extra £200m to restore parity on top of the £150m which Malcolm Wicks, the lifelong learning minister, announced would be available over the next two years.

And so, the education secretary will, according to reports, announce £200m for year three tomorrow. His package is also expected to include a scheme for providing lecturers with free laptop computers and a range of "golden hello" payments to entice people to teach shortage subjects.

The rest of Blunkett's pay announcement may well follow proposals drawn up by the AoC in February, after consultation with the DfEE and Natfhe. If so, the total will be a package which the AoC, at least, thinks should be acceptable.

It won't claw back that 10% pay gap with teachers, but that, according to AoC sources, is an unrealistic expectation in three years.

But will £200m in the third year do the trick for Natfhe? The clear message from the union leadership is that it won't.

His package is also expected to include a scheme for providing lecturers with free laptop computers and a range of "golden hello" payments to entice people to teach shortage subjects. The rest of Blunkett's pay announcement may well follow proposals drawn up by the AoC in February, after consultation with the DfEE and Natfhe. If so, the total will be a package which the AoC, at least, thinks should be acceptable. It won't claw back that 10% pay gap with teachers, but that, according to AoC sources, is an unrealistic expectation in three years. But will £200m in the third year do the trick for Natfhe? The clear message from the union leadership is that it won't.

fields.headline: Play-back time
fields.standfirst: The corporate video market is seeing an 80s-style boom, says John Crace
fields.trailText: The corporate video market is seeing an 80s-style boom, says John Crace
fields.body:
A new John Cleese film will be released in a couple of weeks' time. But don't go looking through the listings magazines for details or expect a promotional tour complete with endless "Me and My Wastepaper Basket" lifestyle interviews. The film in question is a 25-minute training video on counselling skills called "Can You Spare a Moment?"

Even though the UK corporate video market, with a turnover last year of £650m, is larger than the UK film industry, it has still had its fair share of ups and downs. Whereas no self-respecting company would be seen dead without a training video in the 1980s, during the 1990s its popularity declined slightly as people looked to other media to deliver the corporate message. However, in the last year or so business has been booming once more.

"I've noticed that I'm being offered many more parts in training videos," says David Timson, an actor for whom training videos are a lucrative sideline. "In the 1980s there was a glut of this type of work, but it went quiet for many years," he says "Just recently I was up in the Lake District making a film about office skills."

Timson is not alone in noticing this phenomenon. Ashley Callaghan is a management trainer who also runs Role-Call, an actors' agency specialising in corporate work. "Most of the businesses who use my agency tend to want actors for interactive role-play in group training sessions," he says. "But just recently I've had many more phone calls for video work."

So why the resurgence in video?

"I think there's two main reasons," Callaghan continues. "The first is that even though many of the messages that companies want to get across to their staff have remained fairly constant, their managers are always looking for ways to express them differently so no one gets bored. So trends go in and out of fashion, and there's an element of reinventing the wheel.

"However, the more important reason is that companies have to pay more attention to the well-being of their staff at times of fuller employment. When good staff can pick and choose their jobs, companies have to offer more than a decent salary to retain them. They have to think about their employees' personal and professional development as well."

Martin Addison, marketing director of Video Arts, the UK's largest corporate video maker, founded by John Cleese nearly 30 years ago, believes Callaghan is spot on. "Where five years ago employers could pick and choose their staff, they now have to work much harder to retain them," he says. "We have noticed a marked increase in video sales over the first few months of this year."

Video Arts make an average of six new training videos per year, each of which costs between £50,000-£100,000. Some will be remakes of old films, but with a more familiar, modern cast. Most will also be generic videos that a skilled trainer can adapt to any company's management culture. Video Arts also make films for individual companies. "It tends to happen when a large company wants to roll out a new standard practice throughout all its offices worldwide," Addison explains.

But will the video be doomed when the long-promised digital revolution finally delivers the goods and all training can be done interactively through a PC?

Wayne Drew, chief executive of the International Visual Communication Association (IVCA) the trade association for business communication, believes not. "The resurgence of the training video has much to do with the fact that the development of broadband has not been as fast as everyone expected." he says. "Most companies now realise that the best training programmes are multi-faceted, rather than focusing on a single method of delivery."

So video may turn into streaming video, but it looks like it's here to stay. Businesses doubled their training spend from 9% in 1999 to 18% in 2000 and most predict a similar spend for the foreseeable future.

This spells good news for the likes of David Timson. But he is quick to spot a downside. "The last time we had a training video boom it was the height of yuppiedom," he says gloomily. "I hope we're not in for a return of that."

fields.headline: An inspector calls
fields.standfirst: Janet Jones tracks down a benevolent beast lurking in the corridors
fields.trailText: Janet Jones tracks down a benevolent beast lurking in the corridors
fields.body:
A very exciting event took place in our college the other day. An inspector got loose. He escaped management. He escaped control. He evaded his minder. Nobody tried to feed him pieces of paper. Or statistics. Or education speak. Or even a cup of coffee with our new logo on it. He was free!

And he was enjoying himself. It wasn't quite clear whether he was more pleased at having got away or at being away. But pleased he was. We didn't spoil it for him - we kept our thousands of lesson plans well hidden. (What are we going to do with the things?)

He behaved with honour and wore a suit with a label on his chest so nobody could think he was in disguise or working undercover. He told us his name and that he was the reporting inspector, though I thought the label said something that sounded higher and grander than that.

He was sympathetic: "I see your photocopier's not working."

"People have been in trying to mend it," I told him. I did not add, "for years".

"It's a new-old one," somebody else told him, which is the most tactful version of "second-hand" I've ever heard.

At some of our questions he put his hands in his pockets, became coy and said: "That's a matter for the government." But when he was asked which was the smallest further education college in the UK the conversation became interesting. And when he was asked what was happening to inspectors in the change-over from the Further Education Funding Council, he got verbose.

In fact, he got so verbose that I had time to remember that management have been showering us for months with papers to read on exactly that subject. Yet it's not been a hot topic in the staffroom, nor does it seem to be anyone's bedtime reading.

He told us we would "not believe" some of the things he sees in his travels round the country's further education colleges.

"On the other hand", he considered us for a moment, "perhaps you would."

You can take that remark in two ways, but we took him to mean that we were as well travelled and worldly as him - which shows how happily our impromptu meeting was going.

Finally, he told us he would have finished his report in 10 weeks' time. I picked up my lesson plans and went off to teach. It occurred to me that if he was facing the prospect of spending 10 weeks writing a report on our college, it was small wonder that it was such a treat for him to roam around it for an hour or two without constraint.

He never knew what he might see round the next corner. In fact - as a point of interest - a week later he would have been wading through a flood from the toilets.

He was last seen ducking underneath the windows of the approaching lift (it was a week later that the thing was stuck and full of passengers) and legging it down that corridor, past the pristine toilets, with fun in his eyes and a spring in his step.

"That", the staffroom agreed later, "is what an inspector ought to be doing."

fields.headline: College Days
fields.trailText: Name Angela Browning
fields.body:
Name Angela Browning

Born December 1, 1946

Occupation MP for Tiverton and Honiton - the constituency where St Boniface was born in AD680 - and shadow leader of the House of Commons; vice-pres of the Alzheimer's society; co-chair of the Women's National Commission; founder director of the Small Business Bureau - in other words a very busy woman.

Attended Bournemouth and Poole college

Dates Mid-1960s - she's a bit hazy about the exact years, but her 1960s student days vagueness is not for the usual reasons. She fitted her part-time studies into a busy working life.

Courses Various advanced City & Guilds home economics. She recalls: "I was working at the same time as adviser on home economics to the gas board, among others, and I went on to teach adult evening classes. I had fantastic fun and I liked the atmosphere - it was a nice part of the world."
