fields.headline: Are agencies doomed?
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston on a court case which could restore employment rights for millions
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston on a court case which could restore employment rights for millions
fields.body:
A landmark court decision in a lecturer's long-running lawsuit against her former college could radically improve conditions for millions of agency workers.

And it could spell the end for agencies which are used by employers to avoid paying benefits to long-term staff, according to the lecturers' union Natfhe - a claim that is hotly denied by Education Lecturing Services (ELS), the biggest agency in the sector.

The Court of Appeal decided that Debra Allonby, a former office technology lecturer sacked by Accrington and Rossendale College in 1996 and rehired via ELS to do virtually the same work, was entitled to claim the same benefits as directly employed staff doing the same work.

The judges ordered a Manchester employment tribunal which had originally turned down Allonby's claims for sex discrimination to arrange a fresh panel to rehear the case.

Her lawyers argued that European law allows female agency workers to claim equal treatment with workers who are directly employed and doing the same job in the same service or establishment.

The judges admitted they were unclear about this and referred Allonby's claim for equal pay and pension rights to the European Court of Justice to settle the matters. They ordered Accrington and Rossendale college to pay costs.

Equal pay and rights to the lecturers' pensions scheme, with employers' contributions, would remove the financial advantages colleges enjoy in hiring agency staff long-term, said Natfhe's general secretary, Paul Mackney.

"We would like to think that it signals the beginning of the end of using agencies as a cheapskate method for permanent employment," he said.

The erosion of the margin of benefits to colleges of using agency staff, and surveys by the Further Education Funding Council showing that classes taught by hourly-paid agency part-time staff were on aggregate of lower quality than those taught by directly-employed staff must make colleges and ministers rethink their use of agencies, he said.

The government should move quickly to restore pension rights before the European Court makes its decision, which would take at least two years, Mackney said.

Richard Eve, ELS's executive director, said that Natfhe was vastly overstating any success in the case's latest development.

He rejected the notion that the judges were sending a strong hint to the employment tribunal to revise the original verdicts and find in Allonby's favour.

"I've no doubt that the result will be the same as before," he said.

"If Natfhe thinks that they'll be shutting our doors in two weeks' time, they've got another think coming. They are years away from this."

Eve said he had no worries that colleges would now rethink their employment practices in anticipation of an unfavourable verdict.

"There are colleges talking to us now about using us from September."

Allonby was one of 341 hourly-paid lecturers sacked by Accrington and Rossendale College in 1996 and re-employed through ELS.

She got less pay and had no entitlement to contractual sick pay or similar contractual benefits, no place in the career structure and no access to the pensions scheme covering college lecturers and school teachers.

fields.headline: The big blow out
fields.standfirst: Some training and enterprise councils are giving their staff a wonderful send off, but where's the money coming from, asks George Low
fields.trailText: Some training and enterprise councils are giving their staff a wonderful send off, but where's the money coming from, asks George Low
fields.body:
Hic! When it comes to holding a wake, the late West London training and enterprise council takes some beating.

If you weren't among the 300 guests troughing and jiving until 1am at the £50,000 thrash in the ballroom suite at the Dorchester hotel, in London's Park Lane last Friday night, don't fret - we've printed out a souvenir menu.

On Friday, the nation's 72 training and enterprise councils (TECs) went out of business. It's a fair bet that West London threw one of the more lavish hooleys, for spouses, partners and friends, part-paid for from a handsome surplus in its training and enterprise funds.

But it is far from alone among the TECs in choosing the bang rather the whimper exit. There has been a determined effort among some to spend an estimated £50m surplus before Gordon Brown could claw it back.

The extra cash, described by the DfEE as "unallocated funds" which have slipped through the floorboards between the winding up of the TECs and the creation of the Learning and Skills Council on April 1, is being spent on extra pay-offs to redundant staff and on end-of-term revels to mark an end of the Thatcherite training and enterprise era.

In London alone the surpluses of the unallocated funds top £6m and across the country as a whole they are likely to reach £50m.

A spokesman for the TEC National Council said she understood that the surplus funds from the TECs would go into a trust fund. Asked how much the surpluses amounted to, she said she was afraid she was not authorised to make this information public.

Will the Treasury ever recover these left-over funds? The national Learning and Skills Council, which would hope to receive the money for funding further and adult education, referred the matter to the DfEE. Here a spokesman said that they would be looking to recover the surplus millions, but the legislation setting up the TECs had treated them as private companies and allowed them to build up reserves. In a recent speech the employment secretary, David Blunkett, had admitted that he had no power to dictate how these funds were used, although his aides admitted he was left fuming at the situation.

A chief executive of one of the new learning and skills councils said this week that the funds would not come to them immediately, but the Treasury would be likely to recover as much as it could in time. In the meantime, the money was at the TEC chairmen and chief executives' discretion for golden handshakes and for farewell parties.

"During the past 18 months they have been encouraged to build up reserves to meet liabilities at the time of their dissolution including redundancy payments plus bonuses for the top brass and the termination of leases on property. In addition, most of them had surpluses on their training companies which often amounted to six or seven figure sums. All in all it could amount to an average of £1m per TEC. Neither the new local learning and skills councils nor the colleges will be likely to see much of this money."

A spokesman for the Association of Colleges confirmed that the DfEE had told them that the surplus millions, if and when they were recovered, would be re-absorbed into the Treasury.

"There is no reason why the money should be recycled into the colleges or used to fund the lecturers' pay increase, which has already been budgeted for within the DfEE. It certainly will not go to the local learning and skills councils."

Under transfer of employment regulations, TEC staff had the opportunity of re-employment in the 47 new local learning and skills councils.

Much of the extra surplus left in the TECs has been caused by an undershoot in the projected redundancy payments, even though TEC chief executives have left with two or three years of pay as part of company rolling contract agreements. Some 80 to 90% of the TEC staff have found work in the learning and skills councils through the European redundancy regulations and there was a shake-out of many staff before this month's dissolution date - in some cases be cause the TECs were told they could not afford to keep staff on to the end.

Sue Berryman, negotiating secretary of the lecturers' union Natfhe, said lecturers would be dismayed to see the money, which had originated from public funds for economic regeneration, to help the unemployed to acquire new skills and businesses to become more competitive, go to waste in aimless frivolity or golden handshakes to those who already had jobs and were well provided for.

"It looks as if these missing millions will be used by a few people with their noses at the trough. The public accounts committee should look into what is going on before the money disappears for ever."

Tim Boswell MP, Conservative spokesman on further and higher education, said he was not surprised that millions of the TEC money had become surplus. But the education secretary David Blunkett had at the last stages of the learning and skills bill given himself draconian powers to sequester the TEC funds, if necessary. Boswell estimated that between £250m and £350m of the £1.4bn TEC budget had not found its way to the Learning and Skills Council or its subsidiaries.

He said that a distinction had to be drawn between the money that had been publicly provided for the TECs and the private money which belonged, in some cases, to chambers of commerce.

"I have no doubt that the Treasury and DfEE will try to collar the money in the end, but in the meantime everything has gone very quiet. But if the government's handling of the foot and mouth disease is anything to go by, then it is clear that the Learning and Skills Council will take many months to roll out and millions may be spent in vain or lost on the way."

webTitle: Pledge on equal treatment for elderly

fields.headline: Pledge on equal treatment for elderly
fields.standfirst: A new plan to end discrimination in the treatment of older people will include guaranteed equality of access to care and a ban on 'do not resuscitate' notes, reports Patrick Butler.
fields.trailText: A new plan to end discrimination in the treatment of older people will include guaranteed equality of access to care and a ban on 'do not resuscitate' notes, reports Patrick Butler
fields.body:
The NHS and social services departments have been ordered to identify and root out "age discrimination" in the way they treat older people under a initiative aimed at driving up standards of care across the country.

Pensioners are to be guaranteed equality of access to NHS treatment and social care services under the government's long-awaited national service framework (NSF) for older people.

The framework outlines national target standards on hospital and social care, post-hospital care, stroke services, accident and rehabilitation services, mental health, and healthy living.

It effectively bans the refusal of treatment to older people on the grounds of age alone, including the widespread use by doctors of "do not resuscitate" notes when treating terminally-ill patients.

The move was welcomed by elderly rights charities, which said it amounted to the first admission by a government that the NHS discriminates against older patients.

Launching the framework, health minister John Hutton said that in future NHS services would be provided "on the basis of clinical need alone, regardless of age". The document admits that "there have been reports of poor, unresponsive, insensitive and, in the worst cases, discriminatory services" in the NHS and suggests this is a result of "the survival of old systems and practices".

It adds: "This has been shown in specific problems such as the lack of rehabilitation, inadequate dementia services and inconsistencies in stroke care." Mr Hutton promised that over the next three years, the NHS would perform an extra 70,000 cataract operations, 16,000 more hip and knee replacements and 3,000 more heart operations.

There will be an "older patient champion" on patient forums attached to NHS trusts, while each trust board and social services committee will have a designated representative with responsibility for the rights of elderly people.

A sum of £105m - from the £835m fund announced for the NHS in the Budget - has been earmarked for equipment to aid the elderly and infirm, such as chair lifts and grab rails.

The NHS plan, published in July 2000, committed £1.4bn extra for spending on healthcare for older people.

The plan also set out ambitious plans to recruit 140 extra specialists in old age medicine, 85 old age psychiatrists, and thousands of nurses and physiotherapists involved in the care of older people.

Professor Ian Philp, the government's "tsar" for the elderly, said: "This will make age discrimination a thing of the past. Older people will be treated as individuals, with respect and dignity."

Gordon Lishman, director general of Age Concern England, said: "The document must become the cornerstone for promoting and improving the health of older people, but must also ensure that older people are treated as individuals, not simply as a group."

Shadow health secretary Dr Liam Fox called the framework "an election stunt".

webTitle: Degree course for social workers on the cards

fields.headline: Degree course for social workers on the cards
fields.trailText: Social workers will have to gain a three-year vocational degree to qualify as part of a drive to raise standards, the government announced today. Linda Steele reports.
fields.body:
Social workers will have to gain a three-year vocational degree to qualify as part of a drive to raise standards, the government announced today.

Speaking at a Guardian/National Institute of Social Work (NISW) conference, health minister John Hutton said: "Possibly one of the most urgent priorities we face is the need for a better trained workforce."

The minister added: "The new qualification will give greater emphasis to field experience and the practical application to skills and knowledge and with a stronger focus on children." He called it a "once in a generation opportunity to make sure the training equips the profession fully for its future role and tasks".

Last summer the government released a consultant's report calling for a degree level qualification to replace the current two-year diploma in social work. Consultation over the government's quality strategy overwhelmingly backed this proposal.

The new curriculum, to be launched in 2003, will focus on practice and will be partly based on national occupational standards that define what employers require social workers to be able to do when they join the workforce.

"We want social workers with skills in analysis and assessment who can confidently apply knowledge to practice - social workers who create opportunities for users and who work collaboratively with other professionals," said Mr Hutton.

Social workers would also need to demonstrate that they were to continue to refresh their knowledge and skills once in employment, he said. Social workers had to promote independence and opportunity and work with users and their families as part of an "active" welfare state. Neither the free market nor a paternalistic corporate state was acceptable.

Social work experts welcomed the announcement, as the profession has long been calling for a degree-level qualification. Arthur Keefe, chairman of the national social services training organisation (TOPSS), said: "Social work has become much more complicated. Social workers need to make high level judgments and are required to integrate research into their practice. It's about time and level, about broad curriculum and a personal and professional development that will allow them to do the job." A two-year diploma was insufficient in terms of time and academic level, he said.

TOPSS was concerned that there was no bursary scheme to support undergraduate students. However, Mr Keefe welcomed the minister's promise to keep student finance under review.

Daphne Statham, NISW director, said: "As the modernisation agenda takes effect, the job becomes increasingly high risk. There is no way that two years is enough. Nurses and teachers get more time to train. Social work needs no less."

Mr Hutton emphasised that the government was not proposing a takeover of social services by the NHS. "We are not pursuing the so-called medical model over the social care model," he said. "The new ways of integrating NHS and social care services should be built upon a genuine partnership between equals, with each making its own distinctive contribution to what should be a single local care network."

fields.headline: Livingstone appoints cartoon laureate
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: The Queen has poet laureate Andrew Motion, now Ken Livingstone is to have Martin Rowson.
fields.body:
The Queen has poet laureate Andrew Motion, now Ken Livingstone is to have Martin Rowson.

The London mayor today announced that he is to appoint a cartoonist laureate for London.

Guardian cartoonist Martin Rowson, 42, will be paid one pint of London Pride a year for capturing "all the bizarre and surreal goings-on in London government", Mr Livingstone said.

Mr Rowson, who has been a cartoonist for 19 years and has worked for the Guardian, Tribune and Time Out, said: "I imagine it to be a situation as in Roman times when a slave had to follow his master around. I will probably be ignored for months".

His first official task will be to cover the mayor's question time on April 4. From then Mr Rowson of Lewisham, south east London, says his satirical commentary will come by "simply just hoofing it". He is not certain what tasks he will be set or how often he will have to attend the assembly.

"It depends on how much goodwill they can extract from one pint of London Pride," he said. "The last thing that politicians in this country can afford to do if they want to get re-elected is to admit they do not have a sense of humour.

"I think they will be ready for a satirical commentary. It is a very important part of the political process and of journalism. I am glad there is a politician somewhere who is willing to allow a cartoonist inside the loop, however dangerous that could be."

webTitle: How I became Ken's cartoonist laureate

fields.headline: How I became Ken's cartoonist laureate
fields.standfirst:
The Guardian's award-winning cartoonist Martin Rowson explains why he will be chronicling the progress of the London mayor

Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText:
The Guardian's award-winning cartoonist Martin Rowson explains why he is chronicling the progress of the London mayor.
Martin Rowson on Ken Livingstone
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.body:
My appointment as cartoonist laureate to the Mayor of London is one of those wonderful, and slightly terrifying instances when life imitates jokes.

This, I suppose, is only as it should be for a cartoonist, as it's my job to observe the serious and subvert it with humour.

I first suggested that Ken Livingstone appoint me as his cartoonist laureate as a joke. We were at a dinner at London Zoo, held to raise money for the Zoo's new invertebrate centre, where the guest of honour was Margaret Thatcher, to whom Ken had to propose a toast.

Earlier in the evening I'd drawn Ken and Thatcher on the same piece of paper and got them both to sign it. Thatcher said of her caricature: "Couldn't you have been kinder?" I wish I'd thought to ask her the same thing. She wrote: "I don't recognise me."

Anyway, Livingstone liked the idea, and, several times between then and his election, he agreed that, once he was mayor, the job would be mine.

My terms and conditions were simple. I wanted to be paid a pint of Fuller's London Pride per annum, in a quaint evocation of the remuneration of the Poet Laureate. In addition, I wanted to fulfil the role of the slave in ancient Rome, standing behind the hero on his triumph and whispering "You are mortal! You are mortal!" in his ear. Except I intended to whisper "Stop looking so smug!" to Ken.

Anyway, as you'd expect of any politician - even one like Livingstone, who's so brilliant at giving the impression that he's not a politician at all - after the election I heard nothing, until this week.

So now I'm lumbered with the consequences of what started out as nothing more than a cheap gag. That said, one of the main complaints of cartoonists is that they aren't taken sufficiently seriously, either as journalists or as part of the political process.

But  after all, politicians and cartoonists exist in a strange kind of symbiosis: we need each other more than we'd like to admit.

And, to my slight horror, at last a politician has invited a cartoonist inside the loop - to spectate on and to satirise the business of the government of London.

Yum! Fresh meat!

fields.headline: Book reviews
fields.standfirst: Win a copy for your school
fields.trailText: Growing Frogs | Wolf on the Fold
fields.body:
Growing Frogs, by Vivian French and Alison Bartlett (Walker Books)

Price £4.99

Age 4-8 yrs

Whether or not the countryside is completely closed to all comers in the coming weeks, it will soon be frogspawn time. As far as life cycles go, the frog has to be one of the most compelling. This book conveys the faintly magical aspect of their transformation, while planting the seed of conservation and responsible frog husbandry. The French/Bartlett partnership (Oliver's Vegetables, Oliver's Fruit Salad) is an excellent one, displaying a commitment to narrative which a story as exciting as this deserves. There is a freshness to both text and illustration that can't fail to enthuse both teacher and pupil.

Wolf on the Fold, by Judith Clarke (Silverfish Paperback)

Price £5.50

Age 11-15 years

Successive generations of an Australian family provide the common ground in this excellent collection of stories, the first of which is set in 1935, the last in 2002. The tensions of adolescence permeate the writing, but a scattered chronology allows a less relentlessly contemporary perspective. Sibling relationships are central to each story, but unsentimentally so. In relating the stories to actual events - the persecution of the Asian community in Uganda, and the war resulting from Saddam's invasion of Kuwait - the author reminds us that history is about people and that the consequences can ripple on for years.

fields.headline: Royal boost for reform
fields.standfirst: Adoption of anonymous marking at universities may come just in time to safeguard Prince William's results from public scrutiny, reports Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: Adoption of anonymous marking at universities may come just in time to safeguard Prince William's results from public scrutiny, reports Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
Prince William has emerged as the unlikely figurehead for the campaign for anonymous marking in universities.

St Andrews University has announced that it is ending its traditional practice of posting students' examination results on public noticeboards. Officials say that the move is a response to the government's 1998 Data Protection Act, which prohibits the publication of private personal information. But the changes, which will see student names replaced by exam matriculation numbers, are being introduced just in time to ensure that the prince's exam results remain out of the public spotlight. William begins his four-year art history degree this autumn.

The university's principal, Brian Lang, told the university's student paper earlier in the year that students who try to leak information about the prince would be "looking for another university". He also warned that staff would be disciplined if details of the prince's academic performance were revealed.

But now student leaders are urging academic officials at St Andrews to go one step further and introduce anonymous marking at the university. This would help to keep William's exam marks private, they say, but also ensure that lecturers marking exams cannot discriminate against students on the basis of age, sex or race.

Brooks Duke, a national executive member of the National Union of Students, said: "The NUS has persistently campaigned for anonymous marking. The enrolment of Prince William at St Andrews has highlighted a wider issue - that of discrimination at educational institutions. All students should be marked according to ability, not their name, ethnic background, age, gender or sexuality. This is a golden opportunity for universities to institute a system that puts them beyond criticism on the issue of discrimination in relation to marking."

The NUS is currently stepping up its lobby urging university heads to introduce universal anonymous marking. While some university departments already have anonymous marking in place, others have been slow in reforming. The campaign is set to be boosted by the government's drive to tackle institutional racism in universities. The home secretary, Jack Straw, this month announced that the ethnic make-up of academic staff will now be monitored in universities alongside other public-sector organisations, such as schools and hospitals.

The NUS believes that many students suffer unfair discrimination during their degree courses. The union has joined forces with the Equal Opportunities Commission and the Commission for Racial Equality to exert pressure on the Department for Education and Employment to address the issue of discrimination. It is also calling for the subject to be raised as part of teaching inspection visits to university departments.

Research on discrimination and bias commissioned last year by the Association of University Teachers found that a significant number of women students achieved better results when anonymous marking was introduced.

At the University of Wales, the study showed 42% of men in the art faculty achieved either a first or upper second degree compared to 34% of women. However, in the first year after the introduction of anonymous marking, the figures were 42% for men and 47% for women.

In the early 1990s, racial bias emerged as a major concern at the University of East London and Glasgow University's Dental School. At UEL, black undergraduates were awarded marks that were on average 4.2% lower than their white counterparts. Even more worrying were statistics from Glasgow University's Dental School research. These showed that Asian students accounted for 20% of students on the course, but made up 80% of those who failed. Although racial discrimination was not proved conclusively in either case, both institutions subsequently introduced anonymous marking.

A survey of university students' unions conducted by the NUS in August 1999 found that 44% believed that there was discrimination and bias in their institutions. But two out of three of the institutions with full anonymous marking systems believed that there was little or no discrimination in their institutions.

The methods of anonymous marking include marking by numbers, bar codes, double marking, or external or visitor marking.

The NUS argues that one of the main benefits of anonymous marking is that it reduces the risk of suspicion for the markers and minimises potential conflict or tension between students and tutors.

fields.headline: Hoddle in Spurs talks row
fields.trailText: Southampton have denied giving Glenn Hoddle permission to speak to Spurs - even though the Saints manager was reportedly at White Hart Lane this afternoon to discuss the vacant manager's position at the club.
fields.body:
Southampton have denied giving Glenn Hoddle permission to speak to Spurs - even though the Saints manager was reportedly at White Hart Lane this afternoon to discuss the vacant manager's position at the club.

Earlier today, a Tottenham spokesman told the club's official website that executive vice-chairman David Buchler and non-executive chairman Daniel Levy had been granted permission to talk to Hoddle by Southampton chairman Rupert Lowe.

"It is true these talks are taking place," said the spokesman. "There was a meeting due to take place this afternoon with the board, Glenn Hoddle and his agent.

"This is extremely good news for the club. We don't know what's going to happen, but the board got permission from Rupert Lowe over the weekend and they have been working on this meeting ever since.

"Everyone is hopeful that we can persuade him to come sooner rather than later, but we will have to wait and see what comes out of the meeting."

But Lowe immediately responded on his own club's website, saying: "I have not given formal permission to anybody to speak to Glenn."

Hoddle did not show for a scheduled training session at Southampton this morning and his club claimed his return from a week's holiday in South Africa had been delayed.

His assistants John Gorman and Stuart Gray were put in charge of the session and the players were not given a reason for Hoddle's non-appearance.

Hoddle is understood to have an escape clause in his current contract which allows him to join another club upon payment of a compensation figure of £800,000.

Earlier today, a Tottenham spokesman told the club's official website that executive vice-chairman David Buchler and non-executive chairman Daniel Levy had been granted permission to talk to Hoddle by Southampton chairman Rupert Lowe. "It is true these talks are taking place," said the spokesman. "There was a meeting due to take place this afternoon with the board, Glenn Hoddle and his agent. "This is extremely good news for the club. We don't know what's going to happen, but the board got permission from Rupert Lowe over the weekend and they have been working on this meeting ever since. "Everyone is hopeful that we can persuade him to come sooner rather than later, but we will have to wait and see what comes out of the meeting." But Lowe immediately responded on his own club's website, saying: "I have not given formal permission to anybody to speak to Glenn." Hoddle did not show for a scheduled training session at Southampton this morning and his club claimed his return from a week's holiday in South Africa had been delayed. His assistants John Gorman and Stuart Gray were put in charge of the session and the players were not given a reason for Hoddle's non-appearance. Hoddle is understood to have an escape clause in his current contract which allows him to join another club upon payment of a compensation figure of £800,000.

webTitle: MP labels Hague a 'baldy with a funny accent'

fields.headline: MP labels Hague a 'baldy with a funny accent'
fields.standfirst: Special report: The Conservative party
fields.trailText: A senior Tory has admitted William Hague has a Kinnock-like effect on voters because he is "a baldy and has a funny accent."
fields.body:
A senior Tory has admitted William Hague has a Kinnock-like effect on voters because he is "a baldy and has a funny accent."

Tim Loughton, Conservatives spokesperson for the environment, made the remarks during an attack on the media for its London bias and metropolitan elitism.

Mr Loughton said: "The media has a problem with him [Mr Hague] and unfortunately the media has communicated the problem it has with him to many people out there in the country - and that's grossly unfair."

Asked why he thought Mr Hague was unpopular with the media, Mr Loughton added: "I think it's as petty as the fact that he's a baldy and he has a funny accent. And for many people who write the political editorial columns, who are London-based luvvies, that's easy to poke fun at."

It is the latest in a long line of personal criticism of the Conservative leader, but hits the hardest because it comes from his own side. Viscount Cranborne, the former leader of the Tories in the Lords, recently complained the party lacked "gravitas" under William Hague.

But Mr Loughton did go on to claim that the characteristics of Mr Hague for which he was attacked could work in his favour outside the south-east.

He said: "Many people forget that William is a very obvious asset to many people in Yorkshire, in the north. And they don't treat him with this very unfair, rather snide cynicism that the press do, based in London. And there are many, many seats in the north that we stand to win back, where we will largely do it because William is one of our biggest assets.

"I think we'll overcome that in the Southern seats as well and I hope many people will be prepared to give him the benefit of the doubt and judge him on what he stands for and what he believes in. "

Mr Hague tried to turn his humble roots to his advantage in his conference speech in Bournemouth in 2000, when he told an audience of the party faithful he wanted to "take them on a journey to Wath-on- Dearne, where I was born." Making great play of his South Yorkshire upbringing, he talked of friends who dreamed of moving to "Ilkley, not Islington."

Neil Kinnock, the Labour leader between 1983 and 1992, who soaked up huge amounts of personal vitriol and ridicule over his Welsh accent and bald pate, recently claimed he thought his own political career had been held back because of his origins.

fields.headline: Care placement figures provoke anger
fields.standfirst: One in seven children in care in Wales have at least three placements with foster families over the course of a year, according to a new report. Why is the figure so high and why are there such huge variations in figures between individual local authorities, asks Maggie Murray.
fields.trailText: One in seven children in care in Wales have at least three placements with foster families over the course of a year, according to a new report. Why is the figure so high and why are there such huge variations in figures between individual local authorities, asks Maggie Murray
fields.body:
Wide variations in the number of placements that looked-after children in Wales are likely to experience each year have been revealed in a new report.

Throughout Wales almost 500 children - one in seven of those in care - have had at least three placements a year, according to Social Services Statistics 2000, produced by the National Assembly.

But the report shows that the number of placements a child had varied considerably among the 22 local authorities. While some councils have no children with three or more placements, others are reported to have more than 20% of their children with that many placements.

"Our concern with figures like these is that they show a lack of consistency in the way care plans are drawn up," said Deborah Jones, who heads the children's charity, Voices from Care, that works on behalf of children in care.

"From experience in working with young people in care, I know the wide spectrum of problems that can come up when children are moved about and the effect that can have on their lives. Without continuity the child can't focus and build. An obvious problem would come with education. Moving from placement to placement is very disruptive and potentially extremely damaging,"

Hugh Gardner, who chairs the Association of Directors of Social Services in Wales, says the data show that there is a lot of work to be done.

"I think we still have a long way to go in learning to collaborate with each other in and using the experience gained to be able to measure our performance," he said.

"There is a culture of authorities working in their own way without looking at what others are doing. We tend to be like small islands working independently and not sharing valuable lessons from authority to authority.

"Swansea, where I am based, will be taking the lead in an all-Wales unit, which is designed to promote sharing and collaborative work, that we hope can address some of the issues."

The report shows that in more than half the councils, in excess of 10% of children in care had three or more placements during a 12-month period. In total, 476 children out of 3,313 in care had three or more. The data excludes those children who are in a series of agreed short-term placements.

The report shows that in one council, Isle of Anglesey (Ynys Mon), all the looked-after children had only one placement that year. It also shows that in Wrexham council, 44% of children had three or more placements, but the authority told SocietyGuardian yesterday that it was challenging the figure.

Catriona Williams, director of the charity Children in Wales, said: "One of the key issues is better co-ordination of placements available, we need a carefully thought out strategy.

"One of the messages that came from the Waterhouse report was the need for good quality residential care provision and it is a major concern that some authorities have no provision for residential care in their own geographical area.

"This automatically causes dislocation of children because they are then forced to live outside their own communities. All the work that we have done with children in Wales shows that stability is one of the most important factors. For their emotional welfare it is of crucial importance that they are not constantly moved on because they see that as a rejection.

She added "The quality of public care must be better than that provided by the family, otherwise there is little point in offering such care. It is not possible to justify moving children around more than three times during one year."

* Social Services Statistics Wales published by the National Assembly for Wales. £10.

fields.headline: And the winner is . . .
fields.standfirst: Some of the night's best quotes
fields.trailText: Some of the night's best quotes
fields.body:
"During my out-of-body experience earlier tonight, I didn't acknowledge her, shamefully. And really, she is the centre of the universe which was our movie . . . So, with great humility, I acknowledge her profusely."
Best actress winner Julia Roberts on the real Erin Brockovich

"Put down that stick, I'm going to be here for a while . . . I love it up here! I love the world! I'm so happy, thank you . . . A girl's got to have her moment. Everybody tries to get me to shut up. It didn't work with my parents and it didn't work now." Julia Roberts rebels against the 45-second limit on acceptance speeches

"Thank you, Academy, for this special recognition for non-English movies."
Best foreign-language film director Ang Lee brings some dignity to the occasion

"My music is to dream without boundaries. Tonight, with you, I see boundaries being crossed. As a classic musical composer, I am thrilled to be honoured here."
Tan Dun, winner of the best original score Oscar for Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon

"I want to thank the members of the Academy who were bold enough to give me this award for this song, which, obviously, is a song that doesn't pussyfoot around or turn a blind eye to human nature. God bless you all with peace, tranquillity and good will. Thanks."
Bob Dylan accepting the best original song Oscar for Things Have Changed, from Wonder Boys

"It's nice to see Bob Dylan from Australia - an 18-hour time difference - which is normal for Bob."
Steve Martin

"If they say, 'I don't like your movie,' it's kind of like saying, 'I didn't like your life.' And then they say, 'By the way, it was a little too long.'"
Cameron Crowe, best original screenplay winner for the semi-autobiographical Almost Famous

webTitle: Dyke hits out at Cup rights

fields.headline: Dyke slams football body over World Cup rights sale
fields.trailText:
5.15pm: Greg Dyke has branded football governing body Fifa 'hypocritical' for its handling of World Cup TV rights, writes Jason Deans.
Mar 15: TV bosses fear defeat in World Cup battle
fields.body:
BBC boss Greg Dyke has branded football governing body Fifa "hypocritical" for the way it has handled the sale of TV rights to the next World Cup.

He said Fifa was the "real villain of the piece" for selling off TV rights to the 2002 World Cup 2002 to German media group Kirch, instead of sticking with its public service traditions.

"I do grow tired of certain hypocritical sports rights holders who speak of the importance of universal access, while at the same time selling their rights to the highest bidder regardless of their commitment to those same principles," said Mr Dyke.

"If you contrast the action of Fifa with the International Olympic Committee, which has ensured the Olympics have remained universally available, the comparison is stark."

The BBC director general was speaking at a conference of the European Broadcasting Union just weeks after it emerged that ITV and the BBC could lose the battle for the next World Cup because of a legal loophole in British law.

The so called "listed events" rules guarantee that the crown jewels of sport, including the World Cup, are screened on terrestrial TV.

However, it is feared that Kirch can legally sell the tournament to Sky TV because the law only protects the rights of the BBC and ITV to bid for the matches.

Up until now World Cup rights have been sold to Europe's public service broadcasters. But this time Fifa decided to cash in and sell to the highest bidder.

Dyke said Kirch "asked UK broadcasters for a fee 40 times that paid for the 1998 contest.

"The BBC and ITV have made what we regard as a fair and reasonable offer which is still massively more than we paid in 1998.

"Yet Kirch rejected this and is now planning an auction of the rights in a way likely to counter the intentions of the listed events legislation in the UK."

fields.headline: Cook pledges support in Macedonia
fields.trailText: Macedonia must not allow terrorists to succeed in destroying its multi-ethnic society, Robin Cook said today.
fields.body:
Macedonia must not allow terrorists to succeed in destroying its multi-ethnic society, Robin Cook said today.

The foreign secretary pledged that Britain would continue to take "every practical measure" to improve the situation in a bid to curb the conflict in Macedonia.

Mr Cook told the Commons that Britain's commitment to a new battle group within K-For of 400 troops to help secure the Kosovo/Macedonia border had been "well received".

The redeployed British troops in Kosovo will attempt to stop the infiltration of ethnic Albanian gunmen.

Mr Cook said he had told Macedonian president Boris Trajkovski of the importance of keeping the operation "proportionate to the threat" and to restrain from action that could cause civilian casualties.

"I am pleased to report that on information currently available to us, there have been no civilian deaths," Mr Cook said.

Updating MPs on the current situation in the region in an emergency statement, Mr Cook said: "On Sunday the army in Macedonia launched an operation to retake the hills above Tetovo.

"The operation appears to have been a success and the armed extremists have abandoned their positions."

Mr Cook said he had spoken to Javier Solana, the European Union's security affairs chief, in the Macedonia capital of Skopje.

"We both agreed the important priority now for the government of Macedonia is to follow up the military action by taking a political initiative to meet the legitimate aspirations of the Albanian minority," he said. "In the meantime, Britain will continue to take every practical measure to improve the situation on the ground."

Mr Cook said: "Over the past two years we have turned the tide against the nationalists who took to violence in pursuit of a greater Serbia or a greater Croatia.

"We must now be equally firm against extremists who are using terror in pursuit of a greater Albania.

"The period in which borders in the Balkans were redrawn in blood is over and will not be allowed to return," he added.

Earlier today, Mr Solana reaffirmed his push for a peaceful solution to the conflict, urging the Albanian rebels to let the political process run its course.

"You have to achieve a solution to these problems - not by weapons, but by negotiations, by participation in the political process. This is what Europe is all about," Mr Solana said after meeting with ethnic Albanian leader Arben Xhaferi.

He declined to comment on proposals put forth by Mr Xhaferi, whose Democratic Albanian party is a partner in the coalition government. Mr Xhaferi had proposed talks aimed at changing the constitution to ensure a multi-ethnic state, proportional representation in political bodies and a new census.

The former Yugoslav republic was quiet for a second day, but in neighbouring Kosovo, German K-For troops said they were holding 30 suspected rebels intercepted in the mountains of the Serbian province.

Meanwhile, some of the 30,000 Macedonians who fled from their homes this month because of fighting around Tetovo have started returning to the country's second-largest city, a UN official said.

fields.headline: Regulators await Tory 'race' broadcast
fields.trailText:
4pm update: William Hague will not be able to get his latest party political broadcast on TV if it can be deemed racist, reports Claire Cozens.

Mar 27: Loach to direct election broadcast

Mar 27: Tory broadcast plays race card

Mar 27: Jury out on Labour anthem

Mar 27: Guardian launches politics site

Guardian Unlimited Politics
fields.body:
William Hague will not be able to get his latest party political broadcast on TV if it can in any way be deemed racist.

The BBC and regulators for commercial stations operate strict rules banning anything likely to stir racial hatred.

Last night it emerged that the Conservatives plan to play the race card during the election.

Documents leaked to the Guardian's politics website show agents for the Tories are trying to recruit actors who look like eastern Europeans to star in their TV broadcast.

The Independent Television Commission today confirmed that broadcasters are responsible for ensuring the PPBs they transmit do not contravene its programme codes.

A controversial new party broadcast being put together in secret by the Conservatives will show a group of eastern European asylum seekers trying to enter Britain from France.

This could go against the watchdog's codes, which state that "no programme should be transmitted which is intended to stir up racial hatred or, taking into account the circumstances, is likely to do so".

The ITC also stipulates that stereotyped portrayal of racial minorities should be avoided.

"The parties are responsible for the content of PPBs although the broadcasters have an obligation to observe the law," said a BBC spokesman.

"That would clearly include avoiding incitement to racial hatred. The political party would also have to comply with the broadcaster's own taste and decency guidelines."

The Commission for Racial Equality, which earlier this month persuaded the leaders of all the major parties to sign a pledge not to use the race card during the election, said it was not responsible for policing PPBs.

"At the end of the day it's down to the electorate to make up its mind how it feels about this kind of thing," said a CRE spokeswoman.

fields.body:
Palestinian militants set off two explosions in Jerusalem today, killing the suicide bomber responsible for the second attack and injuring 22 others.

The explosions came six hours apart, the first detonated by remote control near a shopping mall and the second by a man with explosives strapped to his body who blew himself up next a bus. Yesterday Palestinian snipers killed a 10-month-old girl in Hebron.

The attacks coincided with the start of the Arab League summit in Jordan, where the issue of Palestine is expected to be a key focus, and placed growing pressure on the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, to retaliate.

Mr Sharon was elected last month on a promise to restore security to Israelis, but the government has been reluctant to respond during the summit.

"We have a war here," said Jerusalem's mayor, Ehud Olmert, adding that the government had expected an escalation of violence during the Arab summit.

A spokesman for Mr Sharon, speaking before the second bombing, said that Israel would retaliate, but refused to say what steps the government would take.

"I can assure them [the Palestinians] that the response ... will be swift and will be coming," he said.

Commenting from the summit in Amman late yesterday, the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, made no reference to the killing of the Israeli girl, only denouncing Israel's immediate response - the shelling of the Hebron neighbourhood of Abu Sneineh, from which the shots on the Jewish enclave had been fired. Seven Palestinians were hurt in the shelling.

Today's explosion close to the bus went off shortly after 1pm local time (11am GMT) in French Hill, a Jewish neighbourhood in a disputed part of northern Jerusalem. Flames shot up the right-hand side of the bus and its back windows were blown out.

Danny Sarero, 35, said he was standing a few metres away from the bus when he heard the explosion.

"The next thing I knew I saw a person cut in two, a body and a head lying in the street. I've never seen such a thing. Pieces of flesh strewn around for 50 metres," Mr Sarero said. "I'm in shock."

In a leaflet sent to news agencies, a previously unknown Palestinian group calling itself the Popular Army Front claimed responsibility for the blast.

The militant Islamic Jihad group, meanwhile, said it was responsible for a car bomb that exploded at 7.40am (5.40am GMT) in Talpiot, a commercial neighbourhood in southern Jerusalem. Three passengers in a bus that was passing by at the time of the explosion were slightly hurt.

webTitle: Dampener for Grand Duchy's grand illusion

fields.headline: Dampener for Grand Duchy's grand illusion
fields.trailText: Luxembourg's national team has specialised in the sort of extended sequence of defeats that amounts less to a losing streak than a lifelong commitment to the naturism of non-fulfilment.
fields.body:
When you follow a football team that once lost 32 matches on the trot and has spent as long as three decades without a victory it is probable that when you wake up on match day with a warm tingle in your loins you are more likely to attribute it to a bladder infection than expectancy. If that is indeed the case then last Saturday morning urologists in the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg must have been inundated with phone calls from anxious fans.

The cause of the symptoms was that afternoon's game at the Stade Josy Barthel.

Luxembourg's national team has specialised in the sort of extended sequence of defeats that amounts less to a losing streak than a lifelong commitment to the naturism of non-fulfilment. Victories are as rare as rocking-horse manure. In fact, if you are looking to punch the air exultantly in a sporting setting you might do better to devote your time to Afghanistan's ice dance squad than Luxembourg's footballers.

But though managers of the "Red Lions" have adhered to the belief that "there are no easy games in international football these days" since they made their debut in 1914 (the 5-4 victory over France that day proved a false dawn; two world wars had been settled before Luxembourg next registered a win), a home game against the Faroe Islands, ranked a mere 23 places above the grand duchy by Fifa, was seen by local supporters as grounds for optimism.

Indeed, it was widely predicted that the so called "Battle of the Dwarves" would result in the home side's first win in a competitive match since 1996.

Luxembourg's longest winning run was back-to-back victories over Belgium and Norway shortly after VE Day. The team's players regularly let a year elapse between goal celebrations. The fans have got used to seeing their side concede shed-loads of goals against the major football powers; they have come to accept regular defeats in friendly matches against Belgian club sides. Having their confidence shattered was a new experience, however. Which may explain the reaction in M-Block when Christian Jacobsen put the visitors in front in the 75th minute.

M-Block is the home of the M-Block Fanatics, a group of fans whose banners boast the slogan "100% Luxembourg". The group was formed during the qualifying rounds for the 1996 European Championships. In that extraordinary campaign Luxembourg won three matches, amassed a staggering 10 points and actually finished above somebody (Malta) in the table. The M-Block Fanatics produce a fanzine - Huel Se! - that details some of their greatest moments. These include the game against Israel in 1996 during which they hurled 80kg of confetti and the home tie with Germany that saw security guards confiscate 500 toilet rolls from them.

On Saturday security was less vigilant. When the Faroes took the lead the boys in M-Block unfurled a banner calling for the sacking of the national team boss Paul Philipp. It was still there when the whistle blew on a 2-0 away win.

Football fans are often criticised for their impatience. This is not the case with supporters of Luxembourg, who down the years have displayed the sort of stoicism that makes Job look like Basil Fawlty, not least when it comes to the coach.

Philipp has been Luxembourg's manager since 1986. In 1997, impressed by his startling record of three wins in 63 matches, the Luxembourg FA awarded him a new five-year contract.

Philipp, who played in the Belgian first division, is a rotund man with a lugubrious moustache and heavy jowls. He does not look like the sort who would get carried away by anything, except possibly a handsomely stocked sweet trolley. Nevertheless during the early days of the 1998 World Cup qualifying campaign he hailed a 2-1 defeat at the hands of Bulgaria as proof that his team were no longer the whipping boys of European football. It was an assertion his players have been working hard to refute ever since. Last year even Andorra, courtesy of a win over Belarus, had a better record.

Charles-Joseph de Ligne, a Belgian aristocrat who served in the army of Napoleon, once wrote: "Every man has two fatherlands: his own country and France." For the sake of Luxembourg's football fans you can only hope the gallant nobleman was right. At least Les Bleus would give Europe's most long-suffering supporters something to cheer about.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: guardian.co.uk/politics
fields.trailText: What price an e-election, one in which the internet and email have a profound impact on the way our democracy is governed and our leaders chosen? Not much, if the politicians' own track record in handling new media is any guide.
fields.body:
What price an e-election, one in which the internet and email have a profound impact on the way our democracy is governed and our leaders chosen? Not much, if the politicians' own track record in handling new media is any guide. Fortunately they do not have a monopoly on the options. Plenty of wannabe e-politics sites have come and some have gone. Today the Guardian's website, Guardian Unlimited, launches its own politics site. It offers a huge new archive of information and expert opinion about politics and politicians - great and small - their policies, their past, their constituency patches.

To mark the event it will tonight stage a debate at the LSE, the panel graced by Whitehall's e-government supremo, Mo Mowlam. Its title is The Net Election: are you ready? Being famously off-message, Mo may say "certainly not" or "not sure".

That would probably be an honest reflection of the truth. Politicians are not always good at practising what they preach. Until recently when I asked a minister, Tory or Labour, "Can you email other ministers?" they replied "No," even as they exhorted us to join the IT revolution. Now they reply: "Yes, but I never do."

Whitehall departments have made leaps and bounds in creating information-rich websites in the past few years. The political parties all have their own sites, about which the trade press (IT trade, that is, not luddite political hacks like me) are routinely scathing.

In the last 150 years of more or less democratic politics, ministers and MPs have learned the hard way that new technologies matter. They remember who grasped the importance of radio politics (FDR, Baldwin, Hitler), and in the 50s of TV (Harold Macmillan, Jack Kennedy). Richard Nixon, who harnessed advertising techniques to win the White House in 1968, was less of a slouch than his defeat by JFK in the 1960 TV debates suggests. But it doesn't always work out that way with new technologies.

Pagers and mobile phones, as I recall, launched hyper-active campaigning in 1987. Multi-faxing was big in 1992 (I recall accusing Chris Patten of possessing "the smoking fax"), 24-hour rolling news on TV emerged by the 1997 campaign.

But the internet? It was less important than expected in 1997 and less important in the Bush-Gore contest of 2000, despite the 50% rate of home access in the US (30% in the UK) and the undoubted success of Bush's e-train, a sort of email equivalent of a chain letter, carrying the Republican message that every vote mattered.

How right they were! From the parties perspectives new media offers the chance to get out the message without it being filtered through old media (newspapers), to inform and motivate activists, to raise money. They have all got ambitious sites because - like the arms race - everyone else has one.

But it isn't like TV in the 50s, when everyone was watching the same thing. Though messages can be customised at target audiences with ever-greater sophistication, the audience is fragmented. Critics (inside parties as well as beyond) say that net surfers are looking for sports, shopping and sex. Far better to get at the uncommitted floating voter on GMTV or Radio 5 Live or canvassing via a phone bank. "Our secret weapon in this election is the phone," one Labour apparatchik assures me.

And yet ... the parties know people are turned off politics, especially the young least-likely-to-vote voters, the very people most likely to surf the net for information, preferably informal and - that elusive formula - serious and humorous.

That is what Guardian Unlimited's politics site will seek to do. It would be good to help surprise the experts and boost turnout in 2001 - instead of see it drop below 70% (it was 71.5% last time) as widely predicted. In the US in 2000 18% of voters went online for election news and both John McCain and Bill Bradley's insurgencies were part-funded off the net.

Like last autumn's fuel protesters, the May Day anarchists and, globally, the Seattle-Prague protests against world free trade, there is scope for insurgents, for instant, in-depth publication of complex documents, not to mention the kind of probing journalism that Matt Drudge's website (the Drudge report) pioneered in the US.

In short, new media is likely to be a mixed blessing for established parties (and old media). But whether at this election or the next, there is no putting the e-genie back in his cyber-bottle.

The Guardian's new politics website can be found at theguardian.com/politics

Michael White is chairing The Net Election: are you ready? tonight at the LSE.

For more information go to www.theguardian.com/eventsandoffers or phone 0870 906 3768 for tickets

fields.headline: IPPR attacks voter apathy
fields.trailText: Comedians, ministers and musicians are to join forces at a unique event this week to explore fresh methods of enthusing an apathetic generation of first time voters.
fields.body:
Comedians, ministers and musicians are to join forces at a unique event this week to explore fresh methods of enthusing an apathetic generation of first time voters.

The attempt to discover why so few young people are involved in politics will be addressed by home office minister Paul Boateng, singer Billy Bragg, comedian Mark Thomas and TV presenter Tony Robinson.

The move comes after an exclusive poll for Guardian Unlimited, revealing that more than two-thirds of young people were unable to even name their own MP.

However, the internet was of more interest to 18-24 year olds, nearly a quarter of whom said they would be surfing the web for political information during the general election campaign.

Now a delegation of French students and the French minister for urban affairs, Claude Bartolone, are en route to London to share the experiences of France in tackling juvenile apathy.

They will be joined by more than 200 UK young people, plus representatives from Voluntary Service Overseas and anti-violence organisations.

The French contingent operate the Jean Jaures thinktank in Paris which studies political turn-off among the nation's young. Magazine editor Rachel Newsome, recently appointed editor of Dazed and Confused, will also give the audience her ideas on the influence of fashion and politics.

Event organiser Matthew Taylor, of the Institute for Public Policy Research, said: "I hope Friday's event will open up debate on apathy, engagement and protest."

The conference will also look at the anti-globalisation protestors who have targeted meetings of the World Trade Organisation in Seattle, Prague and are now planning for a demonstration at the next meeting in Genoa in July.

Julian Glover, launch editor of Guardian Unlimited Politics website, said: "The IPPR event is precisely the kind that is needed if we want young people to increase their political activity."

fields.headline: Millionaire outpaces BBC1 Manhunt
fields.trailText: 4.30pm TV overnights: BBC1's David Suchet detective drama NCS: Manhunt could not match Silent Witness in the tough Monday 9pm slot, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
NCS: Manhunt opened with just 6.9m viewers and a 28% audience share; while last Monday Silent Witness had 8.8m and 33%, according to unofficial overnights.

Last night's ITV opposition, Who wants to be a Millionaire?, took 9.4m and just under two-fifths of the available audience.

But this still represented a respectable start for NCS: Manhunt, which stars Suchet as the head of a crack police national crime-busting squad and is one of the first of the new breed of 60-minute BBC1 dramas to hit the screen.

Another BBC1 debutante, sitcom Lee Evans - So What Now?, had a promising start last night from 8.30pm, despite losing to ITV docusoap Airline.

The sitcom had 7.6m and a 31% share; while Airline had 8.9m.

fields.headline: Nestle blasts 'inflated' TV prices
fields.trailText:
4.15pm: The advertiser has threatend to abandon TV unless TV companies cut their prices, reports Julia Day.
Mar 13: KitKat games appear on mobile phones
fields.body:
Nestle UK is threatening to stop advertising its brands on TV unless TV companies cut their inflated prices.

Andrew Harrison, marketing director of Nestle UK, said TV costs are twice what they were a decade ago.

"We can't cope with TV cost inflation that is out of all proportion to commercial reality - we'll walk away unless we can realign," said Mr Harrison, speaking to an audience of TV executives at the TV 2001 conference in Madrid.

He outlined the steep drop in Nestle's use of TV advertising: TV accounted for all of the company's marketing budget 10 years ago, 80% five years ago, 67% last year and 65% this year.

Within three years, TV will account for "much less than two-thirds" of the marketing budget.

Nestle UK spends £70m on the televised promotion of brands such as Nescafe, KitKat, Shredded Wheat and Perrier.

Mr Harrison said the TV industry was under threat from an explosion of rival media, the importance of which overshadowed arguments about digital TV and industry regulation.

"I would urge us all to stop focusing on protectionism and regulators and, instead, focus on the delivery of integrated cross-media plans," said Mr Harrison.

He called for the TV industry to revolutionise the way it sells advertising, saying brand owners increasingly want to buy a share of total media rather than a share of TV media.

KitKat was held up as an example of the direction in which Nestle is moving. Until a couple of years ago, the brand was promoted solely through TV and posters.

Now it uses TV, radio, press, outdoor, sponsorship and new media, including text message games.

Mr Harrison said Nestle has linked up with Emap to promote Smarties through Smash Hits.

fields.headline: Mayor mulls walk-out from London boroughs' group
fields.trailText: London mayor Ken Livingstone's uneasy relationship with the capital's councils looks set to plumb a new low after it emerged that he is considering pulling out of the boroughs' umbrella group.
fields.body:
London mayor Ken Livingstone's uneasy relationship with the capital's councils looks set to plumb a new low after it emerged that he is considering pulling out of the boroughs' umbrella group.

The move was mooted in a paper put to the mayor's management board yesterday. Although Mr Livingstone has yet to take a decision on withdrawing, Greater London Authority (GLA) insiders have confirmed that a walk-out is on the cards.

Mr Livingstone became a member of the Association of London Government (ALG) last year in a bid to ensure smooth working relations with the boroughs, which still deliver the vast bulk of the capital's frontline services. But the relationship has since soured

The boroughs recently fought a battle against Mr Livingstone's budget, playing a key role in scaling back the increase in the GLA's council tax precept to a still hefty 22%.

The association's chairman, Sir Robin Wales, today sounded a conciliatory note. "We are continuing to seek to work with the mayor and the GLA in consultation and in a positive way, as we have done all along. Hopefully, we will find ways to work together. As for whether or not they should withdraw, that is a matter for the GLA," he said.

The ALG's chief executive, Martin Pilgrim, said a pull-out would be "sad", but that the association would continue to work with the mayor whatever happened.

Bodies such as the Metropolitan Police Authority and the London Fire and Emergency Planning Authority would be free to continue their membership, despite being part of the GLA, he added.

However, it seems the boroughs may already have rejected Mr Livingstone's attempts at mediation. The mayor is thought to have attempted to resolve his differences with the ALG and offered them a fresh start in their relationship. Mr Pilgrim said he was unaware of any such move on the mayor's part.

The issue of pulling out has reportedly arisen because some of the mayor's staff are frustrated by clashes with the boroughs over issues that include the budget, a joint strategy to tackle domestic violence and last year's planned New Year's Eve firework display.

Insiders suggest, however, that a walk-out is not yet a foregone conclusion, as Mr Livingstone's advisors are divided on the issue. They say that if the mayor does leave, he will seek to do so in a way that does not embarrass the ALG.

webTitle: Cocktail of problems as drinks firms zero in on youngsters

fields.headline: Cocktail of problems as drinks firms zero in on youngsters
fields.standfirst:
This week sees the introduction across England and Wales of major reforms to tackle juvenile crime and overhaul the neglected and failing youth justice system. In a special series, Guardian reporters look at the causes of teenage offending and how measures to fight it are working.

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: This week sees the introduction across England and Wales of major reforms to tackle juvenile crime and overhaul the neglected and failing youth justice system. In a special series, Guardian reporters look at the causes of teenage offending and how measures to fight it are working.
fields.body:
They call it the Market Square merry-go-round. From Thursday until Sunday night thousands of revellers pour into Nottingham's historic centre and crawl from pub to bar to club.

Those turned away because they are not old enough might visit an off-licence that is prepared to turn a blind eye or persuade an older friend to buy them a bottle, then find a dark corner in which to drink it.

By the time the Market Square clock begins to strike the early hours, most are staggering home or consummating new relationships in doorways. Others are getting into trouble: fighting or smashing windows or hatching drink-fuelled plans to do mischief.

Of course, such behaviour has gone on across the country since the days of Robin Hood, but clever, aggressive marketing by powerful companies may be encouraging youngsters to drink - and get drunk - from a much earlier age. On offer are colourful, potent drinks with fruity flavours that disguise the taste of alcohol. Many are staggeringly cheap. Some are supplied in a new generation of brightly lit bars often providing live sport or music.

Marketing

Others that researchers believe are intended to tempt even younger drinkers are marketed through local shops and off-licences. Most are designed to be swigged from the bottle, making them easier to carry around - and hide if necessary.

A study released to coincide with a World Health Organisation conference in Sweden last month must have made sobering reading for parents. Three in 10 Britons aged 14 to 16 said they had been drunk at least 20 times. Nearly one in 10 said their families did not know where they were on a Saturday night.

Many researchers believe initiation to drink begins around the age of 11 but can come as early as eight. The average amount of alcohol consumed by 11- to 15-year-olds in 1990 was 0.8 units a week, according to the Office of National Statistics. By 1998 it was 1.6 units. About 1,000 children aged under 15 are admitted to hospital every year with alcohol poisoning.

Why are young people drinking more and earlier? Strathclyde University researchers, in a study published in the magazine Addiction, examined in detail how drinks are marketed. They found that in Britain consumers, especially young people, appeared more willing to experiment than their counterparts in other countries. This was encouraging global producers to use British drinkers as guinea pigs.

The study traced back drinking preferences among the young to the late 1980s, when strong, clear ciders and fortified wines with exciting names and bright packaging came on the market. The mid-1990s were the heydey of these alcopops, and by 1998 Britain's market in so-called flavoured alcoholic beverages was estimated at £750m. Today a new range of products includes pre-mixed cocktails and strong bottled beers. They share bright labelling and often outlandish names that appeal to the young. Quite how young remains a matter for debate.

The Strathclyde team suggests that products such as Bacardi Breezers appeal to "established drinkers" - the 16- to 24-year-olds. But they believe that another range of stronger drinks is designed to attract "starter drinkers" aged 11 to 15.

One product examined was MD 20/20, or "Mad Dog", a fortified wine with an alcohol concentration of 13.1% imported from America which comes in a range of fruit flavours. The drinks come in clear bottles which show off their bright contents. They have a screw top, so are easy to carry around.

The researchers claim that Mad Dog meets the "needs and taste preferences of experimental drinkers". The taste of alcohol is disguised by the fruity flavours. The high alcohol content satisfies the need for "rapid intoxication". They also claim that the drink tends to be sold through smaller outlets which are less easy to regulate and less likely to enforce age limits.

The Drinks Company, which imports MD 20/20, refused to say how many bottles it sold. Its joint managing director, Mike Gilmer, said there was no research on who drank the product but most drinkers would be over 25. It was "nonsense" to suggest it was aimed at children.

The Portman Group, which was set up by Britain's leading drinks manufacturers and has a panel to examine naming, packaging and merchandising issues, has upheld complaints about some products which it thinks are trying to appeal to a younger crowd. But critics argue that the sanctions it can take are limited, and they are uneasy that the group was set up by manufacturers.

The Strathclyde researchers believe that manufacturers "no longer think of themselves as in the alcohol business but in the mood-altering substance business".

In recent years the Portman Group's panel has upheld complaints against a beer called Cannabis and a lager called Greenleaf Hemp. That importers and manufacturers even thought about trying to get such products into bars and off-licences seems to back up the point.

The trend is particularly worrying because often young people with addiction problems take drugs and drink alcohol.

Back in the centre of Nottingham, the tactics that bars and pubs use to draw youngsters in are obvious. Almost every venue has special offers, happy hours, theme nights.

Libertys, for example, encourages drinkers to its "Frisky" Friday night. Admission is free and patrons can drink until 1am. Metz, a schnapps-based drink, is on offer at two for the price of one. At Weatherspoons pub on the square, its "Famous Five" of beers and ready-mixed cocktails are £1 each "all day, every day".

The Palais nightclub has a range of offers to ensure that the venue is as full as possible all week. Thursday is billed as VFM (value for money) night, when all drinks are £1 before midnight. "Beat the clock," its jazzy website urges.

Violence

The drinks would probably be even cheaper were it not for a "gentleman's agreement" brokered by the police that bars will not sell for less than £1 each. But it does not stop the violence. In 1999 police responded to 1,704 calls to licensed premises in the city centre and made 529 arrests. The pattern is similar nationwide. A prison report found that a quarter of young inmates had been drinking before they committed their crime.

The under-age know where they will be served. Indeed one city guide, itchy nottingham (sic), jokes that one bar accepts "bum fluff moustaches" as a form of ID.

Dave, 18, is a regular of this establishment. "I've been drinking around the pubs and bars in Nottingham since I was 15," he said. "Before that I would get booze from off-licences.

"Of course, there are fights and kids getting into trouble. That's the same the country over. It's what Britain is all about at the weekend, isn't it - getting pissed, causing a bit of trouble, having a laugh."

fields.headline: Election doubts threaten advertising revenue
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: Billboard advertiser Maiden has admitted uncertainty over the election date is holding back business. By Dan Milmo

11am: Maiden doubles profits on poster boom
Guardian Unlimited Politics
fields.body:
Billboard advertiser Maiden Group has admitted that uncertainty over the date of the general election is holding back business.

Ron Zeghibe, chief executive of Maiden, said companies were withholding their summer bookings because the foot and mouth crisis might push the election back to June.

A confident start to the year for the group has seen billboards booked up to 12 weeks in advance, but that figure has fallen to between six and eight weeks as companies wait for prime minister Tony Blair to make up his mind.

Advertisers shy away from booking advertising space during elections, and they are waiting to see if the Labour, Conservative and Liberal Democrat parties clog up the hoardings for May and June.

"Due to election issues, the months of May and June are not filling in yet. If this uncertainty were to take hold,then clearly there could be a short-term knock-on effect," said Mr Zeghibe.

Mr Zeghibe added, however, that the group's strong first quarter sales, up 22% on the same period last year, would guarantee a positive beginning to 2001.

"We have built up such a lead over the past four months that we have a cushion for the first half of the year," he said.

Mr Zeghibe would not reveal exact details of Labour and Conservative party spending on hoarding, but said political bookings for next month are "not even close" to the levels of April 1997, when the last election was called.

The main political parties stand to lose millions of pounds if they cancel their bookings at the last moment, incurring a penalty of 90% of the booking fee.

Conservative party insiders have admitted a delayed election would cause problems, as the Tories have struggled to raise the £15m for a May polling date.

fields.headline: Now Millionaire targets web users
fields.trailText: 2pm: Who Wants to be a Millionaire? is to take the internet by storm next week when it launches the first of four games, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Who Wants to be a Millionaire? is set to take the internet by storm next week when it launches the first of four games designed to hook internet audiences.

The first game, Anytime, which has been running on websites in the US and Germany, has already racked up more than 300m page impressions in six months.

ITV's new website, itv.co.uk, will be the biggest beneficiary of online demand for the games, having bought the UK rights to run internet versions of the show.

ITV's marketing and commercial director, John Hardie, said the game would be a great traffic generator for the website.

"We've done this as a marketing tool to draw people into itv.co.uk, which we're going to build up into a strong entertainment website," he said.

Celador has made millions of pounds from the sale of international TV rights and PC gaming products, but now it plans to cash in on new media by extending its franchise to the internet and interactive TV.

Mr Hardie has already developed a new form of advertising, called an "emercial", which will force internet players to watch a seven-second commercial before they can progress to different stages of the game, although he expects sponsorship to play a large part in driving revenues.

Millionaire's TV production company Celador has profited further from the ITV deal, with the UK two-year rights package thought to be worth around £2m and a revenue-sharing deal with ITV also signed.

The rights package covers interactive TV rights and will be introduced to ONdigital's 1m subscribers in autumn on ITV2, and then extended to cable viewers as soon as Telewest and NTL manages to launch enhanced TV.

The interactive TV service will allow ITV2 viewers to play along with the show on their TV sets.

"This is an excellent opportunity for ITV to take a major step forward in its new media strategy," added Mr Hardie.

Prizes have yet to be determined, but Ellis Watson, managing director of international at Celador, said if the games pulled in a wide enough audience, then there was no reason why the home audience couldn't also play to be millionaires.

Other games developed for Millionaire include one that is synchronised with the TV transmission that allows users to compete with on-air contestants; a multiplay game will allow up to 10 players to compete head-to-head online; and one based around big events.
