fields.headline: White House asks for Beers
fields.standfirst: Profile: Charlotte Beers
fields.trailText:
11.30am: The US president has hired the former chairman of J Walter Thompson to look after America's image abroad, writes Claire Cozens.
Profile: Charlotte Beers
fields.body:
George Bush has hired the former chairman of J Walter Thompson to look after the US's image abroad.

Charlotte Beers, who left JWT last month after her contract expired, will be the next undersecretary of state for public diplomacy, a role that involves taking charge of country's public relations efforts abroad.

She will work for secretary of state Colin Powell as one of just six undersecretaries of state.

Mr Powell has said he wants to promote American values to the world, hinting at a more active role in foreign policy than the US has traditionally played.

Ms Beers has known Mr Powell since the pair served together on the board of Gulfstream Aerospace Corp.

Staff at JWT were informed of the move yesterday in an internal memo from worldwide chief executive Peter Schweitzer.

fields.headline: Profile: Charlotte Beers
fields.trailText: Charlotte Beers has been famously dubbed the most powerful woman in advertising for her high-octane lifestyle, powerful contacts book and stratospheric salary.
fields.body:
Charlotte Beers has been famously dubbed the most powerful woman in advertising for her high-octane lifestyle, powerful contacts book and stratospheric salary.

She started her career as a research analyst at Mars before taking her first job in advertising at J Walter Thompson Chicago.

She rose to become senior vice-president of the agency before joining a smaller agency, Tatham Laird, as chief executive.

In 1988, Ms Beers became the first woman to chair the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

In 1992, she moved to JWT's sister agency Ogilvy & Mather.

At O&M, she was credited with a number of major account wins, including the global IBM advertising account.

In 1996, Ms Beers took a back seat at the agency and went into semi-retirement.

But, three years later, at the age of 63, she was drafted back to JWT as chairman by the agency's owner Sir Martin Sorrell.

Her southern-belle charm has helped Ms Beers achieve what all successful advertising agency executives need - a close enough relationship with her clients to make her indispensable.

But Ms Beers' contract with JWT expired last month and she did not renew it; it appears she now has bigger fish to fry.

webTitle: Poll reveals apathy of first time voters

fields.headline: Poll reveals apathy of first time voters
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Election 2001
See the survey results
fields.trailText: Voter apathy at the next general election is in danger of reaching an all time high, according to the results of a new opinion poll published today.
fields.body:
Voter apathy at the next general election is in danger of reaching an all time high, according to the results of a new opinion poll published today.

The poll reveals more than half of adults and over two-thirds of first-time voters were unable to even name their own constituency MP.

But the study also indicates that politicians who provide information on the internet are more likely to attract young voters. Nearly a quarter of first time voters interviewed said they would use the internet to help them decide how to vote, when Tony Blair finally calls the election.

Commissioned for Guardian Unlimited's new politics site, the poll found that 24% of 18-24 year olds will look online for political news and information about party policies and issues.

"This poll shows that as we approach the general election cynicism and disinterest among young voters is overwhelming", said Benjamin Wegg-Prosser, publisher of Guardian Unlimited Politics.

"At the last election, turnout was just 71.5% and if politicians do not act now we are in danger of seeing turnout dipping well below 70%.

Conducted by ICM, the poll coincides with the launch of the Guardian's comprehensive politics website, theguardian.com/politics.

The site, which provides breaking news, political commentary and analysis, also offers users Ask Aristotle, a political database containing more than 4m pieces of political information.

Users can enter their postcode into the search engine find out a wealth of information about their local MP - such as how they voted on fox hunting, how big their majority is and how voters can contact them. The website, which hopes to boost political involvement, is also home to talkboards, election games and online debates with senior figures from political parties.

Mr Wegg-Prosser added: "Both the media and politicians need to encourage people to find out more about the people who represent them and give them an opportunity to get involved."

Users can enter their postcode into the search engine find out a wealth of information about their local MP - such as how they voted on fox hunting, how big their majority is and how voters can contact them. The website, which hopes to boost political involvement, is also home to talkboards, election games and online debates with senior figures from political parties. Mr Wegg-Prosser added: "Both the media and politicians need to encourage people to find out more about the people who represent them and give them an opportunity to get involved." fields.headline: Hoddle is going, claims Le Tissier
fields.trailText: Southampton defender Claus Lundekvam has revealed that team-mate Matt Le Tissier believes that Glenn Hoddle is on his way to Spurs.
fields.body:
Southampton defender Claus Lundekvam has revealed that team-mate Matt Le Tissier believes that Glenn Hoddle is on his way to Spurs.

"Glenn is a good tactician and he has the ability to bring the best out of the players," said the Norwegian defender.

"I spoke to Matt Le Tissier yesterday, and he thinks Hoddle is off in the summer.

"At Southampton, he won't get the pressure that comes with the Spurs job. But, at the same time, it is his club and I think it will be a hard decision for him."

fields.headline: Guardian politics site makes a splash
fields.trailText:
2.30pm: The website launched yesterday with a high-profile scoop about William Hague playing the race card in his election campaign.
Useful link: Guardian Unlimited Politics
fields.body:
Guardian Unlimited's politics website launched amid a blaze of glory yesterday after one of its four exclusive news stories was followed up by seven media outlets.

The site, at theguardian.com/politics, has already created waves in the political community with last night's scoop about William Hague's plan to play the race card in the forthcoming election.

Guardian Unlimited Politics obtained copies of a leaked fax that intimated the Tory party was willing to pay actors a flat one-day fee of £1,000 for pretending to be immigrants entering the UK illegally.

This footage will be used as part of a Tory party advertising campaign.

"The follow-up to yesterday afternoon's story shows the site is already building a reputation in Westminster and beyond," said site publisher Benjamin Wegg-Prosser.

"If we continue to break stories and give people the sort of information they want about politics, the site has the potential to become the election website for the rest of the country and encourage more people to get involved in politics."

After the election, the site will evolve into more of a social-conscience campaigning website.

In addition to breaking news, it will develop a number of games and special features.

One of the highlights of the website is Aristotle, which has been billed as the real A-Z of parliament.

It is the UK's first extensive database of historic data about every MP and election candidate since 1992. It serves up easy-to-digest information on a postcode basis.

Aristotle, which boasts more than 10,000 individual listings, has taken six months to develop.

Users can also play the Turncoats game, developed in conjunction with the Guardian's daily diary.

It gives visitors the chance to vote for the Turncoat of Turncoats - the politician that has made the most u-turns.

Guardian Unlimited Politics is the Guardian's 14th website.

fields.headline: Spurs speak to Hoddle
fields.trailText: Glenn Hoddle has held talks with Spurs this afternoon to discuss the vacant manager's job at White Hart Lane.
fields.body:
Glenn Hoddle has held talks with Spurs this afternoon to discuss the vacant manager's job at White Hart Lane.

According to today's London Evening Standard, Hoddle and his agent Dennis Roach met with Tottenham vice-chairman David Buchler and stand-in chairman Daniel Levy earlier today, following Southampton chairman Rupert Lowe's decision last weekend to give Hoddle permission to speak with ENIC.

A source close to the club told the Standard: "There was a meeting due to take place this afternoon with the board, Glenn Hoddle and his agent.

"This is extremely good news for the club. We don't know what's going to happen, but the board got permission from Rupert Lowe over the weekend and they have been working on this meeting ever since.

"Everyone is hopeful that we can persuade him to come sooner rather than later, but we will have to wait and see what comes out of the meeting."

Hoddle - who is believed to have an £800,000 get-out clause in his present contract - returned to England yesterday following a holiday in South Africa.

Meanwhile, Ruud Gullit has turned down advances from Spurs because he would prefer a coaching job in the Netherlands.

The former Newcastle and Chelsea manager told local Dutch television that he had been contacted by Spurs, but "would prefer to stay here with all my friends and relatives."

"If I could get a coaching job I would prefer to be in the Netherlands," he added, before complaining that Dutch clubs were more interested in hiring teachers than coaches with playing experience.

fields.headline: Emap cuts online operations
fields.trailText: 11am: Emap, publisher of FHM and Heat, is scaling back its internet-based operations in a move that could cut 100 jobs, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Emap, publisher of FHM and Heat magazines, will today announce plans to scale back its internet-based operations in a move that could see up to 100 job cuts.

The publishing company said it would halve its investment in its online operations over the next financial year to £25m.

In a spring trading statement ahead of its May full-year results, the company's chief executive, Kevin Hand, said Emap was "committed to the digital business, but it would be irresponsible to plough on with projects irrespective".

The reduction of Emap's online operations is likely to result in a one-off cost to the business of £10m in its full-year results.

Meanwhile, Emap has admitted it was considering bids for its US-based magazines division, Petersen.

"The Emap board has received a number of approaches with respect to the group's US operations and is considering all of its options in this regard," said the statement.

Emap acquired the company in 1999 for £720m. It is reported to have received offers ranging from £500m to £700m for the business.

Pressure has been mounting on Emap to sell Petersen, which has suffered heavily from the downturn in advertising in the US.

The purchase of Petersen, along with a problematic advertising sales strategy, has lead to spiralling debts, which are believed to exceed £600m.

The company's share price has fallen in the past year from £17.50 to around £7.

fields.headline: Government to champion equal pay
fields.standfirst: The report in full
fields.trailText: The government today announced plans to appoint "fair pay champions" in an effort to combat the growing wage gap between men and women.
fields.body:
The government today announced plans to appoint "fair pay champions" in an effort to combat the growing wage gap between men and women.

Tessa Jowell, the employment minister, wants UK companies to sign up for a voluntary audit of their pay practices in a bid to beat gender inequality that leaves women earning an average of 18% less than men.

The government took the initiative by setting a two year deadline to reform practices across the civil service. However, the scheme backs away from statutory legislation and instead plumps for a system of voluntary regulation.

The appointments are expected to come from the worlds of business and trade unions and the Equal Opportunities Commission will be given £100,000 to launch a campaign.

Julie Mellor, chairwoman of the EOC, said: "At long last the issue of unequal pay is being brought out into the open."

Business groups welcomed the announcement but other campaigners said that they would prefer legislation to force firms to act. Ms Jowell told a London conference that women were still losing out in the labour market, having less responsibility, lower pay and fewer promotion opportunities.

"Discrimination is still, sadly, one of the factors," she said. "Women are still discriminated against at work because too often the culture is hostile and discriminatory."

Ms Jowell said the 18% pay gap was "stark" and that any gap driven by discrimination was too high. The government had supported a report from the EOC on how to close the pay gap and Ms Jowell said the only area of disagreement was on legislation which she did not believe was the right route forward.

"Many of the problems women face in improving their employment opportunities cannot really be addressed by legislation," she said.

As well as the "fair pay champions", Ms Jowell unveiled plans for new annual awards for employers who act on pay reviews and further measures will be announced at an autumn conference. The awards will be named after Baroness Barbara Castle, who introduced the equal pay legislation in the 1970s.

The TUC general secretary, John Monks, welcomed today's announcement as a "positive step forward" in closing the pay gap.

John Cridland, deputy director general of the Confederation of British Industry, said: "This is a good set of proposals for tackling the gender pay gap which should be both workable for business and effective for women in the workplace."

There are already 10 tsars across Whitehall and the number is set to increase with the new appointments.

The best known tsar to be appointed by Labour since 1997 is Keith Hellawell, the drugs tsar, but there is also a tsar for film, cars, rail, cancer, pigs, homelessness, architecture, crime, efficiency - and even a tsar's tsar, Lord Haskins, who heads the better regulation taskforce.

fields.headline: Q&A: the National Trust
fields.trailText:
What is it?
The National Trust is one of Europe's leading conservation charities, founded in 1895 to preserve places of historical interest or natural beauty for the benefit of the nation.
fields.body:
What is it?
The National Trust is one of Europe's leading conservation charities, founded in 1895 to preserve places of historical interest or natural beauty for the benefit of the nation.

What does it do?

 Owns and protects 248 hectares of land and 600 miles of coastline in Britain.

 Manages over 200 historical properties and their contents including major artworks.

 Leases farmland to over 1000 tenant farmers

 Provides habitats for wildlife.

Who funds it?
It receives no direct state grant or government subsidy for its general work, instead relying on funds generated from its 2.64m members and other supporters through membership, gifts and legacies. It also receives income from entrance fees, holiday lettings and sales of merchandise.

Over 38,000 people also volunteer their time for the trust contributing more than 2.25m hours of work annually.

What are its sources of income?

Sources of income in 1999-2000:

Membership £60m

Legacies £34m

Investments £26.4m

Rents £21.5m

Grants £14.5m

Shops, etc £11.7m

Appeals etc £20m

Expenditure in 1999-2000:

Coast and countryside £43.8m

Historic buildings and collections £45.7m

Property management £20.2m

Acquisitions £12.5m

Gardens £10.7m

Conservation, maintenance and administration £15.7m

Does it have any powers?
It has a unique power incorporated in an act of parliament to declare property inalienable, which means it cannot be voluntarily sold or mortgaged. The trust is also able to object to compulsory purchase orders of its own land by invoking special parliamentary procedure.

Who manages it?
A board of 52 trustees oversees the work of its new director-general, Fiona Reynolds.

Who set it up?
It was established by three philanthropists, Octavia Hill, Sir Robert Hunter and Canon Hardwicke Rawnsley, who were concerned about the impact of industrialisation in the late 1800s.

How many people work for it?

It has 3,800 staff and 38,000 volunteers who help run its properties. Its ruling trust has 52 members.

fields.headline: Northern Ireland resumes livestock exports
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth crisis
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland livestock industry was today given the green light to resume exports to Europe after being granted regional status, the province's agriculture minister, Brid Rodgers, announced.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland livestock industry was today given the green light to resume exports to Europe after being granted regional status, the province's agriculture minister, Brid Rodgers, announced.

The decision was made after Department of Agriculture officials successfully argued their case at the European Commission standing veterinary committee in Brussels.

Ms Rodgers said that the ban on meat, livestock and dairy products from most of Northern Ireland would be lifted from April 3 if there are no further outbreaks of foot and mouth disease.

While in mainland Britain 648 cases of foot and mouth had been confirmed by this morning, there has been only one confirmed outbreak in Northern Ireland, at a sheep farm in Meigh, South Armagh. The resumption of exports does not cover the Newry and Mourne area, which includes the affected farm.

The province's first minister, David Trimble, said, "A degree of normality will return. Regionalisation applies to everywhere except for Newry and Mourne.

"We will pursue the issue with regard to Newry and Mourne as we can but may I also say that it is very necessary for people to remain vigilant because the one thing we do not want now is to have any spread of this disease at all in Northern Ireland."

Elsewhere in Northern Ireland, farmers today blocked attempts to dig pits for the burial of culled sheep. They prevented the start of work in Slieve Gullion forest park in south Armagh, not far from the farm at the centre of the province's only outbreak of the disease.

Farmers claimed the digging would destroy an area of outstanding natural beauty and roads were reportedly blocked to prevent lorries and digging equipment being moved into the park.

This afternoon in London, the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, is expected to pinpoint illegally imported meat as the likely source of the outbreak.

A damning official account will claim that pigs were fed meat that was illegally imported for possible use in a Chinese restaurant, he will tell the Commons. Mr Brown is expected to announce a ban on pigswill.

A container of the meat clearly labelled for a Chinese restaurant was reportedly found hidden inside a load of household goods after confirmation of a case in Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland.

The disease is thought to have infected livestock after it was put in pigswill - produced under licence from the Ministry of Agriculture for fewer than 100 farmers. As the crisis continued to escalate, the army said it was preparing to assist in the mass slaughter of healthy animals at a burial site in Cumbria.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, added that enforcing the slaughter of all infected animals within 24 hours would reduce the spread of the disease. His official spokesman admitted that a vaccination programme to control the virus was being given serious consideration.

webTitle: Four Four Two appoints new editor

fields.headline: Four Four Two appoints new editor
fields.trailText:
2.15pm: Four Four Two, Britain's biggest-selling football magazine, has appointed Mat Snow as editor, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 26: BBC gives MoTD magazine the boot
fields.body:
Haymarket's Four Four Two, Britain's biggest-selling football magazine, has appointed former Mojo editor Mat Snow as its new editor.

Mr Snow replaces Michael Hann, who is leaving to edit the Guardian's The Editor.

Mr Snow, a stalwart of the music press and latterly editorial consultant for Sally O'Sullivan's Cabal Communications, has never edited a football magazine before but admitted "it's always been my vice".

He said he wanted to bring the humour that has been the trademark of music magazines like Q and Mojo to the magazine.

"For most football fans - unless you support Manchester United - you are losing most of the time, which breeds gallows humour," said Mr Snow.

"It's a state veering between desperation and grim determination."

Four Four Two recorded a 6% year-on-year fall in circulation at the last ABCs to a circulation of 82,539.

Football titles across the board suffered badly at the ABCs, with BBC Worldwide's Match of the Day announcing this week it would close following a 25% circulation fall.

fields.bodyText: Haymarket's Four Four Two, Britain's biggest-selling football magazine, has appointed former Mojo editor Mat Snow as its new editor. Mr Snow replaces Michael Hann, who is leaving to edit the Guardian's The Editor. Mr Snow, a stalwart of the music press and latterly editorial consultant for Sally O'Sullivan's Cabal Communications, has never edited a football magazine before but admitted "it's always been my vice". He said he wanted to bring the humour that has been the trademark of music magazines like Q and Mojo to the magazine. "For most football fans - unless you support Manchester United - you are losing most of the time, which breeds gallows humour," said Mr Snow. "It's a state veering between desperation and grim determination." Four Four Two recorded a 6% year-on-year fall in circulation at the last ABCs to a circulation of 82,539. Football titles across the board suffered badly at the ABCs, with BBC Worldwide's Match of the Day announcing this week it would close following a 25% circulation fall. Related story Mar 26: BBC gives MoTD magazine the boot

webTitle: National Trust to close London headquarters

fields.headline: National Trust to close London headquarters
fields.trailText: Exclusive: Hundreds of staff have been told to relocate to Bath or face the sack as part of a massive efficiency review. Nicola Hill reports.
fields.body:
More than 200 staff at the London-based headquarters of the National Trust, one of the UK's wealthiest charities, have been told to relocate to Bath or face the sack as part of a massive efficiency review.

Staff based at Queen Anne's Gate were told in a three-hour meeting yesterday that they could either relocate or accept a severance package. The move will be phased in over the next two years and be completed by spring 2003.

The plan, unveiled by recently appointed trust director Fiona Reynolds and aimed at "making the trust fit for the 21st century," is understood to have been met without enthusiasm by many trust staff.

An inside source said: "We are all shocked, it is going to be very difficult as most staff don't want to move out of London. But we were told if we don't move then we lose our jobs, there is no choice. People don't know how much money they will get from severance pay, but I don't think it will be great."

"Managers are worried about how to motivate staff when they know everyone will be looking for another job. The trust will lose a lot of its knowledge base.

"People understand the need to modernise as it is archaic, bureaucratic and steeped in old traditions, it is not about old country houses, we need to forge new partnerships and compete with other charities."

Four regional offices will close with Cornwall and Devon merging and a west Midlands office subsuming surrounding offices. Operations teams based in Cirencester, Gloucestershire and Westbury in Wiltshire will also be relocated to Bath.

Martin Drury, the trust's director general who left last year, commissioned the operational review. His successor, Ms Reynolds, joined in December 2000 and will carry forward the plans.

A spokeswoman, Sarah Clifford, said: "There has not been a review for 30 years and the trust wants to make sure it is fit for the 21st century. The aim of the review was to become as efficient as possible, not to cut costs."

However, she said there would be "six figure" annual savings as a result of the review after initial costs of severance pay and relocation were met.

Over the next few months, three new "territorial directors" will be appointed to cover the north, south and west - the east will be managed by the south's director.

Estates and historical management will merge to form a new conservation services directorate. This department will oversee the gardens, art, farmlands and houses owned by the trust.

Meanwhile the trust is facing a multi-million pound loss in income as a result of foot and mouth disease. The charity is suffering financially through the closure of holiday cottages and historical properties and the cancellation of fundraising events.

Easter is a peak time for the trust and it would normally open up to 160 properties after the winter closures. Mr Clifford said that if foot and mouth was still causing the closure of properties and cottages at the end of May the trust stood to lose £10m.

The National Trust was founded in 1895 and is one of Britain's richest charities, reporting general funds of £738,292m in the last financial year. It protects 248,000 hectares of land and 600 miles of coastline in Britain.

fields.headline: Anti-nuclear protests hit Germany's Greens
fields.standfirst: Environmentalists have voted to demonstrate against a decision taken by one of their own leaders, reports John Hooper
fields.trailText: Environmentalists have voted to demonstrate against a decision taken by one of their own leaders, reports John Hooper in Berlin.
fields.body:
It should all be fine. Germany's Greens should be riding high.

Their central reason for going into government in coalition with Gerhard Schröder's Social Democrats was to secure a timetable for the fading out of nuclear power, and that has been achieved.

In a number of ways, moreover, recent developments - the rise in oil prices, a string of climatic disasters, and the outbreak of first BSE and then foot and mouth disease - can be seen as vindicating the environmentalist cause in Germany. As an added bonus, the discovery of BSE has led to the appointment of a green "super-minister", Renate Künast, who has been made responsible for agriculture, food and consumer protection.

Yet Germany's Greens are once more in crisis. On Sunday, they put in a dismal showing at regional elections in Baden-Württemburg and Rhineland-Palatinate, losing almost a third of the votes they won at the last poll in 1996.

At the same time, one of the party's representatives in cabinet, the environment minister, Jürgen Trittin, is fighting for his political life.

Why? Partly, it is down to Mr Trittin's own imprudence. When a leading member of the opposition Christian Democrats said recently that he was proud to be a German - a sentiment which, because of Germany's ugly past, is rarely voiced by anyone outside the extreme right - Mr Trittin used an equally loaded phrase, denouncing him as a "skinhead". Even otherwise sympathetic commentators have agreed with the Christian Democrats that his remark was unacceptable in a society where "skinhead" clearly means neo-Nazi.

But the main reason Mr Trittin and the Greens are in such difficulties is because of nuclear energy. There is something about it that makes it peculiarly lethal to politicians and political movements. Unlike glib slogans and campaign promises, its timespan is to be measured, not in weeks or even years, but decades and sometimes millennia.

Mr Trittin may be the architect of Germany's nuclear phase-out but, as events this week have shown vividly, he is saddled with the long half-life of decisions taken by earlier governments in the matter of nuclear reprocessing.

Germany has given waste to France which it is contractually bound to take back - waste which it previously stored at Gorleben, a town on the northern German plain. After violent protests near the dump in 1997, shipments were suspended on the grounds that leaks had been detected in the containers. But sooner or later, a decision had to be taken on when to resume them, and in January Mr Trittin felt brave enough to grasp the nettle.

The results are to be seen in the impassioned protests which resumed as the first containers trundled towards the German frontier.

Demonstrations alone would do Mr Trittin little harm. But his problem is that many of those taking part are members or supporters of his own party - and that they are doing so with the express consent of a recent green congress.

That, though, is a problem too for the movement to which he belongs. Germany's Green party must be among the very few anywhere in the world to have voted in favour of mass demonstrations against a decision taken by one of its own leaders in a government to which it belongs.

It may be that the electors who deserted the movement last Sunday were protesting at Mr Trittin's perceived betrayal of pure Greenery. But it is just as possible that they were withdrawing their support from a movement unable to resign itself to the difficult compromises required of a party of government.

fields.headline: Government clamps down on digital rogues
fields.trailText:
1.45pm: The government is clamping down on rogue TV practices and forcing shops to use 'Kitemark' labelling on digital sets. By Jason Deans.

Mar 27: Broadcasters tackle digital apathy
fields.body:
The government is clamping down on rogue TV practices and forcing all shops to use "Kitemark" labelling on new digital TV sets.

The move comes after culture secretary Chris Smith expressed his anger at shops which run misleading promotions following a trip to buy a digital TV set.

From next month the digital video broadcasting logo will appear on the screens and boxes of all digital TVs.

E-minister Patricia Hewitt will be unveiling a digital TV label later today to help consumers identify genuine digital sets.

UK manufacturers and retailers are working together to ensure all new digital TV sets carry the DVB logo.

A training programme is also to be introduced for sales staff to allow them to explain the advantages of digital TVs over analogue sets.

"As a consumer myself, I know how confusing buying a new TV can be," said Ms Hewitt.

"Often the information consumers need is buried in the small print. The DVB logo, prominently displayed on new digital TVs, will help change that."

The DVB logo initiative has been launched following government concern that consumers are being misled into buying TV sets with digital features under the impression they are getting genuine digital TVs allowing them to received digital only channels such as BBC Choice and ITV2.

fields.headline: Q&A: Rent reform
fields.trailText:
What is rent reform?
The government wants both councils and housing associations to put rents on the same footing by linking rents to property values. In ten years it wants all social rents to be based on a formula that gives a 70% weighting to regional earnings and 30% weighting on the capital value of the homes.
fields.body:
What is rent reform?
The government wants both councils and housing associations to put rents on the same footing by linking rents to property values. In ten years it wants all social rents to be based on a formula that gives a 70% weighting to regional earnings and 30% weighting on the capital value of the homes.

What's the point?
Rent setting in the social sector varies enormously, largely reflecting the various subsidy systems rather any market-sensitive pricing. This variety in rents is seen as one of main stumbling blocks to successfully reforming housing benefit - something that recent governments have tried and failed to do for years. Indeed, the inability of the welfare system to cope with variations in rents is seen as one of the main flaws in Sir William Beveridge's original plans for the welfare state.

Why would reforming rents help reform housing benefit?
Unlike most countries, housing benefit pays up to 100% of tenant's rents. Ministers are worried that this system represents a blank cheque for landlords. There are also concerns that a 100% housing benefit encourages dependency and deepens the poverty trap by creating a disincentive to getting a job - if an unemployed tenant finds a job they usually lose some or part of their housing benefit. The government wants to give tenants a reason to "shop around" for housing, by forcing them to pay some portion of the rent themselves. But before it can do that, rents need to based on a rational footing.

Is housing benefit reform the only reason for change?
No, there is also a growing problem of low demand for social housing. Ministers hope that by cutting rents in unpopular areas, tenants will be encouraged to move back to those areas, especially if they can keep some of the benefit saving by doing so. But housing professionals fear that the changes will further polarise communities by concentrating the poorest families in the most unpopular areas.

If you base social rents on property values won't they go up?
Not necessarily. Earnings have a higher weighting than property values, so ministers claim that rents will still be affordable. Broadly speaking, rents will go up in high property areas and down in poorer areas, but overall the effect of changes will be neutral, and the number of rent increases will be off-set by rents cuts.

Does that mean that housing association rents will be cut and council rents will be raised?
Housing association do have higher rents than councils, but housing association homes tend to be newer and so have higher property values. Broadly speaking, council rents will rise to the level of housing association rents.

How will the changes be introduced?
Target rents are to be set over the next year and landlords will need to set out plans for meeting those targets over the next ten years.

What's the problem?
Broadly speaking, the changes could bankrupt housing associations in the north, and tenants in the south. The government admits that some 710,000 tenants will be worse off under the changes because of rent rises. Housing associations in areas where rents will be cut are worried about their future viability because they have to pay off large private sector loans.

What does the government say to this?
There will be flexibility in the way the changes are implemented. Housing associations will be allowed to apply extensions to the ten-year time frame, and there is also a 5% leeway either way on meeting the target rents. Tenants will also be protected from big rent rises. Rents can only be raised by no more than the rate of inflation, plus a half of 1%, plus £2 a week.

If there is so much flexibility on the one hand and limits to rent rises on the other, how will rents be restructured?
Good question. There are already murmurs from housing professionals that the restructured system will be just as chaotic as the current system, with a lot of upheaval along the way.

Can landlords refuse to comply?
If councils fail to restructure rents they will be penalised in the allocation of funds. But the sanctions against housing associations are less clear. In the past the housing corporation, the regulator, has named and shamed housing associations that charge high rents. The policy may be continued for those who fail to cut rents, but landlords cannot be publicly humiliated for failing to raise rents. The corporation can threaten to withhold funding for new homes to those that fail to comply. But if landlords do not wish to develop, the corporation has very little power.

What do tenants think?
Their views have largely been ignored so far, even though the policy has been sold as one that will bring greater clarity and choice to tenants. Now that the implications of the restructuring are clearer, tenants in high price areas are understandably furious that they face rent rises of around £5 a week for the next ten years. But even where rents are set to come down, problems are anticipated, because when tenants are told that the government thinks their rents need to come down they are likely to demand instant reductions rather than cuts phased in over ten years or more.

fields.headline: Qualified triumph for Gladiator
fields.standfirst: Oscar choices cover a wide field as Hollywood braces itself for strikes
fields.trailText: Oscar choices cover a wide field as Hollywood braces itself for strikes
fields.body:
So the gladiator finally defeated the tiger although he had to fight his way through heavy traffic to do so. But hovering over the night of Oscar celebrations was a feeling that this might be the last big bash before the lights go out in Hollywood. Prognostications were gloomy from both writers and actors who are due to go on strike from as early as May 2 if agreements are not reached in the meantime.

The 73rd academy awards ceremony saw victory in the best picture category for Gladiator, the film directed by British director Ridley Scott but no one film dominated. Gladiator took five Oscars to Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon's and Traffic's four apiece.

Julia Roberts, the hottest favourite in any category, won the best actress award for playing Erin Brockovich and in an effusive speech thanked "everyone I've ever met in my life... I love the world". Afterwards she said that during her "out of body experience" receiving the award, she had "shamefully" failed to mention Ms Brockovich, the campaigning legal worker who was the subject of the film.

Russell Crowe took the best actor Oscar for his part in and as Gladiator. He said that the award represented the fulfilment of a dream that, for someone who grew up in the suburbs, must seem "vaguely ludicrous". He added: "For anybody who's on the downside of advantage and relying purely on courage - it's possible."

Crowe appeared unworried by the rumour of kidnap which has hung over him for the past two months and the night's host, Steve Martin, got one of the loudest laughs of the night by suggesting that the FBI had named Tom Hanks as a chief suspect. Hanks obligingly hammed up a look of due shame.

Steven Soderbergh, nominated as best director for both Traffic and Erin Brockovich, won for the former and offered his thanks to "anyone who spends part of their day creating", adding that the world would be "unliveable without art."

Billy Elliot, which had won nominations for Stephen Daldry as best director, Julie Walters as best supporting actress and Lee Hall for best screenplay, came away empty-handed although the nominations in themselves were a remarkable achievement for a film operating on a budget a fraction the size of most of its rivals.

Surprise

One of the few surprises of the evening came when Marcia Gay Harden won the best supporting actress award for her much acclaimed performance in Pollock, the film about painter Jackson Pollock.

Benicio Del Toro won the best supporting actor as predicted in the category in which Albert Finney had been nominated for his Erin Brockovich role. Finney did not attend. Cameron Crowe won the prize for best original screenplay for Almost Famous while Stephen Gaghan won the best adapted screenplay award for his adaptation of the drug saga Traffic from the original British television series. After the ceremony, Cameron Crowe spoke of the threatened strike and said: "I have a lot of sympathy for the writers."

The producer of Gladiator, Douglas Wick, receiving the best picture Oscar, paid tribute to Ridley Scott as embodying the old Noel Coward song Mad Dogs and Englishmen. The costume designer Janty Yates was one of the film's other Oscar winners. Crouching Tiger won Oscars for best foreign language film and art direction.

One of the highlights of the night in the Shrine Auditorium was Björk, dressed with a swan over her shoulder, singing I've Seen It All from Dancer in the Dark, which had been nominated for best song. She said afterwards that acting was "great to try" but she preferred music. Bob Dylan won the award for original song for Things Have Changed in Wonder Boys. and accepted it by satellite while on tour in Australia.

There was an honorary Oscar for the Yarmouth-born Jack Cardiff, the 84-year-old British cinematagropher who won an Oscar back in 1947 for Black Narcissus. Starting as a child actor, he has worked both as a director of photography (on The Red Shoes, Fanny, The African Queen, The Vikings, War and Peace) and as a director (Sons and Lovers, Girl on a Motorcycle). It was the first time that an honorary award had been given to a cinematographer and after receiving it from Dustin Hoffman and a standing ovation from the audience, Cardiff said: "This one tonight is a biggie ... I'm not dreaming but it's mighty close." Producer Dino De Laurentiis won the Irving Thalberg Award for his lifetime's work, receiving his award from Anthony Hopkins. Best documentary went to Into the Arms of Strangers: Stories of the Kindertransport.

A fleet of stretch limos took the guests to the parties. At Vanity Fair's do at Mortons, photographers suffered a feeding frenzy when Liz Hurley and Pamela Anderson arrived together.

Inside, the guests battling their way past the trays of semi-freddo and Francis Coppola Chardonnay included Sean "Puffy" Combs, Donald Trump, and Hugh Hefner.

The party for the Mexican nominee for best foreign film, Amores Perros, produced the best margaritas. But some of the traditional parties had been cancelled as studios tighten their cummerbunds.

The 73rd academy awards ceremony saw victory in the best picture category for Gladiator, the film directed by British director Ridley Scott but no one film dominated. Gladiator took five Oscars to Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon's and Traffic's four apiece. Julia Roberts, the hottest favourite in any category, won the best actress award for playing Erin Brockovich and in an effusive speech thanked "everyone I've ever met in my life... I love the world". Afterwards she said that during her "out of body experience" receiving the award, she had "shamefully" failed to mention Ms Brockovich, the campaigning legal worker who was the subject of the film. Russell Crowe took the best actor Oscar for his part in and as Gladiator. He said that the award represented the fulfilment of a dream that, for someone who grew up in the suburbs, must seem "vaguely ludicrous". He added: "For anybody who's on the downside of advantage and relying purely on courage - it's possible." Crowe appeared unworried by the rumour of kidnap which has hung over him for the past two months and the night's host, Steve Martin, got one of the loudest laughs of the night by suggesting that the FBI had named Tom Hanks as a chief suspect. Hanks obligingly hammed up a look of due shame. Steven Soderbergh, nominated as best director for both Traffic and Erin Brockovich, won for the former and offered his thanks to "anyone who spends part of their day creating", adding that the world would be "unliveable without art." Billy Elliot, which had won nominations for Stephen Daldry as best director, Julie Walters as best supporting actress and Lee Hall for best screenplay, came away empty-handed although the nominations in themselves were a remarkable achievement for a film operating on a budget a fraction the size of most of its rivals. Surprise One of the few surprises of the evening came when Marcia Gay Harden won the best supporting actress award for her much acclaimed performance in Pollock, the film about painter Jackson Pollock. Benicio Del Toro won the best supporting actor as predicted in the category in which Albert Finney had been nominated for his Erin Brockovich role. Finney did not attend. Cameron Crowe won the prize for best original screenplay for Almost Famous while Stephen Gaghan won the best adapted screenplay award for his adaptation of the drug saga Traffic from the original British television series. After the ceremony, Cameron Crowe spoke of the threatened strike and said: "I have a lot of sympathy for the writers." The producer of Gladiator, Douglas Wick, receiving the best picture Oscar, paid tribute to Ridley Scott as embodying the old Noel Coward song Mad Dogs and Englishmen. The costume designer Janty Yates was one of the film's other Oscar winners. Crouching Tiger won Oscars for best foreign language film and art direction. One of the highlights of the night in the Shrine Auditorium was Björk, dressed with a swan over her shoulder, singing I've Seen It All from Dancer in the Dark, which had been nominated for best song. She said afterwards that acting was "great to try" but she preferred music. Bob Dylan won the award for original song for Things Have Changed in Wonder Boys. and accepted it by satellite while on tour in Australia. There was an honorary Oscar for the Yarmouth-born Jack Cardiff, the 84-year-old British cinematagropher who won an Oscar back in 1947 for Black Narcissus. Starting as a child actor, he has worked both as a director of photography (on The Red Shoes, Fanny, The African Queen, The Vikings, War and Peace) and as a director (Sons and Lovers, Girl on a Motorcycle). It was the first time that an honorary award had been given to a cinematographer and after receiving it from Dustin Hoffman and a standing ovation from the audience, Cardiff said: "This one tonight is a biggie ... I'm not dreaming but it's mighty close." Producer Dino De Laurentiis won the Irving Thalberg Award for his lifetime's work, receiving his award from Anthony Hopkins. Best documentary went to Into the Arms of Strangers: Stories of the Kindertransport. A fleet of stretch limos took the guests to the parties. At Vanity Fair's do at Mortons, photographers suffered a feeding frenzy when Liz Hurley and Pamela Anderson arrived together. Inside, the guests battling their way past the trays of semi-freddo and Francis Coppola Chardonnay included Sean "Puffy" Combs, Donald Trump, and Hugh Hefner. The party for the Mexican nominee for best foreign film, Amores Perros, produced the best margaritas. But some of the traditional parties had been cancelled as studios tighten their cummerbunds.  Video footage and exclusive reports from LA at film.theguardian.com/oscars2001 Final tally Gladiator 5 Oscars Traffic 4 Oscars Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon 4 Oscars The awards in full Best Picture Gladiator Best Director Steven Soderbergh (Traffic) Best Actor Russell Crowe (Gladiator) Best Actress Julia Roberts (Erin Brockovich) Best Supporting Actor Benicio Del Toro (Traffic) Best Supporting Actress Marcia Gay Harden (Pollock) Best Original Screenplay Almost Famous Best Adapted Screenplay Traffic Best foreign-language film Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (Taiwan) Best music, song Things Have Changed by Bob Dylan (from Wonder Boys) Best original music Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (Tan Dun) Best costume design Gladiator Best sound Gladiator Best make-up How the Grinch Stole Christmas Best live action short film Quiero Ser (I Want To Be) Best animated short film Father and Daughter Best feature documentary Into The Arms Of Strangers: Stories Of The Kindertransport Best short Documentary Big Mama Best sound editing U-571 Best art direction/set decoration Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon Best editing Traffic Best effects/visual effects Gladiator Best cinematography Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon

fields.headline: Out in the cold
fields.standfirst: Nathan has been excluded from school. When asked why, his father, Michael, says simply: 'The easy way to improve results is to remove the kids with special needs.' Naive? Defensive? Not according to the findings of a new study. Simon Hattenstone reports
fields.trailText: Nathan has been excluded from school. When asked why, his father, Michael, says simply: 'The easy way to improve results is to remove the kids with special needs.' Naive? Defensive? Not according to the findings of a new study. Simon Hattenstone reports
fields.body:
Nathan Hancock is just home from college, and he's feeling good about life. He's only 15 years old, at least a year younger than his fellow students, but he's thinking about getting a job, and making something of himself. If you'd met him last year, he would have told you a very different story.

It was 1998 when Nathan's comprehensive school said they no longer wanted him there. At first they didn't officially exclude him; they simply told him not to bother coming in any more. There had been a fight between two other boys, and somehow Nathan ended up being blamed for it although he always said he'd been in the room next door. There had been earlier incidents at the school involving Nathan, but nothing serious.

Nathan has attention deficit disorder. Michael, his father, says what this means is that he's somewhat hyper, a bit of a fidget, but not malicious, not a bad boy. Nothing the teacher shouldn't be able to cope with. But, as with so many children who have special educational needs or emotional and behavioural difficulties, the teachers couldn't cope. A new report from the Children's Society reveals that a hugely disproportionate number of the children excluded from school have special needs. While 3% of schoolchildren are classed as having severe special needs, 40% of the 80 pupils surveyed for the report, Outside, Looking In, had such needs. A further 15% were on the code of practice, meaning some degree of special needs had been acknowledged.

Often, pupils only get a statement of special needs after their exclusion, which means their learning difficulties have gone unrecognised at school. It can be a vicious circle. If children with learning difficulties are not being looked after, their behaviour is likely to deteriorate, and when they are excluded their learning difficulties almost invariably increase.

Nathan was one of 10,400 young people excluded in England in 1998/99. Although figures have fallen from a 95/96 peak of 12,500, they are still almost four times what they were at the beginning of the 90s. Only 14% of those children permanently excluded were reinstated. Some 69% of exclusions were because of actual or threatened aggressive behaviour. While many of the exclusions concerned children with learning difficulties, some excluded young people were at the opposite end of the spectrum - they were so bright that school bored them and they became a nuisance. The report also shows that black pupils are about six times more likely to be excluded than white pupils - Afro-Caribbean boys are up to eight times more likely to be excluded. This disturbing statistic has been well documented previously.

Like many excluded children, the school labelled Nathan a bully while he said that actually he was the victim of bullying - not just by his peers, but by teachers as well. "The teachers would call me an idiot and say you need drugs because you can't control your temper." He was prescribed Ritalin. "And when I did need help with my work, when I couldn't understand it, they'd just say 'Go and take some pills, Nathan'."

Nathan was bigger than most of the lads at his school - at 15, he's already over 6ft. His dad says all the men in his family are big and broad. And that may be part of the problem. Nathan looks like a toughie. It's hard to believe that a boy-man like him could be bullied. But then you hear him speak and it's all too feasible. He talks in a soft Cornwall burr, and sounds so vulnerable. His dad calls him a gentle giant.

"It starts to get to you, and it makes you feel degraded, like you're not wanted," says Nathan. "It's horrible. I got depressed sometimes and felt, what's the point in going on? I'm going to be one of those people sleeping on the streets. No school, no job, no nothing." You can hear the hurt, and the fear, in his voice.

In the three years he has been away from school, Nathan has received around three hours a week of education. The school is supposed to ensure that excluded children receive 25 hours a week of education while away. On average, they get just four. "It was nothing," says Michael Hancock. "We did everything, sent letters to David Blunkett, but still there was nothing."

Both Michael and Nathan feel the exclusion was unfair and could have been avoided. Chris Osborne, the Children Society's programme manager for Right To Education, couldn't agree more."The whole process of exclusion leaves children and parents isolated. It isn't achieving anything for anyone. We are dealing with some of the most marginalised people in society; the more they are left out the more it leads to problems for these children and society."

The Children's Society has set up its Genesis project to help reduce the number of exclusions. The project works directly with schools (four, so far), and takes a long-term holistic approach because most of the problems, whether they have their roots in behaviour or learning difficulties or family background, are long-term.

Keith Ajebo, headteacher of Deptford Green, says his school has benefited hugely from the project. His school is in an area that has seen exclusions on a shocking scale. At Oliver Goldsmiths, the primary school Damilola Taylor attended before he was murdered last year, there were a reported 150 exclusions after a new headteacher took over. By contrast, Ajebo says Deptford Green excludes one or two kids a year. "We can pick up more of the people at the edges."

Ajebo says the project has enabled him to unite the disparate agencies there to help troubled children - drugs counsellors, truancy workers etc. "There are now six or seven professionals at the school who are not teachers, and staff can refer kids directly to them. Say if a pupil's mum had died, or they were a little wild, or they'd been chucked out of home, there is always someone here who can deal with it."

Ajebo believes a head must ultimately have the power to exclude. "When a child's presence is damaging the education of others you have to take that decision," he says. In 1999 it was made easier for heads to permanently exclude pupils and harder for parents to appeal against the decision.

Yet the government insists that cutting the number of exclusions is a priority. Something doesn't quite add up. Carol Hayden, co-author of Outside, Looking In, says there are conflicting aims. On one hand the government and many parents judge a school purely on its results, on the other schools are being asked to integrate children with severe behavioural and educational difficulties. "Schools are really valued on their ability to normalise behaviour," says Hayden. So when faced with children with real difficulties, it is easier to dismiss them as naughty. "The government assumes a middle-class consen sus about measuring intelligence and rewarding achievement while wanting to be inclusive."

Is that impossible? "No, it's not impossible. But we need a wider range of opportunities on offer. Ironically, we had this in schools before the national curriculum. It used to be much more about teaching children than teaching subjects. Many teachers would say that the national curriculum is the biggest restriction in managing different types of learning."

Perhaps the biggest problem is the underlying philosophy of exclusion - to punish rather than rehabilitate. "Just look at the word exclusion. It's horrible. If you were a parent and heard your child is too awful to be with other children you'd be devastated."

Michael Hancock is one of the roughly 70% of parents in the report convinced that young people with special needs are more likely to be excluded because of the pressure for results. "Even though money is set aside for special needs, they don't want special needs in schools. It's too much hard work. If you have 100 children and 25 are special needs, and are not going to achieve anything, you've automatically got a 25% failure rate from the start. The easy way to improve results is to remove these children."

The government is well aware of this. Last year it ruled that excluded pupils' results had to be included in its performance tables - to discourage schools from cynical exclusions. But the schools kicked up such a fuss that the government has reversed its decision.

In 1999 Nathan Hancock was readmitted to his old school. Within two days he was excluded after he hit another child (he was provoked, he says). Then there was a flare-up with an ancillary worker, which led to a 15-day exclusion. Before long the head banished him for ever.

Michael Hancock says it was virtually impossible for his son to be reintegrated into the school. First, there was so much hostility towards him and, second, he was always aware that he wasn't wanted. Hancock feels he is partly to blame for the exclusion. "Our ignorance of the system allowed us to be pushed around. It took me four years to get hold of his school records, and they're still reported inaccurately. I also discovered he was supposed to have anger management from the school and never received it."

Nathan is still bewildered about his exclusion. "I didn't do anything excludable," he says categorically. "I really did want to be there. All my friends were there. It was quite fun, and sometimes I was learning stuff. They didn't want me there, so they just ditched me."

It was only when his father began to exercise his rights that the council came up with a solution for Nathan. They have provided the cash for him to attend college three days a week. Here he is learning about building and computers, and he loves it. He says he's treated with respect and feels transformed by the experience. "They say if you fail once don't worry, try again. You can't go wrong with that, can you? I've got a lot of confidence in myself. I'm definitely going to get a job now."

 Outside, Looking In: Children's and Families' Experience of School Exclusion by Carol Hayden and Simon Dunne is published by the Children's Society, price £14.95 (plus £1.50 p&p).

webTitle: Casting news: Stallone wants Streisand to be his mum

fields.headline: Stallone wants Streisand to be his mum
fields.standfirst: Plus: Walken slims down for Fatboy; Brit stars join Ripley franchise; Ellen Burstyn goes to the dogs; Sissy Spacek may have a Tuck Everlasting; Arnie sizes up director for T3
fields.trailText: Plus: Walken slims down for Fatboy; Brit stars join Ripley franchise; Ellen Burstyn goes to the dogs; Sissy Spacek may have a Tuck Everlasting; Arnie sizes up director for T3
fields.body:
 Sylvester Stallone is at work on a movie about his mum - and he wants Barbra Streisand to star. The two stars are discussing co-producing a film detailing Mrs Stallone's life from her days as a trapeze artist. "Sly is and always has been close to his mother," says a source close to the project. "He is thrilled about the idea of somebody like Streisand being involved."

 Christopher Walken is to feature in Fatboy Slim's new video. The promo for the single Weapon of Choice, which is to be directed by Being John Malkovich helmer Spike Jonze, will feature the scary-eyed actor dancing alone in an empty hotel lobby.

 Ray Winstone, Dougray Scott and Lena Headey are to join John Malkovich in Ripley's Game, Liliana Cavani's new thriler based on Patricia Highsmith's Ripley novels. Malkovich stars as the anti-hero Tom Ripley, played by Matt Damon in Anthony Minghella's recent adaptation of The Talented Mr Ripley. A source told ananova, "If all goes well this will be the start of a series of movies on Ripley, a kind of Man of the Millennium. Hannibal has proved how popular killers can be."

 Oscar nominee Ellen Burstyn will star in and co-produce Their Last Chance, based on the true story of the redemption of a hardened woman criminal. Laura Dern co-stars as real-life reformer Sister Pauline Quinn, who created a scheme designed to help female convicts train dogs that are used to help the disabled. "Through their work with dogs the women experience unconditional love for the first time in their lives and are finally able to open up emotionally', says Burstyn. Hmmm.

 Sissy Spacek may star in Disney's Tuck Everlasting, alongside William Hurt and Ben Kingsley. Spacek is in line for the role of the mother of a family who have a secret spring on their property that is a fountain of youth.

 U-571 director Jonathan Mostow is in negotiations to helm Terminator 3. Mostow has had several meetings with Arnold Schwarzenegger, but sources say a final deal has yet to be concluded. Although it is believed to have Schwarzenegger's commitment, T3 doesn't have domestic distribution sewn up yet, so Mostow's involvement may prove to be conclusive in that regard.

webTitle: At least eight killed in Belgian train crash

fields.headline: At least eight killed in Belgian train crash
fields.trailText: A crowded commuter train in Belgium today slammed head on into an oncoming train which was on the wrong side of the tracks, leaving at least eight people dead, including one child.
fields.body:
A crowded commuter train in Belgium today slammed head on into an oncoming train which was on the wrong side of the tracks, leaving at least eight people dead, including one child.

Several people are injured and the death toll was expected to rise as emergency services cut into the wreckage to search for more bodies or survivors.

An empty train was riding on the wrong tracks at about 55mph when it crashed into a train crowded with rush-hour passengers in the village of Pecrot, some 15 miles east of Brussels, said Ms Leen Uyterhoeven, spokeswoman for the national SNCB-NMBS rail company.

"There was a noise like two giant tin cans crashing together," said local resident Anna-Marie Choumuerthe. "I went out to see what happened. I heard and saw people at the windows screaming."

Four hours after the 8.45am (0645 GMT) crash, rescue workers where still trying to get to some of the 80 passengers from the twisted carriages. The injured were ferried to several local hospitals.

Both drivers were killed alongside one other railroad official and Ms Uyterhoeven said at least eight other passengers were seriously hurt.

The four carriages of the southbound passenger train were crushed on impact as the empty train careered into them, ending up on top of one passenger car. The mangled leading carriage of the empty train was pointing skyward resting on the other train below.

"It's more than certain a human error was at the origin," the chief operating officer of SNCB-NMBS, Etienne Schouppe, said.

Belgium's King Albert and Queen Paola visited a crisis centre, set up in the nearby town of Wavre, where survivors, passengers in shock and families of victims were being cared for. The prime minister, Guy Verhofstadt, has headed to the scene, delaying a trip to central Europe.

In the early afternoon, rescue workers were still picking bodies out, wrapping them in silvery grey body bags and taken away on stretchers.

The disaster could have been worse because while the trains tottered, they stayed on rails. If derailed, they would have rolled off the embankment on to the village houses below.

"I saw a black cloud of smoke rise up, the train was rocking back and forward, wobbling," said local resident Ameile Jassont, 54, whose home stands next to the track. "It all happened so fast."

In 1974, eighteen people died when a train derailed in southern Belgium, the last major accident in Belgium.

Several people are injured and the death toll was expected to rise as emergency services cut into the wreckage to search for more bodies or survivors. An empty train was riding on the wrong tracks at about 55mph when it crashed into a train crowded with rush-hour passengers in the village of Pecrot, some 15 miles east of Brussels, said Ms Leen Uyterhoeven, spokeswoman for the national SNCB-NMBS rail company. "There was a noise like two giant tin cans crashing together," said local resident Anna-Marie Choumuerthe. "I went out to see what happened. I heard and saw people at the windows screaming." Four hours after the 8.45am (0645 GMT) crash, rescue workers where still trying to get to some of the 80 passengers from the twisted carriages. The injured were ferried to several local hospitals. Both drivers were killed alongside one other railroad official and Ms Uyterhoeven said at least eight other passengers were seriously hurt. The four carriages of the southbound passenger train were crushed on impact as the empty train careered into them, ending up on top of one passenger car. The mangled leading carriage of the empty train was pointing skyward resting on the other train below. "It's more than certain a human error was at the origin," the chief operating officer of SNCB-NMBS, Etienne Schouppe, said. Belgium's King Albert and Queen Paola visited a crisis centre, set up in the nearby town of Wavre, where survivors, passengers in shock and families of victims were being cared for. The prime minister, Guy Verhofstadt, has headed to the scene, delaying a trip to central Europe. In the early afternoon, rescue workers were still picking bodies out, wrapping them in silvery grey body bags and taken away on stretchers. The disaster could have been worse because while the trains tottered, they stayed on rails. If derailed, they would have rolled off the embankment on to the village houses below. "I saw a black cloud of smoke rise up, the train was rocking back and forward, wobbling," said local resident Ameile Jassont, 54, whose home stands next to the track. "It all happened so fast." In 1974, eighteen people died when a train derailed in southern Belgium, the last major accident in Belgium. fields.headline: 'Bargain Britain' slashes rates to tempt tourists
fields.trailText:
1.15pm: The UK is to be promoted abroad as a bargain basement tourist destination as a result of foot and mouth crisis, writes Julia Day.

Mar 22: PM unveils £10m campaign to tackle tourist fears

Mar 19: Government defies foot and mouth with tourist campaign

Feb 27: Foot and mouth hits tourism
fields.body:
The UK is to be promoted abroad as a bargain basement tourist destination as a result of the foot and mouth crisis.

Under an initiative called "Great Value Britain", UK hotels are considering slashing room rates by up to 50% in a drive to combat the fall in bookings.

The major hotel chains and small, independent hoteliers alike are prepared to offer huge discounts not just for foreign tourists but for domestic business as well.

As a result, the British Tourist Authority's planned £10m global advertising campaign to say Britain is not closed for business may promote the country as great value to visit.

Traditionally the UK is seen as an expensive holiday destination. Despite this, 4.1m Americans came to the UK last year, contributing £2.5bn to the national coffers.

The Hilton Hotel chain is already offering 50% discounts on group bookings and the chain is considering rolling out discounts for individual visitors.

"We are looking at how we can work with the tourist boards and airlines to help promote the UK as a destination. We are putting our plans together and discounting will be looked at," says a Hilton spokesman.

Marriott, Bass and Forte are among hotel chains discussing a discounting policy with the British Hospitality Association, whose director Bob Cotton accompanied Tourism minister Janet Anderson to the US last week.

Airlines have also been contacted about joining a cut-price campaign.

A BHA spokeswoman said: "All the leading companies are considering it [discounting] and even the smaller rural hotels, who will find it very hard. They will try every method they can."

She said the foot & mouth crisis was beginning to affect hotel bookings in towns and cities as well as rural areas.

The industry now accepts the crisis will run into tourism's all-important Easter period.

"There is no downturn in [foot and mouth] cases. You have to wait for a month to see if the disease is present and Easter is now less than a month away," said the BHA spokeswoman.

webTitle: Tuck shops targeted by Mugabe's men

fields.headline: Tuck shops targeted by Mugabe's men
fields.standfirst: They may sound like a relic of Zimbabwe's colonial past, but the ramshackle general stores are crucial to Harare's economy. Now they are under attack, writes Chris McGreal
fields.trailText: They may sound like a relic of Zimbabwe's colonial past, but the ramshackle general stores are crucial to Harare's economy. Now they are under attack, writes Chris McGreal.
fields.body:
After targeting wealthy white farmers, Zimbabwe's rulers have now declared war on the little 'tuck shop'. Harare's unelected council - or commission, as it is called - has launched a blitz against the wooden and corrugated iron structures scattered along roadsides and throughout the city's poorer districts.

The commission says that they are illegal. The tuck shop owners say that they have no other means of survival, and suspect a mixture of political vengeance and ruthless business interests are behind the destruction.

The 'tuck shop' name might derive from the days of British rule, but in Zimbabwe they are very different from the ones frequented by Billy Bunter and generations of English public school boys.

In Harare, tuck shops are a source of groceries, clothing, even furniture for those who cannot afford supermarket prices or to travel the long distances from townships to shopping centres.

In turn, they provide a means for the growing army of Zimbabweans driven out of work by Robert Mugabe's disastrous land and economic policies - unemployment now stands at 60% - to eke out a living.

So the owners were understandably horrified when council workers descended on hundreds of rickety tuck shops and began destroying them earlier this month.

"They are punishing those of us who are already suffering," said Esther Mlambo, the owner of a tuck shop selling groceries. "They came and destroyed my tuck shop and now I have to try and sell beside the road but I cannot put out all my stocks and the rains are very bad at the moment. We are poor. Why do they pick on us?"

Many of the owners see a political motivation behind the destruction. They believe that the commission is punishing Harare's poor for their overwhelmingly support of the opposition in last year's parliamentary election, which the government only just won - even with a campaign of widespread intimidation, killings and violent attacks on its opponents.

All 19 of the capital's seats went to the opposition Movement for Democratic Change. It has also not gone unnoticed that some of Harare's commissioners own large supermarkets in the areas where the tuck shops were razed, fuelling suspicions that they wanted rid of rivals for customers.

The traders have their own organisation, the Zimbabwe Tuckshop Association, which protested vigorously to the government. The association's president, Shacky Mukwakwami, accused the commission of breaching an agreement that tuck shops could operate in designated areas, and the destruction was finally put on hold.

In a different era, Harare's councillors would have found it hard to defend the attack on the tuck shops. Few of the city's residents object to them. But Zimbabwe's capital is no longer governed by elected representatives.

After the city council was dissolved in 1998 for alleged mismanagement, the government appointed what was supposed to be an interim commission to run Harare.

However, the ruling Zanu-PF party is now so unpopular that it dare not hold another city council election. The appointed commissioners, who are answerable to no one but the ruling party's leadership, have made themselves even more unpopular with increased rates, higher charges for burial services when funerals are ever more frequent and financially burdensome on many families because of Aids, and a doubling of hospital fees.

But, while costs have gone up, services have deteriorated, with parts of the city left without water for days on end and rubbish uncollected. The city's residents association is now threatening a rates boycott while Zimbabwe's consumer council said Harare's commission is worse even than the corrupt council that went before it.

"Judging by its draconian actions, this is a failed commission that only knows how to hike charges while giving pathetic service to residents," it said.

fields.headline: James retains NUS presidency
fields.trailText: Owain James remains the face of the National Union of Students for another year, after the conference in Blackpool re-elected him as president this morning.
fields.body:
Owain James remains the face of the National Union of Students for another year, after the conference in Blackpool re-elected him as president this morning.

Mr James won nearly twice as many votes as his opponent, Helen Aspell, triumphing by 602 to 327.

With his victory, it became clear that NUS would not veer left towards increased direct action or a more combative stance against government.

Although both candidates sought the middle ground throughout the election, Ms Aspinall has been supported by the Socialist Workers' Party and Mr James by the Labour Students  leading the opponents of each to raise concerns about their leadership.

Alan Clark, of the SWP, who is running for the NUS national executive, said Mr James had an identical voting record to the Labour party, even though he claimed to be independent.

"Students are disenchanted with Labour, and so most Labour party members are running as independents," he said.

Ms Aspellês defeat, according to her opponents, may help the NUS avoid being dangerously close to the SWP with whom she shared an election slate, and may help to alleviate fears of a student hard-left backlash against Labour in an election year.

"The biggest threat is that weêd lose the support of other unions, particularly as Helen supports free education. I canêt see teachers supporting us if we demand £8,000 for every student," Mr James said shortly before this morningês election.

John Monks, the general secretary of the TUC declined to comment directly on the election but added: "I can only think that NUS representation is not enhanced if the leadership is a million miles out of step with common unions."

webTitle: The press on foot and mouth

fields.headline: Day 36: how the press is reporting the foot and mouth crisis
fields.standfirst: Never before has the country been so consumed by rural issues. And as with all crises, newspapers can be a valuable barometer of opinion. MediaGuardian.co.uk  will keep you informed with a daily briefing on the press's coverage of the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.trailText: MediaGuardian.co.uk's daily briefing on the press's coverage of the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
Well into its fifth week and foot and mouth continues to dominate front pages and double-page spreads. Curiously, all but two newspapers (the Guardian and the Daily Mail) took the decision to print the photos of the massive sheep grave in Carlisle in black and white.

The Sun
"God bless the British army" oozes the Sun, as a top army brigadier takes command of the foot and mouth situation. "One man like Brigadier Birtwistle is worth a hundred Whitehall bureaucrats." One can only hope "the action man" can live up to his glowing reputation.
The Sun tones down its "Valley of Death" headline by printing the pictures of carcasses being buried in black and white rather than in gory full colour.
Meanwhile, pressure is mounting for Tony Blair to do a U-turn on vaccinating livestock - an option rejected initially because it would mean a ban on exports for three months. Meanwhile, culture secretary Chris Smith is begging holidaymakers not to avoid the British Isles.

The Mirror
The Mirror devotes its front page to urge Tony Blair to put aside foot and mouth and go for a May 3 election, as voted for by its readers. "It would be an unwise Tony Blair who refuses to listen", says Paul Routledge, adding: "Labour must get on top of this crisis."
The Mirror prints gruesome pictures of lambs being buried in sober black and white, under the headline: "It's like finding a cure for the common cold."

Daily Express
What an aching difference there is between a Mirror reader and an Express reader. According to an Express reader poll, a resounding 67% think Tony Blair should postpone the election or risk being labelled "arrogant" because of the foot and mouth crisis.

The Guardian
There is a simple start the government could make to overhaul Britain's food production system - abolish the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food. The Guardian is the only broadsheet to publish the grave pictures in colour and risks offending squeamish readers by opening its account with: "Downwind, there was a smell like diarrhoea and clotted blood". It says should the government delay the election, millions will have already been wasted on the campaign.

Daily Mail
Even gorier: "I expect them [the sheep] to come tumbling out as big balls of fluff. Instead they slide out in one huge glob... and hardly resemble sheep at all."

The Independent
The Independent says a new stench is pervading the countryside - that of a cover-up, with officials refusing to release two separate reports on the farm thought to be the origin of the crisis.

fields.headline: Greens fight 'illogical' broadcasts ruling
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
Special report: Nationalists and other parties
fields.trailText: The Green party is threatening legal action against the BBC and Channel 4 over plans to deny the party election broadcasts.
fields.body:
The Green party is threatening legal action against the BBC and Channel 4 over plans to deny the party election broadcasts.

The Green party of England and Wales, which is fielding 130 candidates in the general election, has fallen foul of rules drawn up after devolution of power to parliaments in Scotland and Wales.

To qualify for election broadcasts on channels and radio stations received across England, Scotland and Wales - including C4, Channel 5 and BBC radio - parties must field candidates in one sixth of seats in each country. The Greens easily pass that threshold in England and Wales, but do not contest seats in Scotland, which are fought by the Scottish Green party.

The Greens claim they are being penalised further because, under special exceptions agreed by broadcasters, the Scottish Nationalists and Plaid Cymru - who by definition do not stand in England - will qualify for nationwide BBC broadcasts because they have more than one MP at Westminster.

The Greens have been advised that they have a legal case under the European convention on human rights.

Penny Kemp, chair of the party's national executive, said: "Unelected and unaccountable officials, on the basis of inconsistent and illogical rules made on their own whim, are basically preventing voters from hearing about the Green party."
