webTitle: Loach to direct Socialist Alliance campaign broadcast

fields.headline: Loach to direct Socialist Alliance campaign broadcast
fields.trailText: Ken Loach, the award-winning film maker, is to make a party election broadcast attacking the Labour party in the forthcoming general election.
fields.body:
Ken Loach, the award-winning film maker, is to make a party election broadcast attacking the Labour party in the forthcoming general election.

The acclaimed director of films such as Kes and My Name is Joe will make his directorial debut for the Socialist Alliance party with a five minute broadcast, to be shown in the run-up to the election.

The 64-year old film maker is already one of a number of high-profile backers of the fledgling party but he has now agreed to make their TV broadcast too.

The film - which is currently being written - will focus on the failures of the Labour government in areas like the privatisation of air traffic control, the public-private partnership for the tube and a lack of investment in public services.

It is the first time the Socialist Alliance has qualified for a broadcasting slot, awarded to parties fielding more than 100 candidates across the UK.

In 1997 election there was controversy over an election broadcast by the British National party, in which leader John Tyndall stood on the white cliffs of Dover and called for voluntary repatriation of immigrants.

Mr Loach made his first party election broadcast for Arthur Scargill in the 1997 contest, who was fighting under the banner of the Socialist Labour party.

Mr Scargill will be fighting again this time around, in Peter Mandelson's Hartlepool constituency, but not as part of the Socialist Alliance.

The election broadcast, which is expected to be shot on a minimal budget just before being transmitted, is being written by the former editor of the Labour left briefing, Mike Marqusee, the partner of Liz Davies, a former Labour party councillor who recently announced her defection to the Socialist Alliance.

Mr Loach, whose latest film Bread and Roses, which details the exploitation of hispanic workers in Los Angeles and comes out next month, joins a "glitterati" of left-wing celebrities supporting the Socialist Alliance, including the playwrights Harold Pinter and Tariq Ali, the journalist, Paul Foot, and the comedian, Jeremy Hardy.

The solicitor representing the Paddington rail crash victims, Louise Christian, is standing for the party in the constituency of the immigration minister Barbara Roche.

fields.headline: SES to buy General Electric's satellite arm
fields.trailText:
11.30am: Societe Europeenne des Satellites, which broadcasts ITV's digital services, is expanding into the US, writes Dan Milmo.
Mar 19: Satellite firm shows its strength
fields.body:
Societe Europeenne des Satellites, the company that broadcasts BSkyB's and ITV's digital services, is to tie up a major US acquisition.

The Luxembourg-based company is buying General Electric's satellite operation for £3.5bn in a deal confirming its status as a global player.

It is understood SES and GE will announce the deal today and they are confident the transaction will receive regulatory approval on both sides of the Atlantic.

As well as its market-leading position in Europe, SES also has co-ownership deals with companies in Asia and Latin America.

The GE acquisition will enable SES to launch its ambitious broadband internet strategy in the US in a bid to outmanoeuvre the powerful cable companies.

Internet services only provide 5% of the company's revenues - which reached £522m last year - but SES is hoping the US market will boost that percentage.

More than 22m European homes use the SES broadband service, which supplies constant internet access.

However, some industry sceptics believe now is the wrong time to launch the service in the US, which is teetering on the brink of recession.

SES sprang to prominence in the UK this month after striking a £100m deal with ITV to beam the network's programmes onto a digital satellite platform.

webTitle: In brief: Kevin Costner falls for Prince Andrew's star quality

fields.headline: Kevin Costner falls for Prince Andrew's star quality
fields.standfirst: Plus: Heidi Fleiss goes by the book; the real Erin Brockovich back in court; Sigourney goes straight to the top in the US; Barry Levinson lashes out at DreamWorks
fields.trailText: Plus: Heidi Fleiss goes by the book; the real Erin Brockovich back in court; Sigourney goes straight to the top in the US; Barry Levinson lashes out at DreamWorks
fields.body:
 People News reports that Kevin Costner has asked Prince Andrew to be in his next movie. Costner famously claims that Princess Diana was planning to star in his sequel to The Bodyguard just before her death. According to Buckingham Palace insiders, the chunky Thirteen Days star openly invited the Queen's second son to: "Be in my next film. You have what it takes to be a star." Costner met the prince at a lunchtime bash at Andrew's Buck House apartments. "Andrew was delighted," confides a supposed aide. "He is quite vain about his appearance, and to be told by someone like Costner that he has star quality at the age of 40 was a massive boost to his ego. The ball is in his court now, but he seems very keen."

 Heidi Fleiss, the notorious Hollywood madam, is writing her autobiography and has been touting the book around a number of US publishing houses. "She's always resisted naming names, but now I think she's ready to," an insider is quoted as saying. "She could really use the money." One publisher she has approached tells People News, "I told her I can't sign her up until I see something in writing. The only chance she has to sell her story is to name names, and they better be boldface names. People are not interested in a Heidi Fleiss self-help book." Fleiss famously provided call girls for a host of well-known Hollywood stars, including Billy Idol and Charlie Sheen, in the early 1990s, before being exposed and sentenced to two years in prison.

 To add insult to injury after being snubbed by actress Julia Roberts - who made no mention of her in her Oscar acceptance speech - the real-life Erin Brockovich is now being sued by her second husband, Steven Brockovich, who is accusing her in the Los Angeles Superior Court of defaming him with claims that he was a bad dad. Brockovich's first husband is currently on trial for attempting to blackmail the crusading heroine with claims that she was having an affair with attorney Ed Masry. Says Masry (played by Albert Finney in the movie) of this latest court case, "[It's] just another attempt by a whole group of ex-husbands, etc, to try and get money from this successful woman. I can't think of a harder way to earn money than to sue Erin Brockovich."

 Sigourney Weaver and Jennifer Love Hewitt topped the US box office this weekend as Heartbreakers opened at number one. But the film, a comedy about a mother and daughter who use their sex appeal to extract money out of rich men, took just $12.3m (£8.56m) to reach top spot. It is Weaver's first number one opening since 1989's Ghostbusters II.

 Barry Levinson has hit out at Steven Spielberg's DreamWorks studio where he made the recent Irish comedy An Everlasting Piece. The Oscar-winning writer/director, who is peeved at DreamWorks' failure to promote the black farce, described the experience as "the most disappointing experience of his life." He continues: "This is something that I've never heard of or experienced before in all my time in the business. I've never seen where a movie that got good reviews, the studio would hold [back] those reviews from the ad. They refused to use any of these great quotes from highly respected sources. And DreamWorks made no effort to go after the film's core audience in America, the Irish. There's 40m people you could chase, and what did they do? They held competitions and screenings for bald people."

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: A sad story today, of Lastminute.com customers who found the online bucket-shop less than entertaining.
fields.body:
A sad story today, of Lastminute.com customers who found the online bucket-shop less than entertaining. Two friends decided to book tickets to an exclusive event advertised on Lastminute as a "Stars in Their Eyes" party offering "pure glamour, riotous fun and loads of A-list celebrities". The two women stumped up £20 each through Lastminute to get onto a "VIP guest list" (although how VIP could it be for 20 quid?) When the pair turned up to the West End venue, they were disconcerted to find a student's birthday party. Oops. Helen Baker, Lastminute's UK managing director, was quick to apologise. "We've refunded the tickets, and it's highly unlikely we will be using this supplier again," said Helen, but she did also say the "supplier" had come highly recommended.

 Keep your eyes peeled on this column tomorrow for a scoop that could well rock the very foundations of British industry. Well, Britain's excellent fish and chip industry.

 Privatised bus companies, you'll be shocked to hear, are abandoning passengers on "uneconomic" routes, leaving towns isolated and 1.3m journeys disappearing in a process known as deregistration. Travel West Midlands recently abandoned the market town of Chadley Heath, crippling businesses there and making pupils late for school. Sylvia Heal, the local Labour MP, condemned the lack of consultation by the company before inflicting the cuts.

 Meanwhile that sexy old thing Sir Bob Geldof was a guest on the BBC's Breakfast Time TV show yesterday. During the business slot Bob was interviewed on the sale of his Deckchair.com travel website, and managed to slip in "bollocks" in response to a question. Poor Bob was fed up because, halfway through the interview, the presenter announced, "Oh, hold on a minute, we are just going live to the Oscars," and showed a 30-second interview with Julia Roberts. When the show cut back to the studio, Sir Bob was shaking his head, moaning in disbelief: "Julia Roberts!"

 An email arrives from a Alice Paul of cyberspace, claiming to be a regular reader of this column (that's one then). Ms Paul reports that while trying to find this newspaper's website, she typed in ".com" instead of ".co.uk" and found herself at the site of a US company called Guardian. So ("for a laugh") she emailed the company to ask if it had any relationship with the newspaper. "No we do not," came back the reply. "We are a global manufacturer and fabricator of float glass products." That's cleared that up - although what "float glass products" are remains a mystery.

richard.adams@ theguardian.com

webTitle: Microsoft comes to aid of e-envoy

fields.headline: Microsoft comes to aid of e-envoy
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Microsoft today introduces a new server designed to help the British government fulfil its pledge of putting all government services online within four years. By Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
Microsoft today introduces a new server designed to help the British government fulfil its pledge of putting all government services online within four years.

Andrew Pinder, Britain's e-envoy, spent yesterday meeting Microsoft executives in Seattle to discuss plans to give everybody access to the internet by 2005.

Mr Pinder, who was appointed to the post this year, is under pressure to explain how the government will deliver on its pledge.

The government named Microsoft at the end of last year as the leading private sector company involved in its UK Online initiative.

In just 15 weeks the group has developed a portal linking all government services. It is expected to take substantially longer for the service, based on the company's Biztalk server, to be implemented.

The contract, understood to be Microsoft's largest for a foreign government, has potential to be extremely lucrative.

In his keynote address at the meeting today, Bill Gates, the chairman and founder of Microsoft, will credit Britain with pushing for the "largest e-government initiative in the world".

The company invites officials from about 80 states to its government leadership conference each year.

Mr Pinder is also to speak at the conference on The Innovative Government. It is his first overseas trip since being confirmed as e-envoy.

The post, which was created in 1999 to champion internet issues in and outside government, was criticised by the Labour-led trade and industry committee last week as overly bureaucratic and without real power.

After spending three days in Seattle, Mr Pinder, a former information technology director of the inland revenue, will fly to San Francisco for a two-day visit to Silicon Valley.

fields.headline: Ex-Arena editor commands Tank magazine
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Ekow Eshun is to edit a biannual style magazine called Tank, which will launch in May, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Former Arena editor Ekow Eshun is to edit a biannual style magazine called Tank, which aims to be "ideas led, rather than consumer led".

The magazine is being produced by an independent group of journalists and commercial staff.

Commercial director Vicky Stewart said the group had set up the magazine because they were "fed up of reading boring magazines telling you how to do things and what to buy".

"We're going to carry in-depth pieces of writing about fashion, art, music and pop culture," she added.

The debut issue, which will appear in May, will lead with a feature on the secret life of orchids and an interview with French dance music duo Daft Punk.

Ms Stewart kept information about Tank's backers close to her chest but said the first few issues would be supported largely by sponsorship from Levi's.

The magazine's launch team will comprise 10 staff, headed by Mr Eshun and co-editors Masoud Golsorkhi and Andreas Laeufer.

webTitle: Organic farmer sues over government slaughter policy

fields.headline: Organic farmer sues over government slaughter policy
fields.standfirst:
Special report: foot and mouth crisis
Sign up for our free daily foot and mouth email
fields.trailText: Publishing entrepreneur turned organic farmer Peter Kindersley today launched high court proceedings challenging the government's policy of slaughtering healthy animals to combat the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
Publishing entrepreneur turned organic farmer Peter Kindersley today launched high court proceedings challenging the government's policy of slaughtering healthy animals to combat the foot and mouth crisis.

Mr Kindersley, 59, who was behind Dorling Kindersley's educational children's books and is now a commercial organic farmer in Berkshire, lodged application papers at London's law courts seeking a judicial review of the policy.

The farmer, who arrived at the courts today with his wife Juliet, 60, says his application is supported by expert evidence "showing that a policy of vaccinating animals would be more effective".

His application will be considered by a single judge sitting in private within the next couple of days. If the judge decides there is an "arguable" case a full hearing of the application for judicial review is likely to go ahead in the next couple of weeks as a matter of urgency. Speaking on the steps outside the courts, Mr Kindersley said: "The scientific strength of the case for the alternatives to the mass slaughter of healthy livestock, such as vaccination, has been all the more compelling by the shortcomings of the government's present efforts."

He added: "I welcome today's belated recognition by the prime minister of the potential of vaccination. Indeed there are mainstream veterinary, economic and historical reasons why the cull is wrong."

He added: "If allowed to proceed the judicial review will test the rational basis upon which ministers have arrived at their present action.

"We will be asking the court to call a halt to the slaughter of healthy animals and to refer the matter back to ministers for urgent reconsideration."

Mr Kindersley and his wife founded the Dorling Kindersley publishing house in the 1970s. It was sold to Penguin Books last year. They have a 2,500-acre farm at Lambourn, Berks, with beef, sheep, poultry and cereals as well as a few pigs.

Mr Kindersley has put together a legal case through solicitors Burges Salmon and a technical one through the Elm Farm Research Centre, a progressive farming trust.

fields.headline: Animals culls 'turning people into vegetarians'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: foot and mouth
Sign up for our free daily foot and mouth email
fields.trailText:
People have been so traumatised by the distressing images of thousands of animals being slaughtered and dumped in mass graves that they are
considering vegetarianism.
fields.body:
People have been so traumatised by the distressing images of thousands of animals being slaughtered and dumped in mass graves that they are considering vegetarianism.

The Vegetarian Society said it had been "inundated" by calls from people across the country who have found the foot-and-mouth outbreak "the final straw".

Thousands of people ranging from children to a woman in her 80s had called in the past two months asking for advice about a vegetarian diet, said a society spokeswoman.

"We have been very busy with calls, up 100% in March compared to January's figures from members of the public.

"It is mainly people who have made the decision to become vegetarian on the back of the foot-and-mouth crisis. People have seen the images of animals being killed, thrown around, left dead on farms and put on to fires.

"Other people just have a longer feeling of distrust with meat," she added.

Some calls were from parents whose children have been so upset by the images that they had asked to stop eating meat. "We had a call from a woman in her 80s from Jersey who had become a veggie. Having seen and heard all about this she decided she could never eat meat again," the spokeswoman said.

The society's statement came as members of campaign group Viva were set to dress in lamb costumes outside one of the country's busiest railway stations and unfold a giant banner saying: "If killing 'healthy' lambs upsets you - don't eat them".

The group will be urging Londoners at Liverpool Street station to go vegetarian and offer free information to help them make the change. Spokeswoman Juliet Gellatley said: "People have to ask themselves what is it that upsets them about the killing of lambs. It certainly won't stop when foot-and-mouth does. If they are genuinely disturbed then they should stop eating them."

fields.bodyText: People have been so traumatised by the distressing images of thousands of animals being slaughtered and dumped in mass graves that they are considering vegetarianism. The Vegetarian Society said it had been "inundated" by calls from people across the country who have found the foot-and-mouth outbreak "the final straw". Thousands of people ranging from children to a woman in her 80s had called in the past two months asking for advice about a vegetarian diet, said a society spokeswoman. "We have been very busy with calls, up 100% in March compared to January's figures from members of the public. "It is mainly people who have made the decision to become vegetarian on the back of the foot-and-mouth crisis. People have seen the images of animals being killed, thrown around, left dead on farms and put on to fires. "Other people just have a longer feeling of distrust with meat," she added. Some calls were from parents whose children have been so upset by the images that they had asked to stop eating meat. "We had a call from a woman in her 80s from Jersey who had become a veggie. Having seen and heard all about this she decided she could never eat meat again," the spokeswoman said. The society's statement came as members of campaign group Viva were set to dress in lamb costumes outside one of the country's busiest railway stations and unfold a giant banner saying: "If killing 'healthy' lambs upsets you - don't eat them". The group will be urging Londoners at Liverpool Street station to go vegetarian and offer free information to help them make the change. Spokeswoman Juliet Gellatley said: "People have to ask themselves what is it that upsets them about the killing of lambs. It certainly won't stop when foot-and-mouth does. If they are genuinely disturbed then they should stop eating them." webTitle: The end of the school nurse?

fields.headline: The end of the school nurse?
fields.standfirst: Under the Scottish executive's new proposals, the school nurse and the health visitor could eventually be replaced by a two-tier system of community nursing, writes Anne Gulland
fields.trailText: Under the Scottish executive's new proposals, the school nurse and the health visitor could eventually be replaced by a two-tier system of community nursing, writes Anne Gulland.
fields.body:
The words "visionary" and "courageous" were bandied about when Scottish health minister Susan Deacon recently unveiled plans to create a "new breed of health worker" as part of an initiative to end Scotland's reign as the "sickness capital" of western Europe.

The Scottish executive's review into how nurses can contribute to improving Scotland's health has almost 100 recommendations, the most radical of which is the establishment of an 80-strong team of public health practitioners, who will "take on a roving local brief to help families and communities to make improvements in their own health".

School nurses and health visitors are expected to fill the new posts, which will be located in Local Health Care Cooperatives (LHCCs) - primary care groups are the English equivalent - that commission primary care.

In the long term, this could spell the end of the school nurse and the health visitor, who could be replaced by a two-tier system of community nursing, comprising public health practitioners and family health nurses.

The former will carry out research and analysis of population health needs in their locality; the latter - a World Health Organisation idea being piloted in Orkney, the Western Isles and the Highlands - would further develop the "hands-on" work of school nurses and health visitors.

The Community Practitioners' and Health Visitors' Association (CPHVA), called the creation of the public health practitioner "visionary". And Unison applauded the initiative as "courageous and progressive".

Many school nurses and health visitors would say they are already doing much public health work, but this new nurse (or "health champion" as they have also been called) will be dedicated to looking at the "bigger picture", rather than fitting it in between visits to toddlers and doling out meningitis C injections.

Professor Phil Hanlon, director of the Public Health Institute of Scotland, the body that will coordinate the work of the public health practitioners, said: "I genuinely believe they will do different things in each of their LHCCs ,depending on the particular problems of the population.

"If you're a GP or practice nurse you have groups of patients with problems who present themselves to you. You may have pro-active campaigns like screening for cervical cancer, but very seldom do you sit down and try to work out who is the population you serve and what their particular needs are."

But he added that a public health focus had to be embraced by all. "The role has the potential to be radical but the health service doesn't easily branch to the radical. It's not that GPs don't care about public health issues, but when you are confronted with a couple of surgeries a day it's hard to find the time or energy to take that population-based approach.

"Just because you put a new member of staff with a new title on the LHCC it doesn't mean there will be a change across the board."

The Scottish executive has pledged to fund new health visitor and school nursing posts to replace the 80 professionals who become public health nurses, but James Kennedy, Royal College of Nursing Scottish board secretary, is concerned that the age-old problem of nurse recruitment and retention will rear its head.

"We recently published a survey of school nurses, practice nurses and health visitors which showed that the age profile is quite worrying. Half of these people will be eligible to retire within the next 10 years. Where is this new workforce going to come from?" he said.

A separate survey by the CPHVA revealed that the numbers of school nurses and health visitors in training fell by 51% between 1990 and 1996, and have only risen by 14% since that time.

But is the new initiative more concerned with giving out snazzy job titles than improving health?

Jackie Carnell of the CPHVA thinks not. The association has long called for an amalgamation of the training of both school nurses and health visitors. She said: "It's not just the title we have been calling for. What we have been asking for is a sensible rationalisation of the roles within community practice. If you look at the work of a health visitor and school nurse their work is very similar, it's just their populations that are different. To go on educating them separately as if there's no link between them is just daft."

And she hopes the idea is rolled out in some form or other to England, Wales and Northern Ireland. "Within medically dominated organisations like Scottish LHCCs and English primary care groups, it is an excellent idea to have someone whose raison d'etre is public health. I'm sure there are other ways of doing it and the Scottish model may not work elsewhere but it's a good start."

fields.headline: Internet to benefit social care
fields.standfirst: Today's Guardian/NISW conference will highlight the new Social Care Institute for Excellence's work in providing social care references on the web, writes Daphne Statham
fields.trailText: Today's Guardian/NISW conference will highlight the new Social Care Institute for Excellence's work in providing social care references on the web, writes Daphne Statham.
fields.body:
Here at the National Institute for Social Work (NISW), we are working with the Department of Health on setting up the new Social Care Institute for Excellence (Scie) in the summer. Scie has been charged with drawing together and spreading evidence of what works in social care and to make the maximum use of electronic means in doing this.

The internet already provides a wealth of good material for those social workers who know how to find it. At a Guardian/NISW conference today, we will be highlighting some existing evidence-based resources, as well as looking to the future.

That future includes work we are undertaking now with the electronic Library for Social Care (eLSC). The library is being developed to work with and complement the National Electronic Library for Health (NeLH).

The eLSC "knowledge floor" will bring together the guidance, standards, best practice and research findings which together form the evidence base which supports good practice in the field. It will work towards producing widely accessible publications, such as the Economic and Social Research Council-funded Research in Practice series of quality protect research briefings; research reviews commissioned by the Centre for Evidence Based Social Services; the Barnardo's What Works publications, and similar work by many other organisations.

The knowledge floor will also help to promote the good practice identified by the social services inspectorate (SSI), and its audit commission joint reviews.

As with Scie, eLSC will need to be one element of a partnership with others in the field to succeed in feeding information about good practice into the social care knowledge base - and in making sure that it's picked up by busy people on the ground.

One way we'll try to do this is through the Scie best practice guides, again based on the library's knowledge floor. We're now piloting the first, a NISW guide to first line management. We'll soon be consulting users and practitioners - online, through the eLSC - on a second best practice guide

The eLSC knowledge bases floor hosts and links to various databases. Currently, the floor has an online version of Research Policy and Planning, the researchers' network journal. Six issues are on the web and there's a searchable archive of all articles going back to 1996. The NISW caredata database will also be accessible on this floor.

Scie will need to look at how social care staff can gain access to other knowledge bases, such as those developed by the National Children's Bureau, the Centre for Policy and Ageing, the Research in Practice evidence bank, the British Institute for Learning Disabilities and many more.

The eLSC knowledge skills floor links to an internet tutorial for social workers, which helps those taking their first steps on the internet. A "research mindedness" module, aimed at helping social work teams to work with research evidence, is being developed by the Centre for Human Services Technology at the University of Southampton, and will shortly be launched on this floor.

The eLSC users and carers floor highlights the fact that evidence from users and carers about what works in social care is not as well developed as other forms of knowledge. Capacity building - assisting users and carers to make their voices heard - will be a key task for Scie.

In addition to drawing together existing evidence as to what works, Scie will have many other tasks and challenges.

It will have to develop a way of assessing practice. Can social care develop a way of judging practice that recognises the complexities and grey areas in social work, yet is rigorous and stands up to examination?

Rather than simply issuing guidance, Scie will work with those providing and commissioning services to ensure that practice at the front line does change for the better. Scie will also have to work closely with other organisations, including the new general social care council, the national care standards commission, training organisation TOPSS, the SSI, the audit commission and employers' organisations, to ensure that, whoever delivers it, social care is good quality care.

This is a very complex and wide ranging agenda. Today's Guardian/NISW Using Knowledge to Promote Quality conference will begin to address these issues. It needs to be the first of many such events, to ensure that Scie can help social care staff meet the challenges and play a key role in delivering better quality services for users.

 Daphne Statham is director of NISW.

webTitle: Prospects for improvement in Essex county council

fields.headline: Prospects for improvement in Essex county council
fields.trailText: The recruitment crisis in social services is damaging Essex county council's care work, but there are good prospects for improvement, an independent report has found. Simon Parker reports.
fields.body:
The recruitment crisis in social services is damaging Essex county council's care work, but there are good prospects for improvement, an independent report on the authority has found.

The report, from the Audit Commission and social services inspectorate (SSI), says Essex's services present a mixed picture for local people.

The council suffers from "considerable recruitment difficulties" in children's and adult services. Social services teams are not operating at full strength and Essex is unable to allocate qualified staff to all of its statutory work with children.

The report also calls on the council to focus on improving older people's services, where there are delays in assessing clients.

It says the council needs to make better use of data to compare its work with that of others, and use longer-term financial planning to ensure planned changes in the social services department are implemented.

However, the joint review team also found good arrangements for a wide range of services, including those for children with disabilities and people with mental heath problems.

John Bolton, the director of joint reviews, said: "Essex has made significant steps in the last seven years and in particular has made good progress with family centres and working with the health service.

"I am confident that Essex will continue to serve more and more local people well if recommendations made in the review are followed."

Stewart Ashurst, the council's chief executive, added: "The report offers us some sound advice for the future. WeÍre particularly pleased that the commitment and dedication of our staff has been recognised."

fields.headline: Tuesday's rumours
fields.standfirst: Are you gearing up for National Cleavage Week III? Today's rumours - who fondly remember when the Sun's topless bus came down Farringdon Road last August - certainly are
fields.trailText: Real Madrid are the latest European club to express an interest in Mark Viduka. In the last few weeks the Leeds United striker has been linked with Roma, Juventus, Internazionale and Milan. However, Viduka has once again insisted he wants to stay at Elland Road. "There is always going to be speculation, I can't help that. But I am happy here, I really am," he told the Leeds official website.
fields.body:
Real Madrid are the latest European club to express an interest in Mark Viduka. In the last few weeks the Leeds United striker has been linked with Roma, Juventus, Internazionale and Milan. However, Viduka has once again insisted he wants to stay at Elland Road. "There is always going to be speculation, I can't help that. But I am happy here, I really am," he told the Leeds official website.

Real Madrid are also keen on Lazio midfielder Juan Sebastián Verón. According to Teamtalk, they have already made a £30m offer for the Argentina midfielder.

Paris St-Germain are lining up a £3m bid for Christian Karembeu, according to Planet Football. Although the price sounds a touch excessive - to put it kindly - there's no doubting Karembeu is keen on joining Luis Fernandez's team. "It is flattering," he said. "It makes me proud knowing that he wants me, I find that beautiful."

Lazio midfielder Pavel Nedved has dismissed reports he could join Manchester United in the summer. "I am delighted that a club like Manchester United are interested in me. I would be at the absolute summit of the football world there," he told Planet Football. "The climate does concern me though. I appreciate the warm weather in Italy. I know there is not much sunshine in Manchester. It is a bit cold for my liking and too rainy. I love playing in Rome and I don't intend to leave."

Sheffield Wednesday will appoint Peter Shreeves as their full-time manager later this week, claims Teamtalk.

fields.headline: Poster boom helps Maiden double profits
fields.trailText:
11am: Poster specialist Maiden has benefited from the swing towards outdoor advertising, reports Dan Milmo.
Mar 5: Poster advertising booms
fields.body:
Billboard media owner Maiden Group has brushed off the turmoil in the advertising industry by more than doubling its profits.

Maiden has benefited from a swing towards outdoor advertising, with television and ITV the main losers.

The group said its sector grew by 20% last year, while ITV revenues are expected to show negative growth of 1% in 2001.

Maiden said pre-tax profits for 2000 rose from £5.1m to £13m, with revenues climbing 21% to £86.1m.

"Even with growing uncertainty in the economy and a potential reduction in growth in advertising spend, we continue to expect to be able to outperform the cycle," said Ron Zeghibe, chief executive of Maiden.

Maiden now has more than 32,000 advertising panels, bolstered by last year's acquisition of four smaller rivals, including GMG Metro and CP Posters.

"We have leading and valuable positions in key areas of the outdoor market and we expect to see good returns from them," added Mr Zeghibe.

According to Maiden's research, 83% of the top 200 advertisers now use the outdoor medium and the sector took just 6% of dot.coms' now non-existent marketing spend.

The group added 2001 had started strongly, with bookings for the first quarter climbing by 22% compared with the same period last year.

As with all companies involved in the advertising and marketing sector, Maiden is keen to distance itself from the economic uncertainty that is giving the industry a rough ride at the moment.

"Independent forecasters continue to predict the medium will grow at a faster rate in the next few years than either television or press.

"Advertisers are finding the medium increasingly attractive and are committing a greater spend to it," said Mr Zeghibe.

fields.headline: The house that Hyundai built
fields.standfirst: If travelling with your family is like touring with a department store, move into a Santa Fe
fields.trailText: If travelling with your family is like touring with a department store, move into a Santa Fe
fields.body:
Say what you like about the Hyundai Santa Fe, it gets a response. I left it on a street one night and somebody - perhaps straightforwardly objecting to its shiny silver, X-registered newness, or maybe protesting that the 2.7 V6 version of the car is only available as an automatic - smashed two windows on the driver's side and left a brick on the passenger seat.

No attempt seemed to have been made to steal the car, or even to lift the detachable stereo, winking temptingly from the dashboard, or any of the other property lying inside this most capacious of Korean vehicles. (You could fit most of what you own in the rear of a Santa Fe, though, in these particular circumstances, I was quite glad that I hadn't.) As far as one could tell, someone had beaten up the car with a brick simply because they thought it needed it.

I could see what they were getting at, though, personally, if I had taken a heavy object to the car, I would have used it to beat out the door panels, which are moulded to bow smoothly inwards and help lend the car the slight appearance of something that has been shaken out of a jelly-mould just prior to a three-year-old's birthday party.

The jelly mould does seem to figure more and more prominently as a tool in contemporary car design and has perhaps now leapt ahead of the set square and ruler. The great automobile critic John Updike wrote, in the short story Rabbit Remembered, about the back of a 1999 Taurus: "A continuous blob across, like a moustache or a roll of pre-mixed cookie dough being squeezed in the middle."

He added, "Cars used to have such dashing shapes, like airplanes, back when gas was cheap." Now that petrol consumption is an issue, we have to resign ourselves to the fact that cars can't thrust themselves forward in quite the same way; they must look softer, more apologetic about being cars.

Still, as the Santa Fe proves, you can round off all the edges and still looked pretty pleased with yourself. This is Hyundai's first stab at a sports utility ve hicle, or armoured family carrier, and the idea appears to be to cut into some of the sales action enjoyed by the Toyota Rav-4 and the Land Rover Freelander by being wider and longer and cheaper.

Hyundai also refers to its hope that the Santa Fe will be deemed to offer some of the "presence and refinement" of the still bigger Grand Cherokee. But I have no idea what they mean by this, given that the Grand Cherokee has about as refined a presence as Jim Davidson.

On account of the softer, more rubbery shape of the Santa Fe, people who are bothered that they never went to war (a sizeable portion of the target group, one imagines, for sports utility vehicles) will probably end up sticking with the Land Rover and Chrysler Jeep products. But more delicate souls, who are looking for a gentler kind of tank, may wish to take a look at the Hyundai.

It will also appeal to anyone drawn to the pleasure of owning a car that people can't reliably pronounce. Even people who work for the company seem to divide between a kind of received Knightsbridge pronunciation ("Hie-un-die") and a lite Australian version ("Hay'n'day"). If in doubt, blend the two.

The four-wheel drive V6 version that I drove felt overpowered, as if the engine was built to pull a car twice the weight, and I wondered whether the other two versions of the car, with their 2.4 petrol and their 2.0 diesel engines, might behave more sensibly.

But then I probably should have done more to weigh the vehicle down with the ballast of children, animals and speedboats that are part of the life the Santa Fe so clearly envisages you having. The car is another of that growing roster of vehicles aimed at people who have bought, however willingly, into the contemporary, clobber-bound version of family existence - the family as a travelling department store, tyranically organised by children who, like Michael Jackson, will not countenance any kind of journey without an entourage of friends, scooters, snowboards, refrigerated drinks, inflatable pup tents, personal trainers etc.

Because Hyundai is determined to undercut the competition for price, the car does not spoil you with toys. No satellite navigation system or automatic climate control; no multiple CD-loader or boot-mounted barbecue range. There is, however, an illuminated ashtray, for those who enjoy illuminating their ash. And the rear window flips open (a button on the remote control unlocks it for you). I never worked out why that might be especially handy, except for cooling the interior while stationary, or for feeding the ponies which you may have put out to graze in the boot.

It's a hardy, practical vehicle, but a little bland and universal, both to sit in and to drive. But that's only to be expected of a car styled in America by a Far Eastern company using Austrian and German parts. Such is the Santa Fe - a truly global driving experience. Designed in California, built in Korea, smashed for kicks in London.

webTitle: Elegance and frocky horror at the Oscars

fields.headline: The fashion winner ...
fields.standfirst: ...and the also-rans:  Elegance and frocky horror at the Oscars
fields.trailText: ...and the also-rans:  Elegance and frocky horror at the Oscars
fields.body:
It is much about the frocks as the trophies. Beautiful is not enough: you need to look beautiful, important and classy. No wonder the poor souls have to get up at 5am to have rollers put in.

For Julia Roberts, this was her chance to show the world she has clout as well as charm, having first dazzled us in a hooker's Lycra mini, and won her Oscar as a brassy, lipglossed, Wonderbra-ed legal worker. She looked every inch the star: the dress was vintage (read: not just the latest thing, but here to stay), black and white (read: classic), and Valentino (read: timeless glamour). To complete the effect, a grown-up chignon replaced the tousled, kooky curls seen at the box office.

Honours went to the grown-up glamour houses, as the stars eschewed cutting edge for curvy gowns, regal hairstyles, demure wraps, and serious jewels. Sigourney Weaver in red Christian Dior, Catherine Zeta Jones in corsetted, fishtailed black Versace, and Marcia Gay Harden in ruby Randolph Duke all pulled it off.

Presenter Renee Zellweger, anxious to distance herself from her "fat" (size 12) role as Bridget Jones, wore a size 0 yellow boned gown so tight she could hardly walk. Kate Hudson, tipped for a trophy and also as the night's hot fashion ticket, failed to pull off either. Her dress by Stella McCartney verged on the fussy. She would have looked much better in the simple, spaghetti strap Vera Wang worn by her mother Goldie Hawn.

Jennifer Lopez, in Chanel, tried to combine a sheer chiffon wisp of a top with a very proper, stiff silk taffeta skirt. The juxtaposition did not work. Angelina Jolie stood out in a tuxedo-style white satin trouser suit by Dolce e Gabbana. Juliette Binoche looked a little peculiar, with endless lengths of pearls over her Gaultier dress.

But the fruitcake category went to Björk in Marjan Pejoski's peculiarly literal "swan dress", complete with lolling head and yellow beak.

As for the men, the biggest winner looked, frankly, the biggest loser. Russell Crowe may have looked great in a toga, but in ribbon bow-tie, sunglasses and oily quiff he was shown up by Tom Hanks in Gucci, Joaquin Phoenix in Armani, and most of all by young Jamie Bell in Christian Dior.

fields.headline: Why we all want a happy ending
fields.standfirst: When Ellen Fein wrote The Rules, telling single women how to capture Mr Right, millions rushed to give them a go. Now that their author is facing divorce, it's tempting to mock - but the reasons for the book's success remain as real as ever
fields.trailText: When Ellen Fein wrote The Rules, telling single women how to capture Mr Right, millions rushed to give them a go. Now that their author is facing divorce, it's tempting to mock - but the reasons for the book's success remain as real as ever.
fields.body:
One can't help noticing the exquisite irony that Ellen Fein, co-author of The Rules: Time-tested Secrets for Capturing the Heart of Mr Right, The Rules II and the forthcoming Rules III: Time-tested Secrets for Making your Marriage Work, is getting divorced. And one can't help feeling a certain satisfaction that someone who told millions of women the best way to marital bliss is not to talk much on dates may be reconsidering her position.

Fein made the announcement on the eve of publication of her latest book, which claims that "it is easier to stay married than get married". She and her co-author, Sherrie Schneider, suggest that women should defer to their husbands, and recommend that they grow their hair, as men find long hair more attractive.

The 43-year-old had been married to pharmacist Paul Feingertz for 16 years and, along with Schneider, constantly referred to her own marital success when promoting her books. So what went wrong? Did Fein fail to read between her own lines?

It's too easy to dismiss The Rules, to mock them for their earnestness and deplore them for their sexist, condescending attitude towards women. Because this silly paper-back, with pink ribbons all over its cover, obviously captured the imagination of millions of women all over the world. Five years after it first came out, I have noticed The Rules on all sorts of intelligent people's bookshelves, tucked away between The Brothers Karamazov and Zadie Smith. I have noticed smart women buying it and following its ethos.

More than that, I have noticed the spirit of The Rules entering into people's conversations about relationships in a more diffuse way. I have heard educated, liberal women talking about how long to wait before calling a man back, or whether the date should be in her neighbourhood, or how long to wait until sleeping with him, as if there is some secret formula, some mathematical principle to romantic happiness that she has yet to divine.

I have also heard professionally aggressive, ambitious women worry about seeming too aggressive in their romantic lives if they call a man first. It is strange that the 50s courtship rituals our mothers fought so hard to get away from should come to be so appealing, so necessary, to a new generation. But it seems that The Rules tapped into a larger anxiety in the culture; in their simplistic, jingoistic way, they expressed a need, a yearning, a worry about old-fashioned courtship that is worth taking into account.

One of the reasons The Rules has been so successful is that a whole generation of women is marrying later. It has become socially acceptable and entirely common for a woman to spend her 20s focusing on her career and hanging around with her friends and running around with different men. But then, at a certain point, in her early 30s, comes a fear that she will live her entire life like a character trapped in Sex and the City, sipping cosmopolitans at a bar in Manolo Blahniks when she is in her 50s.

She has established her professional life, she has had lots of relationships with men, but marriage itself has come to seem elusive and alien - and she begins to ask herself, how do you get there again? How did I get off track? All the freedom and feminism and sweet drinks and promotions don't hold the answer. And suddenly the comically old-fashioned way of doing things, with dates and flowers and rings, starts to seem more desirable.

Buried in The Rules is the faintest hint of a Jane Austen plot: the man who pursues and the woman who is pursued, the unspoken, delicate, romantic game that unfolds between them. What The Rules offers, in its clumsy, excruciating way, is a path back to that mystery, that loveliness and ease. It promises women not just that they will get married, but that they will be in the traditional position of being chased.

Why should women who are aggressive and ambitious in every other area of life want that so much? Why should they want the traditional feeling of being sought after? Why should they want to surrender control?

The truth is that all the equality we have and require in the workplace is not necessarily what we want in our romantic lives. The journalist who calls strangers all day long for a living may wait for a man to call her for dinner. The woman who is an aggressive lawyer at the office may not want to feel aggressive in her personal life; she may want to feel feminine, taken care of. She may want to give up control because it is pleasurable; it is fun to play that game for an evening, for a week.

With all of its absurd rigidity, its humourless desperation, The Rules offers women old-fashioned roles to play with. To have your dinner paid for, even though you could pay for it yourself. To let him choose the place. To surrender control in just this one area of your life for just this short period of time, even though you are perfectly capable of taking care of yourself.

The Rules taps into the stories we were told as children, the fairy tales and knights, the Mr Darcys and Heathcliffs. It whispers of happy endings that have begun to seem arduous and complicated and out of reach. It may be that these retrograde fantasies still exist because the women's movement hasn't cleared them away; or it may be that they will always exist.

Is the idea of a man paying for dinner so appealing because we know we can take care of ourselves? Or are we still insecure about our independence?

The truth is that there is something infinitely reassuring to everyone about men pursuing and women being pursued. For women, I think it is not so much about "capturing Mr Right" as about capturing an image of ourselves that we find appealing. Maybe we shouldn't find it appealing, in this new millennium, but we do.

webTitle: TV viewers give thumbs down to Oscar night

fields.headline: TV viewers give thumbs down to Oscar night
fields.trailText: Viewing figures for Sunday's Oscar ceremony were the lowest ever for Tinsel Town's biggest night of self-promotion of the year
fields.body:
It might have been a very big day for Russell Crowe, Julia Roberts and Steven Soderbergh, but the TV broadcast of Sunday night's Oscars ceremony was watched by a record low audience, according to statistics released yesterday.

The disappointing figures come despite the Academy's crackdown on long-winded speechifying, which led to a dramatic reduction in the length of the annual bash. America's ABC network averaged 42.9m viewers for the Hollywood love-in, a 40% share of household audiences, but down 10% on last year's show and down 4% on the lowest ever audience share, for Out of Africa's best picture win in 1986.

The figures compare with a mere 40.1m viewers for the 1997 ceremony, when The English Patient struck Oscar gold, and 37.2m for Platoon's 1987 victory. But on both those occasions, the percentage share of household audiences was higher than for Gladiator's Sunday night triumph.

ABC ratings expert Jeff Lindsey's explanation for the slump in audience figures was hardly convincing. Lindsay contrasted Sunday's close-run contest with Titanic's highly-rated runaway win in 1998 and concluded, that, "Quite honestly, I think part of [the problem] was there was no clear standout."

fields.headline: Male perspective for Orange prize
fields.trailText: The old boys' club which women writers have accused of running the publishing world like a public school common room was celebrating an historic victory last night.
fields.body:
The old boys' club which women writers have accused of running the publishing world like a public school common room was celebrating an historic victory last night.

For the Orange prize, the world's premier women-only literary prize and a stout redoubt against literary laddism, swallowed its pride and admitted that it needed a little male advice.

The £30,000 prize, the richest and most controversial in the country - which the late Auberon Waugh labelled the Lemon prize - will this year have a men's jury to second-guess the shortlist chosen by its female judges.

But Rosie Boycott, former editor of the Daily Express and the chair of the judges, who cut her critical teeth on the feminist magazine Spare Rib, vehemently denied that she or her fellow judges, who include Kate Adie and the singer Suzanne Vega, would defer to superior male judgment.

"Far from it, the whole point of the exercise is to try to get men interested in women's fiction," she said. "There has been lots of research showing that men only tend to read books by women if they have male heroes. We have to change that.

"It hadn't occurred to me at all that we are giving in to men, but it will be interesting to see how the shortlists differ. It doesn't matter what they come up with. It's the old story: we don't have to listen to them."

But novelist Paul Bailey, chairman of the male jury, was not content to see his chaps as mere compliant drones. "I prefer to think of our shortlist as a real alternative," he said, confessing that he was not in favour of the Orange prize on principle. "I don't believe in separating the sexes like this in art, but this could be an interesting experiment. We may overlap with one or two books, but I will be horrified if we come up with the same six.

"It is clear from the research Orange has conducted that men don't read women writers unless their books get a lot of hype, as happened with Zadie Smith's White Teeth. But for me, most of the best writing around is by women."

Ms Boycott and Mr Bailey agreed that the list of 18 - which includes such stars as Margaret Atwood and Jeanette Winterson, alongside debut novelists such as Ali Smith and the Booker-nominated Trezza Azzopardi - was probably the strongest Orange list yet.

Ms Boycott said opinions among the judges were already so sharply divided that there could be fireworks when it came to whittling the list down to the final six in May. The award will be presented in June.

The longlist in full

Dog Days, Glenn Miller Nights by Laurie Graham (Black Swan)
Dark comedy about an elderly woman on an estate yearning for a last shot at life.

The Blind Assassin by Margaret Atwood (Bloomsbury)
Multi-layered story of repression, sisterhood and science-fiction.

In the Blue House by Meaghan Delahunt (Bloomsbury)
Russian history in the first half of the 20th century focusing on Trotsky's exile.

From Caucasia, With Love by Danzy Senna (Bloomsbury)
Mixed-race sisters in a fractured activist family on the run from the FBI.

MotherKind by Jayne Anne Phillips (Cape)
A woman nurses her mother through terminal cancer while coping with her first child.

The.PowerBook by Jeanette Winterson (Cape)
Fluid tales of love, loss and indentiy in cyberspace.

The Last Samurai by Helen DeWitt (Chatto& Windus)
First novel about a child prodigy with an intellectually demanding mother, searching for his absent father.

Horse Heaven by Jane Smiley (Faber & Faber)
A sprawling satire on the world of horse racing.

Homestead by Rosina Lippi (Flamingo)
Epic portrayal of the 20th century focusing on different women in a remote Alpine village.

The Bonesetter's Daughter by Amy Tan (Flamingo)
An American woman's difficult relationship with her semi-assimilated Chinese mother.

The Wild by Esther Freud (Hamish Hamilton)
Trials and tribulations of stepfamilies in suburban England, seen from the child's point of view.

Hotel World by Ali Smith (Hamish Hamilton)
Five intersecting characters (one of them a ghost) seen on one night in a hotel.

Nowhere Else on Earth by Josephine Humphreys (Heinemann)
Life in an Indian settlement in mid-19th century North Carolina.

The Hiding Place by Trezza Azzopardi (Picador)
Domestic horrors among Cardiff's Maltese community in the 50s.

The Idea of Perfection by Kate Grenville (Picador)
Unusual romance between two mismatched eccentrics.

Fred & Edie by Jill Dawson (Sceptre)
Hovering between fact and fiction, study of a lovers' conspiracy in the 20s to dispatch the woman's husband.

Fish, Blood & Bone by Leslie Forbes (Weidenfield & Nicolson)
Thriller taking in Victorian botany, Jack the Ripper, family histories and Tibetan treks.

Ahab's Wife by Sena Jeter Naslund (Women's Press)
A hyper-literary spin on the world of Moby Dick, with a seafaring heroine married to Melville's Captain Ahab.
fields.bodyText: The old boys' club which women writers have accused of running the publishing world like a public school common room was celebrating an historic victory last night. For the Orange prize, the world's premier women-only literary prize and a stout redoubt against literary laddism, swallowed its pride and admitted that it needed a little male advice. The £30,000 prize, the richest and most controversial in the country - which the late Auberon Waugh labelled the Lemon prize - will this year have a men's jury to second-guess the shortlist chosen by its female judges. But Rosie Boycott, former editor of the Daily Express and the chair of the judges, who cut her critical teeth on the feminist magazine Spare Rib, vehemently denied that she or her fellow judges, who include Kate Adie and the singer Suzanne Vega, would defer to superior male judgment. "Far from it, the whole point of the exercise is to try to get men interested in women's fiction," she said. "There has been lots of research showing that men only tend to read books by women if they have male heroes. We have to change that. "It hadn't occurred to me at all that we are giving in to men, but it will be interesting to see how the shortlists differ. It doesn't matter what they come up with. It's the old story: we don't have to listen to them." But novelist Paul Bailey, chairman of the male jury, was not content to see his chaps as mere compliant drones. "I prefer to think of our shortlist as a real alternative," he said, confessing that he was not in favour of the Orange prize on principle. "I don't believe in separating the sexes like this in art, but this could be an interesting experiment. We may overlap with one or two books, but I will be horrified if we come up with the same six. "It is clear from the research Orange has conducted that men don't read women writers unless their books get a lot of hype, as happened with Zadie Smith's White Teeth. But for me, most of the best writing around is by women." Ms Boycott and Mr Bailey agreed that the list of 18 - which includes such stars as Margaret Atwood and Jeanette Winterson, alongside debut novelists such as Ali Smith and the Booker-nominated Trezza Azzopardi - was probably the strongest Orange list yet. Ms Boycott said opinions among the judges were already so sharply divided that there could be fireworks when it came to whittling the list down to the final six in May. In the Blue House by Meaghan Delahunt (Bloomsbury) Russian history in the first half of the 20th century focusing on Trotsky's exile. From Caucasia, With Love by Danzy Senna (Bloomsbury) Mixed-race sisters in a fractured activist family on the run from the FBI. MotherKind by Jayne Anne Phillips (Cape) A woman nurses her mother through terminal cancer while coping with her first child. The.PowerBook by Jeanette Winterson (Cape) Fluid tales of love, loss and indentiy in cyberspace. The Last Samurai by Helen DeWitt (Chatto& Windus) First novel about a child prodigy with an intellectually demanding mother, searching for his absent father. Horse Heaven by Jane Smiley (Faber & Faber) A sprawling satire on the world of horse racing. Homestead by Rosina Lippi (Flamingo) Epic portrayal of the 20th century focusing on different women in a remote Alpine village. The Bonesetter's Daughter by Amy Tan (Flamingo) An American woman's difficult relationship with her semi-assimilated Chinese mother. The Wild by Esther Freud (Hamish Hamilton) Trials and tribulations of stepfamilies in suburban England, seen from the child's point of view. fields.headline: Live & Kicking magazine wins reprieve
fields.trailText: 11am: The BBC has told editorial staff on Live & Kicking magazine their jobs are safe for now, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The BBC has told editorial staff on Live & Kicking, the magazine based around its soon-to-be axed children's programme, that their jobs are safe for now.

A spokesman said the magazine's staff had raised concerns that their magazine could be closed after the news that Match of the Day magazine would cease publishing after its May issue.

But they have been told the magazine is still "commercially viable".

A spokesman for BBC Worldwide, the BBC's magazines division, said there was "no question mark at the moment over Live & Kicking magazine".

"We guarantee anything for as long as it's commercially viable, and at the moment the magazine is."

But BBC Worldwide refused to rule out a long-term closure.

Live & Kicking, in common with other teenage magazines, took a circulation dive at the last ABCs, losing over 29% of its circulation.

But the spokesman pointed out that the magazine was still selling a "healthy" 116,000 copies a month.

webTitle: Moderniser hotly tipped for ministerial post

fields.headline: Moderniser hotly tipped for ministerial post
fields.standfirst: Local government moderniser Lord Filkin is being tipped as a strong candidate for a ministerial post in the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions. Simon Parker assesses his CV
fields.trailText: Local government moderniser Lord Filkin is being tipped as a strong candidate for a ministerial post in the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions. Simon Parker assesses his CV.
fields.body:
Lord Filkin of Pimlico is widely credited as being the man who invented best value, the government's council service improvement regime.

Some claim he came up with only the name, others say he was the man behind some of the key ideas as well. Whatever the case, the story goes to show just how highly the local government community rates the peer's influence in the corridors of power.

It might also explain why Geoff Filkin, as he used to be known, is currently such a hot tip for a ministerial post, possibly taking on Lord Whitty's job covering the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions, and hence responsibility for local government.

The rumours, which started in Whitehall, have spread like wildfire and are very credible. Lord Filkin has spent a good part of his 57 years working for local authorities, first as a town planner, then as chief executive of Reading borough council, and finally as secretary of the Association of District Councils.

Despite his impressive credentials, the rumours are being passed around with a slight sense of dread.

This is partly because of the peer's political background. He has been tainted in the eyes of some by his close involvement with the New Local Government Network (NLGN) - a modernising think tank that has been attacked over its perceived enthusiasm for directly elected mayors and council service privatisation.

At least one high profile founder member of the network - Jack Dromey, of the Transport and General Workers' Union - left the organisation over its stance.

The NLGN has called for the government to take the controversial move of imposing referendums for directly elected mayors in the UK's major cities.

It has also argued that councils need to leave behind their role as direct service providers and take on a more strategic "community leadership" role as an all-purpose problem solver for local people.

Neither of these moves was calculated to endear the network to rank and file councillors. Many local politicians are deeply opposed to directly-elected mayors, which they believe concentrate too much power in the hands of one person. A significant number of councillors also want authorities to keep their direct service role. The alternative, they argue, will inevitably leading to more outsourcing and a diminishing role for local government.

Lord Filkin has a reputation for pursuing his vision of council reform with an almost evangelical zeal. He has been described as "a repressed monk" - someone who needs to devote his life to something, but has never really found religion enough.

This raises questions about whether he would be the right man for the job. One friend of the peer describes him as "somebody who wants to look at ways of driving the agenda forward".

But the signs are that the government's current intention is to let best value and the new political structures bed down before deciding whether more reform is needed.

Only one major bill is expected for councils in a second Labour term, and that is likely to propose modest reforms of the local government finance system.

This suggests Lord Filkin might not enjoy the kind of backseat role this legislative programme would require.

The peer's programme for local government reform is summed up in the NLGN's discussion document, Towards a new localism, of which he was co-author.

Aimed at giving more power to councils, it proposes a combination of local government proportional representation, new tax-raising powers, a new department for decentralisation and devolution, and partnership contracts - five-year community plans with new financial freedoms attached and an average £8m in extra funding every year for every council involved.

This manifesto is one of the key reasons for Jack Dromey revising his opinion of both the NLGN and Lord Filkin.

"There he is, this highly intelligent architect of best value associated with a move away from central government compulsion, who then became associated with a new politics of compulsion, but who's now playing quite a positive role in sending the government down a different path," said Mr Dromey.

"It wouldn't surprise me for one minute if he ended up in government."

Those close to the peer say he has not yet been asked to become a minister. But with the general election date still not fixed, and a reshuffle unlikely before then, there is no reason why the prime minister should have started tipping the wink to cabinet ministers, let alone their more junior colleagues.

There are also questions over whether Lord Filkin would accept the job. As a career bureaucrat, he might not want to dip his toe in the political waters, and he may not be interested in the hectic lifestyle and low profile of a junior minister.

If, however, he could be persuaded to take the job, the general consensus is that he would do it well. It would certainly be a fitting reward for a man whose career has been devoted to local government.

fields.headline: Infected blood victims' victory
fields.standfirst: NHS to pay multi-million compensation over virus
fields.trailText: More than 100 people infected with the hepatitis C virus through blood transfusions won compensation totalling millions of pounds in the high court yesterday.
fields.body:
More than 100 people infected with the hepatitis C virus through blood transfusions won compensation totalling millions of pounds in the high court yesterday.

The case against the national blood authority and the Velindre NHS trust, the blood authority for Wales, was the first group action to reach court under a little-used law, the Consumer Protection Act 1987. The act was brought in to implement a European directive on product liability, creating a system of "strict liability" that makes producers and suppliers of defective products liable even if they were not negligent.

Mr Justice Burton ruled that the 114 claimants, who have been granted anonymity, were entitled to compensation. Their lawyers, who were awarded costs thought to be between £2m and £3m, provisionally estimate compensation at £6m to £7m - a total bill for the NHS that could reach £10m.

Patients whose conditions worsen will be able to come back for more. Initial awards will be based on six representative cases, ranging from more than £10,000 to more than £210,000. The largest award was for a woman who developed cirrhosis and had to have a liver transplant.

The ruling sets a precedent for similar cases to be mounted in the future.

The judge will decide next month whether to give permission to appeal.

The act makes producers liable if the product is not as safe as the general public is entitled to expect. But a producer has a defence if it can show that the state of scientific and technical knowledge was such that it could not be expected to have discovered the defect.

The claimants had transfusions following March 1, 1988, when the act came into force. In May 1988, the hepatitis C virus was identified, but before that it was known there was an unidentified virus causing hepatitis, particularly after transfusions. Screening for the virus was not introduced in the UK until September 1991, later than in most other countries in the developed world.

Nicholas Underhill QC, for the blood authorities, told the court: "They do not accept that the moment that the first country introduces screening, unscreened blood products in every other country automatically become defective."

Mr Justice Burton said yesterday that the public expected, and was entitled to expect, clean blood. Blood contaminated with hepatitis C was defective, and anyone who caught the virus as a result was entitled to compensation because the NHS knew about the risk. It should have acted earlier to reduce the risk of transmission, and should have introduced routine screening of all blood transfusions by March 1, 1990.

The judge ruled that under the "no-fault" regime created by the act and the European directive, once a risk had been identified producers should cover themselves against the risk.

Anthony Mallen of Deas Mallen, the Newcastle upon Tyne solicitors which led the action, said: "This is a landmark decision for consumer rights and shows that the effect of the EU directive has been significantly to strengthen product liability law."

The claimants included women who received transfusions immediately after childbirth, and patients given blood during surgery or as treatment for a blood disorder. Several children became infected while being treated for leukaemia.

In May, the judge is to preside over a preliminary hearing involving another nine claimants, including haemophiliacs and a woman who became infected during a heart transplant.

webTitle: Ministers ban age prejudice in NHS

fields.headline: Ministers ban age prejudice in NHS
fields.trailText: A ban on age discrimination in the NHS will be announced by ministers today after evidence that older people are often denied the treatment they need because of the prejudices of doctors and nurses.
fields.body:
A ban on age discrimination in the NHS will be announced by ministers today after evidence that older people are often denied the treatment they need because of the prejudices of doctors and nurses.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will launch a national framework for older people, promising that "NHS services will be provided regardless of age on the basis of clinical need alone".

Social care services will also be told not to use age as a factor in deciding whether people should be eligible for support.

As a first step, Mr Milburn will expand NHS services that disproportionately benefit older people. Over the next three years, people over 65 will benefit from about 70,000 more cataract operations, 16,000 hip and knee replacements and at least 3,000 more heart operations. Money for this will be allocated from the £835m top up in NHS spending in the budget earlier this month.

Mr Milburn will say that age discrimination in the NHS is not as bad as 10 years ago when 20% of cardiac care units would not treat older patients and 40% would not offer them clot-busting drugs.

Protocols were introduced in October to stop doctors and nurses deciding not to resuscitate older patients if they fell into a coma, without prior consultation with the patients or their families.

But a study last year in Scotland found that older trauma patients were much less likely to receive appropriate treatment and the quality of care was affected by doctors' perceptions of their age.

The audit commission found a huge variation in the number of beds available for older people in stroke units that greatly improve patients' prospects of rehabilitation. Campaigners for older people said that two thirds of NHS patients were over 65, but medical staff got little training to understand their needs.

This led to loss of dignity for older people on the wards and disorientation for those left waiting in accident and emergency departments.

Mr Milburn will promise "a more radical approach to rooting out age discrimination across the NHS". A systematic audit of all NHS policies influencing older people's access to services will be carried out over the next six months with a view to eradicating discrimination.

Each NHS trust and social services authority will be told to appoint an executive director to carry out this policy. Older people will be appointed to every patient forum to represent their point of view.

There will also be surveys to compare the treatment of older people with renal failure, heart trouble and cancer to establish whether age is affecting doctors' clinical decisions.

The government will not say older people should necessarily get the same treatment as younger patients. There may be reasons why a particular operation is more risky for an older patient. "But decisions must always be taken on the basis of clinical need and ability to benefit. We are breaking down age barriers in the NHS," a Department of Health source said. Gordon Lishman, director general of Age Concern England, said the new framework would need support at local level.

 People who are blind or partially sighted are left abandoned and confused in eye clinics, according to a report yesterday by the Royal National Institute for the Blind.

It found 86% of patients received appointment letters from clinics in normal size print which they found difficult or impossible to read. Only 40% were told what their eye condition meant and how it would affect them.

fields.headline: Indy's sponsorship 'first': will anybody notice?
fields.trailText:
10.45am: The Independent's building society tie-up will probably go down in as the most unimpressive sponsorship deal in media history, writes Julia Day.

Mar 27: Indy lands building society sponsorship
fields.body:
It will probably go down in as the most unimpressive sponsorship deal in media history.

Today the Independent declared a "publishing first" with its first ever edition to be printed with no advertising.

Readers of the newspaper might benefit from the plug-free pages but they could be forgiven for not noticing anything else unusual.

The novel edition of the paper is a marketing exercise courtesy of a sponsorship deal with Bradford & Bingley believed to be worth less than £50,000.

But the sponsorship is so low-key as to be almost unnoticeable. All the building society gets is a promotional name-check flashed on the front page.

A block above the masthead announces in bold, "Read the first newspaper to be published with no advertising", followed by smaller type declaring "In association with The MarketPlace at Bradford & Bingley".

A small tinted box at the bottom of the front page explains the deal, together with a web link to The Marketplace.

Sponsorship of newspapers is a rare occurence. In 1996 the Mirror was sponsored for a day by Pepsi.

But the cola giant ensured it made an impact and persuaded the paper to change the paper to go blue for the day.

Related story

fields.headline: How drinks products are policed
fields.trailText: Through its "independent complaints panel" the Portman Group tries to ensure alcoholic drinks are marketed responsibly. If a complaint about a product is upheld, the panel asks the manufacturer to make changes and puts out an alert asking retailers not to restock it. But does the panel work? Here are two examples of products that have fallen foul of the code.
fields.body:
Through its "independent complaints panel" the Portman Group tries to ensure alcoholic drinks are marketed responsibly. If a complaint about a product is upheld, the panel asks the manufacturer to make changes and puts out an alert asking retailers not to restock it. But does the panel work? Here are two examples of products that have fallen foul of the code.

Bad Jelly, Haggards Brewery
Greater Manchester police complained about this vodka-based product, claiming it appeared to be aimed at young or under-age drinkers and it was not immediately evident that it contained alcohol.

The panel said the product would be more likely to appeal to under-18s than adults. It took issue with the words "bad" and "jelly" because they were likely to appeal to under-age drinkers. It also said the product's texture and colour, visible through the clear container, were likely to attract younger people.

The panel's report concludes that the company intended to "comply with the code". But when the Guardian spoke to the makers of Bad Jelly last week, they admitted that the label still read "Bad Jelly Company Limited". And the product was still visible through the bottle, although the label had been increased in size slightly to obscure it.

The company's director, Tim Haggard, said it had sold "thousands and thousands" of the product, which was aimed at 18- to 25-year-olds. Customers included big national companies.

Sorted, Halewood International
A member of the public complained that the drink's name, coupled with an image of a target on its label, suggested violent behaviour and had associations with drug culture. The panel agreed with the first point but not the second. It thought it "might" appeal to the under-18s.

Again its report said the company intended to comply with the code. The company has changed the name - to Vodka Sorted. It has removed the offending target picture. It denies that the drink was aimed at under-18s or that its name was intended as a drugs culture reference.

Here are two examples of products that have fallen foul of the code. Bad Jelly, Haggards Brewery Greater Manchester police complained about this vodka-based product, claiming it appeared to be aimed at young or under-age drinkers and it was not immediately evident that it contained alcohol.
