webTitle: Cocktail of problems as drinks firms zero in on youngsters

fields.headline: Cocktail of problems as drinks firms zero in on youngsters
fields.trailText: From Thursday until Sunday night thousands of revellers pour into Nottingham's historic centre and crawl from pub to bar to club. Those turned away because they are not old enough might visit an off-licence that is prepared to turn a blind eye.
fields.body:
They call it the Market Square merry-go-round. From Thursday until Sunday night thousands of revellers pour into Nottingham's historic centre and crawl from pub to bar to club.

Those turned away because they are not old enough might visit an off-licence that is prepared to turn a blind eye or persuade an older friend to buy them a bottle, then find a dark corner in which to drink it.

By the time the Market Square clock begins to strike the early hours, most are staggering home or consummating new relationships in doorways. Others are getting into trouble: fighting or smashing windows or hatching drink-fuelled plans to do mischief.

Of course, such behaviour has gone on across the country since the days of Robin Hood, but clever, aggressive marketing by powerful companies may be encouraging youngsters to drink - and get drunk - from a much earlier age. On offer are colourful, potent drinks with fruity flavours that disguise the taste of alcohol. Many are staggeringly cheap. Some are supplied in a new generation of brightly lit bars often providing live sport or music.

Marketing

Others that researchers believe are intended to tempt even younger drinkers are marketed through local shops and off-licences. Most are designed to be swigged from the bottle, making them easier to carry around - and hide if necessary.

A study released to coincide with a World Health Organisation conference in Sweden last month must have made sobering reading for parents. Three in 10 Britons aged 14 to 16 said they had been drunk at least 20 times. Nearly one in 10 said their families did not know where they were on a Saturday night.

Many researchers believe initiation to drink begins around the age of 11 but can come as early as eight. The average amount of alcohol consumed by 11- to 15-year-olds in 1990 was 0.8 units a week, according to the Office of National Statistics. By 1998 it was 1.6 units. About 1,000 children aged under 15 are admitted to hospital every year with alcohol poisoning.

Why are young people drinking more and earlier? Strathclyde University researchers, in a study published in the magazine Addiction, examined in detail how drinks are marketed. They found that in Britain consumers, especially young people, appeared more willing to experiment than their counterparts in other countries. This was encouraging global producers to use British drinkers as guinea pigs.

The study traced back drinking preferences among the young to the late 1980s, when strong, clear ciders and fortified wines with exciting names and bright packaging came on the market. The mid-1990s were the heydey of these alcopops, and by 1998 Britain's market in so-called flavoured alcoholic beverages was estimated at £750m. Today a new range of products includes pre-mixed cocktails and strong bottled beers. They share bright labelling and often outlandish names that appeal to the young. Quite how young remains a matter for debate.

The Strathclyde team suggests that products such as Bacardi Breezers appeal to "established drinkers" - the 16- to 24-year-olds. But they believe that another range of stronger drinks is designed to attract "starter drinkers" aged 11 to 15.

One product examined was MD 20/20, or "Mad Dog", a fortified wine with an alcohol concentration of 13.1% imported from America which comes in a range of fruit flavours. The drinks come in clear bottles which show off their bright contents. They have a screw top, so are easy to carry around.

The researchers claim that Mad Dog meets the "needs and taste preferences of experimental drinkers". The taste of alcohol is disguised by the fruity flavours. The high alcohol content satisfies the need for "rapid intoxication". They also claim that the drink tends to be sold through smaller outlets which are less easy to regulate and less likely to enforce age limits.

The Drinks Company, which imports MD 20/20, refused to say how many bottles it sold. Its joint managing director, Mike Gilmer, said there was no research on who drank the product but most drinkers would be over 25. It was "nonsense" to suggest it was aimed at children.

The Portman Group, which was set up by Britain's leading drinks manufacturers and has a panel to examine naming, packaging and merchandising issues, has upheld complaints about some products which it thinks are trying to appeal to a younger crowd. But critics argue that the sanctions it can take are limited, and they are uneasy that the group was set up by manufacturers.

The Strathclyde researchers believe that manufacturers "no longer think of themselves as in the alcohol business but in the mood-altering substance business".

In recent years the Portman Group's panel has upheld complaints against a beer called Cannabis and a lager called Greenleaf Hemp. That importers and manufacturers even thought about trying to get such products into bars and off-licences seems to back up the point.

The trend is particularly worrying because often young people with addiction problems take drugs and drink alcohol.

Back in the centre of Nottingham, the tactics that bars and pubs use to draw youngsters in are obvious. Almost every venue has special offers, happy hours, theme nights.

Libertys, for example, encourages drinkers to its "Frisky" Friday night. Admission is free and patrons can drink until 1am. Metz, a schnapps-based drink, is on offer at two for the price of one. At Weatherspoons pub on the square, its "Famous Five" of beers and ready-mixed cocktails are £1 each "all day, every day".

The Palais nightclub has a range of offers to ensure that the venue is as full as possible all week. Thursday is billed as VFM (value for money) night, when all drinks are £1 before midnight. "Beat the clock," its jazzy website urges.

Violence

The drinks would probably be even cheaper were it not for a "gentleman's agreement" brokered by the police that bars will not sell for less than £1 each. But it does not stop the violence. In 1999 police responded to 1,704 calls to licensed premises in the city centre and made 529 arrests. The pattern is similar nationwide. A prison report found that a quarter of young inmates had been drinking before they committed their crime.

The under-age know where they will be served. Indeed one city guide, itchy nottingham (sic), jokes that one bar accepts "bum fluff moustaches" as a form of ID.

Dave, 18, is a regular of this establishment. "I've been drinking around the pubs and bars in Nottingham since I was 15," he said. "Before that I would get booze from off-licences.

"Of course, there are fights and kids getting into trouble. That's the same the country over. It's what Britain is all about at the weekend, isn't it - getting pissed, causing a bit of trouble, having a laugh."

fields.headline: Olympic hero fronts Flora campaign
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Sir Steven Redgrave is swapping oar for butter knife to front a new advertising campaign for Flora, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
It was only a matter of time before Olympic champion rower Steve Redgrave followed fellow sporting heroes Gary Lineker and Ian Wright in to a new career in advertising.

Swapping an oar for a butter knife, Sir Steven is to front a new advertising campaign for Flora pro.activ.

It is the first commercial venture for Sir Steven since retiring after returning from the Olympics where he won his fifth gold medal.

He will star in a new TV and press advertising campaign which breaks on April 2 during Coronation Street on ITV.

The campaign will be based around the cholesterol-lowering properties of the Unilever brand.

But it is not only Sir Steven has been roped in to acting as a spokesman for the brand.

A host of other celebrities will "act as his ambassadors in spreading the word about the importance of knowing your cholesterol level", according to Flora.

They have all had their cholesterol levels tested as part of the campaign.

With the UK Department of Health considering a cholesterol level of <5.2 mmol/L to be normal, the results are mixed: Sir Redgrave's level is 6.6; Jack Charlton 5.2; Henry Cooper 5.7; Sharron Davies 5.6; Edwina Currie 5.9; David Vine 7.6; Pete Waterman, 3.6; Vanessa Feltz 4.0; Deepak Verma 6.4; Gabby Yorath 5.3; Jo Guest 4.3; Gloria Hunniford 6.4; and Stuart Hall 6.1.

"We've all got this number that is personal to us and when considered with the other factors in heart health, it says a lot about how healthy we are and it can be a real signpost for the future," said Sir Redgrave.

"I am very happy to be involved in something that can help make people a bit healthier."

fields.headline: Text message numbers fall
fields.trailText: 10.15am; The number of messages sent by teenagers and adults alike fell in February for the first time in a year, writes Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
For text messaging phobics there is some good news and some bad news.

The good news is that the number of messages sent by teenagers and adults alike fell in February for the first time in 12 months.

But before Luddites of the world unite start rejoicing, the bad news is there are reasons for this blip and Britain is still on course to crash through the 1bn-text-messages-a-month barrier this summer.

In all, 808m text messages were sent in February - down from 927m in January according to the Mobile Data Association.

But a record number of text messages sent on New Year's Day - helped by new members of the mobile phone club joining over Christmas - gave January its head start.

Although Valentine's Day activity boosted the number of text messages sent in February overall, it was not enough to compensate for the shorter month.

Orange recorded 14m text messages passing through its network on the day, according to an MDA spokeswoman.

"At the end of January, a lot of marketing campaigns come to an end," said the spokeswoman. "February and March are traditionally quite months, but it picks up again at Easter."

Significantly, she insisted that predictions of up to 1bn text messages to be sent across the UK by June remain on track.

webTitle: Deal with the disease and go to the polls on June 7

fields.headline: Deal with the disease and go to the polls on June 7
fields.standfirst: Blair will be seen to put duty before ambition if he delays by a month
fields.trailText: Blair will be seen to put duty before ambition if he delays by a month
fields.body:
Public apathy deadens more than politics. It can envelop almost anything, if exposure lasts long enough and rage becomes futile. Sooner or later, passion peters out. The time comes when there's little left to say about a disaster that's immutable. Already beginning to be bored with another piece about foot and mouth? I guess so. But that's the point. The boredom threshold is a political fact, as an apathetic nation is lured towards an election it neither very badly wants nor very badly doesn't want, during a calamity that many people, in their shoulder- shrugging British way, learn to live with.

As decision day approaches for Tony Blair, this has to be a big part of his judgment. What will the voters really care about? Will they rage at him for going too soon, if he sticks with the four-year blueprint ending on May 3? Or soon forget about the horrors they now see on the screen every night? My bet is that he'll settle for a cautious version of the second scenario. Long afraid of apathy's low turn-out, he can now turn apathy to advantage. June 7 would be a good moment to split the difference.

When it happens, this will be an election far removed from 1997 in everything except the approximate result. Staring at these empty fields, and smoking pyres, and slaughterhouse soldiers, not to mention failing trains, and rundown hospitals, and struggling schools, voters need a vast reservoir of tolerance to prevent them rising up in rage to punish the nearest available prime minister. But apathy, and William Hague, will not find them wanting.

Apathy will ensure, first, that foot and mouth disappears from most screens within a week of the election starting. Already bored with it, the majority will soon forget. The campaign will take over all the headlines, because that's what all the parties want and all the media will gladly respond to. Part of the reason why foot and mouth has eaten into the national mood is because there are no pictures to knock it off the bulletins. A campaign, even one that has a hard job making people care, will soon change that.

It needs to be preceded by the impression that the government is at last in charge. That may not happen by May, but will certainly have climaxed before the autumn. In retrospect it's clear that ministers weren't in charge from the beginning. They got the urgency of the thing all wrong. For a few days, Hague at last managed to make the government and not the opposition the target of big questions. But field marshal Blair has handed over command to the brigadiers, who can be heard barking over the air-waves with unagricultural authority.

Though the cases will keep coming for many months after the curve declines, they're still seen more as acts of God and pigswill than the results of political failure. There is political failure, in the rundown of vet services for farm surveillance, but as with so much else the blame is divided: the Thatcher plague on the public sector, as yet unrectified by her successor.

Meanwhile, time passes. F and M, from being a catastrophic novelty, becomes part of almost normal life. Other realities move up alongside it. It's specious to pretend, as the spinners now do, that the whole world is looking to British elections being held in May for proof that the country is still part of the planet. But governing is paralysed by strategic indecision, the blight of pre-election phases in all countries everywhere, regardless of whether they're discretionary or fixed-term. Already, it seems to this observer, the case for indefinite delay is trumped by the need to settle things. What has changed, since the days when imminent elections seemed an affront to democracy, is the discovery that there's no likely time when they would seem much less of one.

These preliminaries should certainly be expected to change the nature of the campaign. It will not be joyful, and is less likely than it was to be casually venomous. The original plans of both main sides were firing up to emphasise anger and contempt. They were going to make it as bitterly personal as they could find the words for: the Tories because they had nothing else to say except how exquisitely they abominated Tony Blair, Labour because it needed something to stimulate the nightmares of supporters and drive them to polls in which they may otherwise have lost faith.

No doubt there will still be some of this. But the sombre context indicates a different presentation, especially by the government. At a time when crisis is still a word in voters' consciousness, ministers will want to emphasise their gravitas, their experience, their dutiful sense of responsibility, even, lord help us, their competence. Instead of parading their bright-eyed triumphs, they'll be offering themselves as solid custodians of the future, the safest pair of hands to deal with future pigswill visitations or any other national crises.

On the face of it, this should be a pretty incredible claim. Standing back from our politics, foreign visitors are struck by the terrible state of things here. These may all have come in a rush, and, deep down, the Blair administration may have laid the ground for massive improvements at some time later. But with the fields stripped bare and the railways in chaos and doctors gloom-mongering the NHS and police numbers in decline and sundry ministers unable to give an honest account of their public lives, the election ought to be lost. That it isn't going to be is tribute to the happy congruence between Blairism's need to be judged in the long term not the short, and the voters' apathetic disbelief in the possibility of anything better. A dismal verdict, I'm afraid. But the most plausible one available.

The best thing to do now would be to announce that all elections, the local and the general, will be held on June 7. This would pay necessary respect to those people, especially in rural areas, who would be justifiably affronted by a rush to the polls, or by local elections that can be changed by statute without terrible insult to anyone. A month is a long delay, and time enough for man to gain some control over the contagion that is decimating the herds. The prime minister would be seen to do his governing duty, at some cost to his political plans. The first half of the allotted period would be spent showing he had got his priorities right.

The second half could then see a campaign that wasn't distracted by charges of opportunism. The balance of opportunism has in any case swung round. It's not at all clear, after all that's happened, that going early is going best for the Labour vote. But all that's happened means that Britain needs a government in place, settled enough to confront the crisis that may be more serious than foot and mouth: a downturn in European economies that could yet be our really fearsome autumn rendering.

They were going to make it as bitterly personal as they could find the words for: the Tories because they had nothing else to say except how exquisitely they abominated Tony Blair, Labour because it needed something to stimulate the nightmares of supporters and drive them to polls in which they may otherwise have lost faith. No doubt there will still be some of this. But the sombre context indicates a different presentation, especially by the government. At a time when crisis is still a word in voters' consciousness, ministers will want to emphasise their gravitas, their experience, their dutiful sense of responsibility, even, lord help us, their competence. Instead of parading their bright-eyed triumphs, they'll be offering themselves as solid custodians of the future, the safest pair of hands to deal with future pigswill visitations or any other national crises. On the face of it, this should be a pretty incredible claim. Standing back from our politics, foreign visitors are struck by the terrible state of things here. These may all have come in a rush, and, deep down, the Blair administration may have laid the ground for massive improvements at some time later. But with the fields stripped bare and the railways in chaos and doctors gloom-mongering the NHS and police numbers in decline and sundry ministers unable to give an honest account of their public lives, the election ought to be lost. That it isn't going to be is tribute to the happy congruence between Blairism's need to be judged in the long term not the short, and the voters' apathetic disbelief in the possibility of anything better. A dismal verdict, I'm afraid. But the most plausible one available. The best thing to do now would be to announce that all elections, the local and the general, will be held on June 7. This would pay necessary respect to those people, especially in rural areas, who would be justifiably affronted by a rush to the polls, or by local elections that can be changed by statute without terrible insult to anyone. A month is a long delay, and time enough for man to gain some control over the contagion that is decimating the herds. The prime minister would be seen to do his governing duty, at some cost to his political plans. The first half of the allotted period would be spent showing he had got his priorities right. The second half could then see a campaign that wasn't distracted by charges of opportunism. The balance of opportunism has in any case swung round. It's not at all clear, after all that's happened, that going early is going best for the Labour vote. But all that's happened means that Britain needs a government in place, settled enough to confront the crisis that may be more serious than foot and mouth: a downturn in European economies that could yet be our really fearsome autumn rendering. hugoyoung@compuserve.com What's going on? webTitle: Foot and mouth: Delays and scale of problem overwhelmed ministry

fields.headline: Mass grave highlights dimensions of a nightmare running out of control
fields.standfirst:
Delays and scale of problem overwhelmed ministry

Special report: foot and mouth
Foot and mouth: free daily email service with latest updates
fields.trailText: The mass grave in Cumbria is the most brutal attempt to get a grip on an epidemic far worse than anyone expected by a government desperate to avoid criticism.
fields.body:
The mass grave in Cumbria is the most brutal attempt to get a grip on an epidemic far worse than anyone expected by a government desperate to avoid criticism.

For three weeks Nick Brown, agriculture minister, insisted that the foot and mouth outbreak was under control, and then his confidence began to evaporate until finally he conceded that the disease was winning.

Angry farmers were the first sign of trouble 10 days ago when they objected to a Ministry of Agriculture (Maff) plan to kill healthy animals to prevent the spread of the disease. What had been a cross-party consensus broke down when piles of rotting animals remained in fields for days in Devon and Cumbria. What started as a few voices demanding a vaccination rather than slaughter became a chorus. The united front of politicians, farmers and vets fell apart.

Maff was in trouble; its policies were seen not to be keeping up with the crisis. The prime minister intervened. But what has gone wrong and why?

Mr Brown, sensitive to the fact that he would carry the can for any mistakes, has constantly deferred to the advice of the chief vet, Jim Scudamore. From the first day that the outbreak was identified at an abattoir in Essex, his has been a copybook response.

First all animal exports were stopped and a tracing system for the pigs involved was put in place. Two days later the origin of the Essex outbreak had been traced to Haddon-on-the-Wall in Northumberland, and Mr Scudamore knew Britain was in trouble. The diseased pigs in Northumberland had been infectious for two weeks; it was urgent to trace every animal involved.

What happened next was a nightmare. Unknown to Mr Scudamore, the pigs had infected sheep a distance away on another farm. These had been sent to market in Hexham, then on to Longtown in Cumbria, and on to Devon, Northampton, and onward for export.

The sheer volume of mixing and marketing of sheep was so great that no one at Maff was aware of it. The nightmare has been getting worse every day.

The logistics of identifying the disease, valuing the stock, killing and then disposing of carcasses became too much for Maff to deal with. Delays led to mounting criticism, with the National Farmers Union and the Conservatives demanding army intervention.

The first problem the ministry had to admit was a shortage of vets to identify outbreaks. The 220 ministry staff vets soon became inadequate for the task. Once a vet had been in contact with foot and mouth he could not inspect another farm animal for five days. While the virus does not normally infect humans, it can live in the throat for three days.

Appeals were immediately sent round the world for volunteer vets. More than 100 have flown in from as far away as Australia, the US and Canada. Final year students from veterinary college and army vets were drafted in, and private vets were paid £150 a day, later increased to £250, to help out.

The issue became a crisis when Maff's hired experts said the main problem in containing the disease was delay between the call from the farmer and destruction of the animals. More vets were crucial.

To ease their burden, army logistic teams were brought in to do their administration. The time between visiting a diseased animals and going on to the next outbreak has been shortened to 72 hours. Mr Blair pledged that the time between the first call and slaughter would be less than 24 hours.

The second problem, which Maff blamed partly on farmers, was the time taken for valuations of animals before slaughter.

Every farmer has a right under the Animal Health Act to have animals valued before being killed. On a farm with 2,000 assorted sheep, cattle and goats, that can take time. A farmer also has the right to choose his valuer and to appeal if he thinks the valuation is wrong, a process that could cost two days.

The ministry has provided blanket valuations slightly more generous than the farmer could expect. It will cost the taxpayer millions.

The third difficulty was getting the slaughter teams to the farms to kill hundreds of animals.

Disposing of the carcasses brought most problems - and the loudest criticism from farmers, the NFU and the opposition.

In the 1967 outbreak most bodies were buried, but modern environmental scruples about poisoning water supplies prevented that in many places. The sheer volume of animals meant massive pyres had to be build, rendering plants brought on line and the army brought in to bury 500,000 sheep in a mass grave in Cumbria.

No one is now pretending the situation is under control, but the ministry seems at least to be catching up. The issue of whether to vaccinate is now the main focus of unrest.

webTitle: Brown to blame trading in sheep

fields.headline: Brown to blame trading in sheep
fields.standfirst:
New controls as ministers pinpoint loophole

Special report: foot and mouth
Foot and mouth: free daily email service with latest updates
fields.trailText: The government will today publish a damning official account of the likely source of the foot and mouth outbreak by pointing the finger of suspicion firmly at excessive movement of sheep.
fields.body:
The government will today publish a damning official account of the likely source of the foot and mouth outbreak by pointing the finger of suspicion firmly at excessive movement of sheep.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, is also expected to publish a consultation paper on banning the use of pigswill from human foodstuffs.

He also intends to close what may have been the fatal loophole which allows movement of sheep, but not pigs or cattle, within 21 days of purchase - which, according to Tony Blair, made tracing the disease as difficult as tracing the common cold in people.

The move amounts to a last-ditch drive to persuade voters that ministers have sufficient control over the deepening crisis to justify pressing ahead with a May 3 general election campaign, rather than postponing polling day until June 7.

Though October has been ruled out, June is a becoming a serious option despite deep reluctance in Downing Street and Millbank to abandon their plans - and tell to the world that Britain has a major problem on its hands.

While the prime minister signalled his determination to let the "containment by cull" policy - coupled with the army's frantic drive to bury, not burn carcasses - prove its effectiveness, he also told MPs that the vaccination option was not being ruled out.

Mr Blair's spokesman later told reporters that the use of pigswill - increasingly from non-local sources - is already banned in Portugal and Luxembourg .Only about 1% of UK pigs are fed on it.

Last night the Conservatives raised the stakes over the government's competence. The Tory agriculture spokesman, Tim Yeo, claimed that Labour had closed down a special unit to crack down on rogue sheep traders in October 1997.

After the unit's abolition, sheep movements around Britain increased, Mr Yeo said. That is highly damaging if the Tories can make it stick.

Another opinion poll, this time for Channel 4's Powerhouse programme, yesterday showed a majority of voters unhappy with the government's handling of crisis and favouring a postponement of the election.

Yesterday - as 21 new cases of foot and mouth were confirmed, bringing the total to 628 - Mr Brown visited both Cumbria and Devon, two of the main hotspots, to explain and defend current policy. If the current cull, coupled with the army's increasingly effective efforts to dispose of carcasses by burying, not burning them, does not work vaccination looks a renewed option.

The prime minister gave clear indications of official thinking on both pigswill and sheep movements. A lot of sheep had been traced to far-flung parts of the country, sold on up to five times after being bought at market, his aides confirmed.

William Hague urged the creation of a "crisis cabinet" to tackle the disease, complaining that current efforts lacked urgency and co-ordination.

The Channel 4 poll, carried out among 1,000 voters at the weekend, found that 77% of voters believed that the crisis was out of control and that 69% believed the handling of the crisis has been slow and inadequate. Over half Labour voters concur.

webTitle: Sketch: Foot and mouth and now bats in the belfry

fields.headline: Foot and mouth and now bats in the belfry
fields.standfirst: Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: Once again the Commons was dominated by the grim and inexorable progress of foot and mouth disease. But one happy moment, a brief relief from the horrors, came first.
fields.body:
Once again the Commons was dominated by the grim and inexorable progress of foot and mouth disease. But one happy moment, a brief relief from the horrors, came first.

Michael Fabricant has for some time been promoting himself as a wise and measured statesperson, apt to be promoted to the front bench of his party. Yesterday he reverted to default mode, and went bonkers again. It may be a subtle career move.

In questions to the church commissioners, who take the corporeal form of Stuart Bell MP, Mr Fabricant expressed sympathy for the archbishops of Canterbury and York, whom, he said, were overburdened by administrative tasks. What this country required, he insisted, was a third archbishop.

Quite why we need a third archbishop when Church of England attendances are lower than ever was not clear until a few moments later, when Mr Fabricant said that the new archdiocesan seat should be in Lichfield - his constituency.

At once, all was revealed. He wants the job himself! Mickey has always loved dressing up, and archbishops have wonderful, flowing silk robes, lovely pointed hats which will save a fortune on summer and winter wigs, and nice curly mitres, perfect for giving friends perky pats on the backside.

You might think that the son of a rabbi should not be first choice for what is basically an episcopalian job. But odder things have happened. Disc jockeying, Mickey's first trade, has much in common with being a bishop. You need to talk fast on one note, must hold a restive audience, and be capable of surviving long periods of boredom, whether during liturgy or equally repetitive technobeat music. And he'll be perfect at royal weddings.

Mr Bell told him, in effect, not to be silly, and we moved on to Tony Blair's report from the Stockholm EU summit. Prime ministers talk about these events rather as if they were dinner parties hosted by themselves to appreciative murmurs from the other countries. ("This agenda is being led by the UK," he said at one point, rather like a hostess might shyly admit that she had made the delicious casserole herself.) Opposition leaders have to point out how it all went wrong - the soup was cold, the wine corked, and the guests loathed each other.

William Hague said that the government had made many mistakes, mostly in taking Keith Vaz who, according to officials, had an entirely empty diary. "But he hosted a meal for EU officials - I really hope he didn't try to charge them for lunch," Mr Hague said. Messrs Blair, Vaz and Robin Cook sat as sour and expressionless as disinfected welly boots.

Mr Hague asked for a war cabinet to co-ordinate the work of the various departments. Mr Blair answered sarcastically that "asking for another committee is beside the point" - a typical Blairite evasion, since Mr Hague was making a quite separate point that the Treasury and the Ministry of Defence need their heads banging together.

But help was at hand. Gerald Kaufman offered fulsome support. He accused Mr Hague of spouting "sub-Churchillian rhetoric... and Churchill never promised 'we shall fight them in the committee rooms'."

He added to this rather unfair mockery, "the only thing worse than a cynical opportunist is an incapable cynical opportunist", and called for a cull of Tory MPs at the coming (or possibly not coming) election. Then he slipped his little face-cage back on.

I find this all slightly distasteful. Mr Kaufman is a distinguished and cerebral MP who has served under five Labour leaders. He doesn't need to sound like a young ambitious brown-noser.

webTitle: Comment: Press and politics in denial over foot and mouth

fields.headline: Fiddling facts while we burn
fields.standfirst:
London press and politics are in denial over foot and mouth

Special report: foot and mouth
Foot and mouth: free daily email service with latest updates
fields.trailText: London press and politics are in denial over foot and mouth.
fields.body:
It's not exactly a war, of course. But it would have been something like this during the Blitz, except in reverse. Then the countryside got by OK - quietly fattening the odd pig, shooting rabbits - with only a hazy notion about life in the Anderson shelters and the tube stations. Now London carries on as normal, while in the country it is just like a war.

The mood veers suddenly between cheeriness and bouts of panic. Hard information is negligible. Rumours spread even quicker than the virus. Everyone knows someone who has heard about some scam or other. There is a universal contempt for authority, though much of the criticism is contradictory. Deep down, in a very British way, people want to do the right thing. Whatever that is.

Wapping screams (and Farringdon Road whispers) that what Britain really, really needs is an immediate general election. In Herefordshire, the notion seems too bizarre to contemplate. There has been only one subject for discussion: foot and mouth. And yesterday, according to rumour, the first case was confirmed in our valley.

If so, this is the fourth phase of the crisis. Phase one was fingers-crossed-and-pass-the-disinfectant. That ended last Tuesday when news came through that one local big-way farmer had the disease on one of his outposts elsewhere. They would thus be shooting and burning at once on his properties here.

The news convulsed the neighbourhood. The school was shut down (on the very morning the Guardian said no schools were closed), to avoid the children being distressed by the gunfire. Straw defences were renewed and redoubled. Some farmers barricaded themselves in to their homes. Then of course there was a delay. And we moved slowly into phase three, which was altogether more fatalistic.

There was a growing sense of pointlessness. We were surrounded by dots on the map; we could now see the fires; and everyone thought it was when, not whether. There were confirmed cases just over the mountain, only a few miles away as the crow flies, which is probably the relevant metaphor given what crows do to unburied carcasses. One neighbour has been losing hens to a fox, which conceivably - in clear breach of Maff guidelines - had not disinfected itself first. The customary trail of blood and feathers was spotted two farms away.

The farmgate straw was becoming less and less convincing, and farmers began to sense that the ones who got the disease might well be the lucky ones. At least they get compensation. They save on the feed bill - higher than usual because of the late spring - and, with no animals to look after, might even consider shoving off to Tenerife for a week sometime soon, which for livestock farmers is normally unthinkable. The ones left behind see costs spiralling and income prospects at zero. Animals stuck the wrong side of a road have been dying in the snow. Nothing can go to market. The AI man (the artificial inseminator) is not allowed to call, so farmers without bulls will get no calves next year. Getting the disease could seem a better bet. "We need a ministry of understanding," said one farmer's wife plaintively.

You can argue, if you like, to what extent farmers have contributed to this tragedy, whether they are sentimental or callous about their animals; villains or victims. The truth of course is that they vary. But none of them constructed the crazed system of subsidies, designed to benefit the French peasantry of the 1950s, which has favoured the rich and the unscrupulous at the expense of the ordinary farmer, and the consumer. This feels now like the final crisis of British agriculture, as we have known it. It is hard to imagine any upshot other than a ruined countryside, producing less, dearer and worse food.

Meantime, London is still in denial. Yesterday there was the Sun, backed by the chairman of the parliamentary Labour party (who represents the pastoralists of Hammersmith) saying that if the election is not held on May 3 (a full year early), "it will cripple the tourist trade". Well, la-di-dah. General Franco postponed Spanish elections for 40 years and Sun readers still went to the Costa Brava.

We are supposed to believe that tourism hasn't already been crippled by ministers screaming at people to keep out of the countryside. All will be well provided Tony Blair stops trying to control foot and mouth, but instead spends a month on the road campaigning instead. Telling us how he has united the nation, no doubt.

Just one question: if the election is on when the last ewe is killed by the last army bullet, will Alastair Campbell ring the BBC and demand that they ignore that item, and instead lead the bulletins with Labour's proposals for the glittering future of agriculture?

webTitle: Leader: Rape victims require fair trials too

fields.headline: Conflicting rights
fields.standfirst:
Rape victims require fair trials too

Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: The law lords are being asked to resolve a conflict between two fundamental rights this week: the right to a fair trial; and the right of victims in rape trials not to be further traumatised by defence lawyers publicly scrutinising their previous sexual history in intrusive detail.
fields.body:
The law lords are being asked to resolve a conflict between two fundamental rights this week: the right to a fair trial; and the right of victims in rape trials not to be further traumatised by defence lawyers publicly scrutinising their previous sexual history in intrusive detail. Defendant Y believes a new law, introduced only last December, breaches his right to a fair trial. He is accused of rape and wishes to introduce evidence which would show the jury that the complainant had willingly had sex with him in the previous week. The trial judge has ruled this inadmissible, under a new Criminal Evidence Act. He has adjourned the trial until higher courts decide whether the new rule contradicts the new human rights act, which guarantees fair trials. The appeal court ruled that it did, but it now goes before the law lords.

The reason why the new rule was introduced was simple enough: the failure of judges to exercise tight control over the admissibility of earlier sexual history. It is now 25 years since a committee under high court judge Dame Rose Heilbron set out why a victim's sexual history was largely irrelevant in a rape trial but "inimical to the fair trial of the essential issues". Discretion was extended to judges to exclude such evidence, but in three out of four cases where admissibility was sought, permission was granted. The law lords should re-read the Heilbron report - particularly as they are all men. They should also read the recent research of Professor Jennifer Temkin, documenting prejudice against rape victims even female barristers can hold, as well as showing how the old trick of discrediting victims in the eyes of jurors lives on. The new rule does not end judicial discretion but rightly seriously curtails it. Whether defendant Y had sex with his complainant in the previous week is quite irrelevant.

Where it would have been relevant is if the defendant had used a second defence: an "honest belief" that consent had been granted. Under one defence (consent of the woman) sexual history will normally be ruled out; under the second (honest belief) it will not. Judges will be required to direct jurors to take account of a previous sexual relationship in assessing the defendant's state of mind, but to disregard it in assessing the woman's. As the appeal court noted this owed more to "Lewis Carroll than to sensible jurisprudence". If the law lords fail to clear up the muddle, parliament must.

webTitle: Comment: law lords deciding rape law is unacceptable

fields.headline: Bad judgment
fields.standfirst:
A crucial issue in rape trials is being decided by male law lords. Can't they see it's unacceptable?

Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: A crucial issue in rape trials is being decided by male law lords. Can't they see it's unacceptable?
fields.body:
The absence of any women among the law lords currently pondering one of the most controversial questions in rape law is both internationally embarrassing and unacceptable in a modern, democratic society. Five male judges in the UK's highest court are currently hearing argument on the extent to which male defendants should be allowed to ask female complainants about their previous sexual history.

This issue involves a direct conflict between, on the one hand, the fair trial rights of male defendants and, on the other, the rights of women to respect for their privacy and dignity, and not to be subjected to inhuman and degrading treatment. Not surprisingly, how to strike this balance is a question on which there has always been a strong divergence of views between men and women. Yet, when the court of appeal decided this case, the three male judges appealed to "common sense" and "human nature" to justify their decision.

In 1999, parliament passed a law which tried to strike a balance between these competing rights. As we all know too well, women are chronically under-represented in parliament, but there are at least some women MPs and peers. Many took an active part in the debate which led to the law being passed.

However, it is an all-male court which will now decide whether parliament got the balance right. Since October last year, under the Human Rights Act, our courts have the power to declare laws incompatible with the Human Rights Act if they disagree with parliament. The House of Lords, the UK's highest court, has effectively become a constitutional court. Its ruling on this question will be the definitive legal ruling. The case therefore raises serious questions about the democratic legitimacy of those deciding it.

Last week, the Fawcett Society asked the House of Lords for permission to intervene in the case to argue that it should not be decided by a House of Lords comprised exclusively of men. The society's lawyers (one woman, one man) advised the society that it had a very serious legal argument that demanded an answer.

One of the most fundamental guarantees of our legal system is the guarantee that cases be decided by an "impartial tribunal". The legal test for whether a court is impartial is very straightforward: it is whether fair-minded and informed members of the public would have "a reasonable apprehension" that the court is biased.

Fawcett argued that, given the nature of the issue to be decided, members of the public would have legitimate concerns about the court's impartiality. They would be concerned that an all-male court, without the benefit of a female perspective, might unconsciously prefer the interests of the male defendant over the female complainant when deciding how to strike the balance.

The legal test for impartiality focuses on the public's perception, and not on whether the court is actually biased. This is because the rationale for the guarantee is that in a democratic society the public should be confident in the administration of justice.

Fawcett was asking for permission to intervene in order to put before the House of Lords arguments and academic research which demonstrate that members of the public would have these serious concerns. This material showed that the inclusion of a female perspective in judicial deliberations makes a difference to reasoning processes and outcomes.

As Madam Justice Bertha Wilson (a member of Canada's supreme court during the 1980s) has said, "The universalist doctrine of human rights must include a realistic concept of masculine and feminine humanity regarded as a whole, that humankind is dual and must be represented in its dual form if the trap of an asexual abstraction in which human being is always declined in the masculine is to be avoided."

The society's request to intervene, however, was refused by an appeal committee of three law lords (Lords Steyn, Hope and Millett). It was refused without even giving the society the opportunity of persuading the committee at an oral hearing.

The report of the appeal committee which rejected Fawcett's request merely reported to the House of Lords the fact of its refusal. It did not explain why. It did not even explain to the House the reason why the Fawcett Society had sought to intervene.

In a case where the purpose of the intervention was to argue that, compared to parliament, an all-male House of Lords lacks the democratic legitimacy necessary to command the public's confidence in its impartiality, don't the law lords owe parliament an explanation about why they slammed the door shut?

The government has not only made international commitments to achieving gender balance in decision-making, it has also made a public commitment to achieving a 50:50 balance in all public appointments. The absence of any women on the UK's highest court is embarrassing and unacceptable. The very least the public can expect is an explanation from the law lords as to why they do not appear to take these concerns seriously.

 Mary Ann Stephenson is director of the Fawcett Society.

webTitle: Foot and mouth and now bats in the belfry

fields.headline: Foot and mouth and now bats in the belfry
fields.trailText: Once again the Commons was dominated by the grim and inexorable progress of foot and mouth disease. But one happy moment, a brief relief from the horrors, came first.
fields.body:
Once again the Commons was dominated by the grim and inexorable progress of foot and mouth disease. But one happy moment, a brief relief from the horrors, came first.

Michael Fabricant has for some time been promoting himself as a wise and measured statesperson, apt to be promoted to the front bench of his party. Yesterday he reverted to default mode, and went bonkers again. It may be a subtle career move.

In questions to the church commissioners, who take the corporeal form of Stuart Bell MP, Mr Fabricant expressed sympathy for the archbishops of Canterbury and York, whom, he said, were overburdened by administrative tasks. What this country required, he insisted, was a third archbishop.

Quite why we need a third archbishop when Church of England attendances are lower than ever was not clear until a few moments later, when Mr Fabricant said that the new archdiocesan seat should be in Lichfield - his constituency.

At once, all was revealed. He wants the job himself! Mickey has always loved dressing up, and archbishops have wonderful, flowing silk robes, lovely pointed hats which will save a fortune on summer and winter wigs, and nice curly mitres, perfect for giving friends perky pats on the backside.

You might think that the son of a rabbi should not be first choice for what is basically an episcopalian job. But odder things have happened. Disc jockeying, Mickey's first trade, has much in common with being a bishop. You need to talk fast on one note, must hold a restive audience, and be capable of surviving long periods of boredom, whether during liturgy or equally repetitive technobeat music. And he'll be perfect at royal weddings.

Mr Bell told him, in effect, not to be silly, and we moved on to Tony Blair's report from the Stockholm EU summit. Prime ministers talk about these events rather as if they were dinner parties hosted by themselves to appreciative murmurs from the other countries. ("This agenda is being led by the UK," he said at one point, rather like a hostess might shyly admit that she had made the delicious casserole herself.) Opposition leaders have to point out how it all went wrong - the soup was cold, the wine corked, and the guests loathed each other.

William Hague said that the government had made many mistakes, mostly in taking Keith Vaz who, according to officials, had an entirely empty diary. "But he hosted a meal for EU officials - I really hope he didn't try to charge them for lunch," Mr Hague said. Messrs Blair, Vaz and Robin Cook sat as sour and expressionless as disinfected welly boots.

Mr Hague asked for a war cabinet to co-ordinate the work of the various departments. Mr Blair answered sarcastically that "asking for another committee is beside the point" - a typical Blairite evasion, since Mr Hague was making a quite separate point that the Treasury and the Ministry of Defence need their heads banging together.

But help was at hand. Gerald Kaufman offered fulsome support. He accused Mr Hague of spouting "sub-Churchillian rhetoric... and Churchill never promised 'we shall fight them in the committee rooms'."

He added to this rather unfair mockery, "the only thing worse than a cynical opportunist is an incapable cynical opportunist", and called for a cull of Tory MPs at the coming (or possibly not coming) election. Then he slipped his little face-cage back on.

I find this all slightly distasteful. Mr Kaufman is a distinguished and cerebral MP who has served under five Labour leaders. He doesn't need to sound like a young ambitious brown-noser.

fields.headline: Greens fight 'illogical' broadcasts ruling
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The Green party is threatening legal action against the BBC and Channel 4 over plans to deny the party election broadcasts.
fields.body:
The Green party is threatening legal action against the BBC and Channel 4 over plans to deny the party election broadcasts.

The Green party of England and Wales, which is fielding 130 candidates in the general election, has fallen foul of rules drawn up after devolution of power to parliaments in Scotland and Wales.

To qualify for election broadcasts on channels and radio stations received across England, Scotland and Wales - including C4, Channel 5 and BBC radio - parties must field candidates in one sixth of seats in each country. The Greens easily pass that threshold in England and Wales, but do not contest seats in Scotland, which are fought by the Scottish Green party.

The Greens claim they are being penalised further because, under special exceptions agreed by broadcasters, the Scottish Nationalists and Plaid Cymru - who by definition do not stand in England - will qualify for nationwide BBC broadcasts because they have more than one MP at Westminster.

The Greens have been advised that they have a legal case under the European convention on human rights.

Penny Kemp, chair of the party's national executive, said: "Unelected and unaccountable officials, on the basis of inconsistent and illogical rules made on their own whim, are basically preventing voters from hearing about the Green party."

webTitle: Election delay would cost parties millions

fields.headline: Election delay would cost parties millions
fields.standfirst:
The billboard battle has already started, and the war rooms are geared up. But what if Blair decides against May 3?

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The billboard battle has already started, and the war rooms are geared up. But what if Blair decides against May 3?
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, Lucy Ward  and Nicholas Watt
fields.body:
The two major parties face a financial headache if Tony Blair delays the general election, with millions of pounds thrown away on billboard advertising, staff hirings and election planning.

The Liberal Democrats have yet to spend serious sums, but may face a cash flow crisis.

Any election-related spending since mid February must be included in the total allowable spending if the campaign takes place in October.

Both the Conservatives and Labour have run big billboard campaigns since mid-February, and would have to regard them as wasted cash in the event of a delay. Both have also geared up their war rooms and regional press offices, as well as spending tens of thousands planning the logistics for the putative date of May 3.

Labour's "economic disaster 2" posters, designed to set the tone for the May election, would largely be forgotten by voters by the time of an autumn election.

The parties also face cancellation fees from poster site companies for forthcoming election posters. Planned polling of the day-to-day election mood would also have to be cancelled.

In the only respite for the two, the Political Parties, Elections and Referendums Act allows a higher level of spending in October, when total spending per party would be capped at £18.78m; in May each party is capped at just under £15m on the assumption it is fighting every seat.

The cap covers anything spent since February 16, when the legislation took effect.

A delayed campaign would also force more to be divulged about the parties' sources of funding. The electoral commission would require a second set of reports in early autumn on recent donations.

Labour has already booked poster sites for the autumn to cope for a possible October poll; it has until mid-summer to take up its options.

Conservative sources admit a delay would be welcomed in public by William Hague, but it would present the party's billionaire treasurer, Lord Ashcroft, with a headache.

The Tories have struggled to raise the £15m for a May election, which shows that central office would find it difficult to finance a lengthier campaign.

Nationwide poster campaigns would be the greatest extra cost. The Tories have had three pre-election poster campaigns this year, run by the Yellow M advertising agency, at £1m apiece. The present campaign - showing miserable victims of public service under the heading: Can you really wait another four years? -, is meant to conclude with the election proper.

The previous campaign was overworked nurses and police under the headings: Nurses will be nurses; and Police will be police. This was meant to suggest public sector workers would face less bureaucracy under the Tories. The first campaign had the theme that "stealth" tax increases had not led to better public service, with posters declaring: You paid the taxes, so where are the nurses?

Although Lord Ashcroft may be anxious, senior Tory strategists will feel that their prayers have been answered if Tony Blair holds back, on the possibly questionable assumption that, like Mr Micawber, something may turn up; they hope for further opinion polls saying to Mr Blair that the public wants a delay.

The Liberal Democrats, minnows in spending by comparison, would be spared severe losses due to postponement since they cannot afford advertising. With no billboards booked, the party has no cancellation fees to pay.

The party's campaign director, Chris Rennard, said a postponed date would be "broadly neutral" in its effect on funding, with the delay allowing time to raise money to compensate for additional costs, such as reprinting leaflets and rescheduling travel arrangements.

The Lib Dems would spend £3m - one fifth of Labour or the Conservatives. The party traditionally raises the last million sum during the election campaign, when news coverage and election broadcasts significantly raise its profile. So far, approaching £2m has been spent or committed by the party for campaign expenses, with the final £1m due to be spent on tour costs, rallies, transport, broadcasting and venue hire.

fields.headline: Tory election film under fire
fields.trailText: William Hague came under fire last night after it emerged that the Tories are planning to screen a party election broadcast which depicts a group of eastern European immigrants attempting to enter Britain.
fields.body:
William Hague came under fire last night after it emerged that the Tories are planning to screen a party election broadcast which depicts a group of eastern European immigrants attempting to enter Britain.

Moderate Tories joined forces with the Labour party to accuse central office of playing a dangerous political game after Guardian Unlimited disclosed that shooting of the short film is to begin in secret this week. It will be broadcast during the election.

Leaked papers, seen by the Guardian's new politics website, call for "eastern European-speaking" actors, aged between 25 and 70, to audition for the film. The filming also requires a "French-looking" barman, suggesting the plot of the party political broadcast will start on the continent before following the "eastern European-speakers" to Britain.

William Hague recently vowed not to play "the race card" during the election. Ian Taylor, MP for Esher and Walton, said he hoped Mr Hague was not about to "repeat the error of Harrogate", at the Tories' spring conference, where the Tory leader warned that Labour wanted to turn Britain into a "foreign land".

"Mingling asylum seekers, illegal immigrants and hostility to the EU is standing on the wrong side of the dividing line in the sand," Mr Taylor said. "If the Tory party wants to get re-elected we must realise the UK's problems are not the fault of asylum seekers." A Labour party source said: "The Tories are always exploiting immigration on the one hand, while refusing to back Labour measures to restrict illegal immigration like the penalties for road hauliers and the voucher system for asylum seekers."

Conservative central office refused to confirm details of the broadcast. But the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, issued a statement criticising the government's failure to tackle the asylum issue. "Labour's appalling failure to tackle the problem of bogus asylum seekers is one of the biggest stains on their four years in power," she said."

webTitle: Tory candidate in race row over faxed accusations

fields.headline: Tory candidate in race row over faxed accusations
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: A Tory parliamentary candidate was yesterday accused of stirring up the race issue by sending faxes to his local newspaper accusing his Labour rival and MP of favouring and letting down the Muslim community in Bolton.
fields.body:
A Tory parliamentary candidate was yesterday accused of stirring up the race issue by sending faxes to his local newspaper accusing his Labour rival and MP of favouring and letting down the Muslim community in Bolton.

The letters, all beginning: "I would like to", were sent from the home fax of Conservative candidate for Bolton South East, Haroon Rashid.

None of the individuals who purportedly wrote the letters to the Bolton Evening News raising the race issue appear on the local electoral register.

Mr Rashid has offered different explanations for how the faxes had been sent from his London home, including the inaccurate claim that his fax machine cannot send out material but only receive faxes.

The Conservative party regional press office refused to allow Mr Rashid to be interviewed. Instead it issued a statement insisting the faxes had been sent by members of the Bolton Muslim Council on visits to Mr Rashid's London home without his knowledge.

The Labour MP for Bolton South East, Brian Iddon, is to write to the commisison for racial equality to ask whether the letters breached its code of practice on election campaigning.

The first handwritten letter dated November 21 from Raja Iqbal and faxed from Mr Rashid's London home praised Mr Iddon for helping gain planning permission for mosques in Bolton and his influence in obtaining special grants.

It added: "Jack Straw, the Home Office minister, relaxed the laws on immigration and it is a lot easier for us to bring our families over from India and Pakistan."

A second letter from a Fern Malik, of Farnworth, praised the MP for supporting state-funded Muslim schools and claimed: "Mr Iddon has done more for us in the Asian community in the last three years than all the Labour councillors in Bolton put together and more than any other Labour MP."

Mr Rashid's supporters claimed the flattering faxes had been sent from Mr Rashid's home by members of the Bolton Muslim Council. A council member, Ahmed Patel, claimed that council officials drafted the letters following meetings at which an agreed policy was settled.

Mr Iddon said yesterday this belated explanation had been "blown out of the water" by the fact that a third letter also sent from Mr Rashid's London fax machine written by an Alam Patel, of Bolton, which accused Mr Iddon and the Labour party of "pampering" the ethnic community. The letter was printed in the Bolton paper on March 9.

The letter added: "There are lots of grants available to ethnic minority groups for mosques and temples. I hear more about him within the ethnic minority community regarding their immigration problems, and that he is the person to vote for if you want help with your families being brought over from India or Pakistan. I think we all need to wake up with this immigration problem and make MPs like Brian Iddon accountable."

Mr Rashid has shown a willingness to campaign for the anti-immigration vote in Bolton. In September last year, he put his name to a circular letter in the Daily Telegraph supporting the Conservative policy of a clampdown on asylum seekers and warning that Labour is considering allowing 1m immigrants in the next decade. He has also sent letters from his own fax to the local paper in his own name, beginning "I would like to."

Yet another letter sent from his London fax to the local paper from a Mary Sutherland praised Mr Rashid for being handsome and the right candidate for Bolton.

Mr Iddon challenged Mr Rashid and the Bolton Muslim Council to produce the individuals who had sent the letters.

The Conservative party in the north west responded: "The accusation that Haroon Rashid sent these faxes is without foundation. The Bolton Muslim Council has gone on the record as saying that it sent the faxes from his home on a visit to London. He did not see these faxes before they were sent and the views are expressed are not his own."

fields.headline: Britain to send heavy tanks
fields.standfirst: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Britain will today send heavy tanks to the Macedonian border to deter ethnic Albanian extremists from crossing from Kosovo, the Ministry of Defence said yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain will today send heavy tanks to the Macedonian border to deter ethnic Albanian extremists from crossing from Kosovo, the Ministry of Defence said yesterday.

Challenger tanks, the strongest armour in the army, will be part of a UK-Swedish battle group of about 400 troops, the overwhelming majority of whom will be British.

The combined force will include a squadron of the Royal Tank Regiment, equipped with 12 Challenger 2 tanks, and an infantry company from the Duke of Wellington's regiment with 13 Warrior armoured vehicles. The troops, already part of the K-For peacekeeping force in Kosovo, will patrol the border in the US south-eastern sector of the Serbian province of Kosovo.

However, the MoD said last night that the battle group - containing what it calls the army's heaviest metal and constituting a weapon with psychological presence as well as firepower - could be deployed later in the German sector further south or other parts of Kosovo where reinforcements are needed.

It is the first time Britain has formed a battle group with non-Nato Sweden, a neutral member of the EU.

The decision to send reinforcements to southern Kosovo was announced in the Commons by Tony Blair. He also said that a specialist unit of 120 Royal Artillery personnel equipped with the Phoenix unmanned aerial reconnaissance vehicle would be deployed to the border region.

The unit, based in Catterick, Yorkshire, is due to arrive in Kosovo in May, when it will join US, French and German unmanned drones already operating in the border region.

The fact that the move was announced by the prime minister in his report back to MPs on last week's European summit in Stockholm gives it added political weight and significance.

The UK-Swedish battle group will operate along a nine-mile stretch north of the Macedonian border town of Blace. It will replace a Polish-Ukrainian unit which was not equipped with surveillance or night vision equipment.

Other Nato governments have placed strict limits on the movements of their troops in Kosovo, but are desperately concerned about an escalation in the Macedonian crisis.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, meanwhile, said the ethnic Albanian insurgents carrying out incursions from Kosovo into Macedonia must not be allowed to succeed.

"I now hope that the message will get across to the terrorists that there is no support anywhere in Europe for any attempt to re-draw boundaries in blood," he said after talks in London with Greek foreign minister, George Papandreou.

"We want to see the government of Macedonia succeed in its objective of building a plural, multi-ethnic society," said Mr Cook. But he said the response of the Macedonian government must be "proportionate" to the terrorist threat.

Lord Robertson, the Nato secretary general, who returned to the capital, Skopje, yesterday, also urged restraint.

"The Macedonian government has regained the military high ground. Now they have to take the political high ground," he said.

webTitle: Mowlam to join international peace body

fields.headline: Mowlam to join international peace body
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam, the most popular cabinet minister, is poised to join the board of the high-powered International Crisis Group, the Brussels-based body that promotes conflict resolution on three continents, when she retires as MP for Redcar at the general election.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam, the most popular cabinet minister, is poised to join the board of the high-powered International Crisis Group, the Brussels-based body that promotes conflict resolution on three continents, when she retires as MP for Redcar at the general election.

Though Downing Street, the Foreign Office and the Cabinet Office - where the former Northern Ireland secretary is minister in charge - declined to confirm the appointment, it is regarded in Whitehall as a done deal which will give full rein to what one insider called "Mo's touchy-feely goodness".

The ICG, set up by her former peace process ally Senator George Mitchell with US and European support, is a $6m (£4.3m) a year, privately funded body whose board includes former presidents, premiers, foreign ministers and General Wesley Clark, Nato commander in the Kosovo conflict.

Along with Congo, Indonesia and central Asian republics, former Yugoslavia is one of the conflict areas, actual or potential, where the ICG's 55-strong team of political an alysts work on the ground to provide "practical recommendations" for action by the international community.

The appointment will be a part-time job for Ms Mowlam, 51, giving her time to juggle other commitments and a contract to write her memoirs of a mercurial career at the centre of New Labour politics and the Good Friday agreement in Belfast.

Though she has sometimes been an awkward colleague for Mr Blair No 10 is keen to see she finds an outlet for her talents. On a practical note, it knows voters would take her side if it did not.

webTitle: NHS 'failing breast cancer victims in north'

fields.headline: NHS 'failing breast cancer victims in north'
fields.standfirst: Special report: north-south divide
fields.trailText: Women in some parts of the country are unnecessarily having their breasts removed after a cancer diagnosis because of the pressures on radiotherapy services in Britain, according to a renowned cancer specialist.
fields.body:
Women in some parts of the country are unnecessarily having their breasts removed after a cancer diagnosis because of the pressures on radiotherapy services in Britain, according to a renowned cancer specialist.

Karol Sikora, who for two years headed the World Health Organisation's cancer programme in Lyon, said yesterday that a north-south divide exists in breast cancer surgery. Mastectomy is least common around London and the south east, where only 12% of women undergo surgery to remove the cancerous breast. In some hospitals in the north-west and north-east, by contrast, it reaches 30%.

The figures come from a voluntary audit carried out by 400 cancer surgeons involved in the NHS breast-screening programme who meet once a year and pool their results. They relate to women with only small tumours that should be susceptible to radiotherapy.

But, Professor Sikora said, surgeons are operating because the radiotherapy service is under strain and the waiting lists are long. "Overstretched radiotherapy services simply cannot cope with the extra work of routine breast radiotherapy, so pushing women to unnecessary mastectomies. It seems intrinsically unfair that those living in certain areas should have a poorer quality of service in the 21st century," he said at a lecture for the pharmaceutical firm, Pharmacia, for whom he is a consultant.

Elaborating yesterday, he said there were reasons why there might be some small variation from one hospital to another. "There are always some women who prefer to have a mastectomy. webTitle: Ministers ban age prejudice in NHS

fields.headline: Ministers ban age prejudice in NHS
fields.trailText: A ban on age discrimination in the NHS will be announced by ministers today after evidence that older people are often denied the treatment they need because of the prejudices of doctors and nurses.
fields.body:
A ban on age discrimination in the NHS will be announced by ministers today after evidence that older people are often denied the treatment they need because of the prejudices of doctors and nurses.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will launch a national framework for older people, promising that "NHS services will be provided regardless of age on the basis of clinical need alone".

Social care services will also be told not to use age as a factor in deciding whether people should be eligible for support.

As a first step, Mr Milburn will expand NHS services that disproportionately benefit older people. Over the next three years, people over 65 will benefit from about 70,000 more cataract operations, 16,000 hip and knee replacements and at least 3,000 more heart operations. Money for this will be allocated from the £835m top up in NHS spending in the budget earlier this month.

Mr Milburn will say that age discrimination in the NHS is not as bad as 10 years ago when 20% of cardiac care units would not treat older patients and 40% would not offer them clot-busting drugs.

Protocols were introduced in October to stop doctors and nurses deciding not to resuscitate older patients if they fell into a coma, without prior consultation with the patients or their families.

But a study last year in Scotland found that older trauma patients were much less likely to receive appropriate treatment and the quality of care was affected by doctors' perceptions of their age.

The audit commission found a huge variation in the number of beds available for older people in stroke units that greatly improve patients' prospects of rehabilitation. Campaigners for older people said that two thirds of NHS patients were over 65, but medical staff got little training to understand their needs.

This led to loss of dignity for older people on the wards and disorientation for those left waiting in accident and emergency departments.

Mr Milburn will promise "a more radical approach to rooting out age discrimination across the NHS". A systematic audit of all NHS policies influencing older people's access to services will be carried out over the next six months with a view to eradicating discrimination.

Each NHS trust and social services authority will be told to appoint an executive director to carry out this policy. Older people will be appointed to every patient forum to represent their point of view.

There will also be surveys to compare the treatment of older people with renal failure, heart trouble and cancer to establish whether age is affecting doctors' clinical decisions.

The government will not say older people should necessarily get the same treatment as younger patients. There may be reasons why a particular operation is more risky for an older patient. "But decisions must always be taken on the basis of clinical need and ability to benefit. We are breaking down age barriers in the NHS," a Department of Health source said. Gordon Lishman, director general of Age Concern England, said the new framework would need support at local level.

 People who are blind or partially sighted are left abandoned and confused in eye clinics, according to a report yesterday by the Royal National Institute for the Blind.

It found 86% of patients received appointment letters from clinics in normal size print which they found difficult or impossible to read. Only 40% were told what their eye condition meant and how it would affect them.

webTitle: Met keeps crime off the menu

fields.headline: Met keeps crime off the menu
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Racist crime is a priority for the Met, so senior officers must have been delighted to get volunteers for undercover duties to crack down on verbal and physical attacks by customers on staff in Asian restaurants.
fields.body:
Racist crime is a priority for the Met, so senior officers must have been delighted to get volunteers for undercover duties to crack down on verbal and physical attacks by customers on staff in Asian restaurants.

Up to 20 officers gave up evenings last weekend to dine anonymously in Indian, Thai and Chinese restaurants in the West End - on expenses, naturally. Unfortunately they failed to deliver any suspects along with their receipts. "We were not expecting to pick anyone up and that's exactly what happened," said Det Chief Insp Brett Lovegrove, head of hate crime initiatives for Westminster.

"It's fair to say this is a very sought-after position. Officers are keen to spend the night in a nice warm restaurant with a meal and a soft drink - no alcohol allowed, of course.

"But to be serious, the message is that anyone thinking of abusing the staff should watch out - they could be sitting next to a table full of police."

In the past there have been incidents in which victims of race crime in Chinatown complained of being treated as if they were perpetrators. Mr Lovegrove said the initiative would break down mistrust.

Westminster councillor Murad Qureshi, who came up with the idea, said: "The Chinese and Bengali community will greatly appreciate this effort by the police."
