fields.headline: Hard times
fields.standfirst:
Even before the foot and mouth outbreak, raising livestock in Britain didn't make economic sense. In the second instalment of his remarkable four-part study into British farming, Andrew O'Hagan visits a Cumbrian market and meets two families facing the end of a way of life.

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Even before the foot and mouth outbreak, raising livestock in Britain didn't make economic sense. In the second instalment of his remarkable four-part study into British farming,  Andrew O'Hagan  visits a Cumbrian market and meets two families facing the end of a way of life.
fields.body:
You hear the Borderway Mart before you see it. Driving out of Carlisle, beyond the roundabouts and small industrial units, you can hear cattle lowing and dragging their chains, and in the car park there are trucks full of bleating sheep arriving at a market that doesn't especially want them. Inside you cannot breathe for the smell of dung: farmers move around, shuffling papers, eating rolls and sausages, drinking coffee from Styrofoam cups. Some of them check advertising boards covered with details of machinery for sale, farm buildings for rent - the day-to-day evidence of farmers selling up. "It could be any of us selling our tractor up there," an old man in a tweed cap muttered at me.

The Tannoy crackled into life. "The sale of five cattle is starting right now in ring number one," the voice said. A black heifer was padding around the ring, its hooves slipping in sawdust and shit, and the man in charge of the gate, whose overalls were similarly caked, regularly patted it on the rump to keep it moving. Farmers in wellington boots and green waxed jackets hung their arms over the bars taking notes. One or two looked more like City businessmen. The heifer was 19 months old and weighed 430kg. The bidding was quick and decisive: the beast went for 79p a kilo.

"If you were here in the prime beef ring six or seven years ago," the auctioneer said later, "you would have seen the farmers getting about 120p per kilo. That is why so many are going out of business. Four years ago, young female sheep would be going for £80-odd, and today they are averaging £30."

Back in his office, the auctioneer took out his book covering the last few years. "Last week, bulls were averaging 82.7p per kilo. Three years ago . . ." He riffled through the pages. "Three years ago the average for bulls was 101.5p, and in October 1995, before BSE, the same bulls were fetching 134.2p. Think about that. There it is. Black and white. You can't argue with those figures. Hellish."

Because of government regulations stemming from the BSE crisis, every cow in Britain now has a passport, which tells where and when it was born, and where it has been since. But despite the seriousness of the attempt to tackle BSE, and the relative healthiness (by EU standards) of the meat on sale here, no one abroad wants British beef any more. Peo ple are always sensitive about meat, and they find it difficult to forget bad news - a fact which is already turning the BSE, swine fever and foot and mouth crises into a full-blown catastrophe, especially in respect of European buyers.

At the moment there are only two abattoirs that export beef. The market is dead. (Before 1996, British beef was generally considered the best in Europe.) Current EU proposals seem set to tackle overproduction by making subsidy payments relate to acreage rather than headcount. "It will result in a reduction in livestock units," the auctioneer said, "and if we don't have the units, it's hopeless for the whole community." The auctioneer was defending his own business, as he should, but why should taxpayers pay subsidies to farmers?

The auctioneer's boss was more strident. "The industry's going under," he said, "and you'll notice something: the common agricultural policy works for the rest of the European Union, but it's not working for us."

"In what ways?" I asked.

"Well, first, the animal welfare rules are more strongly applied here than anywhere, and in this, as in so many areas, British farmers find themselves not on a level playing field. We are not competing on equal ground. The weakness of the euro, with the subsidy payments coming in euros, is a killer;and as well as that, we are still being punished over the BSE crisis. There doesn't seem to be the appreciation in some quarters . . . "

"You mean government?"

"I'm not going to say that . . . Confidence has dropped. This is the largest mart in the UK, and what we see is that volumes are holding up, but costs have gone out of control: increased animal welfare, water usage, effluent handling and passports. Today alone we will be handling 1,500 passports for cattle."

The boss dropped his middle finger ominously on to the table. "Unless there is reinvestment the industry will . . . well, you check your crystal ball," he said. "It is unbelievably serious in the rural community and I don't think people properly appreciate it. It's no longer a north/south divide we have in this country: it's a rural/urban divide. It's easy to work out: after 18 months or more of breeding and feeding and labour, a farmer today is walking home with £339.70 for a good heifer. Nothing." Five months after he said this, many of the farmers weren't even getting that. "Nothing" was the accurate figure; compensation the only hope.

Climbing to Rakefoot Farm outside Keswick, you see nothing but hills and, in the distance, the lakes like patches of silver; teashops and heritage centres and Wordsworth's Walks serve as punctuation on the hills going brown in the afternoon. Will Cockbain was sitting in front of a black range in a cottage built in 1504. "There are ghosts here," he said, "but they're mostly quite friendly."

Cockbain's father bought Rakefoot Farm in 1958, but his family has been working the land around Keswick for hundreds of years. "There are more Cockbains in the local cemetery than anything else," he said, "and they have always been sheep farmers. Sitting here with you now, I can remember the smell of bread coming from that range, years ago, when my grandmother was here."

Cockbain has 1,100 Swaledale sheep and 35 suckler cows on the farm. "Seven thousand pounds is a figure you often hear as an annual earning for full-time farmers round here," he said. "Quite a few are on family credit - though not many will admit it. We farm 2,500 acres, of which we now own just 170, the rest being rented from five different landlords, including the National Trust. The bigger part of our income comes from subsidies we get for environmental work - keeping the stone walls and fences in order, maintaining stock-proof dykes, burning heather, off-wintering trees."

"Can't you make anything from the sheep?" I asked. "No," he said. "We are selling livestock way below the cost of production. Subsidies were introduced in 1947 when there was rationing and food shortages, and the subsidies continued, along with guaranteed prices, and now even the subsidies aren't enough. We've got the lowest ewe premium price we've had for years. In hill farming the income is stuck and the environmental grants are stuck, too. Fuel prices are crippling us. We are in a job that doesn't pay well and we depend on our vehicles. We are responsible for keeping the landscape the way people say they are proud to have it - but who pays for it? The people down the road selling postcards of the Lake District are making much more than the farmers who keep the land so photogenic."

Cockbain was the same size as the chair he was sitting in. Staring into the fire, he waggled his stocking-soled feet, and blew out his lips. "I think Margaret Thatcher saw those guaranteed prices farmers were getting and just hated it," he said. "And now, though it kills me, we may have to face something: there are too many sheep in the economy. Farmers go down to the market every other week and sell one sheep, and then they give 30 or 40 away. They're not worth anything. There are mass sheep graves everywhere now in the United Kingdom." Cockbain laughed and drank his tea. "It's only those with an inbuilt capacity for pain that can stand the farming life nowadays," he said. "I like the life, but you can't keep liking it when you're running against the bank, when things are getting out of control in ways you never dreamed of, relationships falling apart, everything."

On the walls of Cockbain's farm there are dozens of rosettes for prize-winning sheep. A picture of Cockbain's son holding a prize ram hangs beside a grandfather clock made by Simpson of Cockermouth, and an old barometer pointing to Rain. "This is a farming community from way back," Cockbain said, "but they're all getting too old now. Young men with trained dogs are a rarity, and hill farming, of all kinds, needs young legs. We've lost a whole generation to farming. My boys are hanging in there for now, but with, what, £27,000 last year between four men, who could blame them for disappearing?"

Another day, in the tiny kitchen of a hill farm above Bewcastle, 800ft above sea level, a little girl called Louise Carruthers walked to the sink in her blue parka, carrying a jug of water. She smiles and looks like a girl in a Vermeer. "I've made nothing this year," her father, Brian, told me. "I'm on family credit and dependent on family allowance to get from week to week. And I'm working from daylight to dark. I'm trying to encourage my boy not to go into this. One of my friends gave up and now he's working on a building site earning £280 a week."

Carruthers' farm is a confusion of mist and rotting leaves. When I arrived, he slammed the door of his Land Rover shut and tasted the air. "Last year we were buying fuel at 11p a litre, and now it's 22p, and has even been up as high recently as 27p."

Inside the cottage, there is a pair of Massey Ferguson overalls hanging above the Aga and a waxcloth on the table. "You know all the reasons for this," he said, "but people ought to look at the supermarkets: they are really taking the piss. They talk about partnerships and all that but they have the farmers at each other's throats. Forget the landscape, forget the culture, and forget traditions, forget the efforts being made by farmers to produce good quality stuff - most supermarkets will buy from wherever they get the best deal. They don't support the British farmer, although it suits them to say they do. They squeeze everyone."

Couldn't Carruthers diversify? "Oh aye," he said, "they're always talking about diversify. Into what? It's hard to believe the way people plough nowadays. You can't buy into that now, not with those giant agribusiness people, who buy everything and turn it arable. Tenant farmers are no match for those big businesses. Diversify? How else? It's heavy clay land up here, it's wet, there's no tourism, no ponies, no golf."

"So what do farmers do who can't cope?" I asked. "Commit suicide," he replied, "or drive a dumper."

Carruthers is 42 years old. He is separated with two children. His wife left him after beginning an affair with a man she met in the office where she worked. He keeps all his cattle passports in a tin and at one point he held a passport up and said to Louise: "It looks a bit like our family allowance book." They had been watching Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? the previous night, "and this guy lost £125,000 on a question we knew the answer to. It was amazing, wasn't it, Louise?"

Out in the yard I saw some of Carruthers' Galloway cows. It takes three years for these famous animals to mature, but under the new BSE regulations cows have to be slaughtered before their 30th month. Brian patted one of the cows on the way past. "It's going to be a nightmare if they let farming go the same way as mining," he said, "but still, we all vote Conservative up here. The Tories were much better to us."

You could see the Solway Firth 20 miles away. There it was: Scotland and England balanced along a line of blue mist. And it felt as if there was a freeze coming down. Carruthers nudged me with his arm as I left, and he laughed, looking into the wild, unpeopled hills. "If you find me a new wife make sure she's an accountant," he said.

We are in a job that doesn't pay well and we depend on our vehicles. We are responsible for keeping the landscape the way people say they are proud to have it - but who pays for it? The people down the road selling postcards of the Lake District are making much more than the farmers who keep the land so photogenic." Cockbain was the same size as the chair he was sitting in. Staring into the fire, he waggled his stocking-soled feet, and blew out his lips. "I think Margaret Thatcher saw those guaranteed prices farmers were getting and just hated it," he said. "And now, though it kills me, we may have to face something: there are too many sheep in the economy. Farmers go down to the market every other week and sell one sheep, and then they give 30 or 40 away. They're not worth anything. There are mass sheep graves everywhere now in the United Kingdom." Cockbain laughed and drank his tea. "It's only those with an inbuilt capacity for pain that can stand the farming life nowadays," he said. "I like the life, but you can't keep liking it when you're running against the bank, when things are getting out of control in ways you never dreamed of, relationships falling apart, everything." On the walls of Cockbain's farm there are dozens of rosettes for prize-winning sheep. A picture of Cockbain's son holding a prize ram hangs beside a grandfather clock made by Simpson of Cockermouth, and an old barometer pointing to Rain. "This is a farming community from way back," Cockbain said, "but they're all getting too old now. Young men with trained dogs are a rarity, and hill farming, of all kinds, needs young legs. We've lost a whole generation to farming. My boys are hanging in there for now, but with, what, £27,000 last year between four men, who could blame them for disappearing?" Another day, in the tiny kitchen of a hill farm above Bewcastle, 800ft above sea level, a little girl called Louise Carruthers walked to the sink in her blue parka, carrying a jug of water. She smiles and looks like a girl in a Vermeer. "I've made nothing this year," her father, Brian, told me. "I'm on family credit and dependent on family allowance to get from week to week. And I'm working from daylight to dark. I'm trying to encourage my boy not to go into this. One of my friends gave up and now he's working on a building site earning £280 a week." Carruthers' farm is a confusion of mist and rotting leaves. When I arrived, he slammed the door of his Land Rover shut and tasted the air. "Last year we were buying fuel at 11p a litre, and now it's 22p, and has even been up as high recently as 27p." Inside the cottage, there is a pair of Massey Ferguson overalls hanging above the Aga and a waxcloth on the table. "You know all the reasons for this," he said, "but people ought to look at the supermarkets: they are really taking the piss. They talk about partnerships and all that but they have the farmers at each other's throats. Forget the landscape, forget the culture, and forget traditions, forget the efforts being made by farmers to produce good quality stuff - most supermarkets will buy from wherever they get the best deal. They don't support the British farmer, although it suits them to say they do. They squeeze everyone." Couldn't Carruthers diversify? "Oh aye," he said, "they're always talking about diversify. Into what? It's hard to believe the way people plough nowadays. You can't buy into that now, not with those giant agribusiness people, who buy everything and turn it arable. Tenant farmers are no match for those big businesses. Diversify? How else? It's heavy clay land up here, it's wet, there's no tourism, no ponies, no golf." "So what do farmers do who can't cope?" I asked. "Commit suicide," he replied, "or drive a dumper." Carruthers is 42 years old. He is separated with two children. His wife left him after beginning an affair with a man she met in the office where she worked. He keeps all his cattle passports in a tin and at one point he held a passport up and said to Louise: "It looks a bit like our family allowance book." They had been watching Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? the previous night, "and this guy lost £125,000 on a question we knew the answer to. It was amazing, wasn't it, Louise?" Out in the yard I saw some of Carruthers' Galloway cows. It takes three years for these famous animals to mature, but under the new BSE regulations cows have to be slaughtered before their 30th month. Brian patted one of the cows on the way past. "It's going to be a nightmare if they let farming go the same way as mining," he said, "but still, we all vote Conservative up here. The Tories were much better to us." You could see the Solway Firth 20 miles away. There it was: Scotland and England balanced along a line of blue mist. And it felt as if there was a freeze coming down. Carruthers nudged me with his arm as I left, and he laughed, looking into the wild, unpeopled hills. "If you find me a new wife make sure she's an accountant," he said. © Andrew O'Hagan. webTitle: MP offers a vote of thanks

fields.headline: MP offers a vote of thanks
fields.trailText: Austin Mitchell, Labour MP for Great Grimsby, is proud that his constituency falls within Britain's most profitable business location, but his pride is tempered by concern that many in the town are being left behind in a two-speed economy.
fields.body:
Austin Mitchell, Labour MP for Great Grimsby, is proud that his constituency falls within Britain's most profitable business location, but his pride is tempered by concern that many in the town are being left behind in a two-speed economy.

"We should be proud of this achievement because it is an inducement to investment - particularly for bigger firms," he says.

"They now know there are great opportunities in Grimsby: we have a very loyal workforce, with comparatively low wages; we offer a real prospect of profitability; and provide excellent access to British and the European markets."

But, he adds: "The reverse of the coin is that we have been less attractive to the more diverse, smaller-scale investment than we should have been. We are a very blue collar manufacturing economy without a strong tier of white collar employment.

Losing the best

"Meanwhile, our level of unemployment is the second highest in the region, and our wages per capita are the lowest. We are also losing the best and the brightest of our young people to the drift southwards."

Mr Mitchell insists that almost four years of a Labour government has served the town well and denies that Gordon Brown has failed in his efforts to redistribute wealth to the low-paid and unemployed.

"It is not a question of blame," he says. "Gordon is expanding regional policy, and we are benefiting from that."

Asked if the chancellor could do more to curb the extremes of corporate profitability and social deprivation in Grimsby, Mr Mitchell is less than clear.

"We have not benefited as much as we would have hoped from the fact that these firms are profitable," he concedes. "But that is a question of company taxation and the contributions firms make to the local economy."

What Mr Mitchell and his constituents really want from Mr Brown is a more competitive pound to help exporters to Europe.

fields.headline: It's still grim in Grimsby
fields.standfirst: The most profitable town for big business delivers a simple response. 'You'd better leave now, son'
fields.trailText: The most profitable town for big business delivers a simple response. 'You'd better leave now, son'.
fields.body:
Eyebrows will undoubtedly have been raised at the news that Grimsby, the impoverished shell of a once great fishing port, yesterday won the title of most profitable town in the UK for big business. Nowhere were they raised higher than in Grimsby itself, where unemployment has refused to follow the declining trend found elsewhere in Britain - it rose to 6.6% in February - and where some in local government believe deprivation to be among the most acute in Europe.

Nevertheless, statisticians at Dun & Bradstreet insist that a survey of Britain's top 50,000 firms clearly shows Grimsby in pole position, with 88.5% of businesses in the area recording a profit.

Ivan Hinchliffe, economic and community development officer for North East Lincolnshire council, greets the news with a mixture of pride and despair. He points out that the town's port at Immingham handles 50m tonnes of cargo a year, making it the country's largest and the most profitable for Associated British Ports. He recalls that Grimsby's food processing businesses boast the largest concentration of cold storage facilities in Europe, and that the chemical plants sprawling northwards along the estuary make up the UK's second most important region for the industry.

In short, a lot of money is being made in Grimsby. But, Mr Hinchliffe says, that is only half the story. Unemployment is twice the national average and second highest in the Yorkshire and Humber region. Average weekly earnings are the lowest in the area, while Grimsby has the highest proportion of employees with gross salaries of less than £250 a week. It also ranks among the most socially deprived regions, according to government figures.

Washed-up trawlermen

"Frankly, it is almost an insult to talk about corporate profitability to people in Grimsby," he says. "If you tell low-waged people here that companies in Grimsby are making huge profits, it's a bit of an insult, isn't it?"

He is not wrong. Behind scores of empty moorings on the Old Pontoon, among the boarded up boathouses and derelict shops that once serviced the bustling fishing harbour, news that Grimsby is the most profitable town in Britain is not well met at TC's members-only bar, a regular haunt for the town's washed-up trawlermen.

"You're joking, aren't you?" says one. "Take a look around." Some howl with laughter at the news, but most look furious and say nothing. Frank, an elderly man who has been playing cribbage, puts down his hand and says: "I think you'd better leave now, son."

In the 1950s, Grimsby harboured 279 vessels, employed 3,371 registered fishermen, and claimed to be the world's largest fishing port. The loss of a diplomatic row with Iceland over fishing rights and declining North Sea stocks have since decimated the fleet.

Today, drivers approaching Grimsby along the A180 are quickly struck by the scale of industry in the town as grass meadows give way to fields of Volkswagen cars shipped in from Europe, and mountains of coal and ore destined for the steelworks at nearby Scunthorpe. Northwards, along the bank of the Humber, is a strip of chemical plants making man-made fibres, agro-chemicals, whitening agents, plasterboard and other products. Next to them, two oil refineries, owned by Lindsey Oil and Conoco.

The impressive scale of industry is accompanied by an eerie absence of manpower. Even on busy working days, as the chemical plants, refineries and cargo docks are doing millions of pounds worth of trade, little human activity is visible in Grimsby's industrial districts.

"We have high volume, capital intensive industries here, but they tend to use just a small number of people," says Mr Hinchliffe. "For example, we have calculated that for every £1m of investment in the chemical industry, we get just one job created. Hopefully that job will be here for a long time and will create other support sector jobs, but it is not a very promising statistic."

Many multinational corporations leave a skeleton staff to manage their highly automated plants in Grimsby, while decisions are taken at headquarters elsewhere. "All these sites are just branch plant sites," says Mr Hinchliffe. "The decisions, the research and development, the marketing, the financial controls and, of course, the profits are all taken somewhere else. Naturally, we are very pleased to have the plants and the jobs but they are not quite as embedded in the area as they would be if the headquarters were here."

Meanwhile, the town's workforce is left to make a living processing imported fish into frozen meals - one of the few labour intensive industries in the town. Carol Russell, who used to earn £3.50 an hour processing fish into shaped fish meals for export to French supermarkets before becoming a taxi driver, insists Dun & Bradstreet's research must be mistaken.

Driving around the harbour area, she points out the areas where, as a child, she would go with her father to collect fish for the dinner table. "Look at it. It's a ghost town now," she says. "There was a time when nobody in Grimsby ever paid for their fish - there was always someone in the family working on the docks who would throw you some fish for your dinner. Nowadays, most people in this town can't even afford to buy wet fish - unless it's off the back of a lorry."

Like Ms Russell, many Grimbarians have turned to the food processing factories - owned by Heinz, Young's, Bluecrest and Birds Eye, among others - for jobs.

Agnar Fridricksson, managing director of Icelandic-owned firm Coldwater, which makes convenience seafood including filet-o-fish for all McDonald's restaurants in the UK, says the town's fishing heritage and transport links makes it an ideal location for food processors.

'They know fish'

"People in Grimsby are used to fish, they know fish, they know how to handle fish," he says. "Grimsby has transformed admirably from being dependent on local fisheries to becoming a major secondary processing location, with its service industries and transport links."

More recently, the factories have been diversifying away from seafood, and the smells of beef dinners, pizzas and oriental meals are now commonplace. Baxter's, the soup maker, is to bring in 200 jobs at the company's first factory outside Scotland.

Local government and industry groups continue to lobby for increased grants from Westminster and Europe to attract investment in the region. They say that Grimsby is worse off than some parts of South Yorkshire, which receives "objective one" grants from the EU.

"We are the gateway to Europe and are trying to attract investment. But at the moment we can't offer the same kind of regional incentives as other areas," says Austin Mitchell, Labour MP for Great Grimsby.

While the lobbying for grants to attract multinational firms continues, there is little evidence that this is benefiting the townspeople.

Six years ago Grimsby topped the same Dun and Bradstreet survey, prompting Mr Mitchell and others to observe that the town was only truly profitable for the larger industries, with low staffing levels, and for businesses that offered low wages to a low-skilled workforce.

After almost four years under a Labour government - with a chancellor who is said to be committed both to creating a stable economic environment for business and to the redistribution of wealth - little in Grimsby has changed.

fields.headline: Maze escapees told: go home
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Eight republican terrorists who escaped from prison in Northern Ireland over the past 20 years have given themselves up to the authorities and been quietly told to go home in what is believed to be a government amnesty aimed at cementing the faltering peace process.
fields.body:
Eight republican terrorists who escaped from prison in Northern Ireland over the past 20 years have given themselves up to the authorities and been quietly told to go home in what is believed to be a government amnesty aimed at cementing the faltering peace process.

Three lifers convicted of murder and five others presented themselves to officials over the past few days. The move came in a republican attempt to force the issue of what happens to men still on the run - of whom there are scores. It is understood that the sentence review commission, set up under the terms of the Good Friday agreement, freed them under licence in the same way as prisoners belonging to republican and loyalist paramilitary groups on ceasefire have been let out over the past two years.

Sinn Fein has been agitating for some sort of gesture on escaped prisoners as part of an overall package of demilitarisation and more extensive policing reform to end the current political deadlock threatening the future of the power-sharing executive at Stormont.

The government has never officially announced an amnesty and yesterday played down this latest development as part of an ongoing assessment process.

A Northern Ireland Office spokesman said: "As the former secretary of state, Peter Mandelson, announced in September, these prisoners have been allowed to return to Northern Ireland to make an application to the sentence review commission."

Sinn Fein and prison authorities refused to comment.

But a security source said: "It's just one stage in a process the former secretary of state announced he was working toward. These men contacted the authorities and spoke to a government official. They have been freed under temporary licence just like others in similar organisations."

A republican source said: "Last year Peter Mandelson acknowledged an anomaly had arisen with regard to people on the run. Last May, the British government agreed to remove the anomaly but it is only now they are moving on it.

"It's a welcome move for these men and their families but it is only a small step and much, much more is needed. There are lots of people in the same position."

The timing of the gesture is highly symbolic, given the importance of prisoners' rights to republicans, particularly in this 20th anniversary year of the death of 10 hunger strikers, who were trying to gain political status in the Maze, Co Antrim, in 1981.

With the IRA's recent re-engagement with General John de Chastelain's disarmament body, it could be read as part of a carefully choreographed sequence of moves to try to get the provisionals to decommission their weapons.

But unionists will be furious at what they will view as virtually an official pardon for murderers and bombers.

One of the freed men is Liam Averill, a member of the Irish National Liberation Army, convicted of two murders in 1994. He made an audacious escape dressed as a woman during a Christmas party on December 10 1997.

The others are all thought to be IRA men. One, Gerard Sloan, was one of eight men who shot their way out of Belfast's Crumlin Road jail in 1981. Four fellow gang members, Angelo Fusco, Robert Campbell, Patrick Magee and Anthony Sloan, were effectively pardoned in December.

The four were captured in the Irish Republic and served jail terms there but did not qualify for early release because they had served less than two years in prison in Northern Ireland.

At the time, the Ulster Unionist deputy leader, John Taylor, condemned the decision to free them as deplorable and far too liberal.

Five of those freed in this latest gesture are Seamy Campbell, Gerard Fryers, James Clarke, Dermott McNally and Seamus Clarke, brother of Terence "Cleeky" Clarke, Gerry Adams's minder and friend, who died of cancer last year.

They escaped during the mass breakout from the high-security Maze jail in 1983, when 38 inmates, armed with guns and knives, seized a lorry in the prison compound. One prison officer was killed and another seriously wounded.

Nineteen prisoners were quickly recaptured but the rest got away. By 1992, five had been recaptured, three killed in ambushes and 11 were still on the run.

The other man involved in the apparent amnesty is Patrick McIntyre, who failed to return from home leave in 1986.

webTitle: Comment: Deal with the disease and go to the polls on June 7

fields.headline: Deal with the disease and go to the polls on June 7
fields.standfirst:
Blair will be seen to put duty before ambition if he delays by a month

Special report: election countdown
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Foot and mouth: free daily email service with latest updates
fields.trailText: Blair will be seen to put duty before ambition if he delays by a month.
fields.body:
Public apathy deadens more than politics. It can envelop almost anything, if exposure lasts long enough and rage becomes futile. Sooner or later, passion peters out. The time comes when there's little left to say about a disaster that's immutable. Already beginning to be bored with another piece about foot and mouth? I guess so. But that's the point. The boredom threshold is a political fact, as an apathetic nation is lured towards an election it neither very badly wants nor very badly doesn't want, during a calamity that many people, in their shoulder- shrugging British way, learn to live with.

As decision day approaches for Tony Blair, this has to be a big part of his judgment. What will the voters really care about? Will they rage at him for going too soon, if he sticks with the four-year blueprint ending on May 3? Or soon forget about the horrors they now see on the screen every night? My bet is that he'll settle for a cautious version of the second scenario. Long afraid of apathy's low turn-out, he can now turn apathy to advantage. June 7 would be a good moment to split the difference.

When it happens, this will be an election far removed from 1997 in everything except the approximate result. Staring at these empty fields, and smoking pyres, and slaughterhouse soldiers, not to mention failing trains, and rundown hospitals, and struggling schools, voters need a vast reservoir of tolerance to prevent them rising up in rage to punish the nearest available prime minister. But apathy, and William Hague, will not find them wanting.

Apathy will ensure, first, that foot and mouth disappears from most screens within a week of the election starting. Already bored with it, the majority will soon forget. The campaign will take over all the headlines, because that's what all the parties want and all the media will gladly respond to. Part of the reason why foot and mouth has eaten into the national mood is because there are no pictures to knock it off the bulletins. A campaign, even one that has a hard job making people care, will soon change that.

It needs to be preceded by the impression that the government is at last in charge. That may not happen by May, but will certainly have climaxed before the autumn. In retrospect it's clear that ministers weren't in charge from the beginning. They got the urgency of the thing all wrong. For a few days, Hague at last managed to make the government and not the opposition the target of big questions. But field marshal Blair has handed over command to the brigadiers, who can be heard barking over the air-waves with unagricultural authority.

Though the cases will keep coming for many months after the curve declines, they're still seen more as acts of God and pigswill than the results of political failure. There is political failure, in the rundown of vet services for farm surveillance, but as with so much else the blame is divided: the Thatcher plague on the public sector, as yet unrectified by her successor.

Meanwhile, time passes. F and M, from being a catastrophic novelty, becomes part of almost normal life. Other realities move up alongside it. It's specious to pretend, as the spinners now do, that the whole world is looking to British elections being held in May for proof that the country is still part of the planet. But governing is paralysed by strategic indecision, the blight of pre-election phases in all countries everywhere, regardless of whether they're discretionary or fixed-term. Already, it seems to this observer, the case for indefinite delay is trumped by the need to settle things. What has changed, since the days when imminent elections seemed an affront to democracy, is the discovery that there's no likely time when they would seem much less of one.

These preliminaries should certainly be expected to change the nature of the campaign. It will not be joyful, and is less likely than it was to be casually venomous. The original plans of both main sides were firing up to emphasise anger and contempt. They were going to make it as bitterly personal as they could find the words for: the Tories because they had nothing else to say except how exquisitely they abominated Tony Blair, Labour because it needed something to stimulate the nightmares of supporters and drive them to polls in which they may otherwise have lost faith.

No doubt there will still be some of this. But the sombre context indicates a different presentation, especially by the government. At a time when crisis is still a word in voters' consciousness, ministers will want to emphasise their gravitas, their experience, their dutiful sense of responsibility, even, lord help us, their competence. Instead of parading their bright-eyed triumphs, they'll be offering themselves as solid custodians of the future, the safest pair of hands to deal with future pigswill visitations or any other national crises.

On the face of it, this should be a pretty incredible claim. Standing back from our politics, foreign visitors are struck by the terrible state of things here. These may all have come in a rush, and, deep down, the Blair administration may have laid the ground for massive improvements at some time later. But with the fields stripped bare and the railways in chaos and doctors gloom-mongering the NHS and police numbers in decline and sundry ministers unable to give an honest account of their public lives, the election ought to be lost. That it isn't going to be is tribute to the happy congruence between Blairism's need to be judged in the long term not the short, and the voters' apathetic disbelief in the possibility of anything better. A dismal verdict, I'm afraid. But the most plausible one available.

The best thing to do now would be to announce that all elections, the local and the general, will be held on June 7. This would pay necessary respect to those people, especially in rural areas, who would be justifiably affronted by a rush to the polls, or by local elections that can be changed by statute without terrible insult to anyone. A month is a long delay, and time enough for man to gain some control over the contagion that is decimating the herds. The prime minister would be seen to do his governing duty, at some cost to his political plans. The first half of the allotted period would be spent showing he had got his priorities right.

The second half could then see a campaign that wasn't distracted by charges of opportunism. The balance of opportunism has in any case swung round. It's not at all clear, after all that's happened, that going early is going best for the Labour vote. But all that's happened means that Britain needs a government in place, settled enough to confront the crisis that may be more serious than foot and mouth: a downturn in European economies that could yet be our really fearsome autumn rendering.

webTitle: What papers say on election timing

fields.headline: What papers say on the timing
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Labour strategists recognise it would be a disaster if they went into a May poll with the country and the national press opposed to the timing of the election. Here we outline how the papers see it.
fields.body:
Labour strategists recognise it would be a disaster if they went into a May poll with the country and the national press opposed to the timing of the election. Here we outline how the papers see it.

The Sun

"Sorry, we're closed" - this is the message Britain will send to the world if the May 3 election is called off. On balance as things stand we still back May 3 unless we are all overtaken by events.

The Mirror

Cancelling the elections would be the worst possible way to rekindle confidence in the countryside.

Daily Mail

If it (the government) insists on an unnecessary election in a ruined smoke-blackened countryside, it will stand condemned for its selfishness, opportunism and breathtaking cynicism.

Daily Telegraph

With strong public support, a huge majority and more than a year to run, Mr Blair does not need a new mandate: he needs to do his job.

Daily Express

When the Queen and her 10th prime minister since Churchill meet, Mr Blair would be well advised to be honest, listen and take heed of his sovereign's warnings.

The Times

To suggest that the largely fictious hurly burly of the election campaign could add measurably to the risk of spreading the disease is nonsense. The sensibilities of farmers should be treated with respect, but that should not include pointless gestures.

Financial Times

Blair is probably still tempted to press ahead with the election. That would be the better course.

The Guardian

Mr Blair should nerve himself for the wave of abuse that will surely follow, but do the brave thing all the same. Call it for May 3.

The Independent

That a general election was held in 1945 when the nation was still at war with Japan ... suggests that the democratic arguments against an election on May 3 remain flimsy.

webTitle: Leader: we need a new ministry to replace Maff

fields.headline: After the crisis
fields.standfirst:
We will need a new ministry

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Foot and mouth: free daily email service with latest updates
fields.trailText: The traditional law of news holds that very few "stories" last longer than a couple of days. The rare, dramatic one holds the national imagination for a week. Only wars and general elections tend to dominate for a full month. Now foot and mouth has come along to tear up the rulebook.
fields.body:
The traditional law of news holds that very few "stories" last longer than a couple of days. The rare, dramatic one holds the national imagination for a week. Only wars and general elections tend to dominate for a full month. Now foot and mouth has come along to tear up the rulebook. Well into its fifth week, it continues to dominate the headlines but also, more deeply, the national mood. The images are becoming iconic through repetition: first the flaming pyres, and now the sight of lorries tipping their load of slaughtered sheep into deep pits.

We are fast becoming a kind of plague nation, ostracised by others as bearers of disease. Air travellers have to wade through a bath of disinfectant before they disembark, lest they bring the dreaded bug onto foreign soil. Even the prime minister suffered the indignity of having the food on his plane incinerated once he had touched down for the European summit in Stockholm over the weekend. The Swedes did not want Tony Blair importing foot and mouth into their pristine country, thank you very much. One family who had moved recently from England to Ireland had to get their British number plates replaced: they had been taunted and harassed as they drove around, reviled as carriers of the plague.

Against this backdrop, it's not surprising that people are casting around for ideas and solutions. The Conservatives want Mr Blair to appoint a war cabinet to combat the disease; the PM responds that it's hard to see what good "another committee" will do. He wants to focus instead on cutting the time between spotting F&M and destroying the animals carrying it. He also remains officially open-minded on the Dutch option - vaccinating all animals close to an infected area, and destroying them later.

These options may well be sensible, but they hardly grapple with the heart of the problem. Once the immediate crisis has eventually passed, and that moment may take months to come, we shall have to look long and hard at British agriculture and what really ails it.

Of course, the list we could draw up is long. Supermarkets' demand for cheap food has forced farmers into intensive methods even they regret. The common agricultural policy, which subsidises over-production, has been crying out for reform for too long. The way food is distributed has created insanities: a lettuce grown in Cornwall may be transported by road to Bristol to be wrapped in plastic, only to be driven back to Cornwall again. There is so much madness in our food production that the government could dedicate all of its second term to overhauling it and still not be finished.

But there is a simple start it should make - by abolishing the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, or Maff. It has become an arm of the food industry, the captive of the retailers and agri-businesses rather than the champion of the consumer and small farmer. It looks out for the big supermarket chains, often passing their demands on to already pressed farmers - forcing them into practices that are wholly unsustainable.

The remedy is clear. Maff should make way for a department of food and rural affairs. Such a ministry could look out for the quality of what we eat, liaising with the Department of Health and a muscled food safety authority, while genuinely fighting for those farmers who try to produce food of quality and by sustainable methods. It would take a full view of the needs of the countryside, from rural bus services to village schools. We need a new body, one that would work not for one industry - but the whole nation.

webTitle: 5,000 IT vacancies set aside for jobless

fields.headline: 5,000 IT vacancies set aside for jobless
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Thousands of long-term unemployed people are to be offered jobs in the hi-tech sector under a £50m scheme unveiled by the government yesterday.
fields.body:
Thousands of long-term unemployed people are to be offered jobs in the hi-tech sector under a £50m scheme unveiled by the government yesterday.

Around 5,000 vacancies will be reserved for people out of work for longer than 18 months as well as single parents and young people on the New Deal.

Companies including IBM, Siemens, Cisco Systems, BT and Microsoft have signed up to participate in the scheme, offering jobs that will pay between £15,000 and £20,000 a year.

In return the government has agreed to pay for around 7,500 people to train in information technology skills under the scheme called, Ambition:IT.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, said that the scheme would give hope to the long-term unemployed as well as meeting demand by employers for people with IT skills. He said the government needed to find new ways of combating skills shortages.

"In five years' time, 90% of jobs will need IT skills, compared with 70% today and just 25% in 1992," Mr Brown said. "So Ambition:IT matches unemployed men and women to the businesses that need skilled IT technicians, a demand itself that is set to rise by 25% in the next three years."

Microsoft said the new jobs would help make Britain a leader in the world's digital economy. "By targeting unemployed and other disadvantaged people it will have the added advantage of building a digitally inclusive society and releasing untapped potential which help address the UK IT skills gap," said Neil Holloway, managing director of Microsoft UK.

Other companies involved in the scheme include FI Group, Consignia, Cap Gemini, Ernst & Young, Dixons, ICL, EDS and Oracle.

The scheme will place special emphasis on high unemployment regions where there also happen to be a large number of IT vacancies. Ten areas have been short-listed for the programme including London, Manchester, Birmingham, Leeds, Glasgow and Cardiff, from which five will chosen to take part. The others on the list are South Yorkshire, Liverpool, Tyneside and Edinburgh.

Including other New Deal schemes, 15,000 jobless will undergo IT training over the next year.

Mr Brown said that he believed the kinds of jobs being created by the initiative would be long-term and survive the ups and downs of the economy.

The unemployed will have to undergo a new compulsory skills check, while for the 140,000 long-term unemployed there will be wider access to training and help in setting up businesses. Repeatedly refusing to take up opportunities will result in the withdrawal of benefits for up to 26 weeks.

Similar employer-led schemes will be announced in the coming weeks, focusing on the construction, hotels and hospitality and financial services industries. Hilary Cropper, chairwoman of Ambition:IT said: "We expect to break new ground by involving major firms in designing training so it prepares unemployed people for good jobs and new careers."

She said that as a result, people would be fully prepared for the jobs on offer after they had been trained. The duration of each training courses is expected to be from four to eight months.

Ten areas have been short-listed for the programme including London, Manchester, Birmingham, Leeds, Glasgow and Cardiff, from which five will chosen to take part. The others on the list are South Yorkshire, Liverpool, Tyneside and Edinburgh. Including other New Deal schemes, 15,000 jobless will undergo IT training over the next year. Mr Brown said that he believed the kinds of jobs being created by the initiative would be long-term and survive the ups and downs of the economy. The unemployed will have to undergo a new compulsory skills check, while for the 140,000 long-term unemployed there will be wider access to training and help in setting up businesses. Repeatedly refusing to take up opportunities will result in the withdrawal of benefits for up to 26 weeks. Similar employer-led schemes will be announced in the coming weeks, focusing on the construction, hotels and hospitality and financial services industries. Hilary Cropper, chairwoman of Ambition:IT said: "We expect to break new ground by involving major firms in designing training so it prepares unemployed people for good jobs and new careers." She said that as a result, people would be fully prepared for the jobs on offer after they had been trained. The duration of each training courses is expected to be from four to eight months.

fields.headline: Steel union braced for action
fields.trailText: Union bosses today will authorise a ballot on industrial action at Llanwern and Teesside steel plants if, as expected, Corus rejects their rescue plan and proceeds with plant closures and 6,000 redundancies.
fields.body:
Union bosses today will authorise a ballot on industrial action at Llanwern and Teesside steel plants if, as expected, Corus rejects their rescue plan and proceeds with plant closures and 6,000 redundancies.

The ISTC steel union has already held talks with Dutch counterparts to ensure Corus facilities in the Netherlands are not used to offset production shortages in Britain.

Last night Michael Leahy, general secretary of the ISTC, was locked in talks to secure final government support for a £100m rescue package to be placed before Corus chairman Sir Brian Moffatt this morning.

There is growing certainty within the union, however, that the steel group has already decided to reject the proposals. Corus insisted yesterday it was committed to fulfilling its contractual obligations to consult over the future.

A Corus spokesman admitted he had seen media leaks on the content of the ISTC plan, adding: "We have not seen anything yet to change our mind [about closures]."

The union scheme involves funding the existing level of workforce and steel-making capacity with a mixture of public money and cash from private sources, including Corus, for about 12 months in the expectation the market will show an upturn.

Corus rejects accusations from critics, including prime minister Tony Blair, that it is acting with of only short-term interests in mind.

A steel group spokesman said: "We have looked at the long term prospects for the markets - particularly in the UK - and we do not foresee any turnaround, with the UK manufacturers sourcing more and more products from abroad."

He said any union plan would have to include proposals for dealing with this.

Corus said earlier this month that losses from carbon steel were still running at £1m a day although there were signs of some prices edging up.

Corus wants to cut about 20% of its capacity in Britain but keep substantial volumes in Scunthorpe, Teesside and the Sheffield area.

The ISTC believes its plan will be viable even if fails to gain the backing of industry secretary Stephen Byers. It has put together a contingency scheme building on the money it has already secured through the European Union and the Welsh Assembly.

The ISTC has become alarmed at the last minute wavering from civil servants from the Department of Trade and Industry.

A host of arguments, including the legality of the financial package using public money, have been used to question whether the government should put its weight behind the union scheme.

Mr Leahy has warned that the union believes in the force of argument but if this is rejected then it is prepared "to use the arguments of force".

The union is one of the more conservative in the labour movement but is also one of the richest. With £20m of liquid assets, it is well equipped for a drawn-out battle with Corus.

A source close to the union said: "They [the ISTC] do not want to damage the steel industry but believe Corus should not get away with this. They know they can damage Corus by just withdrawing key personnel from each plant."

fields.headline: Ericsson cuts back in UK
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Mobile phone giant Ericsson is to close two factories with the loss of 1,200 jobs, it was announced today.
fields.body:
Mobile phone giant Ericsson is to close two factories with the loss of 1,200 jobs, it was announced today.

The plants to shut are in Carlton, Nottingham, and Scunthorpe, Lincolnshire.

The Swedish company said it had been hit by the slowdown in the world economy, which has led to "slower than expected growth" in the mobile phone industry.

The decision to cut back production is part of a drive by Ericsson to slash £1.36 billion from its annual cost base.

webTitle: NHS 'failing breast cancer victims in north'

fields.headline: NHS 'failing breast cancer victims in north'
fields.trailText: Women in some parts of the country are unnecessarily having their breasts removed after a cancer diagnosis because of the pressures on radiotherapy services in Britain, according to a renowned cancer specialist.
fields.body:
Women in some parts of the country are unnecessarily having their breasts removed after a cancer diagnosis because of the pressures on radiotherapy services in Britain, according to a renowned cancer specialist.

Karol Sikora, who for two years headed the World Health Organisation's cancer programme in Lyon, said yesterday that a north-south divide exists in breast cancer surgery. Mastectomy is least common around London and the south east, where only 12% of women undergo surgery to remove the cancerous breast. In some hospitals in the north-west and north-east, by contrast, it reaches 30%.

The figures come from a voluntary audit carried out by 400 cancer surgeons involved in the NHS breast-screening programme who meet once a year and pool their results. They relate to women with only small tumours that should be susceptible to radiotherapy.

But, Professor Sikora said, surgeons are operating because the radiotherapy service is under strain and the waiting lists are long. "Overstretched radiotherapy services simply cannot cope with the extra work of routine breast radiotherapy, so pushing women to unnecessary mastectomies. It seems intrinsically unfair that those living in certain areas should have a poorer quality of service in the 21st century," he said at a lecture for the pharmaceutical firm, Pharmacia, for whom he is a consultant.

Elaborating yesterday, he said there were reasons why there might be some small variation from one hospital to another. "There are always some women who prefer to have a mastectomy. In others it may be that a mastectomy would be slightly better. But regional variations shouldn't be more than a few per cent."

Delyth Morgan, chief executive of Breakthrough Breast Cancer, urged that there should be a much fuller audit of the treatment and outcomes for women with breast cancer. "There are variations," she said. "There are variations in survival rates. The debate has been raging as to what the underlying causes are. It could be radiotherapy. It could also be cultural differences - that women choose to have different kinds of treatment or are not offered different kinds of treatment. This is a cause for concern. We would want all women to have equal access to the treatments that are best for them."

The government's national cancer director, Mike Richards, did not deny the figures but stated that measures were being taken to make more radiotherapy available in hospitals. "I am aware that radiotherapy services are very stretched," he said in a statement. "We are tackling this in a number of ways. Over the next three years, funding from the new opportunities fund and the Department of Health will be used to buy 101 linear accelerators (machines to kill cancer cells with accurately delivered high doses of radiation). Twenty-one of these will be in place in the NHS by the end of this year alone."

By 2006, there will be nearly 800 extra trained radiographers to operate the machines.

But even though the government has pledged large new sums of money for the NHS and for cancer treatment, Prof Sikora, now visiting professor of cancer medicine at Hammersmith hospital in London, feels it is far from enough to bring Britain up to the standards elsewhere in Europe.

Waiting times for breast cancer surgery are still slipping, he claimed in his lecture. The numbers being diagnosed within 14 days have declined from 50% to 44% between 1997 and 1999. The proportion getting their first treatment within 21 days has dropped in the same period from 77% to 74%. The data for 2000 is likely to show a further deterioration.

"These targets are extremely generous by European standards and the fact that so few patients are meeting them reflects badly on our NHS. Most breast cancer patients in France, Italy and Germany start definitive surgery within five days of diagnosis," he said.

Prof Sikora held out hope for a revolution in cancer care through a new breed of cancer drugs made possible by the mapping of the human genome. These will undoubtedly be very expensive.

fields.headline: Broadcasters tackle digital apathy
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Carlton and Granada are to address confusion about digital TV with an on-air promotional campaign, writes Jason Deans.

Mar 23: Digital TV sets to get 'Kitemark'
fields.body:
Carlton and Granada are to tackle consumer confusion and apathy about digital TV by launching an on-air campaign promoting the take-up of the technology next week.

The initiative comes just days after a Consumers Association study found 32% of respondents said they would never get digital TV and nearly 50% said they would only watch free-to-air digital channels after analogue switch-off.

The TV industry, government and equipment manufacturers have been talking for the past year about a public information campaign, to deal with consumer confusion about digital TV and help drive take-up of the technology.

But the two ITV companies are to take the lead and run a promotional campaign from next week, highlighting the difference between analogue and digital TV sets in the run-up to Easter when sales of TV sets usually pick up.

The campaign will guide consumers towards sets with the Kitemark-style digital video broadcasting label, which is to be introduced from April as part of an initiative spearheaded by Department of Trade and Industry e-minister Patricia Hewitt.

It will run across the 10 ITV franchises owned by the two companies, including LWT and Carlton in London, Carlton Central, Yorkshire, Granada, Anglia, Meridian and HTV.

The promo has been produced by ONdigital, the digital terrestrial pay-TV operator jointly owned by Granada and Carlton.

But a source involved in the project stressed the campaign was a generic one promoting digital TV, not the ONdigital platform in particular.

"The promo doesn't even mention ONdigital," the insider said. "We believe there's a need to explain the difference between a digital TV and an analogue TV, so the digital message is clear."

The promotion will also feature the on-screen logos for all 10 free-to-air digital services, including ITV2 and BBC Choice.

Carlton and Granada's campaign has the backing of the DTI and the Digital TV group, an umbrella body representing broadcasters, retailers and equipment manufacturers, according to the source.

But the campaign and ONdigital's involvement in it is not likely to be greeted with much enthusiasm by digital satellite broadcaster BSkyB.

BSkyB insiders have argued that any campaign encouraging people to buy digital TV sets is effectively promoting rival terrestrial pay-TV platform ONdigital by the back door.

webTitle: Is this the real face of Jesus Christ?

fields.headline: Is this the real face of Jesus Christ?
fields.standfirst: Talk about it
fields.trailText: With computer reconstructions from first-century Jewish skulls, the BBC claims to have come up with the best possible likeness of Christ for the third millennium, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
'There is a Christ for every age," wrote the art historian and director of the National Gallery, Neil MacGregor. Now, with computer reconstructions from 1st-century Jewish skulls, the BBC claims to have come up with the best possible Messianic likeness for the third millennium.

While Christian artists have liked to depict Jesus Christ in images that are far removed from his Middle Eastern Jewish origins - fair-skinned, long-haired, even blue-eyed - today's image shows him as dark, swarthy and sporting a closely shaven beard.

The image is the centrepiece of a new BBC series, the Son of God, which begins this Sunday. The three-part film cost £1.5m to make and is likely to prove highly contentious.

Analysis of excavated skulls of 1st-century Jews and images from ancient Syrian frescos reveals that the traditional image - from that depicted on the Turin Shroud to Willem Dafoe's blond-haired portrayal in the Last Temptation of Christ - is a fictitious construct based on centuries of erroneous impressions.

By combining computer images of ancient skulls with 6th century images of Christ, the series producers believe they have come up with a far closer likeness.

"It's not the face of Jesus, but how he is likely to have looked given the scientific information we've got," said Lorraine Heggessey, controller of BBC1. "That's what people from that area of the world looked like at that time."

Jean-Claude Bragard, the producer of the series, a co-production with Discovery and France 3, said he hoped the image would be a point of debate for all. "If you look at the programme, we are going to be challenging the perceptions of agnostics, atheists and believers."

The peak-time series, which Ms Heggessey described as a "landmark" project for BBC1 and should answer criticism that the corporation has marginalised religious debate, also provides explanations for gospel stories which many rationalists believe to have been mythical. There is evidence, for instance, to support the story that Christ sweated blood on the cross. Evidence from the US shows it could have been a medical condition.

"There are more than 100 reported cases of people under extreme pressure who know they're going to die, on their way to the gallows or the gas chamber, they're sweating blood," Mr Bragard said. "We looked at the scientific and archaeological evidence for the stories in the gospels."

While the miracles told in the gospels were not explored ("They are a matter of faith, you either believe them or you don't," said Mr Bragard), the series tackles a number of thorny issues. It suggests, for example, that Judas may not deserve the reputation conferred upon him by history. A re-examination of the original Greek versions of the gospels reveals that the expression translated as "betrayed" actually has a more anodyne meaning: Jesus was "handed over" to the authorities rather than "turned in".

Judas Iscariot, for his 30 pieces of silver, may simply have believed he was arranging a meeting between Pontius Pilate and Christ - whose natural instinct was to confront authority. "History has recorded Judas as the betrayer, and history may have got it wrong," Mr Bragard said.

The series uses intricate computer graphics to reconstruct the buildings of Bethlehem, Jerusalem and Nazareth, showing the cities as they would have looked to contemporaries of Christ. The programme also attempts to give an impression of Christ's youth: a period almost totally ignored by the gospels.

The series presenter, the BBC's former Middle East correspondent Jeremy Bowen, hopes the series will challenge traditional beliefs on all sides of the debate. "I'm not a religious person, but this series is not about belief, it's about fact," he said. Before embarking upon the project, he said, he had never conceived that it could be possible to understand the existence of Jesus as an activist and hero without believing in God.

"I'm very sceptical about religion and my instinct was to disprove a lot of this stuff. But it simply can't be dismissed. I don't think you can deny that there was this person called Jesus - he was a hero, he did have a following."

He said the computer-generated image of Christ was impressive: "He was a Middle Eastern Jew. If you go to Jerusalem today, a lot of people look like that."

fields.body:
Downwind, there was a smell like diarrhoea and clotted blood. A block of more than 100 decomposing sheep thumped from a dumper truck into a pit. Limbs flapping, the yellowed carcasses slid fast, because they were turning to liquid slime. They left a trail of blood and clumps of rotting fleece on the metal container.

The death smell, more pungent than manure, is now common around Cumbria. It is known as "the honk". People gag on it but are resigned to it. A quarter of a mile from Britain's first foot and mouth burial site yesterday, there was laundry drying on lines. It would have to be washed again.

Great Orton airfield, near Carlisle, is now known as "the killing fields". Long abandoned by the Royal Air Force, it was already bleak and grey. By the end of this week, there will be 2km of mass graves there. About 20 trenches, four metres deep and 150 metres long, will hold half a million carcasses.

Yesterday 7,500 dead sheep made the fast slide into the pits, were drenched in lime then covered over almost immediately by mountains of excavated mud. The thud of landing carcasses was barely audible over the beeps of digging machinery churning out more burial pits. At least 10,000 carcasses will be dumped in the trenches tomorrow; after that 20,000 a day will be buried. Tomorrow, they will start to bring healthy animals here; they will be lined up, killed humanely and tipped into the pits. With 240 cases in Cumbria, more than one third of the national total, half a million carcasses, stand to be buried here.

At the burial pit, Major Guy Richardson, said: "It is a colossal operation which involves a huge team effort and we are moving things forward. People are just getting on with the job. If people sat back and had time to themselves, they would think. But everyone is knuckling down. We do not want to be complacent, we want to keep the momentum up."

Maj Richardson said the trenches were being built as needed, to avoid the risk of empty pits filling with rain. Carcasses were being dumped at one end of a trench while bulldozers still worked at the other end.

Twenty-seven leak-proof containers on articulated lorries carried the diseased carcasses under sealed tarpaulins, through a neat-lawned village to the site.

Today 25 more containers will arrive, their odour seeping out. The only touch of humanity was the decoration in the truckers' cabs - leopard skin seats and curtain tassels. Elsewhere, contractors waded across straw fortresses in baggy protective suits, hard hats and face masks.

A quarter of a mile down the straw-lined lanes is the village of Great Orton, population 235. It has two dairy farms and three hobby farms; all animals are disease-free but due for slaughter because they lie in the 3km buffer zone.

At the Wellington pub, the landlady, Liz Currie, said disinfectant was ruining the carpet, and foot and mouth had killed trade. In the corner sat a group of French journalists making calls to Paris about the scale of the disaster.

Ms Currie said: "It has been drastic. The darts matches have been cancelled, plus the old people's activities. I have spent six months learning my lines for the panto, Cinderella, now that has been cancelled. It has killed the village."

At the butcher's shop, which doubles as a post office, the owner, James Mulholland, said business was down by 25%. His son has 15 pedigree cows landlocked in a field 400 metres from the pit. "The mass burial has to be done and that is all there is to it," he said.

While the first carcasses were heaved into the pit, the minister of agricul ture, Nick Brown, flew from London to meet farmers and ministry officials in a Carlisle pub. Outside the Auctioneer drinking house, he jumped out of his car to calls of "murderer" and jumped back in two hours later to calls of "you bastard." Around 10 farmers, gardeners and riding instructors had gathered, but he ignored them.

After the meeting Mr Brown denied that the government had run out of answers to the question of foot and mouth. "Just because it is a difficult situation, that doesn't mean we don't have answers to it," he said. Asked if the disease was out of control, he said: "No, the policies for control and containment are the right ones."

He added: "We have already disposed of more animals in this disease outbreak than in the 1967 outbreak. There has been an enormous amount of work done already."

He called for the time from reporting symptoms of the disease to slaughter to be improved, and asked vets worldwide to come and help. He then travelled to Devon to give farmers there the same message.

But Steve Heaten, a local National Farmers' Union leader, said of the meeting: "Frustration is the word. If I had any hair to pull out, I would have pulled it out."

He said promises made by Tony Blair in his rushed visit to Carlisle last week had not yet been delivered. In particular, Carlisle abattoir should be opened to slaughter sheep in the 3km firebreak zone con currently with the burial site at Great Orton. Mr Heaten said the process of diagnosis and confirmation of the disease on farms urgently needed to be speeded up.

Back at the airfield, Brigadier Alex Birtwhistle, who is in charge of the operation, said the army was looking at five further sites in Cumbria for the mass burial.

Jim Charters, 69, from nearby Kirkbampton, said: "I am glad that they have finally got their fingers out and got going with this. It has all happened very, very slowly to start with. I am not opposed to them putting the dead animals there. But I hope they keep a very close eye on it and take soil samples from the fields around for a few years to come."

webTitle: Foot and mouth: Smuggled meat blamed

fields.headline: Smuggled meat blamed
fields.standfirst:
• Damning account published today
• Pig swill blamed
• Blair contemplates vaccination as solution
Special report: foot and mouth
Foot and mouth: free daily email service with latest updates
fields.trailText: Contaminated meat smuggled into Britain will be highlighted today by the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, as the most likely source of Britain's foot and mouth epidemic.
fields.body:
Contaminated meat smuggled into Britain will be highlighted today by the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, as the most likely source of Britain's foot and mouth epidemic.

A damning official account of the likely source of the outbreak will claim that pigs were fed meat that was illegally imported for possible use in Chinese restaurants.

Meanwhile, the prime minister underlined the government's growing alarm at the scale of the crisis by saying that ministers are finally contemplating a vaccination programme. Mr Blair told BBC Radio 4's Farming Today: "A few days ago even, this was generally regarded as anathema to very large parts of the farming community. As you track the disease and see how it spreads, things that may have seemed utterly unpalatable a short time ago have to be on the agenda."

"Of course it has consequences for the farming industry for the future.

"But we keep this under review, we are urgently looking at all those possible options for the future and it's something that we want to sit down and discuss with the farmers' leaders because we want to try, in so far as is possible to do this in a way that the farming community accepts and understands."

A Downing Street spokeswoman said: "Nick Brown will say that foot and mouth may have entered the country through illegally imported meat fed to pigs as catering waste pigswill."

Mr Brown will stop short of naming restaurants which allegedly imported the smuggled meat for fear of prejudicing a possible police investigation. It is understood, however, that ministers believe officials have pinpointed the most likely source of the epidemic.

Serving illegally imported meat in a restaurant is a serious criminal offence which would attract a jail sentence, government sources indicated last night. A restaurant owner could be prosecuted for a breach of health and safety regulations.

Mr Brown will underline the government's concern over animal feed today by announcing plans to ban pigswill. The epidemic has been traced to a farm in Northumberland where animals were fed pigswill. The feed, which is made up of leftovers from restaurants and school dinners, is banned in Luxembourg and Portugal. It is fed to about 8,000 pigs in Britain.

Unconfirmed reports last night suggested that health officials in the north-east had been alerted to possible illegal activity after a container of illegal meat, labelled for a Chinese restaurant, was found concealed inside a load of household goods after confirmation of the case at the farm in Heddon-on-the-Wall.

Mr Brown will also announce other measures to ensure there is no repeat of the foot and mouth epidemic. He will close what may have been the fatal loophole which allows movement of sheep, but not pigs or cattle, within 21 days of purchase - which, according to Tony Blair, made tracing the disease as difficult as tracing the common cold.

In Cumbria, contractors yesterday began the gruesome task of burying hundreds of thousands of animals in mass graves at Great Orton airfield, a long-abandoned Royal Air Force base near Carlisle. By the end of the day, 7,500 dead sheep had been dumped in the pits, drenched in lime and covered almost immediately with mountains of excavated mud.

The air was full of the smell of diarrhoea and clotted blood and the thud of carcasses was barely audible above the noise of digging machinery churning out more burial pits. With 238 cases in Cumbria, more than a third of the national total, half a million carcasses stand to be buried at the site.

Government sources said last night that any vaccination would be limited and would be designed to "buy time". Infected animals would all have to be slaughtered eventually to ensure Britain is able to resume exports.

The government's moves highlight a last-ditch drive to persuade voters that ministers have sufficient control over the deepening crisis to justify pressing ahead with a May 3 general election campaign, rather than postponing polling day until June 7.

Though October has been ruled out, June is becoming a serious option despite deep reluctance in Downing Street and Millbank to abandon their plans.

Last night the Conservatives raised the stakes over the government's competence. The Tory agriculture spokesman, Tim Yeo, claimed that Labour had closed down a special unit to crack down on rogue sheep traders in October 1997.

After the unit's abolition, sheep movements around Britain increased, Mr Yeo said. That is highly damaging if the Tories can make it stick. William Hague urged the creation of a "crisis cabinet" to tackle the disease, complaining that current efforts lacked urgency and co-ordination.

An opinion poll for Channel 4's Powerhouse programme, yesterday showed a majority of voters unhappy with the government's handling of crisis and favouring a postponement of the election.

The poll, carried out among 1,000 voters at the weekend, found that 77% believed that the crisis was out of control and that 69% believed that its handling had been slow and inadequate. More than half of Labour voters concurred.

Yesterday - as 27 new cases of foot and mouth were confirmed, bringing the total to 634 - Mr Brown visited both Cumbria and Devon to explain and defend current policy.
