Unconfirmed reports last night suggested that health officials in the north-east had been alerted to possible illegal activity after a container of illegal meat, labelled for a Chinese restaurant, was found concealed inside a load of household goods after confirmation of the case at the farm in Heddon-on-the-Wall. Mr Brown will also announce other measures to ensure there is no repeat of the foot and mouth epidemic. He will close what may have been the fatal loophole which allows movement of sheep, but not pigs or cattle, within 21 days of purchase - which, according to Tony Blair, made tracing the disease as difficult as tracing the common cold. In Cumbria, contractors yesterday began the gruesome task of burying hundreds of thousands of animals in mass graves at Great Orton airfield, a long-abandoned Royal Air Force base near Carlisle. By the end of the day, 7,500 dead sheep had been dumped in the pits, drenched in lime and covered almost immediately with mountains of excavated mud. The air was full of the smell of diarrhoea and clotted blood and the thud of carcasses was barely audible above the noise of digging machinery churning out more burial pits. With 238 cases in Cumbria, more than a third of the national total, half a million carcasses stand to be buried at the site. Government sources said last night that any vaccination would be limited and would be designed to "buy time". Infected animals would all have to be slaughtered eventually to ensure Britain is able to resume exports. The government's moves highlight a last-ditch drive to persuade voters that ministers have sufficient control over the deepening crisis to justify pressing ahead with a May 3 general election campaign, rather than postponing polling day until June 7. Though October has been ruled out, June is becoming a serious option despite deep reluctance in Downing Street and Millbank to abandon their plans. Last night the Conservatives raised the stakes over the government's competence. The Tory agriculture spokesman, Tim Yeo, claimed that Labour had closed down a special unit to crack down on rogue sheep traders in October 1997. After the unit's abolition, sheep movements around Britain increased, Mr Yeo said. That is highly damaging if the Tories can make it stick. William Hague urged the creation of a "crisis cabinet" to tackle the disease, complaining that current efforts lacked urgency and co-ordination. An opinion poll for Channel 4's Powerhouse programme, yesterday showed a majority of voters unhappy with the government's handling of crisis and favouring a postponement of the election. The poll, carried out among 1,000 voters at the weekend, found that 77% believed that the crisis was out of control and that 69% believed that its handling had been slow and inadequate. More than half of Labour voters concurred. Yesterday - as 27 new cases of foot and mouth were confirmed, bringing the total to 634 - Mr Brown visited both Cumbria and Devon to explain and defend current policy. webTitle: BBC's attempt to deduce face of Christ

fields.headline: Artists sought truth not fantasy
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC's attempt to deduce what Jesus Christ might really have looked like may seem like a radical innovation. But the conventional face of Christ has always claimed to be more than an artist's fantasy. By Jonathan Jones.
fields.body:
The BBC's attempt to deduce what Jesus Christ might really have looked like may seem like a radical innovation. But the conventional face of Christ has always claimed to be more than an artist's fantasy.

Images of Christ in the medieval church claimed to be true portraits, copies of copies of copies of contemporary images of the Messiah. Certain images were said to have survived from his lifetime; a painting of the Virgin and Child in the Pantheon in Rome was supposed to have been done from life by Saint Luke, an image of the enthroned Christ was made by the angels themselves. Most influentially in western art, there was the so-called Veil of St Veronica, found in the 12th century and kept as a relic in the Vatican until it was destroyed in the sacking of Rome in 1527.

St Veronica was a bystander who wiped Christ's face as he carried his cross to Calvary, and it left its image on her cloth. Paintings of the Veil show the familiar face with its short beard, long dark hair and thin, long, holy demeanour. This is the image that artists reproduced again and again in some of the greatest European paintings and sculptures.

Michelangelo's Pieta (1498-99) in the Vatican has the same lengthy locks, slightly eastern curl to the beard and delicate facial features. This delicacy of face is also emphasised in Hieronymous Bosch's Christ Mocked (1490-1500), in the National Gallery.

Christ's pallor, thinness, beard and long hair were universal in Renaissance art, but some images go further in trying to place him geographically and ethnically; Hans Holbein's disturbing Dead Christ (1521) is definitely intended to look eastern, with his beard sticking out in a patriarchal, almost Persian, style. By contrast Matthias Grünewald's resurrected Christ from the Isenheim Altarpiece (1510-16) is a northern blond, his golden hair and beard glowing against white flesh.

Leonardo da Vinci's Christ, in his painting of The Last Supper, has downcast eyes, a tender face, long hair. His face has a photographic quality, which is why it looks to us so like the Turin Shroud, a medieval cloth which 19th century photographic negatives made look like an authentic imprint of a man's face.

fields.headline: Inspector mores
fields.standfirst: Social services staff are more positive about the inspection regime than their colleagues in other council departments but there's still room for improvement, writes Linda Steele
fields.trailText: Social services staff are more positive about the inspection regime than their colleagues in other council departments but there's still room for improvement, writes Linda Steele
fields.body:
Social services managers may be surprised to learn that they are a happier bunch than colleagues in other services when it comes to being inspected.

For all their behind-the-scenes grumbles about joint reviews and the social services inspectorate (SSI), a Local Government Association survey suggests that they're still prepared to give their social care-specific inspections a qualified thumbs-up.

There's widespread support for the principle of external inspection. Nearly eight in 10 social services respondents feel that SSI inspections "enhanced accountability".

And slightly more said inspections were "an important potential catalyst for improvement" (compared with seven in 10 councils which say that of inspections in general).

Social services respondents also have a more positive view than their colleagues about the theory matching the reality.

Less than half of the latter group felt their inspection actually resulted in service improvements and a little over a quarter thought it led to innovation.

Here, social services respondents are definitely more satisfied - 71% say that improved services came about thanks to visits from the SSI or joint review teams.

"I do find it amazing that anyone can be subject to an inspection and not find areas where they can get better. That's surely what we're about as managers," says Michael Hake, Solihull social services director.

Doreen Redwood, assistant director with responsibility for performance management in Lambeth council, agrees that inspections can be tough but worthwhile.

She says that in Lambeth the joint SSI and Audit Commission review has "driven the improvement agenda and validated what we're doing and what we need to do".

Inspections, she says, are "onerous" but "for us, they've helped make the 'change agenda' move".

But, there is all-round agreement that inspections make great demands on staff time.

Ms Redwood says that, from June 1999 to March 2000, she worked full time, "coordinating and writing the position statement needed by the joint review team and pulling together a library of key documents". And that was before the inspection had even started.

"The position statement [a prerequisite for all joint reviews] was very time-consuming, answering a number of questions asked by the joint review team. The key managers also had to be involved in giving the answers. And they also had to ensure that they had the evidence.

"If we said we held regular supervision and appraisal of staff, the inspectors might say: 'Could I see your supervision notes for this member of staff?'"

And then there was the actual inspection. "The inspectors were probably on site for a couple of months, virtually full time. It was very intensive. We had one member of staff co-ordinating it full time.

"In total, it probably took up a year of my life." No small commitment - especially in a department suffering the serious staff shortages common to all inner city authorities.

If that one inspection were the be all and end all, maybe it wouldn't be so bad. But there are numerous inspections that social services are subject to.

Mike Leadbetter, director in Essex, says: "Last week, I saw my eighth set of inspectors in the past four months. They've included the joint review team, district audit, SSI, Mental Health Act commmission, West [winter emergency strategy team], Best value.

"I am tremendously supportive of the need to improve services and also to make sure that vulnerable people are safe. However, the amount of inspection and range of differing inspections is a cause for concern.

"One of my senior managers said to me: 'Some time we've got to stop counting and monitoring, and start managing.'"

Yes, agree managers, inspections are needed. But couldn't there be more joined-up working between the inspection teams, so that staff didn't have to keep providing different sets of data to different teams? Couldn't the inspection teams at least talk to each other - and agree on one set of data?

Mr Hake says: "There is an issue about bringing inspections together. But, in the longer term, the development of public service agreements should lead to common datasets, because you will agree targets and areas for improvements in advance."

Paul Clark, former SSI inspector and deputy director of Hertfordshire county council's new children, schools and families department, says that things should get easier over time.

Management information is improving, in part through the introduction of the Department of Health's performance assessment framework but also because of more powerful software and computer systems.

Moreover, he says, the best inspection teams can often "negotiate" over the data that are available, so as not to put as great a burden on staff expected to collect more facts and figures for every fresh inspection.

But sometimes, different data will have to be prepared for different inspections, so that like can be compared with like across the country. And, he agrees, that can feel like "a burden too far".

Social services turn out to be less pleased than council respondents in general over the issues of the consistency of approach and the experience of the inspectors.

According to one senior social services manager: "Concerns have been voiced by directors about the lack of strategic experience. Inspectors may be very clever people.

"But not many of these people have had senior positions - they've been a middle or upper senior manager and the reviewers don't possess a sense of what it's like to run a large, complex organisation."

One area that the survey just touches on is just what it feels like to be inspected. By and large, the SSI is felt to be "fair and rigorous".

However, there is no doubt that having the SSI or joint review inspectors come in is stressful, as well as time-consuming.

Chief social services inspector Denise Platt says she makes "no excuse for the fact that external scrutiny can be a challenging process. After all, the role of the inspection team is to make sure that the services provided meet the agreed standards."

Ms Redwood says: "For many staff, there was the fear of the unknown," when the joint review took place in Lambeth.

"But it was also an opportunity for staff to voice their views. All the meetings were confidential and they could put comments [to the inspectors] in writing. On the whole, staff were positive."

So, there is backing for Ms Platt's assertion that: "It is important to remember that the SSI is also there to support councils in their efforts to improve and, furthermore, that we should have a key role in identifying and promoting good practice. That should not be ignored."

However, Ann Nutt, chairwoman of the participation advisory group, a users' and carers' organisation in Essex, says the county council's joint review was "quite a negative experience" from where she was sitting.

"It felt tokenistic at times," she says. "It wasn't like a two-way conversation. The joint review just wanted to pick up on what they wanted to pick up on."

Ms Nutt says: "Essex is quite forward about involving users and carers" and was happy to let the group see the draft report. However, she says there was reluctance on the part of the inspectors and it took some to-ing and fro-ing before her group got their hands on a copy.

Once the joint review team had released the document and held a meeting with both the council and users and carers, things became a little easier. Nutt hopes her group's experiences will be taken on board by the review team nationally.

Overall, as they might say in one of their reports, the inspectors are serving most of their clients well most of the time - but there's room for improvement.

webTitle: GlobalNet cuts jobs and plush offices

fields.headline: GlobalNet cuts jobs and plush offices
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: GlobalNet Financial yesterday added to the gloom surrounding financial news websites by announcing it was shedding 35% of its media staff. By John Cassy.
fields.body:
GlobalNet Financial, owner of UK-iNvest.com, yesterday added to the gloom surrounding financial news websites by announcing that it was shedding 35% of its media staff and preparing to move out of its offices in London's West End.

About 50 jobs, mostly those of journalists, are to go from GlobalNet's international offices in Europe and the US, resulting in an immediate saving of around $3m, chief operating officer Ron Goldie said.

A further $2m in savings will be found by moving from offices near Piccadilly Circus. "They're very expensive and we're looking for somewhere cheaper," Mr Goldie admitted.

The savings are added to $12m of costs taken out of the business by a strategic review in January. The review divided GlobalNet's assets into three divisions: brokerage operations; media; and business-to-business transactional services.

It is thought to be looking to drive consolidation of financial news websites, many of which appear frail following the slowdown in advertising spend and a reduction in share trading volumes.

GlobalNet's merger talks with Interactive Investor International appear to have been put on hold. It is now thought to be in talks with another privately owned website.

webTitle: McDonald's designs meal for older kids

fields.headline: McDonald's designs meal for older kids
fields.trailText:
8.30am: McDonald's is launching a bigger version of Happy Meals to appeal to older children, writes Julia Day.
Mar 22: McDonald's attempts to woo back French
Mar 20: Stick to burgers, marketeers tell McDonald's
fields.body:
In an attempt to keep kids hooked on its food, McDonald's is launching a larger version of its Happy Meals.

The Mighty Kids Meal is aimed at eight to 10-year-olds who have grown out of the kiddie-style coloured packaging and smaller portions offered by Happy Meals.

A toy will still be included in the new size portion but the hamburger will be a double and there will be six pieces of chicken instead of four, plus fries and a soft drink.

The meals will be served in brown paper bags more akin to the standard packaging than the coloured promotional boxes Happy Meals come in.

Burger King stole a march on McDonald's in 1998 when it introduced the Big Kids Meal for older children.

The McDonald's version will launch in the US next month, supported by an advertising campaign linked to the Miramax film Spy Kids.

"We are continually looking at developing the menu and the Mighty Kids Meal is something we might look at," said a spokeswoman for McDonald's UK.

"We never say never but there are no immediate plans to introduce it in the UK."

The move is part of McDonald's search to keep customers of all ages hooked on its burgers.

In the US, it has opened diners with menus that changes throughout the day, and it is opening a chain of hotels in Europe.

fields.headline: Ulster TV slams 'overpriced' ITN
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Ulster TV, which is challenging ITN for the ITV news contract, claims its rival is seriously overpriced, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
News organisation ITN has been branded "unfocused" by one of its ITV clients.

Ulster TV, which has launched a challenge to ITN for the £50m-a-year news contract with ITV, says the service is seriously overpriced.

Jim Downey, finance director of Ulster TV, said ITN could lose the ITV news contract in a cut-price bidding war, adding the battle for the franchise will be "down to price".

Ulster TV has joined Sky News, Chrysalis, Bloomberg and CBS in a bid for the service.

"We will be offering a quality service at a competitive price, which will be more than challenging to ITN," added Mr Downey.

The consortium, called Channel Three News, still needs to acquire nominated news provider status from the Independent Television Commission but negotiations are expected to begin in the autumn.

"ITN is not focused on ITV. Our bid is focused on ITV and we know what we can do price wise," said Mr Downey.

"ITN delivers that service at a very high price and at the end of the day it is not a focused service."

Mr Downey added ITN shareholders Carlton and Granada now face a quandary because they are also the major players in the ITV network and would clearly save money by accepting a rival offer.

ITV is in the midst of an advertising recession and would welcome a cut in the cost of its news service.

"For Carlton and Granada, they have to judge the overall value of ITN against the value of a reduced price for the ITV news contract.

"What is the worth of ITN if it gets the contract at a much lower price?" he said.

The ITV franchise is understood to account for 45% of ITN's revenue but nearly 100% of the company's profit.

ITN also provides the news for Channel 4 and Channel 5 but the ITV contract is the linchpin of the company's balance sheet.

ITV pays nearly £50m a year to ITN for its news.

However, Ulster TV and Sky will be willing to offer a service for significantly less and will work hard to hammer down the price.

"From a quality point of view, we can match ITN so any negotiations will be a matter of price," said Mr Downey.

Related story

webTitle: Peers vote against fox hunting ban

fields.headline: Peers vote against fox hunting ban
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Angry peers last night provoked a fresh confrontation with the Commons when they voted overwhelmingly to oppose a ban on fox hunting.
fields.body:
Angry peers last night provoked a fresh confrontation with the Commons when they voted overwhelmingly to oppose a ban on fox hunting.

During a passionate debate in the Lords peers voted by 317 to 68 - a majority of 249 - to reject a ban which was supported by a majority of 213 MPs in January. Peers later voted in favour of allowing hunting to continue under a system of self-regulation by 249 votes to 108, a majority of 141. They then voted against the so-called "middle way" option by 202 to 122. This would have allowed hunting to continue under a statutory licence system.

The final vote came as a blow to Downing Street which was privately hoping that peers would opt for the "middle way" option. Tony Blair, who is concerned by the rural backlash against the government, had hoped that a strong vote for the licence system would build up momentum behind the compromise proposal which is favoured in Downing Street.

The free votes, during the lords committee stage of the hunting bill, guarantee a lengthy "pingpong" session between the Commons and Lords over hunting if the general election is delayed. Peers will throw the amended bill back to the Commons where MPs are adamant hunting should be ended.

Peers demonstrated their determination to preserve fox hunting when they lined up to tear strips off the government for attempting to ban the pursuit. Lord Cope of Berkeley, a Tory frontbencher, moved his party's campaign against the bill into a new gear when he complained it was "distasteful" to be asked to debate the issue while the countryside is being ravaged by foot and mouth.

"I find it distasteful, to say the least, to be discussing this bill when the countryside is itself plunged into such dreadful agony," he said. Earl Ferrers, a former countryside minister, complained that peers were being forced to debate hunting at a "grotesque moment".

fields.headline: Party people
fields.standfirst:
As an election approaches, the campaigning arms of the political parties become more important and their views are taken into account

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: As an election approaches, the campaigning arms of the political parties become more important and their views are taken into account.
fields.body:
As the general election approaches the centre of gravity of political life moves away from Westminster towards the constituencies. Local parties are gearing themselves up to do their bit - and the evidence is that they do make an important contribution to turnout and party support. A key to Labour's landslide in 1997 was the revival of the grassroots party set in train by Tony Blair. From 1994 when he became leader until the 1997 general election, the grassroots party increased in size by about 40%. Many of these new recruits helped to turn the Labour vote out on polling day.

A campaigning party is an asset and there have been calls to transform Labour into a full-time campaigning organisation. Traditional party structures would be largely abandoned and the grassroots become a series of ad hoc temporary organisations centred around campaigns. As happens in the United States, the local party organisation would effectively disappear in many places during the period between elections.

The case for this type of campaign-orientated party is based on three propositions. Campaigning is said to energise members who are put off by long and boring meetings with arcane agendas. Members (it is said) do not have the expertise to be involved in policy making and they do not want to spend their time discussing resolutions and points of order; instead they would like to be out and about, campaigning.

A second argument is that a campaign-orientated party is likely to be much more outward-looking. Party members would get involved in local activity and act as Labour ambassadors in the community, helping to create and solidify support. In this view the faction fighting within Labour's ranks during the 1980s was due in part to the way activists focused on themselves not on the outside world.

Finally, and this is not usually mentioned in public, a campaign-orientated party is likely to be easier to manage. Opposition and dissent require organisation and if the grassroots organisation is transitory and linked only to campaigns, it would lack the continuity and institutional memory required to challenge the status quo. From a party managers' point of view the ideal party would consist of a sales force who are willing to go out and promote policies which have been decided elsewhere, while at the same time supporting the party with generous donations of money.

What do Labour party members think of this campaign orientated model of party organisation? Insight into this question is provided by our 1999 survey of a representative national sample of all Labour party members. The evidence is that there is very little support for the campaign orientated model.

Party members want to be actively involved in decision making. Some 54% disagreed that "party members lack the knowledge to make policy", and 60% thought that "those most active in the party have most influence over policy making". In other words they saw influence as a reward for hard work.

Did they think party meetings were boring and uninteresting? Again the evidence suggests not. About 39% of party members had attended at least one meeting in the previous year and most found these to be interesting, friendly, easy to understand and efficiently run. Few found such meetings to be boring or badly run.

The campaign model would remove the last vestiges of influence members have over policy making. With that in mind, we asked them to select one of three options for the future of the policy making process within the party. As the table shows, 37% supported the idea that policy should be formed solely by the leadership and endorsed by members in postal ballots. This is essentially the campaign orientated model, which in effect creates a plebiscitary party organisation.

National, regional and local policy forums have been an important feature of grassroots' party activities since 1997 and our survey showed that participants in these forums really enjoyed the experience. Participants thought that they were interesting, efficiently run and easy to understand, although they did have misgivings about how influential they were. We will know better whether their misgivings are valid or not when we see the extent to which their views have been incorporated into the party's election manifesto. However, the recent announcement of the creation of specialist secondary schools played no part in national policy forum deliberations on education and therefore bodes ill for members' influence. Since at present the mechanism for making the government accountable to policy forums is weak, they are likely to wither on the vine unless far more party resources are devoted to sustaining ordinary members' participation in them.

An alternative to the campaign orientated model is one in which structures facilitate advocacy, discussion, disagreement, accountability and responsibility. The communication of ideas and opinions upwards, downwards and across the party is possible and desirable. Members join the party and are active in part because they want to change policies and have influence over the future development of the Labour government. Take away that motivation and party activity will decline and members leave. Paradoxically this will destroy the campaign party - the very thing the Blairite reforms were meant to create.

 Paul Whiteley is professor of government at Essex University and Patrick Seyd is professor of politics at Sheffield University.

fields.headline: Express splits media task three ways
fields.trailText:
8.30am Express Newspapers has taken the unusual step of dividing its media buying between three agencies, reports Claire CozensRelated stories
Mar 23: Express sports chief quits
Mar 21: Fraser gave up £1.2m company for Desmond
Mar 21: New boy Fraser makes a splash
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Express Newspapers has taken the unusual step of splitting its media buying between all three of the agencies that pitched for it.

CIA, the incumbent agency, will retain the lion's share of the business, planning and buying all campaigns for the Sunday Express.

But rival OMD takes on the Daily Express business and MediaCom has been awarded the Daily Star account.

The company says it will spend between £10m and £12m on advertising the new-look Sunday Express.

The Daily Express will have a budget of £7m-£8m, while £6m has been earmarked for the Daily Star.

The decision takes the company's total advertising spend to £25m, around three times what the Express used to spend on advertising.

It brings it into line with arch-rival Associated Newspapers, which spends around £25m on promoting the Daily Mail, the Mail on Sunday and the Evening Standard.

"It is a sign of our commitment to rebuilding these great titles that Northern & Shell has chosen to increase its investment in above-the-line advertising," said Stan Myerson, joint managing director of Northern & Shell.

fields.headline: Indy lands building society sponsorship deal
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The Independent is to have its pages sponsored after signing a deal with the Bradford & Bingley building society, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Independent has agreed to have its pages sponsored after landing a deal with the Bradford & Bingley building society.

Today's issue carries the Bradford & Bingley name as part of a major rebranding exercise for the company.

Bradford & Bingley has just launched a multimillion pound advertising campaign to rebrand itself as The Marketplace.

The move follows the building society's decision to quit the increasingly competitive mortgage market and sell other banks' home loans instead.

The Times was sponsored by Microsoft in 1995 when the paper was given away free as part of a massive marketing campaign to promote the launch of Windows 95.

But the most famous case of newspaper sponsorship was when the Mirror agreed to turn its pages blue for a day to promote Pepsi's rebranding.

fields.headline: Highbury upbeat on ad spending
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Magazine publisher Highbury House yesterday bucked the advertising slowdown by announcing sales are running ahead of last year's. By John Cassy.
fields.body:
Magazine publisher Highbury House yesterday bucked the advertising slowdown by announcing that sales are running ahead of last year's.

The group, which said it was on the lookout for more "bolt-on acquisitions," has achieved 49% of its budgeted advertising sales for this year compared to 45% at the same stage last year.

A number of rival media companies - particularly in broadcasting - have warned that their revenues are likely to be depressed this year due to lower spending by dot.com companies.

"We did not benefit from the upside generated by dot.com advertising and so we are not experiencing the downturn," chief executive Ian Fletcher said.

Highbury House owns a stable of specialist business and consumer publications including Total DVD, Beanbag World and Fast Car.

Mr Fletcher saw property, recruitment and cars as the markets most susceptible to a further downturn in advertising. Together they accounted for about 10% of Highbury's revenues.

In the year ending December 2000 turnover leapt from £29.8m to £77.8m, largely due to acquisitions. Highbury paid more than £100m for Nexus Media Communications, Columbus Group and SPL Publishing.

"We'll continue to consider bolt-on acquisitions as long as the price, quality and fit is right," Mr Fletcher said.

Pretax profits rose from £3.4m to £6m during the period, while operating profit margins climbed from 9.7% to 11.6%.

Since 1991, Highbury has reduced its dependency on advertising from 74% of group revenues to 48%.

Circulation now accounts for 20% of revenues, subscriptions 10% and list rentals, exhibitions and internet activities accounting for 5% each.

Shares in Highbury have risen sharply during that time and last night closed up 1p at 50p.

That values the firm at £141m, but Mr Fletcher said he plans to build a £500m business within five years.

webTitle: ITV and C5 go for easy popularity, says watchdog

fields.headline: ITV and C5 go for easy popularity, says watchdog
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The battle for television viewers is being fought at the expense of variety in serious programming, the Independent Television Commission said yesterday. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The battle for television viewers is being fought at the expense of variety in serious programming, the independent television commission said yesterday when it accused ITV and Channel 5 of ignoring major international stories and concentrating on crime and dysfunctional behaviour.

ITV's flagship current affairs series Tonight with Trevor McDonald ignored the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, while factual programmes such as This Morning, Live Talk and Trisha competed to cover the same topics, the ITC said. Channel 5 concentrated too much on human interest, disasters and sex.

Both channels rejected the criticisms, saying they were committed to providing a wide range of programmes.

According to the ITC, Tonight's coverage of international affairs was "much lighter" than its strong domestic reports. The Middle East crisis and US elections fiasco were ignored altogether. But the regulator conceded that Tonight, derided by critics when it was launched two years ago to replace World in Action, is now delivering "strong and original journalism".

It is the most-watched current affairs show on British television although last year's average of 4.7m viewers has fallen to 4.2m since it was moved when News at Ten was reinstated in January.

ITV pointed out that Tonight had covered 20 international news stories in the 41 episodes shown last year, including films on the far-right Austrian politician Jorg Haider, the threats facing white farmers in Zimbabwe, and the Mozambique flood crisis.

It also announced that the veteran reporter Michael Nicholson is to present a series of four hour-long documentaries revisiting some of the stories covered in his 35-year career as a correspondent for World in Action, News at Ten and Tonight.

While Channel 4 came out with a glowing report, Channel 5 was criticised for the number of complaints upheld. Earlier ITC criticism forced it to cut back its erotic output.

Factual programmes "would benefit from greater resources and a wider range of themes beyond human interest, disasters and dysfunctional behaviour", the ITC said.

A Channel 5 spokesman said: "These news themes dominate the agenda of national newspapers and it seems odd that we are criticised for reflecting this. In terms of adult programming [we have] moved on .. the ITC hasn't."

fields.headline: Hooray for Hollywood
fields.standfirst: Julia was there, so was Russell. Even Bob Dylan put in an appearance. But where was Barry Norman, asks  Andrew Pulver.
fields.trailText: Julia was there, so was Russell. Even Bob Dylan put in an appearance. But where was Barry Norman, asks Andrew Pulver.
fields.body:
In America, they tell you, the Oscar ceremony is a primetime TV party, up there with the Superbowl as an annual popcorn-guzzling get-together around the small screen. For we Britishers, however, as the small hours approach, supposedly enthusiastic viewers fall away one by one, normal life hunkers down for the night, the sounds of the city die away and, finally, it's just the cable hook-up and you, hanging on with grim, unspeakable determination to see this thing through . . .

It didn't start out like that. At 2.30am, when Barry Norman floated up from some nether armchair-world in Isleworth (the London suburb that's home to Sky's studios), I was feeling pretty sprightly. Barry promised us it would be fun, offered a patriotic word of encouragement to the (obviously doomed) British hopes and said he'd be back later. (He never was - clearly he got the hell out and went home to bed.)

Cut to LA, and you're pitched headlong into the interminable frenzy that is the red-carpet crawl. Three grinning lunatics are our guides to the parade of billion-dollar celebrities strolling at a snail's pace towards their appointment with an inter- national TV audience of 800m (or so they say). Leading the way was a woman called Julie Moran from the TV show Entertainment Tonight. Sporting that patent Hollywood nip-and-tuck look, Julie reeled the A-list faces in. Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas were first. Zeta-Jones sounded like a West Coast oil heiress - the first of several identity reorganisations her accent would undergo during the evening.

Shoehorned into the following 20 minutes was an exhibition of the most cravenly insincere soundbite interviews I have ever heard, and I've heard some major-league crap in my time. Julie and her microphone-toting buddies radiated gallons of pre fabricated slavering excitement - at no stage even pretending to listen to what their subjects were saying. You could actually see Anthony Hopkins's eyes glaze as he tried manfully to match his interrogator's enthusiasm for the impending spectacle.

Trying to spot the biggest idiot is a time-honoured Oscar sport, and a tittering Björk, apparently swathed in a giant swan, was an early contender, as was Jennifer Lopez - was that a trick of the light, or were her clothes really transparent?

At 3.06am it was time to move inside and, after an inaudible routine involving astronauts from the international space station (note to producers: lose the intergalactic stuff next year), the cheery face of Steve Martin hove into view. Thank God for the simple things - a smile, a wave and the ability to time a comic line. His opening routine indulged in the traditional big-timer bashing: "Ellen Burstyn made herself 30lbs heavier and 20 years older, and Russell Crowe still hit on her." Cut to Crowe for reaction and he looks less than delighted.

Now, one of the few benefits of watching the entire Oscar ceremony is that you can gauge how certain individuals' evenings are shaping up. Crowe, having turned up in sunglasses and some kind of Doc Holliday-style rig, exuded a you-da-man breeziness on the red carpet. Martin's little jabs turned the tide a little, but he pulled himself together later to present an award, for best editing. Then he was clapping fellow Gladiator employees on the back and looking on graciously as they name-checked him in their acceptance speeches. At just after 5am, Hilary Swank read his name out and forward he stumbled to receive the trophy.

But that was later. The first Oscar was let go at 2.48am - to Crouching Tiger's art director - and three minutes later we witnessed the first attack of thespian ridiculousness, as Marcia Gay Harden won best supporting actress for Pollock. Her director and co-star, Ed Harris, a previously steely-eyed tough guy, lost his specs as he smothered her in hugs, and blew kisses as she hit the stage. My tape of The Rock goes straight in the bin.

And then, at around 3.04am, the cold, clammy hand of boredom settled on proceedings. It came in the shape of Sting, who sang a song he wrote for the cartoon The Emperor's New Groove. It's a well-established unwritten rule that Oscar-nominated songs are terrible, and Sting's was a classic of its kind. A bit later we got the song from Crouching Tiger - that was terrible too, and they added a terrible dance sequence to go with it. Björk made another bid for the evening's biggest idiot with her lifeless performance. It wasn't until two hours after Sting's turn, when Bob Dylan was beamed in from Australia at 4.57am, that things perked up a bit. Of course, his song was terrible, but Dylan has grown a pencil moustache and looks like Vincent Price.

The organisers tried to juice things up by getting Hollywood's slinkiest to present the awards - an informal way of finding out who the film industry establishment thinks are the up-and-comers. So, everyone, get ready for a blast of movies over the next few years starring Penelope Cruz, Julia Stiles, Kate Hudson, Ben Affleck, Angelina Jolie and Mike Myers. Can't say you weren't warned.

At around 4am battle fatigue really sets in, as the first birdsong begins. Amusing and/or interesting moments are few and far between, and you're reduced to giggling when Goldie Hawn loses her place on the autocue. Lots of broken English on the platform indicated that, despite Gladiator's final awards tally, South East Asians, Hispanics and Italians were a force to be reckoned with.

In the final hour we get to the heavy stuff. Crowe grabs his award. And, at last, we get our prize idiot. Julia Roberts may have fallen short of the demanding standards set by Roberto Benigni and Gwyneth Paltrow in previous years, but for babbling incoherence and self-serving, manufactured hysteria, Roberts beats all comers. That's what you call a reliable performer.

The last few awards get distributed, but it's all an anticlimax. No one's going to beat Julia. Poor Ridley Scott can't hide his grumpiness when pretty much everyone else from Gladiator gets a take-home and he loses out to snot-nosed punk Steven Soderbergh. Gladiator's three remarkably sane producers step up for their best-picture award. Seconds later, it's all over. Martin closes the show, the credits roll, the audience leap to their feet and rush the exits. Back in Blighty, it's 6am: grey skies, rumbling traffic and those birds are still chirping. fields.headline: Tiger thrown to the lions
fields.standfirst: Everyone predicted it, and it came to pass: this was Gladiator's year, not by a landslide but by a very substantial showing, beating Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon in the glam categories.
fields.trailText: Everyone predicted it, and it came to pass: this was Gladiator's year, not by a landslide but by a very substantial showing, beating Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon in the glam categories, writes Guardian film critic Peter Bradshaw
fields.body:
Everyone predicted it, and it came to pass: this was Gladiator's year, not by a landslide but by a very substantial showing, beating Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon in the glam categories. Any hopes of an uprising by the northern colony of Britain was crushed by Rome's imperial mastery, with its big performances, big effects, big box-office takings and big costumes - though it did give the UK its one out-and-out gong: best costume design for Janty Yates.

Hoping for British success at the Academy Awards is a tradition as unvarying as the state opening of parliament; and, as in so many years, "we" didn't seem to do so well, with the LA fat-cats cruising up the red carpet apparently unaware of the renaissance in British film-making.

As widely feared, plucky little Billy Elliot's hopes evaporated in the harsh glare of Oscar reality. Lee Hall's sparkling script and Stephen Daldry's intelligent, confident direction had to be content with nominations, and the same went for Julie Walters's performance as Billy's teacher. If it's patriotic uplift you're after, this came from the best documentary award for Into the Arms of Strangers: Stories from the Kindertransport. Although an American movie, it praises the prewar British government's mission to give asylum to Jewish children when all the world, including the US, closed its doors.

Julia Roberts steamrollered the competition with her bold, gutsy, well-observed cleavage in the role of Erin Brockovich, a self-taught heroine working the system against the big corporations. It's very worthy stuff, and Roberts certainly gives it plenty of chutzpah. Her first Oscar since nominations for Pretty Woman and Steel Magnolias 10 years ago is thoroughly deserved on account of her being a stylish and awe-inspiringly glamorous veteran of the movie business. But I couldn't help thinking she was seriously outclassed this year by Laura Linney, whose performance in Kenneth Lonergan's You Can Count on Me was at once more subtle, more moving and more real.

Steven Soderbergh's remarkable ascendancy this year, a winner in the best-director section, with nominations for two films (Erin Brockovich and Traffic), hardly counts as a comeback as he has been back at the top for a while now, as director and producer. But the Academy gave him the prize for the right film: Traffic, a bravura display of exciting film-making, interweaving many different plot strands but never losing control of the exhilarating narrative force. I'm not sure I can endorse Stephen Gaghan's prize for best-adapted screenplay quite so enthusiastically, as it is a script that claims American officialdom is utterly guilt-free in the matter of drug traffic, blaming everything on the filthy Mexicans.

Traffic's most euphorically greeted award was that of best supporting actor for Benicio Del Toro, who produced easily the best and most exciting Oscar-winning acting. His Mexican cop, speaking mostly in Spanish, was a tour de force.

It has to be said that the best supporting actress category was the dullest of the evening, with none of the contenders setting the pulse racing. Dame Judi Dench's tough, querulous performance in Chocolat was swamped by the glucose sentiment; Julie Walters was watchable in Billy Elliot but didn't get much chance to show her comic flair; Frances McDormand and Kate Hudson in Almost Famous were both, in different ways, irritating; and Marcia Gay Harden in Pollock - well, she won. I haven't seen Pollock yet, but the award seemed to catch everyone by surprise. By all accounts it was a craftsmanlike performance from a talented performer, but in Oscar-land there is a sense of "Huh?"

And, finally, there is the firm put-down administered to Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, whose award for best foreign film seemed to indicate that, as far as conquering the prestige prizes went, Ang Lee could dream on. That said, Peter Pau got a well-deserved cinematography award, and Tan Dun was similarly distinguished for the score. But the delicate, oblique charms of this unique, wonderful film were largely ignored.

That's a real shame. But there is a simple justice in the big prize for Gladiator: it's a monumentally big film, with monumentally big takings and a monumentally big performance from Crowe, who exudes real star quality. The 2001 Oscars might not have been a vintage year, but they elevated his grizzled masculinity in tandem with the dazzling glamour of Roberts, who has become one of the movie icons of the 21st century: a real, old-fashioned Hollywood star.

webTitle: Killer with IQ of 60 prompts review of US death penalty

fields.headline: Killer with IQ of 60 prompts review of US death penalty
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The widespread US practice of executing convicts with learning disabilities comes under scrutiny today when the supreme court hears an appeal by Johnny Penry, a Texas death row inmate with the mental age of six.
fields.body:
The widespread US practice of executing convicts with learning disabilities comes under scrutiny today when the supreme court hears an appeal by Johnny Penry, a Texas death row inmate with the mental age of six.

The case comes amid signs that the court may be ready to reconsider its decision 12 years ago that such executions were constitutional. This month alone, it has stayed two executions of criminals suffering from learning disabilities.

The Penry case is expected to revolve around procedural issues, in particular whether the juries which heard the case were fully informed about his disability.

However, the supreme court agreed yesterday to hear the case of Ernest McCarver, a death row inmate in North Carolina with a mental age of 10, whose lawyers are objecting to execution on the constitutional grounds that it would represent "cruel and unusual punishment". No date was set for the McCarver hearing.

Penry's lawyers will argue today that the Texas juries which sentenced him to death for a 1979 rape and murder, were not properly informed of the mitigating evidence of his learning difficulties. He has been assessed as having an IQ of about 60.

Twenty-five states allow the imposition of the death penalty on defendants with learning disabilities, despite arguments by the American Bar Association and human rights groups that the practice violates the US constitution's eighth amendment banning cruel and unusual punishment.

It will be argued that Penry was not morally culpable for his acts, citing a long history of abuse by his mother, who beat him, scalded him and forced him to eat his own faeces.

Penry forced his way into the house of Pamela Carpenter, 22, in the Texan town of Livingston, beat her, raped her and stabbed her to death with a pair of scissors she had used to try to defend herself.

Ms Carpenter's relatives and victims' rights organisations say his crimes showed signs of premeditation. They argue that a ban on executions of convicts with learning difficulties would open a loophole for murderers to escape the death penalty.

This is the second time the supreme court has examined the Penry case. In 1989, by a 5-4 majority, it upheld the constitutionality of executing criminals with learning disabilities, but issued a separate ruling - also by a one vote majority - that Penry should be retried because the original jury was not told that his learning capacity could be a mitigating factor in sentencing.

At the second trial, in 1990, the jury disregarded the advice of the judge to impose a life sentence and took just over two hours to sentence Penry to death once more. His lawyers argue that the instruction given to the jurors on the importance of mitigating factors was not specific enough about his learning disability and his history of childhood abuse.

Last November, Penry was within four hours of execution when the supreme court granted him a stay, saying it wanted to re-examine the case. Since the 1989 hearing, popular support for capital punishment has softened: 67% back it now, compared with 78% in 1989. Some 64% oppose executing people with learning disabilities.

Richard Dieter, the head of the Washington-based Death Penalty Information Centre, said: "Clearly the grant of these stays and hearings show [the members of the supreme court] are concerned about the whole issue... It seems strange they would take these cases if they don't plan to do something about it."

webTitle: Ban on sex history in rape cases challenged in Lords

fields.headline: Ban on sex history in rape cases challenged in Lords
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: Lawyers for the home secretary, Jack Straw, were yesterday locked in a legal battle to avoid having to rewrite part of a law designed to protect rape complainants from having their previous sexual activity dragged up in court.
fields.body:
Lawyers for the home secretary, Jack Straw, were yesterday locked in a legal battle to avoid having to rewrite part of a law designed to protect rape complainants from having their previous sexual activity dragged up in court.

The law, which came into force last December, has been thrown into conflict with a defendant's right to a fair trial under the Human Rights Act.

Five law lords at a House of Lords hearing are being asked to review a court ruling that the law unjustly prevents an alleged rapist from referring to his recent sexual activity with his accuser as part of his defence that she consented to sex on the occasion in question.

The accused man, who cannot be named for legal reasons, is among a number of accused whose trials have been delayed while the issue is thrashed out.

The appeal court said in January it was "common sense" that a person who had recently had sex with the defendant might have consented at the time of the alleged offence.

But parliament had stipulated in the 1999 Youth Justice and Criminal Evidence Act that a complainant's sexual history could not be introduced in evidence or by way of cross-examination except in specific circumstances.

On the face of it, said the appeal judges, this offended against the principle that everyone was entitled to a fair trial.

At the start of a two-day hearing in the House of Lords, David Perry, counsel for the crown, said one of the problems that the new act sought to address was that "insufficiently relevant" evidence of a complainant's sexual history tended to "overwhelm" the main issues in a sex trial.

In modern society, it was generally accepted that a woman's sexual experience with partners of her own choosing did not indicate a general willingness to consent or any lack of credibility in her evidence, he told Lords Slynn, Steyn, Hope, Clyde and Hutton.

Such evidence "introduces prejudicial material which invites the jury to condemn the complainant by reason of his or her morality prior to the event", he said. He supported the view of the home secretary, separately represented at the hearing by David Pannick QC, that the act was workable and would not lead to unfairness because it allowed for exceptions.

The law lords were due to hear argument from Mr Pannick and from Peter Rook QC, for the accused. They were also considering written representations. The hearing continues.

fields.headline: New blow for Railtrack
fields.standfirst:
Election setback for Labour as favoured candidate for 'job from hell' pulls out

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Election setback for Labour as favoured candidate for 'job from hell' pulls out.
fields.body:
The government's determination to approve a new chairman for Railtrack before the election received a considerable setback last night when the latest candidate withdrew for personal reasons.

Sir John Parker, aged 59, chairman of the gas pipeline Lattice Group, announced that because of a family illness, he has had to withdraw from the part-time £250,000 a year job.

It is understood that he has been forced to stand down because his wife is ill. He withdrew his candidacy over the weekend and informed Railtrack's board yesterday.

The government had been hoping that Railtrack would have been in a position to announce the appointment of the new chairman later in the week. With it was due to have come government initatives on rail designed to give passengers positive news before the general election.

Ministers will be disappointed at Sir John's withdrawal. They had tacitly approved the appointment because of his work in both the pubic and private sectors and his background as a trained engineer.

This is the second time in a month that Railtrack appeared to be on the point of finding a successor to its current chairman, Sir Philip Beck, who is due to stand down in July but wants to go earlier.

Sir John's decision to stand down gives Railtrack little time to find a replacement for the two and half day week job before the Prime Minister is expected to call the election.

Railtrack said that Sir John had been in advanced discussions about the post "but for personal reasons unfortunately had to withdraw his candidacy." It said that it expected to make an announcement about the appointment in the near future "reflecting the high calibre of candidates on the short list."

Sir Philip said: "We had all looked forward to Sir John joining the team and his proposed appointment had met with the approval from all the relevant parties. His late withdrawal due to understandable personal circumstances is obviously disappointing."

Sir John was appointed chairman of Lattice last year when the group was created out of British Gas.

Part of his previous experience was in shipbuilding. As chairman and chief executive of the loss making Belfast shipbuiders, Harland and Wolff, he managed a buy-out by the Norwegian shipping magnate, Fred Olsen.

In spite of Railtrack's optimism, filling the position which the City has described as "the job from hell" is not going to be easy. The search has been going on since January after Sir Philip, often described in the business as "the invisible chairman" for being absent on key occasions, offered to quit.

The chairman's job is key to the changes which are inevitable at Railtrack. The new appointment is expected to make important changes at board level, bringing in people with a practical experience of engineering.

The government has been indirectly involved in the consultation, although Sir Philip has warned it off from trying to interfere too publicly.

Railtrack is waiting for a government decision on whether it can have an advance of £1.5bn to carry out further maintenance of the network following the Hatfield rail crash last October. The money would come out of a tranche of £15bn already awarded by the rail regulator over the next five years.

This is the second time in a month that Railtrack appeared to be on the point of finding a successor to its current chairman, Sir Philip Beck, who is due to stand down in July but wants to go earlier. Sir John's decision to stand down gives Railtrack little time to find a replacement for the two and half day week job before the Prime Minister is expected to call the election. Railtrack said that Sir John had been in advanced discussions about the post "but for personal reasons unfortunately had to withdraw his candidacy." It said that it expected to make an announcement about the appointment in the near future "reflecting the high calibre of candidates on the short list." Sir Philip said: "We had all looked forward to Sir John joining the team and his proposed appointment had met with the approval from all the relevant parties. His late withdrawal due to understandable personal circumstances is obviously disappointing." Sir John was appointed chairman of Lattice last year when the group was created out of British Gas. Part of his previous experience was in shipbuilding. As chairman and chief executive of the loss making Belfast shipbuiders, Harland and Wolff, he managed a buy-out by the Norwegian shipping magnate, Fred Olsen. In spite of Railtrack's optimism, filling the position which the City has described as "the job from hell" is not going to be easy. The search has been going on since January after Sir Philip, often described in the business as "the invisible chairman" for being absent on key occasions, offered to quit. The chairman's job is key to the changes which are inevitable at Railtrack. The new appointment is expected to make important changes at board level, bringing in people with a practical experience of engineering. The government has been indirectly involved in the consultation, although Sir Philip has warned it off from trying to interfere too publicly. Railtrack is waiting for a government decision on whether it can have an advance of £1.5bn to carry out further maintenance of the network following the Hatfield rail crash last October. The money would come out of a tranche of £15bn already awarded by the rail regulator over the next five years.

fields.headline: Troops pull back in Congo
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: President Joseph Kabila of the Democratic Republic of Congo flew to Zimbabwe yesterday for talks with  Robert Mugabe, as the major belligerents begin to implement a peace accord to end central Africa's two-and-a-half year war.
fields.body:
President Joseph Kabila of the Democratic Republic of Congo flew to Zimbabwe yesterday for talks with his main military backer, Robert Mugabe, as the major belligerents begin to implement a peace accord to end central Africa's two-and-a-half year war.

The United Nations says Rwanda, Uganda, Zimbabwe, Angola and Namibia have all met a commitment to pull back nearly 10 miles at about 100 key locations along the 1,500-mile frontline in Congo. The various forces are scheduled to disengage completely along the front by Thursday.

But a number of obstacles remain to the peace plan, including persuading foreign forces to withdraw from Congo altogether, establishing political talks between the government and rebels, and whether a transitional administration should replace Mr Kabila's rule.

Mr Kabila has shown more willing than his murdered father, Laurent, to end the war and has permitted the deployment of the first UN peacekeepers. But few believe he is in full control of his government, and there are powerful elements in his regime opposed to talks with Congolese rebel groups until their Rwandan and Ugandan backers pull troops out.

There are also questions about whether any of the foreign leaders involved, including Mr Mugabe, is really interested in seeing Kinshasa reassert its authority. They all have strong financial incentives to keep a foot in Congo.

Today, Mr Kabila will address Zimbabwe's parliament, only the second foreign leader to do so since independence. But behind the scenes, it is likely to be Mr Mugabe who lays down the conditions for finally ending the war.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 www.theguardian.com/turncoats - remember these characters, for they herald the Diary's first, predictably faltering, steps on to the web, under the watchful and reproving eye of political website supremo Oofy Wegg-Prosser. Here at last, then, is what Mr Tony might call our "new dawn", which the missing picture of Diary pundit Steptoe was powerless to stall. Since first he dreamt of signing us up to his political branch of the Guardian's website, Oofy has urged us on with ruthless efficiency, with the Diary keeping our half of the bargain by displaying the sort of organisational skills most frequently seen in repertory productions of Noises Off. We may find ourselves in the ludicrous situation of having to apply to the Evening Standard syndication department for a picture of Steptoe, who enjoys a double life as Matthew Norman's pet dog. A reader may indeed have registered guardiandiary.co.uk as a domain name and be refusing to surrender it to us unless we pledge a large amount of money to Comic Relief. And Oofy may have advised me to put this matter in the hands of our lawyers. But let's just enjoy the moment, shall we?

 In this spot we had hoped to bring you an officially confirmed sighting of Home Secretary Jack Straw at a recent Brixton Ritzy screening of Last Resort, Pawel Pawlikowski's acclaimed film about asylum seekers. Remembering Jack's fury last year that newspapers were unable to produce photographs to "corroborate the allegations" that he had shaken hands with some refugees, we call the Home Office to inquire whether he was moved by the cinematic depiction of a young Russian mother and her son condemned to the wretched purgatory of one of Margate's asylum seeker "holding areas". "We cannot comment on the movements of the home secretary," says James Sorene, confusingly for a Home Office press officer."You're not still going to run this, are you? How many witnesses do you have?" Never you mind, James. Ritzy manager Sue Bamford is happy to confirm that Jack attended an opening night showing the Friday before last, if corroborating evidence is needed.

 On a related matter, many thanks to those who have somehow managed to find a follow-on from the thought provoking Readers'/ readers' editor issue we explored last week. One correspondent, who will sign him/herself only "The Dunce", is incensed by the Guardian's policy on capital letters: "When the paper describes Jack Straw as 'home secretary', I always think his wife must have a business at their home and he does the typing." It's certainly a more endearing image than that of a man whose office refuses to confirm whether he has made a visit in any capacity to a film about asylum seekers, but in future might all points about style be addressed to our Readers' editor? Or maybe to Oofy.

 Surveillance: Benjamin "the Binman" Pell, wearing his trademark flat cap and dustman's overalls, in the small hours of Sunday morning, rooting in the communal bins in my street. Benjamin's appearance (the second in as many months) left me feeling in no way unsettled.

 With Mr Tony fleeing worriedly from a foot and mouth press conference on Friday, Diary fears for his state of mind grow. Imagine, then, our concern at receiving a gardening flier headed "T. BLAIR, supplier of organic horse manure compost". Jokes about our beleaguered leader being a purveyor of excrement on all fronts would be churlish in the circumstances, so we ring Downing Street to ask whether Mr Tony's sideline has been badly affected by the current crisis, and if the "spreading service" touted in the leaflet is a reference to their gospel-like ministry. But they are not minded to talk to us today, so we must draw our own conclusions.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a preview of the Boat Race, page 4, Sport, March 24, we described the Oxford president Dan Snow as the son of the newsreader Jon Snow. He is actually the son of Peter Snow.
fields.body:
In a preview of the Boat Race, page 4, Sport, March 24, we described the Oxford president Dan Snow as the son of the newsreader Jon Snow. He is actually the son of Peter Snow.

In an article headed Light Blues pull for their mentor, page 4, Sport, March 24, we should have described Rowley Douglas as the cox of the GB Olympic champion eight, not the coach. The coach is Martin McElroy.

In a panel of facts and figures about Preston, accompanying an article, page 19, March 24, we said that Preston North End was one of the founding clubs of the Football League in 1885. The Football League was founded in 1888. Professionalism in association football was legalised in 1885. See www.football-league.co.uk/history/

In an article about the Scotland football captain Colin Hendry, page 2, Sport, March 24, we said that the Croatia v Scotland World Cup qualifier resulted in a 0-0 draw. The result was in fact, 1-1.

In a piece about investigative reporting, page 8, Media, March 19, we said Phillip Knightley was the only (print) journalist to win the award of Journalist of the Year twice. In fact, John Pilger won the award in 1967 and 1979.

The place in Carmarthenshire, mentioned in the obituary of Brian Trubshaw, page 22, yesterday, is Pembrey (Welsh: Pen-bre) and not Pembury.

The place in the Isle of Anglesey where a new out break of foot and mouth disease was reported at the weekend (a map, page 4, yesterday) was Llangristiolus. We printed a garbled version: Llangrifprolus.

The Around Britain weather details for Saturday, printed on page 18, yesterday, were incorrect. Our suppliers, PA Weather Centre, gave us the wrong figures. Apologies.

fields.headline: War of words
fields.standfirst:
How products are policed

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: How drinks products are policed.
fields.body:
Through its "independent complaints panel" the Portman Group tries to ensure alcoholic drinks are marketed responsibly. If a complaint about a product is upheld, the panel asks the manufacturer to make changes and puts out an alert asking retailers not to restock it. But does the panel work? Here are two examples of products that have fallen foul of the code.

Bad Jelly, Haggards Brewery
Greater Manchester police complained about this vodka-based product, claiming it appeared to be aimed at young or under-age drinkers and it was not immediately evident that it contained alcohol.

The panel said the product would be more likely to appeal to under-18s than adults. It took issue with the words "bad" and "jelly" because they were likely to appeal to under-age drinkers. It also said the product's texture and colour, visible through the clear container, were likely to attract younger people.

The panel's report concludes that the company intended to "comply with the code". But when the Guardian spoke to the makers of Bad Jelly last week, they admitted that the label still read "Bad Jelly Company Limited". And the product was still visible through the bottle, although the label had been increased in size slightly to obscure it.

The company's director, Tim Haggard, said it had sold "thousands and thousands" of the product, which was aimed at 18- to 25-year-olds. Customers included big national companies.

Sorted, Halewood International
A member of the public complained that the drink's name, coupled with an image of a target on its label, suggested violent behaviour and had associations with drug culture. The panel agreed with the first point but not the second. It thought it "might" appeal to the under-18s.

Again its report said the company intended to comply with the code. The company has changed the name - to Vodka Sorted. It has removed the offending target picture. It denies that the drink was aimed at under-18s or that its name was intended as a drugs culture reference.

webTitle: Anita Roddick celebrates 25 years of Body Shop

fields.headline: Anita Roddick celebrates 25 years of Body Shop
fields.trailText: Body Shop founder Anita Roddick yesterday celebrated the 25th anniversary of her health and beauty chain by stacking shelves in South Kensington, London.
fields.body:
Body Shop founder Anita Roddick yesterday celebrated the 25th anniversary of her health and beauty chain by stacking shelves in South Kensington, London.

Ms Roddick said she had managed to create a successful public company which is accountable to shareholders while refusing to compromise its principles.

She scotched rumours of a potential takeover by a former employee, but did not rule out a future bid. She said that any bidder would have to take a strong political stance, like Amnesty International.

Ms Roddick told how a bank loan for £4,000 to open her first shop in Brighton had to be taken out by her husband as being a woman she was not considered a safe bet.

The chain now has 1,800 branches in 49 countries.

She said: "I like to get feedback about campaigns. We turned each shop into an action station."

Signatures were collected from customers to change the laws against animal testing and to improve human rights.

Body Shop is said to have an annual turnover of £300m. All yesterday's profits will go to Children On The Edge, an organisation Ms Roddick founded in 1990, which helps youngsters in Romania, Albania, Kosovo and East Timor.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Hotline is silent
fields.body:
Hotline is silent

A government hotline for reporting bad behaviour by multinational companies has had no phone calls since it was set up in June last year, the Department of Trade and Industry admitted yesterday.

Trade minister Richard Caborn is to launch a pamphlet today explaining how to report breaches of the international good conduct code.

Britain is the first western country to publicise its national contact point under Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development guidelines agreed last year.

Endowments guaranteed

About 80,000 customers of the insurers Pearl, London Life and NPI were promised yesterday that their mortgage endowments will meet target values provided certain conditions are met.

Australian financial services group AMP, which owns the three companies, said the "mortgage promise" would reassure customers who were worried they could face a shortfall in the future.

However, AMP's pledge will take effect only if the funds in which policyholders' money is invested earn an average of at least 6% a year after tax. Policyholders must also continue to pay the current level of premiums for the rest of the policy's term.

AMP has almost 150,000 mortgage endowment holders, 70,000 of whom have been advised that their policies are expected to meet their targets.

Ulster TV shows up rivals

Ulster Television, owner of the ITV franchise for Northern Ireland, is proving more robust than its larger rivals. The company said yesterday that advertising revenues in the first quarter of the current year were likely to be 3-4% down on 2000, compared with a fall of 8%-10% in the wider network. The company reported pre-exceptional profits of £13.6m for 2000, against £12.6m in the previous year. Revenues were £40.8m.

British Biotech symbol sold

British Biotech has agreed to sell its head office, Windrush Court, for £12.7m and lease it back for 20 years at £1.1m annually.

The building in Oxford was completed five years ago and was considered a symbol of the ambitions of founder Keith McCullagh. The firm's new management has scaled back plans following a series of product failures.

fields.headline: Losses of £35m strike Chelsea
fields.standfirst: Club's poor performance blamed
fields.trailText: The owner of Chelsea football club yesterday warned that the team's failure to mount a meaningful challenge in European competition this season would lead to bigger than expected full year losses.
fields.body:
The owner of Chelsea football club yesterday warned that the team's failure to mount a meaningful challenge in European competition this season would lead to bigger than expected full year losses.

Chelsea Village Plc said that full year losses would exceed last year's £3.5m - six times as big as the year before - when the continuing cost of building works at the club's Stamford Bridge headquarters was taken into account.

Shares in the company were unchanged at 31.5p.

Last year Chelsea qualified for the quarter finals of the European Champions League and won the FA Cup.

But this year the team was eliminated in the first round of the less lucrative Uefa Cup. It was knocked out of the FA Cup in the quarter finals and is struggling to qualify for any of next season's European cups.

The team's failure means revenues from television and gate receipts will be lower.

Despite the losses chairman Ken Bates said the board remained committed to plans to turn the ground into a leisure village with two hotels, flats, restaurants, a health spa, a museum and a nightclub.

Those plans have cost the company £100m, and a further £50m is likely to be spent before they are finished. Although some investors are sceptical, chairman Ken Bates said it would be money well spent.

"There is no doubt that the facilities at Chelsea Village could have been built for less than £150m, but the quality finishes and the high standards we have set would have been compromised. This decision by the board is a far-sighted option."

In the six months to December 31 losses narrowed from £3.95m to £2.32m but that was largely due to the £12m received from the sale of striker Tore Andre Flo to Glasgow Rangers.

Mr Bates said that merchandising sales remained "flat". However, new commercial deals should enable him to present a more positive picture next financial year.

Lucrative sponsorship deals with Umbro and Emirates, cash from a broadcasting deal with Talk Radio and the club's share of Premier League television monies should all boost the bottom line.

webTitle: Notebook: Americans see London as the future

fields.headline: Americans see London as the futures
fields.standfirst: International financial link-up
fields.trailText: Notebook: International financial link-up.
fields.body:
Eighteen years ago there was a turf war between America's two principal financial regulators, the Securities & Exchanges Commission and the Commodities & Futures Trading Commission over who should oversee a new financial instrument called a "stock future." It was not something like a pork belly and therefore suitable for the pits of Chicago, even if the maths associated with trading the things was similar. But neither was it a regular piece of equity, more suited to Wall Street.

So the regulators found a simple solution: the things were banned under the Shad Johnson accord.

Since then the use of financial derivatives has ballooned and there is some irony in the fact that it is innovation by a British institution, the Liffe futures exchange, that is now forcing the Americans to rethink their legislation. In one respect at least, globalisation is not one-way traffic from the US.

Yesterday's alliance between Liffe and Nasdaq to develop stock futures for trading a range of global equities is sensible stuff, bringing together British technical and financial expertise with American marketing muscle.

How quickly these derivatives catch on, however, is another matter. Liffe and Nasdaq would like us all to believe that stock futures will be used as a hedging instrument by institutional investors anxious to protect their underlying cash market portfolios. And it is true that versions of individual stock futures are already sold by big investment banks to their institutional clients on a lightly regulated over-the-counter basis.

But speculative activity (much of it by retail punters) will drive the popularity and growth of this new market - a fact which could yet delay repeal of the old Shad Johnson accord.

As for a British derivatives exchange getting into bed with an American stock exchange, the wider politics here are difficult to entangle. From a state of near-death, Liffe has been ably resuscitated by chairman Brian Williamson. But he and his former colleague Clara Furse, now running the London Stock Exchange, have ruled out any merger of the British institutions. Nasdaq, on the other hand, has been resoundingly rebuffed in its attempts to take over operational control of the LSE, while Nasdaq has simultaneously turned down the LSE's offer of subscribing for a minority stake in the London exchange.

Meanwhile, over in Frankfurt, Deutsche Börse has gone for a full-blooded merger of the local cash and derivatives markets, also taking in the clearing and settlement systems. Its energetic chief executive, Werner Seifert, thinks Nasdaq is all bluff and no action, but still does not rule out some sort of transatlantic alliance. And the Germans still hanker after a presence in London, if only through the LSE using a common pan-European trading platform.

Confused at these stock exchange futures? There is enough uncertainty around to make, well ... a market.

Cut quandary

The European Central Bank is in a bind. True Europe's political leaders left Stockholm at the weekend making moderately optimistic noises about the economic outlook. But there were hints, too, that a cut in interest rates would not come amiss.

Some of Europe's central bankers have been taking a similar tone of late. Suddenly inflation is yesterday's problem - even if that has yet to be confirmed by the figures. Today's worries centre on ensuring sufficient growth.

Other central banks have cut rates - why not the ECB? The move might even perk up the euro. The single currency has rallied since its nadir last autumn - but the recovery has since run out of steam. Getting the euro on the march again would be a useful benefit as the introduction of notes and coins looms closer.

Not everyone is convinced. and the councillors of caution are to be found just down the road from the ECB's Frankfurt headquarters - at the Bundesbank.

At first sight that might look odd. Germany is probably the eurozone economy most in need of a rate cut. The government may be sticking to its growth forecast of 2.75% but everyone else regards that as the economic equivalent of predicting that Andorra will win the football world cup.

Even so Ernst Welteke, the Bundesbank president, has made it clear that the ECB should not be rushed into action but should wait for more economic data.

The risk of the Welteke approach is that the ECB could find itself behind the curve if it delays cutting rates; forced to respond to events rather than hoping to shape them. But as the Bundesbank knows, anti-inflation credibility is built on a tenacity which verges on the bloody minded. Inflation can never be yesterday's concern. For the long term anything which smacks of "cut and run" has to be avoided. Not easy.
