webTitle: New Look chided for being too new

fields.headline: New Look chided for being too new
fields.trailText: Women's wear chain New Look faced a dressing down from City analysts after warning it had alienated older customers by stocking too many skimpy outfits.
fields.body:
Women's wear chain New Look faced a dressing down from City analysts after warning it had alienated older customers by stocking too many skimpy outfits.

The company's shares plunged 10.5p to a new low of 50.5p on the news, which followed a series of setbacks last year. Chief executive Stephen Sunnucks said: "It's always been the case that about half our customers are over the age of 25. There's some evidence we've gone a little bit 'young' in our range."

He said the shops contained too many vest-shaped tops, while more mature customers wanted sleeves.

To make matters worse, deterioration in the property market will cost a £2m, as the firm sells its smaller shops and concentrates on larger outlets.

One analyst, who declined to be named, said: "The management changed for the worse last year. I don't think Sunnucks is good enough."

Richard Ratner of Seymour Pierce said: "This is very disappointing. They've not been able to attract enough good buyers to their head office down in Weymouth."

New Look parted company with its former boss, Jim Hodkinson, after a bottom-pinching scandal a year ago. The firm then blamed poor trading on a lack of "transitional clothes" to bridge the gap between spring and summer.

The company yesterday announced a 2% fall in like-for-like sales for the year to March. Profit forecasts were cut from about £40m to £34m.

Mr Sunnucks said: "The performance isn't satisfactory and I'm completely focused on fixing it."

fields.headline: At this price?  TT Group
fields.trailText: TT Group yesterday saw its shares go up by more than 10%. Was this just a reward for not issuing a profits warning like the rest of the engineering sector?
fields.body:
TT Group yesterday saw its shares go up by more than 10%. Was this just a reward for not issuing a profits warning like the rest of the engineering sector?

Investors had anticipated a gloomy announcement, given that 50% of the company's profits come from the hard-pressed automotive sector.

Instead TT reported a profit of £44.2m for 2000 before tax, goodwill and exceptionals, up 17% from 1999, which was a bad year for the company.

Turnover rose from £612.4m to £746m to 31 December 2000, while the dividend was raised from 9.79p to 10.05p. TT has made up for a slowdown in orders from Ford with new contracts from General Motors and better trading in Europe.

Chief executive John Newman says TT is at the high value end of the market and has a series of new patents on accelerator sensors and ignitors for high intensity headlamps that allow it to buck any downward trend.

To attract investment in the business's hi-tech sector Mr Newman is changing the company's name to TT electronics, saying that 60% of future turnover will be generated in this area.

The figure is higher than anticipated because TT is also demerging a ragtag of activities associated with its glass container packaging industry. TT is on a price/earnings multiple of 6.5%, half the average of the electronics sector so there are many reasons why its shares could go up even in today's difficult market.

With many traders dumping highly-rated shares, TT might be just the stock to buy. But it must be noted that TT makes 30% of its profits from the turbulent telecom sector. The group still has some loss-making businesses - most notably in the field of power generation.

It is a well-managed business with conservative accounting policies and considerable potential. As the company continues to focus on high-value electronics, there are good reasons to believe the shares should be re-rated from last night's close of 149p, up 11.5p.

webTitle: Market forces: Time for a technical rally

fields.headline: Time for a technical rally
fields.trailText: Billions of pounds were wiped back on to share values yesterday, as the City decided, after spending a weekend thinking about it, that last week's sell-off had been rather overdone.
fields.body:
Billions of pounds were wiped back on to share values yesterday, as the City decided, after spending a weekend thinking about it, that last week's sell-off had been rather overdone.

Stocks that dealers could not find a buyer for a few sessions ago were in demand, shooting ahead by 10% to 20%.

As ever, the catalyst for this performance was events on the other side of the Atlantic where the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq followed up Friday's solid showings with further gains yesterday.

Emboldened by the rise, brokers like Lehman Brothers were increasing their exposure to equities and advising clients that it was time to buy European shares again.

"The accelerated sell-off in stocks over the past few weeks means that European equity markets are at valuation levels that, in the past, have preceded sustained rally," said a Lehman strategist, Ian Scott.

With investors targeting those issues that had fallen the furthest in recent weeks - telecoms and techs mainly - the FTSE 100 clawed back 174.3 points to finish at 5,576.6.

All the other main indices were in positive territory, with the FTSE Techmark 100 rising 62.1 points to 1,999.08.

Troubled telecoms group Cable & Wireless topped the blue chip performance chart rising 49p to 493p on confirmation that it had sold its controlling 52% stake in Optus to Singapore Telecom in a deal worth £6bn. With £6bn of cash now on its balance sheet traders reckon it will have to return some of it to shareholders.

Marconi was also showing signs of life, up 19p to 389p, on the back of positive comments from WestLB Panmure. Contrary to what the rest of the Square Mile believes, the German broker thinks that trading is still fairly robust at Marconi - especially in the company's key European markets.

It says feedback from last week's hi-tech trade fair in Hanover, CeBIT, suggests that trading in the second half of the current fiscal year has been robust.

Elsewhere in the sector, Colt Telecom gained 59p to 889p and Vodafone added 11.75p to 206p.

Over in the tech world, Dimension Data, the networking specialist, moved forward 22p to 332p after a big push from its broker Deutsche Bank.

But the day's hot activity was in the utilities sector and chat ter that German power group E.ON, was putting the finishing touches to its offer for Powergen, 26p stronger at 736p.

According to the gossips, E.ON used a supervisory board meeting yesterday to get approval for the deal that will be unveiled alongside today's full year figures. But from here the tale became confused with dealers unable to make up their minds at what price E.ON might bid.

Based on press reports from Germany which said that E.ON was prepared to pay a 30% premium, some were putting forward a figure of 900p. However, given that Powergen was trading around 600p when talks were first revealed in January, others suggested a price of 800p might be more realistic.

The other story doing the rounds involved perennial bid favourite Royal & Sun Alliance, 33.5p better at 484p. But the hot rumour pushing the insurer yesterday had a new twist, namely that the company was considering selling its life and asset management business to Dutch rival Aegon for £500m.

Among smaller companies, Black Leisure, was marked up 21p to 177.5p after revealing it had received a buyout approach from chief executive Tom Knight.

Cambridge Minerals Resources, the mining tiddler, fell 2.75p to 30p, but market professionals claim that Canada's Newmont Mining is close to taking a 29.9% stake.

On Ofex, First Artists, which represents professional football players, got off to flying debut. The shares, placed at 33p, ended the day at 55.5p.

webTitle: First non-Jewish cabinet minister will have tough job ahead

fields.headline: Outsider finds his way in Sharon's inner sanctum
fields.standfirst: First non-Jewish cabinet minister in Israeli history knows his job will not be easySpecial report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: First non-Jewish cabinet minister in Israeli history knows his job will not be easy.
fields.body:
In his 10 years in parliament, the former Israeli army captain must have risen for the national anthem hundreds of times. But Salah Tarif, who this month became the first non-Jew to hold cabinet rank in Israel's history, always refused to sing along.

"I really respect Hativka [literally "Hope"] but the words there are not really relevant to me," Mr Tarif told the Guardian. "I can understand that for the Jewish people it is relevant to their feelings, but I hope they can also understand the feelings of others."

The delicacy of Mr Tarif's position on the national anthem - with its line about a "Jewish soul" - extends to his participation in a government led by the notorious hardliner Ariel Sharon and stacked with politicians who are even more extreme.

Mr Tarif's elevation to cabinet rank could hardly have come at a more sensitive time: six months into a Palestinian uprising which has killed more than 420 people and midway through an explosive Israeli judicial inquiry into the deaths of 13 Arab Israeli protesters who were shot dead by police last October.

He has no portfolio, although last week he was made chair of a ministerial committee on Arab affairs.

Amid such heightened passions, Mr Tarif's presence in Mr Sharon's cabinet has made many of Israel's 1m Arab citizens suspicious. As have his origins: he is a member of Israel's tiny Druze minority and served in the Israeli army for eight years before joining the Labour party.

Arab community leaders have condemned Mr Tarif's promotion. "Any non-Jew who accepts a position in this government is a fig leaf to cover the nakedness of Sharon's government," an Arab member of the knesset, Hashem Mahmid, said this month. "What he is doing is unacceptable to the great majority of the Arab population. It looks like he has crossed over to the other side."

Mr Tarif appears too shrewd for that - and far too conscious of his image. In a country where politicians seem oblivious to appearance - or at least their attire - Mr Tarif automatically reaches for his jacket when a TV camera looms into view.

From his wood-panelled office in the prime ministerial secretariat, he says he will promote economic development in the Arab towns of the Galilee, which have been subjected to 50 years of economic discrimination.

Healing words

He promises to heal the deep wounds inflicted on a community which lost 13 of its sons to brutal policing, and win over mistrustful community leaders. He also has ambitions to act as a bridge between the Israeli establishment and the Palestinian leadership.

But he knows his missions will be compromised from the start by Mr Sharon's tactics to snuff out the intifada, and by the open racism and inflammatory rhetoric of colleagues such as the tourism minister, Rehavam Ze'evi, and the infrastructure minister, Avigdor Lieberman.

"Their ideas, their ideological basis is problematic first of all, and then I have some fears of what will happen if there is an escalation on the security issue," Mr Tarif said. "I don't know what will happen - if I can stay."

He said repeatedly he had "great sorrow" for the 3m Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza - ethnic cousins of Israel's 1m Arab citizens. He tutted over the devastation Mr Sharon's siege policy has brought to Palestinian towns.

But, in the end, his loyalties are to the Jewish state. "I cannot ignore that now we have a struggle with the Palestinians as a state," he said. "Israel, I am really sorry to say, has seen a lot of terror."

Despite a promise to quit if Mr Sharon goes too far, Mr Tarif said he was reassured by the prime minister's first steps, which included laying siege to Ramallah, the political and commercial heart of the West Bank. "This is part of the war between Yasser Arafat and the prime minister to make pressure in order to go straight ahead to the negotiating table," he said.

Aside from the government's rightwing slant, Mr Tarif's position is compromised by the fact he is a Druze, who number just 100,000 in Israel and the Golan Heights, which Israel has occupied since 1967.

Unlike Israeli Arabs, Druze perform military service. Tarif, 47, was an army paratrooper for eight years. Before his election to the knesset 10 years ago, he served as mayor of his village in the northern Carmel region.

But unlike other non-Jewish members of parliament from the mainstream Israeli parties, Mr Tarif can be outspoken. He has accused the Israeli army of rank ingratitude towards Druze servicemen, and advised Israeli Arabs not to enlist unless given full civil rights.

During the election campaign, he accused Mr Sharon of "defiling" Jerusalem's al-Aqsa mosque during his morning stroll around the holy site last September - the act that detonated the intifada. He also described several of his cabinet colleagues as "rightwing fascists".

Now safely installed in the cabinet, Mr Tarif dismisses his earlier defiance as electioneering to get the Israeli Arab vote out for the vanquished Labour party leader Ehud Barak. But he insists he will not be reduced to mere camouflage for a hardline government. "I am ready to defend the country, but I am not ready to be part of provocation against the Palestinians."

 Palestinian gunmen shot dead a two-year-old Jewish girl and seriously wounded her father in an attack at a playground in the West Bank city of Hebron yesterday, the army said. Noam Arnon, a spokesman for the Jewish settlers in Hebron, said Shalhevet Tass was shot in the head. Her father, Yitzhak Tass, was taken to hospital, he added.

webTitle: Marc Rich's £1m cash seized at Gatwick

fields.headline: Marc Rich's £1m cash seized at Gatwick
fields.trailText: Marc Rich, the billionaire commodity trader and US tax evader who was given an unexpected pardon by Bill Clinton, used to be adept at spiriting his money abroad. Old habits, it seems die hard.
fields.body:
Marc Rich, the billionaire commodity trader and US tax evader who was given an unexpected pardon by Bill Clinton, used to be adept at spiriting his money abroad. Old habits, it seems die hard.

Lawyers for his company headquarters in Zug, Switzerland, yesterday confirmed that they were "cooperating" with the British Customs and Excise Department over $1.9m (£1.1m) in cash seized in a courier's bag at Gatwick this month.

Customs officers discovered the cash arriving on a flight from Europe during a routine search. They can now hold it for three months, giving Mr Rich, 64, an opportunity to show that it was legitmately acquired.

That should not be too difficult. Last week the Russian Alfa Group said it would be paying Mr Rich $100m for his commodity trading firm, Marc Rich Investment, which has annual sales of $5bn.

Mr Rich, whose pardon is being investigated by the New York prosecutor and a congressional committee, has had previous experience of allowing money to go astray.

In 1986, three years after he became a fugitive from justice owing $48m in taxes, he flew into Britain. Walking towards the departure gate on the flight back to Zurich he was panicked by the tightened police security - in place for an anti-terrorist operation. Afraid of arousing suspicions, he abandoned three cheques totalling $1.6m in a phone booth.

Mr Rich's pardon has caused an uproar in the US after it was revealed that his ex-wife Denise, a White House socialite, had given $450,000 to the Clinton library and $1.2m to Democratic campaigns.

The extent of the lobbying on his behalf was what American's would call awesome. The former Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, raised the pardon with Mr Clinton on three occasions, according to presidential aides. There was also a message of support from King Juan Carlos of Spain. Mr Rich holds Spanish and Israeli citizenship.

Although his philanthropic work in Israel was cited by Mr Barak as the reason, oil traders have confirmed that Mr Rich was instrumental in helping Israel to get oil during the Arab oil embargo.

Besides being charged with tax evasion, he and his colleague Pincus "Pinky" Green were charged with racketeering and trading with Iran during the 1979 hostage crisis. They faced up to 300 years in prison.

The pardon application by Mr Rich's lawyer, the former White House counsel Jack Quinn, so infuriated prosecutors that they have published a point by point rebuttal of it.

Mr Clinton wrote in the New York Times that a key consideration for the pardon was Mr Rich's charity work in Israel. But the prosecutors claim that letters of support were included in the application without the authors' consent.

fields.headline: Leakey quits arap Moi's cabinet
fields.trailText: Richard Leakey, chief of the "dream team" meant to extricate Kenya from its myriad economic problems, has resigned from his key post as head of the civil service and from President Daniel arap Moi's cabinet.
fields.body:
Richard Leakey, chief of the "dream team" meant to extricate Kenya from its myriad economic problems, has resigned from his key post as head of the civil service and from President Daniel arap Moi's cabinet.

The president's office said Mr Leakey, a celebrated palaeontologist and conservationist, had been replaced by Sally Kosgei, a longtime Moi ally and former ambassador to Britain, who belongs to Mr Moi's Kalenjin ethnic group.

Mr Leakey is a white Kenyan who served several times as the head of the Kenya Wildlife Service, from which Mr Moi once sacked him, and was one of the founders of the Safina party which opposed Mr Moi and his Kenya African National Union party in the elections of 1992 and 1997.

After the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund had suspended loans to Kenya in 1997 to push for political reforms, Mr Moi named Mr Leakey, 56, to head the civil service in July 1999.

He became the informal head of the so-called dream team recruited from the private sector to clean up the corrupt and inefficient civil service, work towards privatisation of state-owned companies and rationalise Kenya's ailing economy.

Mr Moi's office said the president "noted that with the completion of stage one [of Kenya's recovery strategy], it is therefore time for others to take over and move the process of reform forward. President Moi said that he had agreed with Dr Leakey that he, Dr Leakey, stand down".

Mr Leakey's blunt approach has earned him enemies on all sides in Kenya. Parliament overruled his attempt to reduce the number of employees in Kenya's bloated civil service.

Two days after moving into the job, he said he would work to end widespread corruption, inefficiency and nepotism.

webTitle: 58 boys die in Kenyan school blaze

fields.headline: 58 boys die in Kenyan school blaze
fields.standfirst: Disgruntled ex- pupils accused of starting fire with petrol
fields.trailText: Disgruntled ex- pupils accused of starting fire with petrol.
fields.body:
At least 58 Kenyan schoolboys died in a fire which swept through their dormitory early yesterday, burning them in their beds and as they crushed against a locked door and barred windows.

It was feared the blaze was started with petrol by former pupils protesting about the cancellation of their exam results for alleged cheating. Police confirmed that it was started deliberately.

With 28 boys in hospital, suffering up to 90% burns, the death toll at Kyanguli secondary school, 40 miles east of Nairobi, was expected to rise.

Dormitory captain Maweu Ngao, 17, said he was woken at 1.30am by his bedmate in time to scramble out of a back door usually reserved for prefects. The skin on his face was blistering and his lungs were filling with smoke when he fell on to the grass among 70 choking survivors, many of them with hair and pajamas alight.

"The other half of the dormitory was cut off by a ball of fire," said Maweu. The main door on that side was locked, and the key had been lost weeks before.

"They were screaming in there. Some were shouting 'help', but mostly they were screaming no words."

The dormitory housed 150 boys in 120 bunks. The fire started in an explosion across the middle of it. The raw timber beams burned quickly and the corrugated iron roof collapsed within 20 minutes of the fire starting, said Wellington Choka, the district police chief.

A rain shower eventually put out the flames. By then, there was almost nothing left for the fire to burn.

In the roofless wreck of the dormitory - a concrete building about the size of a railway carriage with bare plaster walls - bodies of the schoolboys, aged 14 to 20, lay on the wire mesh of bunk beds, their mattresses burned from under them. More bodies lay in a tangled heap in the aisle between beds.

As they waited for President Daniel arap Moi to inspect the site, police and Red Cross workers used the charred spars of the collapsed roof to hold back a crowd of terrified family members and curious onlookers, who gathered in their thousands.

Grace Kitubo asked every passing schoolboy for news of her 14-year-old son, Ndolo. He was not on the list of injured at Nairobi's Kenyatta hospital and no one had seen him.

"He started here in February and I have not seen him since," said Mrs Kitubo. "Please God I will find him."

When Mrs Kitubo had moved away, schoolboys said Ndolo's bunk had been positioned against the locked door.

"This is the most costly incident we have ever seen," said President Moi, promising an immediate investigation into the cause of the fire.

"The door should have been open one way or the other. Those children should have been able to escape."

Though far from unique in Kenya's riotous education system, Kyanguli was a troubled school. In February, 117 of 129 school-leavers had the results of their Kenyan certificate of secondary education exams nullified because of alleged cheating, as did pupils at 99 other schools around the country.

Last week, the school's governors met to investigate the matter. According to Francis Ngunga, the school's English teacher, their findings were due to be announced yesterday.

On Friday afternoon, a handwritten notice was pasted on the walls of the boys' toilets, calling on students to strike, and citing the governors' slow progress; the recent suspension of boys whose fees were outstanding; and dislike of the new headmaster who, unlike most of the 600 boys and girls, was not from nearby Machakos town.

The author of the notice was the arsonist, said Maweu. "The fire came from nowhere - it was a petrol explosion," he said. "We are sure one of these school-leavers wrote the paper and started the fire."

The local police chief, Julius Narangwi, said: "We have heard students were smelling petrol around the school since Saturday," he said. "It seems most probable that a former student did this because of a grievance over the cancelled exam results."

There were unconfirmed reports of a student seen running from the dormitory shortly before the fire broke out.

But Jennifer Nzilami, the school's matron, said: "These students were brothers and sisters - they could not burn each other."

Twenty boarding schoolgirls died in a similar blaze near the Indian ocean resort town of Mombasa in 1998. The cause of that fire is still unknown.

After President Moi's brief visit, Red Cross workers wearing protective gloves and face masks packed corpses into body bags and loaded them on to a truck. As they began, a smell of burnt flesh wafted across the neighbouring playing field where the crowd had gathered.

One woman cried: "Show me my son". But people were mostly silent, including the huddle of family members squatting by a set of goal-posts, waiting for news of their sons and brothers.

Those who had perished would be formally identified by ticking survivors off the roll call, said local Red Cross chief Vera Kimetu. None of the bodies was recognisable. "The fire was so quick, I think most of the boys died from the flames rather than the smoke," she said.

"The bodies have no hair, no features. It is the worst thing I have ever seen."

webTitle: Rebels abandon Selce 'stronghold' to uncertain fate

fields.headline: Rebels abandon Selce 'stronghold' to uncertain fate
fields.standfirst:
Macedonian army halts near deserted guerrilla HQ

Macedonia
fields.trailText: Macedonian army halts near deserted guerrilla HQ.
fields.body:
For 10 days this obscure little mountain village was tagged in a thousand newspaper dispatches as the "stronghold" of the latest Balkan guerrilla movement.

Now its red-tiled, two-storey houses and its fields dotted with blossoming fruit trees float helplessly in one of those strange vacuums which war often throws up.

Selce is no longer "controlled" by the rebels, the self-styled National Liberation Army (NLA). Nor is it yet "held" by the government whose tanks and ground troops were still waiting three miles away when we walked in at midday yesterday.

The reality is a village of deserted houses, some destroyed by Macedonian artillery, others abandoned, with their doors left open in the haste of sudden departure, with men, women, and children either leaving on foot or on mules to neighbouring settlements, or trudging for 10 hours across the snow-covered mountains towards Kosovo.

The Macedonian government in Skopje has claimed a partial victory: after sending ground and helicopter-borne troops into the mountains, backed by tanks, the army was celebrating the capture of Gajre, a village on the ridge closest to Tetovo, the country's second city.

The army had not yet penetrated more distant villages although guerrillas had retreated or put down their weapons and resumed civilian life.

The people in Selce appear as abandoned as their homes. "The NLA soldiers told us to leave, at about eight o'clock after dark last [Sunday]night. They said it was not safe to stay," said 29-year-old Enver Demiri when we met him with his neighbour and her small boy on one of Selce's steep streets. "All except the oldest went to the hills. We decided to come back today because it seems calm but the whole place is empty and the NLA is gone."

Indeed, the gunmen have vanished. In their hurry, or perhaps because they could not carry everything (the only road out of Selce is blocked by tanks) they left a sack of grenades, two ancient Chinese machine guns, and an old mortar in the main square outside the mosque.

A trail of bloodstains was visible on the road. About a dozen houses were damaged in Sunday's ferocious barrage, their roofs smashed, jagged holes in walls, broken furniture thickly coated with brick dust, family photographs on the floor, and the teethmarks of shrapnel everywhere.

Most people had spent the day in their cellars and only 10 or 20 suffered minor injuries, according to a local teacher, speaking by mobile phone about two hours before the rebels gave orders to leave.

Did Enver Demiri feel better off without the NLA? "We really don't know what to think," he replied. Did he feel abandoned? His answer was the same.

Finding the village so empty, Enver was planning to leave again, fearing what a Macedonian army assault with ground troops might bring.

An elderly couple pottered along, his stick tapping the cobbles. A traumatised calf careered around the streets, lowing in fear as it retreated, then gathered speed, not knowing where to turn. It had been in the yard of a house hit by a shell, we were told.

On the walk into Selce, in a wooded hillside near Gajre, another scene of hasty abandonment. Blankets and shovels lay beside recently dug trenches. A pair of new boots stood near a lean-to made of sheets of metal covered in dead branches and leaves. A grenade launcher was propped against a pile of wood. At least two dozen guerrillas must have used this place to monitor the asphalt road below.

The reason for their hurried exodus was clear. In scores of places lay evidence of Sunday's bombardment - huge round patches of leaves on the ground were charred and blackened, set on fire by the exploding shells.

At Sipkovica across the valley we found another ethnic Albanian village where fear and relief flowed back and forth.

The village might still be an artillery target, but so far it had only suffered minor damage in two short attacks.

Only two houses had been hit, but in one of them 25 women and children had been sheltering on the ground floor when a shell crashed through a first-floor wall above.

No one was wounded physically, but the shock has left many survivors bed-ridden with fear.

In Sipkovica's small square, beside a minaret, stood a large group of men in leather jackets. They looked neither fully at home nor fully out of place. Who were they?

The man appointed to guide journalists to the damaged houses did not explain their presence, though we had our suspicions.

Were these the "heroes" of Selce, the men who turned it briefly and so expensively into a so-called guerrilla stronghold?

Had they caused the wrath of the Macedonian artillery to descend?

And when the "victorious" Macedonian army withdraws from Selce and its neighbouring string of isolated villages, will the NLA re-emerge with their rifles and their camouflage fatigues for another go at "liberation", whatever, in these mountain fastnesses, that word really means?

webTitle: Turkey baffled by stream of doubtful smuggled Picassos

fields.headline: Turkey baffled by stream of doubtful smuggled Picassos
fields.trailText: Turkish police are questioning four men who were arrested in Istanbul at the weekend as they tried to sell two paintings attributed to Pablo Picasso to undercover officers for (£2m).
fields.body:
Turkish police are questioning four men who were arrested in Istanbul at the weekend as they tried to sell two paintings attributed to Pablo Picasso to undercover officers for (£2m).

One of the paintings was of a clown and the other of a female nude. Both bore the stamp of a Paris art gallery. The three men who were arrested include the nephew and the bodyguard of a controversial Turkish MP. Mustafa Bayram, the MP, was also at the scene but he escaped arrest by claiming parliamentary immunity.

Mr Bayram has drug-smuggling charges pending against him, and there have been demands to remove his immunity from prosecution.

Eight paintings attributed to Picasso have been recovered by the Turkish authorities in the past year. But they are a mystery. Five of them now hang on the freshly painted walls of a small room in Turkey's state art museum.

Have they reached a safe haven after an extraordinary odyssey, or are they part of an elaborate hoax?

The five paintings in the museum were seized from smuggling gangs and art dealers in southern Turkey last year in a series of sting operations. Police officers posed as buyers to recover a hoard believed to be worth millions of pounds.

"We think they are authentic Picassos," said Vural Yurdakul, director of the museum, in a recent interview. "But we can't do the pigment analysis which could prove it until we know who the real owners are."

The faces staring out from the canvas are as enigmatic as ever, but a possible clue is revealed when one of the paintings - The Farmer's Wife, dated 1908 - is taken off the wall. Alongside stamps from the Hermitage Museum in Russia and the Berko art gallery is what Turkish experts say is a royal Kuwaiti seal.

The Turks know that the paintings were brought into the country at different times in recent years across the borders from Iraq and Syria. They believe they were stolen from Kuwait by Iraqi soldiers who plundered the Emirate during Saddam Hussein's invasion in 1990.

Since then, the theory goes, the paintings have been on the move, until the smugglers brought them to Turkey to cash them in.

"They've certainly been damaged on their travels," Vural Yurdakul said. "This one's been rolled, this one's been folded, and this one's even been washed and lost some of its colour. It's sad."

The earliest painting - dated 1903 - is entitled Portrait of a Young Woman. There are three other portraits, signed and sealed. There is also a faded painting called Two People at a Table Holding Wine Glasses, which was offered to an undercover police officer for more than £3m.

The paintings can be restored, at least partially, but for the moment they are just being conserved in their current condition behind glass.

After remaining silent for several months, the Kuwaiti authorities have made a formal request for further information about the paintings, to clear up the confusion.

"The Kuwaitis know the paintings are here," said Mehmet Ozel from the culture ministry. "Our policy is that all works of art should be returned to the country they come from".

So why did it take the Kuwaitis so long to inquire about the mystery Picassos? One theory is that they were embarrassed about having the paintings in the first place, and did not want to be reminded of the Iraqi plunder. Another theory is that they were not interested because they knew the paintings were fakes.

"The better the story the more suspicious I become," said Ozgen Acar, a journalist who has been researching plundered works of art on the Turkish black market for years. Many of them, he said, turn out to be forgeries. "All the talk about Iraqi soldiers and Kuwaiti palaces helps to inflate the price quite nicely."

Turkey's position between Asia, the Middle East and Europe has made it a centre for lucrative smuggling activities, and the fact that Picasso is a favourite of the forgers has raised suspicions even further.

Nevertheless Turkish experts who have examined the paintings are convinced that they are genuine."They are the most popular item in the museum", Vural Yurdakul said. "We would be very happy to keep them here."

One of the paintings was of a clown and the other of a female nude. Both bore the stamp of a Paris art gallery. The three men who were arrested include the nephew and the bodyguard of a controversial Turkish MP. Mustafa Bayram, the MP, was also at the scene but he escaped arrest by claiming parliamentary immunity. Mr Bayram has drug-smuggling charges pending against him, and there have been demands to remove his immunity from prosecution. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Tribunal denies Milosevic move
fields.body:
Tribunal denies Milosevic move

Serbia's justice minister, Vladan Batic, said yesterday that the UN war crimes tribunal had unofficially agreed to give Belgrade a year to hand over the former president Slobodan Milosevic.

But the tribunal's chief prosecutor, Carla del Ponte, denied the claim, insisting it was not in her remit "to give time to arrest somebody".

Reuters, Belgrade

Court bails media tycoon

Spain's national court freed Russian media magnate Vladimir Gusinsky on bail yesterday, an indication that it would reject a request by Moscow to extradite him on fraud charges, according to court sources.

Mr Gusinsky, 48, is wanted in Russia in connection with an alleged multimillion-pound fraud case involving his Media-Most empire. He claims he is a victim of political prosecution because of Media-Most's criticism of President Vladimir Putin.

AP, Madrid

Russia declares war on terrorism

Moscow set up a top-level anti-terrorist unit yesterday after a series of deadly car-bomb attacks in the northern Caucasus prompted warnings that Chechen rebels were bringing their war deeper into Russia.

The move came as hundreds turned out for the funerals of 23 blast victims, killed after car bombs exploded in three towns near Chechnya on Saturday. More than 130 people were injured in the explosions.

AFP, Moscow

Pavarotti loses unpaid bill case

Luciano Pavarotti was left with egg on his face yesterday after losing a libel suit over an unpaid £16,000 banquet bill. He had sued over a newspaper interview in which Venice bar owner Arrigo Cipriani suggested the tenor should be considered a star "not of the score but of the bill, in the sense that he doesn't pay it".

Philip Willan, Rome

Rats are back in the kitchen

Rat-loving Vietnamese gourmets who feared floods in the Mekong delta would cause a shortage of their favourite meat have been cheered by the arrival of thousands of the rodents to local markets.

One report said 270,000 rats had been caught in 34,000 hectares of rice fields in Bac Lieu province so far this year, helping to satisfy the taste for dishes such as rat soup and curried rat.

Reuters, Hanoi

fields.headline: Showdown over nuclear waste
fields.trailText: Police and border guards yesterday moved in to clear several hundred protesters from a railway line near the town of Lüneburg as the biggest civil security operation to be mounted in Germany since the second world war swung into action.
fields.byline: John Hooper  in Dannenberg, northern Germany and  Jon Henley  in Paris
fields.body:
Police and border guards yesterday moved in to clear several hundred protesters from a railway line near the town of Lüneburg as the biggest civil security operation to be mounted in Germany since the second world war swung into action.

Between 15,000 and 20,000 officers were deployed by the German government to quell demonstrations against the resumption of nuclear waste shipments from France to Germany after a four-year pause.

The first massive helium sealed containers were due to reach German territory late last night before travelling to Dannenberg where they were to be unloaded on to lorries.

The convoy of six containers carrying 60 tons of nuclear waste pulled out of Valognes railway terminal, near the reprocessing plant at Le Hague, at 6.47am with two contingents of French riot police in its front and rear carriages.

Another 1,200 police were deployed in the Manche region and several thousand more took up posts along the train's route through Caen, Amiens, Rheims and Nancy before a scheduled border crossing at Lauterbourg near Strasbourg before midnight.

But despite the French authorities' fears, only about 20 protesters gathered at Valognes to witness the train's departure, firing a flare and holding banners reading "La Hague: the dustbin is overflowing".

Anti-nuclear groups say their aim is to drive up the cost of waste shipments and persuade utilities that nuclear plants are not economical.

"Every transport from La Hague makes another transport to La Hague possible, securing the continued operation of the nuclear power plants," said Rasmus Grobe, a spokesman for a protest group whose symbol, a large yellow X, has appeared across the country.

French anti-nuclear campaigners had earlier said they would not try to block the shipment. "We think it's only right the waste should go back to where it came from," said Frederic Marillier, of Greenpeace. "But we want to denounce this return, because it opens the door to trains coming from the other direction."

In Germany, the last shipments four years ago sparked battles between police and demonstrators opposed to the storing of waste in a disused salt mine at Gorleben, south of Hamburg. Evidence of radioactive leaks prompted the German government to halt the shipments the following year.

The resumption has shaken the Green party, the junior partner in Gerhard Schröder's coalition, to its roots. The decision to take back the waste was made by the environment minister, Jurgen Trittin, a leader of the Greens who once protested against nuclear dumping.

At the railhead in north Germany, the nearest crossing was protected by three border guard armoured personnel carriers. A further three were positioned 100 yards back up the track, equipped with ploughs at the front to sweep obstacles off the rails. Police said they had made 80 arrests in a string of incidents across the area. Demonstrators yesterday appeared to be concentrating on getting stretches of the line blocked in advance of the containers' arrival.

The French reprocessing agency, Cogema, which operates the La Hague facility, estimates about 15 more transports will be needed - at a rate of about two a year - to ship the backlog of waste back to Germany.

Hear John Hooper reporting on the controversy at www.theguardian.com/audio

fields.headline: New clues in JFK shooting
fields.trailText: A report in a British forensic science journal has reopened the debate over one of the central mysteries of the assassination of John F Kennedy, arguing from audiotape evidence that a second sniper was almost certainly involved.
fields.body:
A report in a British forensic science journal has reopened the debate over one of the central mysteries of the assassination of John F Kennedy, arguing from audiotape evidence that a second sniper was almost certainly involved.

The analysis by a US government scientist was subjected to review by a scientific panel before publication in Science & Justice, quarterly journal of the Forensic Science Society.

It lends weight to the longstanding insistence by conspiracy theorists that at least one of the shots on Dealey Plaza in Dallas on November 22 1963 was fired from a "grassy knoll" ahead and to the right of President Kennedy's motorcade. The official verdict of the Warren commission on the assassination found that Lee Harvey Oswald had acted alone, firing three shots from the Texas school book depository behind the president.

But DB Thomas, a government scientist, conducted an acoustic analysis of police tapes of the assassination and concluded that it was 96% certain that a fourth shot had come from the grassy knoll.

The new report confirms the findings of a 1978 congressional investigation of the tapes by the House of Represenatives select committee on assassinations. However, the committee's findings were overturned by a subsequent study by the National Research Council, commissioned by the justice department, which dismissed the sound of apparent gunshots on the police tapes as static noise.

Mr Thomas argues that the NRC erred in believing that the shot-like noises on the tapes came after the killing. In fact, the noises occurred "at the exact instant that John F Kennedy was assassinated".

The tapes were recorded by a microphone on a police motorcycle in the motorcade. The congressional committee compared the acoustic signature on the tapes with the sound of shots fired from different places on Dealey Plaza. Mr Thomas found that the third of the four shots exactly matched the sound of a rifle muzzle blast from the grassy knoll. The famous film of the killing also seems to show the fatal shot to Kennedy's head coming from the front.

webTitle: Baby's death stokes West Bank tensions

fields.headline: Baby's death stokes West Bank tensions
fields.standfirst:
Shooting of 10-month-old Jewish girl by a Palestinian sniper poses the biggest test so far of the Israeli prime minister's hardline credentials

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Shooting of 10-month-old Jewish girl by a Palestinian sniper poses the biggest test so far of the Israeli prime minister's hardline credentials.
fields.body:
The highly emotive death of a baby Jewish girl, shot dead in her father's arms by a Palestinian sniper in the West Bank city of Hebron, looked likely last night to unleash fresh spasms of violence.

As Israeli tanks pounded Palestinian neighbourhoods, there were widespread fears that the death of the 10-month-old infant could ignite barely contained hatreds in Hebron, where an enclave of 400 Jewish settlers - the most extreme in the West Bank - have regularly clashed with their resentful Palestinian neighbours.

Yesterday's killing provides the most serious test yet for the hardline prime minister, Ariel Sharon, who was elected to serve as Israel's strongman. Last night, he directly blamed Yasser Arafat's administration for the death, setting the stage for reprisal.

Meanwhile, the army sealed all exits from Hebron - home to 120,000 Palestinians - and imposed a curfew on the 40,000 people living in the old town. The Jewish settlement there, which remained when the city was handed over to Palestinian rule in 1997, has been a regular source of tension and violence for years.

Residents of the Abu Sneineh neighbourhood - the most likely source of fire on the infant - were told to evacuate their homes, suggesting imminent Israeli reprisals.

"The Palestinians are continuing to cause provocations with the purpose of drawing the Israeli Defence Force to respond harshly and escalate the situation in order to achieve their political goals," a statement from the Israeli army said.

The dead baby, Shalhavet Pass, is the youngest Jew to die in a six-month uprising that has killed more than 430, mainly Palestinians. About 20% of the Palestinian victims were children.

As news spread that Shalhavet had been shot in her father's arms, and that he was also wounded, demonstrators from the nearly settlement of Kiryat Arba began stoning Palestinian homes.

The settlers of Hebron have been clamouring for the army to occupy the Palestinian-controlled neighbourhood of Abu Sneineh, where snipers, operating from half-built houses, have been firing on their outpost.

"We demand that all this territory be recaptured and the terrorists be wiped out. There is no other solution. The head of the snake must be crushed," said Noam Arnon, a spokesman for the Hebron settlers.

Tensions in Hebron's old city will be even higher today when settlers say they will hold a 24-hour protest in the lanes of the Palestinian markets until Mr Sharon retakes the hills of Abu Sneineh.

In the past, Palestinian stallholders say their carts have been regularly overturned by the armed Jewish settlers, and previous vigils have invariably ended in violence.

Mr Sharon, who was meeting with his security advisers last night, must at last reveal the substance behind his promises to strike at those who shoot at Israeli soldiers and civilians, without subjecting Palestinians to collective punishment.

Since his return from a visit to the US last week, he has grown increasingly bold in his pronouncements against the Palestinians.

Mr Sharon now directly accuses Yasser Arafat's bodyguard - Force 17 - of plotting attacks on Israelis, in language that suggests the prime minister is providing the pretext for a major offensive against the Palestinian authority.

"We know with certainty that the Palestinian Authority security mechanisms, including the Force 17 guard, are behind the latest terrorist attacks," Mr Sharon told the former senator George Mitchell this week.

Mr Mitchell is leading an international fact-finding team into rights abuses during the intifada.

fields.headline: 'What can we sing that will make them really mad?'
fields.standfirst: The diehard fans of Hellas Verona search for the ultimate insult
fields.trailText: The diehard fans of Hellas Verona search for the ultimate insult
fields.body:
After Verona's game with Atalanta (Bergamo), the police kept us on the terraces for almost two hours in sub-zero temperatures. There is an ancient enmity between these two cities and we had to be protected from their fans. Or perhaps keeping us numb and shivering in the cold was the authorities' way of expressing that enmity.

Stamping our feet, we huddled together and sang songs insulting the departing Bergamaschi. "Sempre di meno," we called mockingly, "O siete sempre di meno" - there are fewer and fewer of you. It's the song you sing when you're winning and the opposing fans start to leave early, whereas in fact we had lost 3-0. Then no doubt because it was All Souls' Day, someone made a crucifix of plastic flag poles, the chorus leader spread his arms, let his head fall to one side and everybody sang the church hymn Risorgeremo - We shall rise again.

At last all the Bergamaschi were gone, only the carabinieri were left. Since one of their helicopters had crashed only a couple of days before, the fans launched into an old fascist song that celebrated the modern and mechanised army, but with slightly altered words:

" E gira gira l'elica, romba il motor,

L'elicottero dell'arma è tornato al creator."

(Turn propeller turn, out roars the motor,/ The policemen's 'copter's gone back to its maker.)

How can one laugh at such bad taste? Ten men had died. Everyone laughed. I even saw a carabiniere smile. "Verona merda!" the Bergamaschi shrieked as we were escorted back to our bus. An ancient man leaned one arm on his walking stick to give us the finger raised high with the other. His face lit up in a wild grin. In the San Nicolò stadium in Bari, high on cocaine and sodden with beer, a young Veronese went on and on shouting: "Albanesi! Kurdi! Scafisti!" The scafisti are the unscrupulous men who bring in illegal immigrants on their rubber scafi, or motorboats. "Albanians! Kurds! Scafisti! Your mothers are whores! You live off our taxes."

Suddenly the wind blew his hat off. It was a precious 1985 hat, the year of the miracle, when tiny Hellas Verona won the Italian championship, against the opposition of Michel Platini's Juventus and Alessandro Altobelli's Inter. There was a gale blowing. The hat sailed over the fence segregating the visitors area. "Give me my hat back," the man shouted. "Please! It's a 1985 hat. It's an original!"

In Bologna we lost 1-0. After taunting the home team's black players with monkey grunts, the Brigate gialloblù - the Yellow-Blue Brigades, as the hardcore fans call themselves - bought Coca-Colas from a vendor at half time, slapping the boy on the back and chatting away cheerfully. He was black. "Communisti!" they shouted at the Bolognese. "Rossi di merda" - shit reds. Verona played terribly, as if the players didn't want to be there.

In Perugia, the local fans had strung up a banner: "A NON-RACIST TOWN IS ALWAYS IN SERIE A." The Veronese felt such provocation too banal to deserve comment. "Merda siete," they began, "e merda resterete" - shit you are and shit you'll stay. It was routine stuff, ordinaria amministrazione, as they say. Likewise the game, which we lost 1-0.

In Lecce it was the Verona fans who hung up a banner - " CIAO NICOLÒ, EVEN ABSENT YOU WILL ALWAYS BE AMONG US." One of their own had died of cancer. Such commemorations are part of stadium ritual. "Oltre la morte" - beyond death - it says over the central gate to Verona's famous curva sud . "Ciao Nicolò!" they shouted. There was a slow hand-clap. Then they got down to it: "Acqua e sapone, ci vuole acqua e sapone" - soap and water, it takes soap and water (to wash a southerner).

In the north-eastern town of Udine, half an hour before the game, one of the chorus leaders, a handsome man with salmon-pink shaven scalp and wrap-around blue sunglasses, said: "Kids, the first chant is the most important. It sets the tone. So what can we sing that will make them really mad?"

It was a tough question. When you're down south, it's easy: you tell the opposition they're filthy, they stink. When you're in Turin they're gobbi - hunchbacks - because they're bent over Fiat's production line all day. The Bolognese are reds. That's obvious. The Vicentini are magnagatti - cat eaters, a half-starved underclass. But what can you say to the affluent, clean-living folks of Udine, just a stone's throw from the Slovenian border?

"Come on," the chorus leader challenges. "What can we sing?" His voice is that of the amused teacher, waiting to see if any of his pupils is especially clever.

"Slavi di merda?" someone suggests. Slavs?

The chorus leader shakes his head. "It has to be something that will drive them completely crazy."

Nobody knows. We've no idea.

"Terremotati!" he declares.

Of course: a terremoto is an earthquake. Terremotati are the victims of an earthquake. In 1976 the region of Friuli-Venezia Giulia, of which Udine is the capital, was devastated by an earthquake that caused thousands of deaths. We are going to insult these people by reminding them that they were once profoundly unlucky. No doubt there will be some here who lost loved ones in that quake.

There is something fantastically atavistic about this. For a moment it's as though we're back in one of the Sicilian novels of Giovanni Verga, full of the peasant community's choral contempt for those who have been born poor, or fallen fatally ill. The contemporary rhetoric of compassion dissolves in the acid of this cruel glee. If the final truth about the world is that it is a struggle for survival, a struggle that football endlessly re-enacts, maximum derision is reserved for the loser.

"This'll get them going," the chorus leader laughs. He raises his red face; the blue wrap-around sunglasses gleam. His hands are cupped round strong, well-moulded lips. The voice is huge, the tune the ever-serviceable Guantanamera . Now! "TER-RE-MO-TA-TI!" he sings and shouts together, "O siete terremotati. Terremota-a-a-a-ti, o siete terremotati."

Everybody joins in. There are only a few hundred of us, but the stadium is quiet. Or rather was. We have barely started a second round before the place explodes with rage. "Veronese figlio di troia! Son of a bitch. Serie B. Serie B."

The chorus leader rubs his hands and congratulates everyone. "That's got 'em going." And I realise he has actually done the Udinese fans a favour. He has united them. They are feeling properly angry. The game will mean more for everybody.

And so it did. It meant disaster for Verona, who played unusually well and lost against the run of play to go deep into relegation territory. A generous crowd of Udinese fans waited a good 40 minutes to scream their contempt as we were finally escorted to our buses. "Sfigati!" - unlucky ones!

"The civilising passage from blows to insults," wrote the Romanian philosopher Emil Cioran, "was no doubt necessary, but the price was high. Words will never be enough. We will always be nostalgic for violence and blood."

Strange, it occurs to me, as the bus accelerates through the jeering crowd and somebody hurls a can - strange that a Romanian wouldn't have thought of football as a possible solution.

 Tim Parks is writing a book about following Hellas Verona. A Season with Verona will be published by Secker & Warburg in March 2002. His website is at www.timparks.com
fields.bodyText: After Verona's game with Atalanta (Bergamo), the police kept us on the terraces for almost two hours in sub-zero temperatures. There is an ancient enmity between these two cities and we had to be protected from their fans. Or perhaps keeping us numb and shivering in the cold was the authorities' way of expressing that enmity. Stamping our feet, we huddled together and sang songs insulting the departing Bergamaschi. "Sempre di meno," we called mockingly, "O siete sempre di meno" - there are fewer and fewer of you. It's the song you sing when you're winning and the opposing fans start to leave early, whereas in fact we had lost 3-0. Then no doubt because it was All Souls' Day, someone made a crucifix of plastic flag poles, the chorus leader spread his arms, let his head fall to one side and everybody sang the church hymn Risorgeremo - We shall rise again. At last all the Bergamaschi were gone, only the carabinieri were left. Since one of their helicopters had crashed only a couple of days before, the fans launched into an old fascist song that celebrated the modern and mechanised army, but with slightly altered words: " E gira gira l'elica, romba il motor, L'elicottero dell'arma è tornato al creator." (Turn propeller turn, out roars the motor,/ The policemen's 'copter's gone back to its maker.) How can one laugh at such bad taste? Ten men had died. Everyone laughed. I even saw a carabiniere smile. "Verona merda!" the Bergamaschi shrieked as we were escorted back to our bus. An ancient man leaned one arm on his walking stick to give us the finger raised high with the other. His face lit up in a wild grin. In the San Nicolò stadium in Bari, high on cocaine and sodden with beer, a young Veronese went on and on shouting: "Albanesi! Kurdi! Scafisti!" The scafisti are the unscrupulous men who bring in illegal immigrants on their rubber scafi, or motorboats. "Albanians! Kurds! Scafisti! Your mothers are whores! You live off our taxes." Suddenly the wind blew his hat off. It was a precious 1985 hat, the year of the miracle, when tiny Hellas Verona won the Italian championship, against the opposition of Michel Platini's Juventus and Alessandro Altobelli's Inter. There was a gale blowing. The hat sailed over the fence segregating the visitors area. "Give me my hat back," the man shouted. "Please! It's a 1985 hat. It's an original!" In Bologna we lost 1-0. After taunting the home team's black players with monkey grunts, the Brigate gialloblù - the Yellow-Blue Brigades, as the hardcore fans call themselves - bought Coca-Colas from a vendor at half time, slapping the boy on the back and chatting away cheerfully. He was black. "Communisti!" they shouted at the Bolognese. "Rossi di merda" - shit reds. Verona played terribly, as if the players didn't want to be there. In Perugia, the local fans had strung up a banner: "A NON-RACIST TOWN IS ALWAYS IN SERIE A." The Veronese felt such provocation too banal to deserve comment. "Merda siete," they began, "e merda resterete" - shit you are and shit you'll stay. It was routine stuff, ordinaria amministrazione, as they say. Likewise the game, which we lost 1-0. In Lecce it was the Verona fans who hung up a banner - " CIAO NICOLÒ, EVEN ABSENT YOU WILL ALWAYS BE AMONG US." One of their own had died of cancer. Such commemorations are part of stadium ritual. "Oltre la morte" - beyond death - it says over the central gate to Verona's famous curva sud . "Ciao Nicolò!" they shouted. There was a slow hand-clap. Then they got down to it: "Acqua e sapone, ci vuole acqua e sapone" - soap and water, it takes soap and water (to wash a southerner). In the north-eastern town of Udine, half an hour before the game, one of the chorus leaders, a handsome man with salmon-pink shaven scalp and wrap-around blue sunglasses, said: "Kids, the first chant is the most important. It sets the tone. So what can we sing that will make them really mad?" It was a tough question. When you're down south, it's easy: you tell the opposition they're filthy, they stink. When you're in Turin they're gobbi - hunchbacks - because they're bent over Fiat's production line all day. The Bolognese are reds. That's obvious. The Vicentini are magnagatti - cat eaters, a half-starved underclass. But what can you say to the affluent, clean-living folks of Udine, just a stone's throw from the Slovenian border? "Come on," the chorus leader challenges. "What can we sing?" His voice is that of the amused teacher, waiting to see if any of his pupils is especially clever. "Slavi di merda?" someone suggests. Slavs? The chorus leader shakes his head. "It has to be something that will drive them completely crazy." Nobody knows. We've no idea. "Terremotati!" he declares. Of course: a terremoto is an earthquake. Terremotati are the victims of an earthquake. In 1976 the region of Friuli-Venezia Giulia, of which Udine is the capital, was devastated by an earthquake that caused thousands of deaths. We are going to insult these people by reminding them that they were once profoundly unlucky. No doubt there will be some here who lost loved ones in that quake. There is something fantastically atavistic about this. For a moment it's as though we're back in one of the Sicilian novels of Giovanni Verga, full of the peasant community's choral contempt for those who have been born poor, or fallen fatally ill. The contemporary rhetoric of compassion dissolves in the acid of this cruel glee. If the final truth about the world is that it is a struggle for survival, a struggle that football endlessly re-enacts, maximum derision is reserved for the loser. "This'll get them going," the chorus leader laughs. He raises his red face; the blue wrap-around sunglasses gleam. His hands are cupped round strong, well-moulded lips. The voice is huge, the tune the ever-serviceable Guantanamera . Now! "TER-RE-MO-TA-TI!" he sings and shouts together, "O siete terremotati. Terremota-a-a-a-ti, o siete terremotati." fields.headline: No 1847 Grimsby
fields.trailText: Grim up north, eh? Grow up, and try to shake off your pathetic prejudices.
fields.body:
Grim up north, eh? Grow up, and try to shake off your pathetic prejudices.

Chippy. Yeah, all right, and fishy. Very good.

Alright, keep your sou'wester on. So why is it called Grimsby, anyway? North Sea legend has it that it was named after some Danish bloke called Grim, who settled there a long long time ago.

Didn't he have a brother? Probably, though I imagine you're thinking of the Brothers Grimm. Who were German. Close, though.

Anyway. Back to Grimsby. Is it, or is it not, grim? Well, it's just been named the most profitable town in Britain in a survey by business information group Dun & Bradstreet.

Should the rest of us abandon ship and up sticks for sunny Grimsby then? It's not actually that sunny. Yesterday the outlook was cloudy.

Why is it so profitable? Since the fishing industry hit the rocks, Grimsby has reinvented itself as a centre for frozen food.

Good news. Well, it's not all good actually. More than 8% of the population is still unemployed, it has the lowest wages in the north, and average earnings actually fell by £10 a week last year. You can pick up a three-bedroom house in Grimsby for £10,500.

So where's all this profit going? Straight out of town and into the pockets of the frozen food manufacturers, it would seem.

Has it always been that bad? Not at all. Grimsby used to be the greatest fishing port in the world.

Until? Well, it all started going wrong with the Cod wars in the early 70s.

Cod were fighting? No, people were fighting. Over cod.

Nasty. Yes. Iceland imposed a 200-mile fishing limit around itself and its fish, and all of a sudden Grimsby wasn't so great any more. Recently, fish quotas have practically sunk the fishing industry.

Do say: "Nice place."

Don't say: "Nice plaice."

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Benison and hedges
fields.trailText: Benison and hedges
fields.body:
Cheshire

With the valley now firmly closed to public access, I have had to reorganise my regular routine to record the arrival of spring from the tarmacked lanes around the village, taking great care not to encroach too closely upon those farms with vulnerable livestock. Many of the older thorn hedgerows that now form boundaries between field and lane provide a special habitat, one I have always thought to represent a woodland in miniature. These are the relics of the old stock fences, erected at the edge of the old forest to prevent cattle, pigs and sheep from straying into the Lord of the Manor's preserve, for which there were severe penalties. As the woods were cut down to open up more land for farming, these hedgerows provided shelter and living space for plants that had been part of the original woodland floor. Out of the reach of both plough and grazing animals, they have survived and spread, and so we have a reminder of just how extensive the ancient forest was.

Seen in the right light, the hawthorns have a bright purple tinge about them, which, on closer inspection, turns out to be the reflection from the tightly closed leaf buds; yet in some of the more sheltered stretches, crisp green leaves have already appeared. Few of the flowers in this miniature habitat have dared to burst into colour just yet, with the bitterly cold north winds still blowing, but the buds are there - bluebell, wood anemone and primrose. Among the larger plants along the lanes, the hazel is festooned with lambs' tails - the catkins, and its small crimson flowers are well out, but the highlight has to be the brilliant white petals of the wild cherry.

Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. All you have to do is come up with each day's answers, then send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders (www.bordersstores.com).

(a) Handbag warfare.

(b) Aggressive camping.

(c) Barbie-doll battling.

(d) Catfights at dawn.

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Murder, Magic And Medicine | The Unsung Voice | Harry James - High Notes And Home Runs
fields.body:
Dr Michael O'Donnell highlights the continued use of old-style medicine in Murder, Magic And Medicine (11.0am, Radio 4). Pat Wagner is convinced that bee venom transformed her from a breathing corpse with multiple sclerosis into her present lively self. Many others think so too, and turn up regularly at her house in Maryland for treatment. Elsewhere, a Brazilian viper's poison has been adapted to offset heart attacks, and leeches are still thought invaluable by plastic surgeons.

The extraordinary story of Marnie Nixon is told in The Unsung Voice (1.30pm, Radio 4). She began by studying opera but was diverted into films when her voice was dubbed for the child actress Margaret O'Brien. Its quality was so remarkable she was then asked to do the same for Deborah Kerr in The King And I and for Natalie Wood in West Side Story. However, concern for their stars' reputation made the studios bar Nixon from revealing her role, or receiving royalties for the ensuing hit records.

By contrast a circus performer's son easily managed to hold Hollywood in his hands. Campbell Burnap tells his story in Harry James - High Notes And Home Runs (10.0pm, Radio 2), the first portion of an eight-part biography. James's technical skill on the trumpet was unrivalled at the time. It brought him an income in the millions and Betty Grable, Tinseltown's highest earner, as his wife. Sadly he needed booze as well.

fields.headline: TV pick of the day
fields.trailText: American Graffiti | A Midsummer Night's Dream | American Pie | The Two Jakes | Sonatine
fields.body:
Films

American Graffiti (George Lucas, 1973) 7pm, The Studio Lucas's rock'n'rolling anthem to his Modesto, California youth follows a group of teenagers cruising through one hot night in 1962. It's a beautifully played, funny and affectionate picture, cutting from one worried youngster to the next: Ron Howard's Steve is off to college the next morning; his girlfriend Laurie (Cindy Williams) doesn't want him to go; her brother Curt (Richard Dreyfuss) is chasing the girl in the white T-Bird; and Paul LeMat's ultra-cool John is revving up the fastest car in the valley. All gleaming chrome, neon lights, and pulsating period soundtrack.

A Midsummer Night's Dream (Michael Hoffman, 1999) 8pm, Sky Premier A starry cast twinkles brightly if not always coherently in this extravagant and colourful staging of Shakespeare's much filmed comedy. Set in lush, seductive Tuscany, it has Rupert Everett and Michelle Pfeiffer as Oberon and Titania, king and queen of the fairies, working their sensual magic on human lovers, while Stanley Tucci's Puck has his own impish fun. But at the film's centre, around which all else revolves, is Kevin Kline, who makes a marvellous Bottom.

American Pie (Paul Weitz, 1999) 10pm, Sky Premier This sub-Farrelly brothers high-school comedy has four teenagers vowing to lose their virginity before prom night, but basically it's a celebration of the richly comic potential of masturbation. These boys are whacking off all the time, everywhere, the film's title referring to a particularly creative variation on the theme. As you may gather, the question of taste does not arise in this American Pie: there simply isn't any, and it's hugely funny, with engaging performances from a young cast including Jason Biggs, Chris Klein, Natasha Lyonne and Mena Suvari.

The Two Jakes (Jack Nicholson, 1990) 10pm, Sky Cinema Jack Nicholson returns as private eye Jake Gittes, and also directs this belated sequel to Chinatown. It's 1947, 11 years on, but he's still haunted by the events of the earlier film. And once again Los Angeles is a cruel place of earth tremors, blood, and relentlessly shifting realities in Robert Towne's labyrinthine script.

Sonatine (Takeshi Kitano, 1993) 11.55pm, FilmFour Kitano also stars in this well structured thriller, as a hit-man trying unsuccessfully to hang up his guns and knives. Sent to Okinawa to settle a gangland dispute, most of his men are wiped out in an ambush; after a peace-and-harmony interlude at an abandoned beach house, the survivors storm back like an oriental Wild Bunch. Paul Howlett

Sports

Under-21 Football 6pm, British Eurosport Picture the scene: About a month ago, the British Eurosport team of ridiculous ideas get together to discuss their international football coverage. With all the top games pilfered by their chequebook-waving rivals, choice is limited. Severely limited. So in their infinite wisdom they snap up the rights to screen the Under-21 game between two of England's group rivals, Germany and Greece. Well, it beats tractor-pulling I suppose. Simon Burnton

fields.headline: The new seekers
fields.trailText: NCS: Manhunt | Time Of Our Lives
fields.body:
NCS is not a title which trips off the tongue. They are the Nasty Crime Squad or something of the sort, and they don't half fancy themselves. Commander Bob Beausoleil (Keith Barron) is intervewing an applicant. "I am proud and I say that with all humility. This is the NCS, young lady. We require the best, the very best, because it's our job to look into the very worst. The pit. First principle: we look after our own, you look after us, we look after you, we're all in it together. Or nothing. Understand?"

Frankly, no, Bob. Run that last bit past me again.

NCS: Manhunt (BBC1) by Malcolm McKay is a highly polished, accelerating thriller. The squad of 10 specialist detectives is led by DI Borne (David Suchet) who is, of course, the best. Their first case is to catch Ricky Valesi (Kenneth Cranham), who is the worst but, unfortunately, rather good at it. A sadist, sexual fantasist and all-purpose loony, Valesi has kidnapped the elderly mother of Inspector Anne Warwick (Phyllis Logan), the officer who arrested him for murder.

(Inspector Borne describes Mrs Warwick as very old, frail and vulnerable. He has not, in my opinion, met many 72-year-old women. How do you think they got to be 72?)

This is a thriller with technological knobs on. "We have the technology! We can do it!", as they used to say in dear old Six Million Dollar Man. Isn't it wonderful what six million dollars used to buy? In NCS: Manhunt the time, date and place are typed fashionably in the lower left-hand corner of the screen. Faces and places are blown up in the background. The young lady referred to earlier graduated in electronic communications and financial tracking so she can shout out "Milton Keynes!" or "Southbound!" as she pinpoints Valesi's position from his mobile.

These tally-ho ("Closing, closing!") chases are very compelling. At first they flag down the wrong motorist. A series tempted by a touch of humour would have shown us the face of this unfortunate man, suddenly surrounded by a swarm of police for, he would assume, using a mobile while driving. But NCS takes itself very solemnly. Finally they follow the victim's daughter as she races up the M1 to deliver the ransom money, pursued by the best of the best. It is all very intense, urgent and adrenaline-fuelled.

By slow suspicious drips we have come to suspect that this woman is not just the distraught daughter she seems. With a police helicopter hovering like a mad bat, she vanishes. "He's got her. He was better than us", said Borne. A bitter pill for the best. There is a second helping tonight.

It is a dark, shadowy, clinical and uncomfortable story. Borne is very inward and self-contained. The down side of this is that there is no one with whom you can connect as a human being. Except, perhaps, the desperate daughter, who may be Valesi's accomplice.

Time Of Our Lives (ITV), which follows the fortunes of three families since the war, is one of those series that ITV does because they look good on the cv. It is, nevertheless, true that if you point a camera patiently enough at anyone the most extraordinary things will emerge.

The most immediately interesting family are the lordly and landed Rowallans, whose adventures and misadventures are well documented. It was, of course, a bit of bad luck for the Rowallan boys that their father was the Chief Scout.

"Trusty loyal and helpful;

Brotherly, courteous and kind;

Obedient, smiling and thrifty;

And pure as the rustling wind."

The heir married April Ashley, a showy model who was a merchant seaman before her sex change. There was nothing in Scouting For Boys to cover this eventuality. Now, you notice, the notorious April Ashley wears bifocals. Heigh-ho. Wandering around the sad shell of Rowallan Castle, the present Lord Rowallan offered a most unexpected explanation for the practice of dressing for dinner. fields.headline: Harold Williamson
fields.standfirst: Gifted television journalist with a mission to let children speak
fields.trailText: Gifted television journalist with a mission to let children speak.
fields.body:
The journalist Harold Williamson, who has died aged 78, was known on radio and television - in Braden's Week and That's Life - as the man who talked to children. Yet he would be better described as the man who listened to children. He believed that bringing up a child was the most skilled job anyone could have, and to see him take a child's hand in the school playground was like a benediction, only noisier and merrier.

He was also a noted current affairs reporter, in particular on Man Alive, the BBC documentary series on which he worked for two decades. Brought up in County Durham, Williamson left school at the age of 16. The careers officer gave him the choice to be a miner or a policeman, but he wanted to be a journalist - despite being told that "boys from County Durham don't become journalists". After war service in the Merchant Navy, he joined the Durham Advertiser for three years, before moving to the Newcastle Evening Chronicle, where he became education correspondent.

In 1954, he moved to radio and joined me in Voice Of The People, a new venture at BBC Newcastle. The engineers had just been supplied with a portable tape recorder - portable, that is, in the sense that it was not screwed to the floor. A heavy, clumsy, unreliable machine, it nevertheless had tremendous potential, and was welcomed most of all by Harold because it meant he could conduct his interviews without being stuck in a studio.

As a slogan, Harold suggested "man's inhumanity to man" - and that's what we chose. So off he would go, on the strength of a tip we had received, into the slums of Newcastle to talk to, for example, an elderly woman whose 40-year-old daughter had just died of tuberculosis. When Harold moved from radio to television - to the Look North news magazine in Newcastle, and then, in 1968, to London - his scope widened and resources increased.

At Man Alive, he reported on a wide range of social issues, becoming known for his sensitive interviewing and championing of the underdog. Among his documentaries was Gale Is Dead (1970), about a heroin addict whom Harold had known and tried to help. The film won the Golden Globe award at the Monte Carlo festival.

Other noted documentaries included Christians At War, about an Ulster Protestant family; Test For Life, on school examinations; and For The Love Of Triumph, a report on the Meriden motor-cycle factory where the workers formed a cooperative. There was also Guy Fawkes Night, a graphic account of the mutilation and misery heaped on the victims of fireworks. As a result of that film, regulations about the sale of fireworks were tightened up.

Williamson retired from the BBC in 1986 and started travelling - to Russia, China, north Africa, Turkey - with his wife Audrey, and always with that sense of inquiry that was the hallmark of his journalistic work. He was kind and gentle, a man who occupied the middle ground between religion and humanism, and a lifelong Labour supporter.

But he did have one little weakness. He was very squeamish. In the days of his courtship, he would take Audrey to the cinema to see such pictures as her favourite film, Young Doctor Kildare, one of a long series. The climax of each story was an operation, with the surgeon calling for his instruments. As soon as the word "scalpel" was uttered, Harold would flake out. The first time this happened, Audrey rose and hurried him to the doctors. The second time, she took him down to the foyer. And the third time, she beckoned an usherette to carry him out.

Audrey survives him, with their son and daughter.
