fields.headline: Lord Cocks of Hartcliffe
fields.standfirst: As Labour's chief whip, he was a scourge and a victim of the left
fields.trailText: As Labour's chief whip, he was a scourge and a victim of the left.
fields.body:
The Labour peer Lord Cocks of Hartcliffe, who, as plain Michael Cocks, was James Callaghan's chief whip from 1976 to 1985, has died aged 71. Deselected from his Bristol South seat in 1985 by the leftwinger Dawn Primarolo, who is now paymaster-general, he became an obsessive critic of the left. Then, in the decade after going to the Lords in 1987, he played the curious role of a bruising critic of the establishment, while attracting lucrative appointments from the Conservative government.

He became vice-chairman of the BBC (1993-98) after a stint as deputy chairman of the London Docklands Development Corporation, where, on the nomination of environment secretary Nicholas Ridley, he succeeded Lord (Bob) Mellish, his predecessor as Labour chief whip.

Cocks's willingness to take public jobs clashed with his reluctance to spend public money. At the BBC, he refused to inherit the chauffeur-driven car supplied to his predecessor, Joel Barnett, explaining that "the 88 bus runs from my home to Oxford Circus. It's just a short walk from Broadcasting House."

When he retired as BBC vice-chairman in June 1998, he revealed that feuding on the board had been so bad that he had not been told of the impending departure of the BBC director-general Lord (then Sir John) Birt.

He also resisted what he called "remorseless pressure" to redecorate his room, explaining he had prodded Lord Irvine about his expensive wallpaper in the Lord Chancellor's official residence - and was unwilling to be categorised in the same way.

Michael Cocks always volunteered, even to those who knew, that he spelled his name like "the organ, not the apple". This was his way of saying that, despite being the son of a congregationalist minister, he was one of the boys. This was helped by his bald head and soup-strainer moustache, which gave him the look of a well-fed Mexican bandit.

As chief whip, he was known for his sometimes artificial rages and barrack-room invective against deviating Labour MPs. One heard this only rarely in the Commons, as during a 1983 speech by Michael Heseltine, then secretary of state for defence, when Cocks kept shouting: "What about your war record?"

After he was ousted from Bristol South, his volcanic bile was largely directed at the left, and occasionally against establishment elitists like Lord (Roy) Jenkins of Hillhead. His anti-left views were distilled in his 1989 book, Labour And The Benn Factor, which blamed his party's decline in the 1980s almost wholly on Tony Benn, his former Bristol neighbour, and on London's "loony left". In the Lords, he became identified with Mellish, another rightwing social radical, who had also fallen out with his party after a leftwing takeover of his constituency, in Mellish's case in Bermondsey, south London.

Cocks was born in Leeds, the son of Dr HF Lovell Cocks, a former principal of Western College, and the man who coined the phrase "the Labour party owes more to Methodism than to Marx". Young Michael was educated at George Watson's Academy, Edinburgh, and Silcoates School, Wakefield. After Bristol University, where he earned a BSc with honours, he taught geography at Filton high school (1954-58) and lectured at Bristol Polytechnic (1966-70).

He joined the Labour party in 1955, becoming a CND supporter shortly afterwards. He contested hopeless Bristol West in 1959, and less hopeless South Gloucestershire in 1964 and 1966. Three years later, he was selected to follow Will Wilkins in safe Bristol South, where he defeated the Conservative candidate, David Hunt, the following year.

Cocks made a mixed beginning in the House of Commons. In 1970, he complained of the inadequate arrangements for MPs' declarations of outside interests, and tried to end ground rents on freehold land. Then, a year later, he attacked Sir Gerald Nabarro's bill on the perils of smoking, preferring to insist on nicotine warnings to avoid job losses in Wills' Bristol factory. He also emerged a strong opponent of entry to the European Economic Community.

He became an assistant whip in 1973, and pairing whip the following year, when Labour returned to government. When Callaghan succeeded Harold Wilson as prime minister in 1976, he named Cocks as his chief whip and made him a privy counsellor. With occasional lapses, he proved competent, for example, in warning against using the guillotine on devolution.

This preceded the announcement of Cocks's separation from his first wife Janet, a nurse and social worker whom he had married in 1954, and with whom he had two sons and two daughters. In 1979, he married Valerie Davis, an aggressive Israeli zionist, whose lead on the Middle East he often followed.

By then Cocks was in trouble with his constituency. The compulsory reselection process pushed by the left put rightwing MPs under pressure, and in Bristol the move to deselect him came from a coterie of semi-hard leftwingers, some encouraged by Tony Benn. In 1985, he faced a challenge from Benn's former constituency secretary, Dawn Primarolo, who defeated him by 71 votes to 56.

His elevation to the Lords was overshadowed by his claims in the Sunday Times that his ouster from Bristol South was "part of a campaign to push the party decisively to the left". It was twisting the knife in that ever-bleeding wound to find, a decade later, that the instrument of his ouster had become financial secretary on Gordon Brown's Treasury team and then paymaster-general.

Cocks is survived by Valerie and the children from his first marriage.

fields.headline: Bert Wickstead
fields.standfirst: Flamboyant police chief who fought crime and corruption
fields.trailText: Flamboyant police chief who fought crime and corruption.
fields.body:
He was the Old Grey Fox and Gangbuster Wickstead, one of the last of the high-profile Scotland Yard detectives, part of an era when men in belted raincoats would stand on the steps of the Old Bailey after a trial and pronounce on this gangster or that underworld feud. Commander Bert Wickstead, who has died aged 77, carried out hundreds of arrests, retired to become head of security at the News of the World and the Sun, and wrote his memoirs.

Wickstead's admirers - and there were many both within and without the police - will recall the flamboyant head of many operations against some of postwar Britain's best-known criminal families. Nonetheless, his involvement in a number of controversial cases raised questions about his methods of achieving convictions.

Born in Plaistow, the son of a railway foreman, Wickstead was educated at Burke senior school, and then took factory work. His chosen career would have been as a West Ham footballer, but two broken legs ended that possibility. During the war, he served with the SAS, stationed in India, Burma and Ceylon (Sri Lanka), and, after demobilisation, joined the police, encouraged by an uncle in the force.

As a young detective inspector in Stoke Newington, north London, he solved 19 murders in two years. In 1965, he investigated a series of arson attacks on synagogues by the neo-fascists of the National Socialist Movement, and was delighted when the perpetrators were jailed. He was promoted to the rank of commander to run what was then J division, in London's East End. In 1970, he handled the investigation into what was then Britain's biggest bank robbery, the theft of £237,736 from Barclays in Ilford.

A year later, Wickstead was given a free hand to form his own team, the serious crimes squad, to tackle major professional crime in the capital. The group was the first of the specialist units set up within the Metropolitan police in the 1970s.

Unlike many of his plainclothes contemporaries at Scotland Yard, Wickstead was not a man to take a bribe. And, when the opportunity arose, he pursued the Met's bent officers with relish. He played a leading part in the investigation of Soho pornographers Bernie Silver and Jimmy Humphreys, whose revelations led to the jailing of 13 corrupt members of the obscene publications squad. He also investigated the case of the prostitute Norma Levy, which was to lead to the downfall of the Conservative minister Lord Lambton.

In 1976, he reinvestigated the 20-year-old murder of gangster Tommy Smithson, who had been shot dead in 1956. But, although two Maltese criminals were charged with the crime, both were cleared after a key witness disappeared.

During his three years with the serious crimes squad, Wickstead was often in the newspapers for his gangbusting exploits. His critics query whether the gangs, who were supposedly trying to fill the vacuum left by the Kray twins, were quite as mighty as he claimed. Some were really just extended families with violent tempers. But among those jailed as career criminals were the Tibbs, the Dixons and Philip "Little Caesar" Jacobs.

A fearless soul, Wickstead once received threats that acid would be thrown at his wife, and he himself was bashed over the head when he went to investigate a burglary at a neighbour's house in Loughton, Essex, in 1975.

It was in the early 1970s that he acquired his nickname as the Old Grey Fox, because, he claimed, he was always popping up and disappearing. Unimpressed by the trappings of wealth which dazzled some of his colleagues, he lived for many years in a council flat in Plaistow, east London, with his wife and three sons. His squad - whom he liked to call the Incorruptibles - was devoted to him, as he was to them, sending flowers to sick wives and showing concern for their personal welfare.

"I look for three main qualities in my officers," he said once, "honesty, integrity and professional capability." He also had a gargantuan appetite for work, and would keep his detectives at it round the clock.

Wickstead's most controversial case was the torso murders investigation of 1976-77, at the end of which Reg Dudley and Bob Maynard were both jailed for life for the murders of Billy Moseley and Micky Cornwall. The two men claimed in court that Wickstead had fabricated their confessions. As Dudley was taken from the dock, he shouted at Wickstead: "You got the Tibbs, the Dixons, Silver and now us. You fitted us all up. But don't worry, you'll be fitted up, in the end, by your own kind."

A campaign followed to free the men, and, after a three-year examination of the evidence, the criminal cases review commission last year recommended that the matter should go to the court of appeal, where it is now pending. Dudley was paroled in 1997, and Maynard was released on bail last November. Wickstead had predicted at the time of the conviction that "do-gooders" would claim it as a miscarriage of justice.

Another criminal who claimed he had been verballed by Wickstead had his conviction overturned. Jimmy Saunders, jailed for his part in the 1970 Ilford robbery, was cleared after the bank-robber-turned-police-informer Bertie Smalls said that Saunders had not been on the job - and was therefore hardly likely to have confessed to it.

One of Britain's best-known and most active thieves recalled Wickstead thus: "He didn't take money and, if you're a policeman, you have to deal with scumbags every day. You have to go down to their level to achieve any results, so I understand why he did what he did."

In 1977, Wickstead retired from police work to become security adviser to what was then News Group Newspapers, which serialised his memoirs in the Sun. He later became seriously ill with emphysema. But he remained, to the end, one of the Yard's legendary figures, far removed from performance indicators and best practice, admired by former colleagues, hated by villains - which is the way he would have wanted it.

His first marriage was dissolved. He is survived by his second wife Jean, their two sons and a son from his first marriage.

You fitted us all up. But don't worry, you'll be fitted up, in the end, by your own kind." A campaign followed to free the men, and, after a three-year examination of the evidence, the criminal cases review commission last year recommended that the matter should go to the court of appeal, where it is now pending. Dudley was paroled in 1997, and Maynard was released on bail last November. Wickstead had predicted at the time of the conviction that "do-gooders" would claim it as a miscarriage of justice. Another criminal who claimed he had been verballed by Wickstead had his conviction overturned. Jimmy Saunders, jailed for his part in the 1970 Ilford robbery, was cleared after the bank-robber-turned-police-informer Bertie Smalls said that Saunders had not been on the job - and was therefore hardly likely to have confessed to it. One of Britain's best-known and most active thieves recalled Wickstead thus: "He didn't take money and, if you're a policeman, you have to deal with scumbags every day. You have to go down to their level to achieve any results, so I understand why he did what he did." In 1977, Wickstead retired from police work to become security adviser to what was then News Group Newspapers, which serialised his memoirs in the Sun. He later became seriously ill with emphysema. But he remained, to the end, one of the Yard's legendary figures, far removed from performance indicators and best practice, admired by former colleagues, hated by villains - which is the way he would have wanted it. His first marriage was dissolved. He is survived by his second wife Jean, their two sons and a son from his first marriage.  Albert 'Bert' Wickstead, policeman, born April 23 1923; died March 19 2001

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Maybe it's the weather, or the surfeit of grey sky, but Sidelines has got the blues. Nothing's perfect, everything ends and some days it's not even worth beginning
fields.body:
Maybe it's the weather, or the surfeit of grey sky, but Sidelines has got the blues. Nothing's perfect, everything ends and some days it's not even worth beginning. There will be no jokes in this column today, and probably not for a long time to come. What's so funny, anyhow? Sigh. Not even a small mammal story could cheer me up. And if the farming crisis, the future of London Underground and continuing cruelty to children were not enough to leave the heart heavy, Friday is National Cleavage Day, which will doubtless be marked by liberal use of the word "boob" (hateful moniker) and relentless squishing of said parts into paddy, wirey, cleav-y contraptions which are bad for your back and worse for your sense of humour. According to Gossard, most women will be celebrating the day by "wearing a Gossard Ultrabra and a low-cut top to both work and play". Not bloody likely. Sidelines will be wearing three layers of sacking in protest. And weeping beneath them.

In desperation, I turned to (new! handbag size!) Glamour magazine's website,glamour.com, to consult their fortune-telling page, since the magazine has lately been so accurate in predicting my eyeliner choice (aubergine and, yes, I did become suicidal when the cat used it as a cake skewer). So, Oracle, is it true that, as Doris Lessing was quoted as saying over the weekend, feminism took a wrong turn in the 60s and is now just about man-bashing? The Oracle ponders a moment, before responding mysteriously: "You're a lucky lady." Perhaps this is the answer to another question, a question I haven't even thought to ask yet . . . or perhaps the Oracle hasn't applied itself to post-feminism quite yet. Maybe it will be more confident in the arena of international politics? Isn't it dreadful about Macedonia, I offer. It's more small talk than serious interrogation, but I sense the need to put my interlocutor at ease. "Baby, think twice," comes the response. Kofi Annan couldn't have put it better himself.

It could be that the Oracle has more of an emotional than a cerebral intelligence. Bad, masculinist me for presuming that it should converse only on international affairs - why not affairs of the heart? Will I get my heart broken, I simper. "I have my doubts." Hmm. Not exactly the unswerving affirmation I was hoping for. I attempt a final salvo. Why is it, dear Oracle, that I always end up looking like a dental assistant when I wear white? Another pause and then - inspiration. "Look out for a handsome stranger - he may hold the answer." Spent the rest of the day out on the pavement waiting for him, but he didn't turn up, so I just got cold.

webTitle: Unmarried fathers offered full parental rights

fields.headline: Unmarried fathers offered full parental rights
fields.trailText: Unmarried fathers who register their children's birth jointly with the mothers will obtain full parental rights under a clause in the adoption and children bill, which had its second reading in parliament yesterday.
fields.body:
Unmarried fathers who register their children's birth jointly with the mothers will obtain full parental rights under a clause in the adoption and children bill, which had its second reading in parliament yesterday.

The reform will give unmarried fathers who sign the birth register the same rights as married fathers automatically have to a say in their children's upbringing.

Under the current law, if parents are not married, the mother is treated as the child's sole parent and fathers can obtain rights only through a parental responsibility order by the court or a written agreement with the mother which is registered with the court.

The government announced the planned reform in July 1998 to encourage fathers' commitment to the one in three children born outside wedlock.

Ministers believe the distinction between married and unmarried fathers is now out of date.

In 78% of births outside marriage, the father's details were included on the birth certificate. In three out of four of these joint registrations - and in 58% of all births outside marriage - the parents were living together.

But the numbers of parental responsibility orders and agreements are only a small fraction of the number of births. Most unmarried fathers are thought to be unaware of their lack of legal rights.

Jane Kennedy, minister in the Lord Chancellor's department, said: "I am pleased to to bring about this long-needed reform."

 New one-stop shops for people with family and relationship problems are to be piloted in five areas of England and Wales, the lord chancellor announced yesterday.

The family advice and information networks will be accessed through 10 solicitors' offices in the five areas. Clients will be given legal advice, help and information, encouraged to use marriage counselling, given access to mediation services and offered support in talking to their children. Children who need help will be able to get it through expert children's services.

webTitle: 5ive star forks out over drunken brawl in Irish bar

fields.headline: 5ive star forks out over drunken brawl in Irish bar
fields.trailText: Parents who have banned Eminem and Marilyn Manson but thought their kids were safe in the hands of clean-cut pop acts may want to think again. Chart-topping teen stars seem determined to grab back the headlines with their bad behaviour.
fields.body:
Parents who have banned Eminem and Marilyn Manson but thought their kids were safe in the hands of clean-cut pop acts may want to think again. Chart-topping teen stars seem determined to grab back the headlines with their bad behaviour.

A few days after some members of pop group S Club 7 were caught sharing a joint, Ritchie Neville from boy band 5ive yesterday pleaded guilty to being drunk and disorderly and causing a breach of the peace in a scuffle in a Dublin bar last December.

The 21-year-old singer paid IR£3,000 to charity for his part in the fracas at the Palace Bar, which left one man with head injuries

Arresting police officer Mark Cushen told Richmond court in Dublin that the singer, who appeared under his real name, Richard Dobson, had been drunk and had told him: "I can't go anywhere without getting hassle, just because I'm in a boy band. Why should I let them get away with it? I'm sick of it."

Fellow band member Jason Brown, better known to fans as Jay, was unable to face an assault charge because he was visiting his mother in America, where she has been undergoing surgery. The judge adjourned the case against him and awarded costs of £475 against him.

Apparently unfamiliar with hits such as Slam Dunk Da Funk and their number one cover of Queen's We Will Rock You, Judge Michael Connellan said: "Is that what it is?" when lawyers explained that 5ive was a pop group.

Peter Charleton, SC, defending, replied: "There is a certain hierarchy within it, whether it is rock or pop - I can't say I am too familiar with it." He said that Dobson had no previous convictions and added that his life was "one of extreme hard work".

Judge Connellan applied the country's Probation Act to both charges, meaning that Dobson has no conviction but that the matter could be raised should he commit a further offence.

webTitle: Actor tells of debilitation that ended his career

fields.headline: Actor tells of debilitation that ended his career
fields.trailText: Timothy Pearce, a 60-year-old actor, of Highgate, north London, became infected with the hepatitis C virus after a hip replacement in May 1991. Hepatitis C was not diagnosed until 1995. His work includes the film Jesus of Nazareth and TV television appearances in Minder and EastEnders.
fields.body:
Timothy Pearce, a 60-year-old actor, of Highgate, north London, became infected with the hepatitis C virus after a hip replacement in May 1991. Hepatitis C was not diagnosed until 1995. His work includes the film Jesus of Nazareth and TV television appearances in Minder and EastEnders.

"I am frightened about what the future holds because of the risk of developing serious liver disease and because I am not confident there will ever be a cure.

"I am willing to try the Interferon treatment now available, although I have been told it is likely to be very unpleasant and will last several months. I feel bitter that I may have been given a death sentence and that it could have been avoided by the introduction of a screening test that was in use in other countries.

"I have not got anything like the energy or vitality that I had. I'm very susceptible to colds and flu and have had massive problems with my teeth, which I never had before. Ever since the operation, I had never really felt like myself.

"I have always been active, playing physically demanding acting roles ... Since the operation I have become increasingly lethargic. I returned to work between 1992 and 1995 and am convinced that without my hepatitis C infection I would have been able to carry on acting."
Press Association

webTitle: NHS to pay multi-million compensation over virus

fields.headline: Infected blood victims' victory
fields.standfirst: NHS to pay multi-million compensation over virus
fields.trailText: More than 100 people infected with the hepatitis C virus through blood transfusions won compensation totalling millions of pounds in the high court yesterday.
fields.body:
More than 100 people infected with the hepatitis C virus through blood transfusions won compensation totalling millions of pounds in the high court yesterday.

The case against the national blood authority and the Velindre NHS trust, the blood authority for Wales, was the first group action to reach court under a little-used law, the Consumer Protection Act 1987. The act was brought in to implement a European directive on product liability, creating a system of "strict liability" that makes producers and suppliers of defective products liable even if they were not negligent.

Mr Justice Burton ruled that the 114 claimants, who have been granted anonymity, were entitled to compensation. Their lawyers, who were awarded costs thought to be between £2m and £3m, provisionally estimate compensation at £6m to £7m - a total bill for the NHS that could reach £10m.

Patients whose conditions worsen will be able to come back for more. Initial awards will be based on six representative cases, ranging from more than £10,000 to more than £210,000. The largest award was for a woman who developed cirrhosis and had to have a liver transplant.

The ruling sets a precedent for similar cases to be mounted in the future.

The judge will decide next month whether to give permission to appeal.

The act makes producers liable if the product is not as safe as the general public is entitled to expect. But a producer has a defence if it can show that the state of scientific and technical knowledge was such that it could not be expected to have discovered the defect.

The claimants had transfusions following March 1, 1988, when the act came into force. In May 1988, the hepatitis C virus was identified, but before that it was known there was an unidentified virus causing hepatitis, particularly after transfusions. Screening for the virus was not introduced in the UK until September 1991, later than in most other countries in the developed world.

Nicholas Underhill QC, for the blood authorities, told the court: "They do not accept that the moment that the first country introduces screening, unscreened blood products in every other country automatically become defective."

Mr Justice Burton said yesterday that the public expected, and was entitled to expect, clean blood. Blood contaminated with hepatitis C was defective, and anyone who caught the virus as a result was entitled to compensation because the NHS knew about the risk. It should have acted earlier to reduce the risk of transmission, and should have introduced routine screening of all blood transfusions by March 1, 1990.

The judge ruled that under the "no-fault" regime created by the act and the European directive, once a risk had been identified producers should cover themselves against the risk.

Anthony Mallen of Deas Mallen, the Newcastle upon Tyne solicitors which led the action, said: "This is a landmark decision for consumer rights and shows that the effect of the EU directive has been significantly to strengthen product liability law."

The claimants included women who received transfusions immediately after childbirth, and patients given blood during surgery or as treatment for a blood disorder. Several children became infected while being treated for leukaemia.

In May, the judge is to preside over a preliminary hearing involving another nine claimants, including haemophiliacs and a woman who became infected during a heart transplant.

fields.headline: Injunction case woman has abortion
fields.trailText: A woman whose former boyfriend took out a high court injunction in a bid to prevent her from having an abortion has had her pregnancy terminated, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A woman whose former boyfriend took out a high court injunction in a bid to prevent her from having an abortion has had her pregnancy terminated, it emerged yesterday.

Stephen Hone, a 24-year-old sales consultant from Coventry, had tried to stop 31-year-old Claire Hansell from ending the pregnancy as he was opposed to abortion.

Mr Hone, who has two children from a previous relationship, stated he would seek access to the unborn baby's remains so he could arrange a burial or take responsibility for the new baby if the birth went to term.

But solicitors for Ms Hansell today said she had already undergone the procedure.

Sara Leslie, of law firm Irwin Mitchell, said in a statement: "Ms Hansell has undergone a lawful abortion.

"I consider Mr Hone's application to deliver up the foetus to be macabre.

"The unfortunate circumstances faced by Ms Hansell are being cynically exploited by the anti-abortionist lobby to generate media interest for the forthcoming general election."

Mr Hone's lawyers last week argued that the abortion planned for one clinic was unlawful because only one doctor was consulted, instead of two.

But family division judge Mr Justice Sumner said the clinic had given a "highly responsible and helpful" undertaking that, if Ms Hansell continued to seek an abortion at the clinic, it would not rely on the certificate signed by the doctor originally seen by her.

Following the hearing, Mr Hone said the agreement was a partial victory.
Press Association

webTitle: Foot and mouth: Lakeland rare breed faces extinction

fields.headline: Lakeland rare breed faces extinction
fields.standfirst:
National Trust calls for swift slaughter of infected herd

Special report: foot and mouth
Foot and mouth: free daily email service with latest updates
fields.trailText: The director of the National Trust yesterday called for the swift slaughter of a flock of Herdwick sheep infected with foot and mouth on one of its farms in remote hill country in the Lake District.
fields.byline: David Ward, Angelique Chrisafis  and  Liz Nightingale
fields.body:
The director of the National Trust yesterday called for the swift slaughter of a flock of Herdwick sheep infected with foot and mouth on one of its farms in remote hill country in the Lake District.

Fiona Reynolds, who took up her new post in January, warned that without the hardy Herdwick flocks, the hills of the region would be damaged for ever, transformed from picturesque grasslands into shabby scrub.

She also called for all neighbouring flocks to be immediately vaccinated.

The outbreak, which has jumped all attempts at creating firebreaks in the north of the county, is on a farm high in the Duddon valley. Roads in the area were closed yesterday, including the popular routes over the dramatic Hardknott and Wrynose passes.

Herdwick sheep are "hefted" to the fells and graze on common land, without fences or shepherds because they instinctively know their boundaries in a local knowledge passed from ewe to lamb.

"We have been saying for the last week that we did not want foot and mouth to get to the high hills and it has," said Ms Reynolds.

"The risk is of the disease spreading to the whole of the hill flock. The priority is to get a grip on the outbreak as soon as possible.

"I have been on to Maff this morning because the delays we have been seeing between diagnosis and slaughter have been the cause of most of the trouble.

"We are convinced that if there are delays we will have a very serious problem indeed. So we are promoting not only the slaughter of that flock but also the vaccination of the surrounding sheep."

She added that she feared the entire Herdwick flock in the Lake District could be wiped out.

"That would be devastating for the farming community and also for the cultural integrity of the landscape.

"These are flocks which have been on those hills for literally thousands of years and it's very difficult to imagine the Lake District without them. You can't bring sheep from elsewhere on to those hills because they wouldn't survive."

Herdwick sheep have been grazing above the Duddon valley since the 12th century.

"We have 12,000 Herdwick sheep but that should increase to more than 2,000 after lambing," said Hazel Relph, who with her husband, Joe, farms at Rosthwaite in Borrowdale.

"We call them Lakeland farmers, because they keep the land clear of bracken," she said. "They are like wild animals - each one has its own area. They are not like other sheep - they are much smaller and stockier.

"Foot and mouth is the worst thing that could have happened. It's like a bomb. It's bad enough losing stock, but losing a breed is just awful. We are no longer worried about foot and mouth. It's got past that point. We are worried about our ewes dying," said Mrs Relph.

The sheep produce a thick, hardwearing and wiry wool, but most farmers breed them for their free-range meat. "The meat is unbelievable, it's 85% organic. The Queen ate it at her coronation breakfast in 1953," she added.

Herdwicks may have come to Britain from Norway or even from shipwrecked galleons of the Spanish Armada. They were threatened with extinction in the 1920s - Beatrix Potter helped save them when farmers were breeding other, more productive sheep. She bought a 19,000-acre sheep farm near the Kirkstone Pass in 1923 and after her death in 1942, she left her land to the National Trust, which now owns most fell farms in the Lake District.

Most trust properties in the Lake District - including Townend farmhouse and Hill Top, Beatrix Potter's former home - are unlikely to open at the end of this month.

Roads in the area were closed yesterday, including the popular routes over the dramatic Hardknott and Wrynose passes. Herdwick sheep are "hefted" to the fells and graze on common land, without fences or shepherds because they instinctively know their boundaries in a local knowledge passed from ewe to lamb. "We have been saying for the last week that we did not want foot and mouth to get to the high hills and it has," said Ms Reynolds. "The risk is of the disease spreading to the whole of the hill flock. The priority is to get a grip on the outbreak as soon as possible. "I have been on to Maff this morning because the delays we have been seeing between diagnosis and slaughter have been the cause of most of the trouble. "We are convinced that if there are delays we will have a very serious problem indeed. So we are promoting not only the slaughter of that flock but also the vaccination of the surrounding sheep." She added that she feared the entire Herdwick flock in the Lake District could be wiped out. "That would be devastating for the farming community and also for the cultural integrity of the landscape. "These are flocks which have been on those hills for literally thousands of years and it's very difficult to imagine the Lake District without them. You can't bring sheep from elsewhere on to those hills because they wouldn't survive." Herdwick sheep have been grazing above the Duddon valley since the 12th century. "We have 12,000 Herdwick sheep but that should increase to more than 2,000 after lambing," said Hazel Relph, who with her husband, Joe, farms at Rosthwaite in Borrowdale. "We call them Lakeland farmers, because they keep the land clear of bracken," she said. "They are like wild animals - each one has its own area. They are not like other sheep - they are much smaller and stockier. "Foot and mouth is the worst thing that could have happened. It's like a bomb. It's bad enough losing stock, but losing a breed is just awful. We are no longer worried about foot and mouth. It's got past that point. We are worried about our ewes dying," said Mrs Relph. The sheep produce a thick, hardwearing and wiry wool, but most farmers breed them for their free-range meat. "The meat is unbelievable, it's 85% organic. The Queen ate it at her coronation breakfast in 1953," she added. Herdwicks may have come to Britain from Norway or even from shipwrecked galleons of the Spanish Armada. They were threatened with extinction in the 1920s - Beatrix Potter helped save them when farmers were breeding other, more productive sheep. She bought a 19,000-acre sheep farm near the Kirkstone Pass in 1923 and after her death in 1942, she left her land to the National Trust, which now owns most fell farms in the Lake District. Most trust properties in the Lake District - including Townend farmhouse and Hill Top, Beatrix Potter's former home - are unlikely to open at the end of this month. What's going on? webTitle: US fighter jets missing on flight over mountains

fields.headline: US fighter jets missing on flight over mountains
fields.trailText: A massive search was underway last night after two US fighter jets disappeared during a training flight over the Cairngorm mountains in Scotland.
fields.body:
A massive search was underway last night after two US fighter jets disappeared during a training flight over the Cairngorm mountains in Scotland.

The F-15 aircraft were on a routine low-level training flight from the US airbase at Lakenheath in Suffolk when contact with both pilots was lost at the same time near Ben Macdui.

There were unconfirmed reports that an explosion had been heard by staff at the Glenmore Lodge outdoor centre, east of Aviemore, around the time the aircraft disappeared.

Two Nimrods from RAF Kinloss and three Sea King helicopters - two from RAF Lossiemouth and one from RAF Boulmer - were dispatched to the area where they were joined by three mountain rescue teams.The search area covers more than 100 square miles of unhospitable terrain and efforts to find the aircraft were said to be hampered by low cloud.

The RAF said the F-15s left RAF Lakenheath at around 12.30pm for a three-hour sortie in the Scottish Highlands. Both aircraft last made radio contact at 1.15pm and both disappeared from radar screens at the same time just afterwards. The aircraft, from 493 Fighter Squadron, have one person on board each and are fitted with emergency beacons and state-of-the-art navigation equipment.

RAF spokesman Michael Mulford said there had been no distress calls from either plane before they disappeared from the radar screens and no emergency signals had been picked up since. The planes only had enough fuel for three hours and would have to have landed by 3.30pm at the latest.

"It is something of a mystery," said Mr Mulford. "The planes are well-equipped safety-wise. That will only be answered if and when we find these aircraft and these aircrew."

A spokesman for Grampian police said several police forces had been notified by the US Airforce that the planes were "overdue". It is understood the aircraft should also have reported they were clear of the mountains by 1.30pm but no call was made. The jets were due back at Lakenheath by 3pm.

Fred Lawson, a tourist from Edinburgh, who was on a walking holiday in the area, told BBC Scotland he had been driving along a road near Braemar and had seen a fighter jet flying erratically shortly before the planes disappeared. "It just came straight at us and I said to my wife it looks completely out of control," he said. "It was extremely low then it veered up very sharply and turned north towards the mountains and flew into a snowstorm in the direction of Marr Lodge and then towards Ben Macdui.

"I have seen lots of low-flying jets and there looked something very much wrong. The second one came following it and it looked as if it was under control. There was a lot of snow. There were heavy snow, storms and blizzards."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Record sales of organic food | PC 'let friend attack man' | Met chief's view 'unfortunate'
fields.body:
Record sales of organic food

Sales of organic food grew by a record 55% last year, but 75% had to be imported, says the Soil Association. Only 3% of UK farmland is organic, and subsidies to convert were unavailable last year because funds ran out. Over 65% of households made at least one purchase, but 7% were responsible for 57% of purchases.

PC 'let friend attack man'

A police constable was accused yesterday at Birmingham crown court of ignoring an attack by a companion on the owner of an Indian restaurant in the city in 1999, when he was on sick leave. Joseph Naughton, 40, denies misconduct while holding a public office.

Met chief's view 'unfortunate'

An assertion by Met police commissioner Sir John Stevens that he had to resist a "compensation culture" was described as unfortunate by the founder of the Black Police Association. Det Insp David Michael was giving evidence in a discrimination claim by a black policewoman.

Injury risk from air cell trainers

The British Journal of Sports Medicine reports that wearing trainers with air cells in the heels made basketball players 4.3 times more prone to twist their ankles, and was the most likely predictor of injury after having had a previous injury.

That's torn it - or maybe not

The Department of Trade is researching how to improve packaging, especially the sort designed to be torn or peeled open, which often causes resort to knives - with 60,000 people a year going to hospital as a result.

fields.headline: Having faith in politics
fields.trailText: Roy Hattersley rather shows his ignorance about religious matters when he speaks of the danger of the prime minister "evangelising" at the Christian Socialist Movement conference on Thursday (Beware of religious links, PM is warned, March 26).
fields.body:
Roy Hattersley rather shows his ignorance about religious matters when he speaks of the danger of the prime minister "evangelising" at the Christian Socialist Movement conference on Thursday (Beware of religious links, PM is warned, March 26). If one is evangelising one does not invite representatives of other faith communities to share the platform, and there will be speakers from the Sikh, Jewish, Muslim and Hindu communities participating.

Neither CSM nor, we imagine, the prime minister are attempting to evangelise. What we seek to do is to improve the quality of understanding and debate about the views of the large numbers of people in faith communities, and the contribution they continue to make to our society. We hope Lord Hattersley can attend the conference, he may then be clearer as to what it is we are about.
Rev David Haslam
Christian Socialist Movement
davidhaslam@easynet.co.uk

 Why is Mr Blair proposing to hand over even a part of the state's welfare provision to religious charities? Experience in the US demonstrates the divisions such a policy creates. We must not return to the Victorian value that regards welfare provision as a matter of patronage, rather than as a right. Charities can withdraw and deny services - as religious charities almost certainly will - to those of whom they disapprove.

This dangerous and unnecessary experiment must be resisted by all who value our unconditional welfare state.
Terry Sanderson
National Secular Society

webTitle: Letters: A stitch up for democracy

fields.headline: A stitch up for democracy
fields.trailText: If Labour and Lib Dem candidates took your advice (Leader, March 26) and ran "non-campaigns" in seats where their counterpart seemed more likely to beat the Tory, democracy would be the first casualty.
fields.body:
If Labour and Lib Dem candidates took your advice (Leader, March 26) and ran "non-campaigns" in seats where their counterpart seemed more likely to beat the Tory, democracy would be the first casualty. How can it be right for politicians who ostensibly espouse a more open type of politics to stitch up deals behind closed doors that deny the voters choice?

With a busy job, a young family and a rather daunting Labour party policy manual to contend with, it would be all too easy for me to put my feet up over the next few weeks. I just happen to believe that voters in every constituency have the right to pass judgment on the record of the government and that the governing party has an obligation to justify its record in office.

Controversially, I shall therefore be speaking at meetings, knocking on doors and all those other irritating things that my opponents would rather I didn't do. I suspect the Greens and Arthur Scargill's lot will be doing the same. It's terribly inconvenient, but rather essential for a healthy democratic system.
Phil Woodford
Prospective Labour parliamentary candidate for Kingston and Surbiton
phil.woodford@virgin.net

 Your leader commending the proportional representation agreement between Tony Blair and Charles Kennedy does not consider by what authority Mr Blair has made such an agreement.

It is clear that he has not consulted the present cabinet, nor the national executive of the Labour party, nor the parliamentary Labour party, nor indeed any other representative Labour party body.

Has he consulted anyone other than, perhaps, those publicly-funded members of his staff who stood as SDP candidates in parliamentary elections? Is this a further demonstration of his assertion that the Labour party is "the party I run"? Isn't this, to coin a phrase, bog-standard democracy?
Roy Roebuck
London

 If a week in politics is a long time, 2003 is never. The PR deal might help LibDem MPs keep their seats, but it doesn't bring them any closer to real power or even influence. Tactical voting delivers power to New Labour, no one else. The only hope now for proportional representation and real democracy is to reduce the Labour majority to the point that the next government gets genuinely scared the Tories might get back in.
LR Lilley
Portsmouth
Lrlilleyski@aol.com

 When it comes, the referendum on electoral reform will settle the issue for a generation or more. Your leader was right to say that the Blair/Kennedy deal means the referendum cannot be held until 2003 or 2004, but wrong to conclude that this delays the campaign.

If reformers are going to win convincingly, then we need to use the remaining two-and-a-half years to build support in every constituency.
Stephen Twigg MP
stephentwigg@makevotescount.org.uk

 Charles Kennedy's performance so far only confirms my faith in oriental astrology. "A Snake [birth year 1953] will make a complete slave out of a Pig [1959] in no time, enmeshing the pig in his coils so that he loses all power of movement (from Paula Delsol's Chinese Horoscopes, 1973).

Blair was born in May '53, Kennedy in November '59.
Richard Burch
Exeter, Devon

webTitle: Letters: Our teeth are on edge

fields.headline: Our teeth are on edge
fields.trailText: Everytime our meat-eating friends are faced with a crisis in their food chain they reel out the same tired waffle about teeth (Letters, March 26). Because (they reason) we don't have the dentition or the stomachs to eat and digest grass, we must be carnivores.
fields.body:
Everytime our meat-eating friends are faced with a crisis in their food chain they reel out the same tired waffle about teeth (Letters, March 26). Because (they reason) we don't have the dentition or the stomachs to eat and digest grass, we must be carnivores.

Not so, and neither do we have the teeth or the digestion to be predators. We are as far removed from cows as we are from wolves. We evolved as (and remain) consumers of fruit, nuts, berries, leaves, seeds and roots. If our meat-eating friends ate a great deal less of their unnatural product and were prepared to pay a fair price for it the world would be a happier place. Now, that is a fact.
David Newstead
Staines, Middx
dnewst@horticulturists.net

 Neither man, nor any part of him, is "designed" by anyone, to eat meat or to do anything else. Man as a species has evolved, and the success of that species over a range of environments must be due at least in part to its ability to derive essential nutrients from a wide variety of sources according to what is available.

Granted we don't have the teeth or the stomachs required to digest raw grass - but unlike the ruminants, we can cook our vegetables to break down the cellulose.

Has your correspondent not noticed that millions of people all over the world live perfectly healthily and happily without eating meat? There are certainly plenty of rough, nasty meat-eating men around, but it's a little harsh to tar all humanity with that brush.
Sarah Hale
Newhaven, East Sussex

 There is nothing strange or horrible about the fact that humans eat carrion (AC Grayling, March 24); it is merely reality. What is odd is that we despise other creatures (hyenas, vultures) who do the same.

The horror of rot is no more reasonable; bacteria are everywhere, and their controlled action is required to make many foods (fruit, wine, cheese, bread) edible. To object to meat because bacteria have defecated on it is no more reasonable than refusing to sleep because of the millions of mites lurking in your pillow.
Elizabeth Moore
London

 As a 43-year-old, 6-foot tall, 15 stone vegetarian who works out four times a week and has six children, I can assure your correspondent that I have no desire to give up sex or run off and join a religious commune.
Steve Little
Lytham St Annes, Lancashire
steve@cliftonco.co.uk

fields.headline: This splash was bigger
fields.trailText: If Mir's re-entry was a metaphor for the fall of Communism (Letters, March 24), what are we to infer from the similarly meteoric fall of the world markets on Thursday?
fields.body:
If Mir's re-entry was a metaphor for the fall of Communism (Letters, March 24), what are we to infer from the similarly meteoric fall of the world markets on Thursday? It might also be worth pointing down that Mir came down on time, on target and caused almost no damage - whereas the stock market's out-of-control re-entry caused billions of pounds of damage in the UK alone.
Gideon Hallett
London
diogenes@freeuk.com

 I am not surprised that many are unaware of Radio 5 Live (Never heard of them, March 26). Have you ever tried to listen to medium wave in a car? It sounds like a live transmission from a drunken office Christmas party. If the BBC want us to listen, they should put it on VHF or, better still, on digital radio that covers the whole of the UK.
John Tait
Walton, Derbyshire

fields.headline: It's history
fields.trailText: Martin Kettle's exposé of US-Russian attitudes (Back to the bad old days?, March 23) admirably demonstrates how, for the US, Russia is a remnant of the extinct Soviet Union: ie a fag end of recent history.
fields.body:
Martin Kettle's exposé of US-Russian attitudes (Back to the bad old days?, March 23) admirably demonstrates how, for the US, Russia is a remnant of the extinct Soviet Union: ie a fag end of recent history. But for Europeans, Russia is, as it was for Castlereagh, Talleyrand etc, a permanent prime element in European affairs. It seems to me that this aspect of Russia escapes the attention of President Bush II. It could become - perhaps already is - a major factor in US-European relations. More than anything else I can think of it exemplifies the pitfalls of US-European attitudes no longer justified by the simple certitudes of the cold war.
Peter Calvocoressi
Bath

fields.headline: Still talking rubbish
fields.trailText: John Gripton (Letters, March 24) was told by his local waste contractor that recycling is uneconomic. Uneconomic relative to what?
fields.body:
John Gripton (Letters, March 24) was told by his local waste contractor that recycling is uneconomic. Uneconomic relative to what? That there are no markets for recyclable material is a myth. The markets are there, but why should recycling have to pay for itself when landfill and incineration do not?

The Community Recycling Network represents 300 not-for-profit environmental organisations. In partnership with local authorities, it delivers kerbside collection services to over 1.2m households (and rising) in the UK. We have never to my knowledge dumped any recyclable materials to landfill.

We need the assorted financial instruments in the government's strategy to be made to work. Recycling, and through it real waste reduction, will surely yet become our everyday reality.

Like Michael Quinton (Letters, March 24) I don't take a Sunday paper. The Saturday edition of the Guardian is newspaper enough for me.
Andy Moore
Coordinator, Community
Recycling Network
andym@crn.org.uk

 Are any other readers as embarrassed as I am? Every three weeks I take my newspapers (daily Guardian and weekly Observer) to be recycled. The stack of newsprint seems to grow depressingly larger at each visit. Today there are 38 pages of broadsheet and 96 pages of tabloid; not untypical. Why do you think we all need these supplements? Who reads them?
Eamon Grant
Birmingham
Eamon.Grant@uce.ac.uk

Every three weeks I take my newspapers (daily Guardian and weekly Observer) to be recycled. The stack of newsprint seems to grow depressingly larger at each visit. Today there are 38 pages of broadsheet and 96 pages of tabloid; not untypical. Why do you think we all need these supplements? Who reads them? Eamon Grant Birmingham Eamon.Grant@uce.ac.uk

webTitle: Letters: The sign of the turkey

fields.headline: The sign of the turkey
fields.trailText: Thanks to Catherine Bennet (More astrology folly, G2, March 22) for debunking Jonathan Cainer's attempt at renaming the constellations of the zodiac, in particular the sign of Scorpio into an eagle, with appropriate noble characteristics, of course.
fields.body:
Thanks to Catherine Bennet (More astrology folly, G2, March 22) for debunking Jonathan Cainer's attempt at renaming the constellations of the zodiac, in particular the sign of Scorpio into an eagle, with appropriate noble characteristics, of course.

There is already a constellation called Aquila (Eagle) and if the Sun were to appear in it I would be seriously worried. Nevertheless, there is an option which Cainer might consider: the designations by the International Astronomical Union of the constellations clearly indicate that the zodiac is made up of 13 signs, the one missed by the astrological fraternity being Ophiuchus.

I propose to name this new sign the Turkey, to be the star sign of those who are likely to become astrologers (with appropriate noble characteristics, perhaps).
EJ Zuiderwijk
Cambridge

 As an ex-professional astronomer, I was entertained by Catherine Bennett's article on astrology.

I'm afraid that Jonathan Cainer doesn't know his arthropod from his elbow if he thinks that the scorpion is an insect. Perhaps it's not only Jupiter which has an influence on intoxication. Maybe one of Mr Cainer's new signs of the zodiac should be the Famous Grouse?
Dr David Harper
Cambridge

webTitle: Landlords accused of breaching the Human Rights Act

fields.headline: Bar to justice
fields.standfirst: Gloucester's landlords thought the Pubwatch scheme was a sure-fire way of dealing with troublemakers. But two men banned from their locals say the exclusion initiative breaches the Human Rights Act. Fran Abrams investigates
fields.trailText: Gloucester's landlords thought the Pubwatch scheme was a sure-fire way of dealing with troublemakers. But two men banned from their locals say the exclusion initiative breaches the Human Rights Act. Fran Abrams investigates
fields.body:
It's late in the evening and little knots of T-shirted teenagers are trawling the bars of Gloucester, seemingly impervious to the wind-driven March rain. A police van noses slowly along Eastgate. Outside each venue stands a bouncer in a Crombie-style overcoat.

The only sign of trouble tonight is some loud banter and two girls in sparkly tops arguing furiously outside the H2O Bar. Even here, no one is taking much notice.

Inside the bar ("All Drinks £1") minimal decor is supplemented by swirling lights and a heavy beat. A booted girl with cleavage and a mini-skirt spots a friend and totters over to give her an alcohol-fuelled hug. But despite the warm atmosphere there are some who are not welcome in Gloucester's city-centre bars - troublemakers barred under the city's Pubwatch scheme for violence or involvement with drugs. And some of these alleged miscreants have complained that city landlords breached the Human Rights Act when they got together to ban them.

Under the Pubwatch scheme, one of more than 3,000 around the country, the licensees of more than 40 city pubs have agreed to stand together against disorder. Displayed prominently inside their premises are the names of the banned, printed in 36-point bold letters. There are 23 people serving out 12-month exclusions at the moment, six of them female.

Now, though, the Gloucester police force has been forced to withdraw from the programme after a local solicitor representing two excludees claimed it breached the Human Rights Act on two counts: that his clients were being punished without a fair trial, and that a ban interfered with their right to respect for their private lives. Around the country, other schemes have been forced to change their practice as a result of similar complaints. Even the government has got involved, with ministers promising legislation that should lead to more legally binding bans.

In Gloucester, pub landlords still get together regularly to discuss troublesome individuals but they don't receive information or back-up from the police any more. Previously a police licensing officer passed details of offenders to landlords and served notices on those who were barred.

In the circumstances, Clinton Douglas and Simon Morris might be feeling rather pleased with themselves. It was a letter from their solicitor, John Holmes, that persuaded the police to drop out of the Gloucester Pubwatch scheme. But the two bricklayers aren't in the least smug. They are still rattled by what happened after they got into a ruck with the doormen at Lanson's nightspot in December 1999. Although they were charged with affray and assault causing actual bodily harm, they had not been convicted when a police officer asked them to sign a form acknowledging they were barred from city pubs for a year. They agreed, but later Holmes protested on their behalf.

Douglas, who admitted hitting a doorman though he said he didn't start the trouble, was fined £100 for assault; Morris was bound over to keep the peace after the other charges were dropped. Even though their ban has now expired, the pair say they don't go out to the pub any more. They feel marked, and they are angry that acquaintances have seen them listed as troublemakers outside local bars they have never even been into.

"Basically we were guilty before they even proved anything. I just think it's wrong that people are believed to be guilty when they haven't been given a chance to say anything," says Morris, a former goalkeeper for Gloucester City Football Club.

Holmes, who was a city councillor at the time of the incident and a former leader of the council, agrees with him. Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights, enshrined in UK law by the 1998 Human Rights Act, gives all citizens the right to a fair trial, he points out. And because the police were involved in the scheme, it became in effect a public body covered by the act. Furthermore, Article 8, which protects respect for private life, was also breached because Morris and Douglas could no longer go about their lives as they did before.

"I do think these quasi-judicial proceedings can fall foul of the Human Rights Act. And these two lads had a strong sense of injustice that this had been done to them when they hadn't been found guilty of anything. But in the end it got dropped because their case finished and we didn't take it further," he says.

The management of Lanson's has changed since the incident and the former owner has left the area, but officers of the local Pubwatch scheme say the pair could have used a right of appeal if they wanted to try to overturn the ban. And Malcolm Eidmans, Secretary of National Pubwatch, is also unimpressed by Holmes' stand.

"This was all about protecting his clients' rights, but sometimes people forget there are responsibilities that go with rights, too," he says.

"Article 8 is a right to freedom of living. It doesn't give anyone the right to walk into a pub and demand to be served."

The potential threat of legal action has presented major headaches for Pubwatches around the country, Eidmans says. "We have advised schemes not to involve the police service in the process because if they do, the Pubwatch scheme can be thought to constitute a public authority. And the thought of being taken to judicial review can make people quite nervous."

Ministers agree that something has to be done, not least because of the terrible consequences of alcohol-related crime. One in five violent incidents now happens in a pub or club, and eight out of 10 cases at accident and emergency departments in peak time are alcohol-related.

Home Office Minister Charles Clarke, told the House of Commons last month that the government planned to legislate as soon as possible to force courts to consider passing exclusion orders on problem drinkers. Although the power to pass such legal orders already exists, it is little used. In 1995, the last year for which figures are available, just 28 orders were issued.

Several of those orders have been passed recently in York, though, where there is a thriving Pubwatch scheme working closely with magistrates. Members of the scheme believe it complies fully with the Human Rights Act.

Ashley Fitzhugh, a licensing officer in the city, explains that door or bar staff in more than 200 city pubs hold pagers, through which they can be alerted if trouble is coming their way. In addition, the local police magazine, The Copper's Tale, currently bears the pictures of 11 people banned for troublemaking, plus a further three who have been officially declared "habitual drunkards." These may not have been violent, but are recognised as having serious drink problems. Because all these people have been served with exclusion orders by the courts, Fitzhugh says, the scheme is beyond challenge.

"All these people have been convicted of offences. It isn't just done willy-nilly," he says. "I think the trouble starts when the police get together with landlords and just decide to ban a particular person. Here, we've got the crown prosecution service on side so they ask for exclusion orders as a matter of course."

However, the human rights organisation Liberty would like to see the issue clarified in the courts. Its associate director, Mary Cuneen, says Liberty might be interested in bringing a case to highlight the rights granted by the act to liberty and a fair trial.

"There's a question as to what extent the police have a duty of confidentiality, and to what extent they can discuss the information they have. On the one hand there is information which is really in the public domain, such as previous convictions, and on the other hand there is information which is really intelligence or suspicion - gossip almost," she says.

Meanwhile, pub landlords continue to defend their right to exclude. In Blyth, Northumberland, a local solicitor has twice complained on behalf of clients that pub bans constituted a breach of human rights. One of the two was accused of threatening a pub landlady. The other was the father of a man jailed for an attack in a pub, who said his rights were contravened by the shame of having his son's name posted on a list of banned individuals.

The local Pubwatch chairman, John Lewis, describes such interventions as "diabolical". He adds: "Everyone deserves human rights - you and I and everyone else. But now it seems that human rights are only for the criminals of this world. These people have continually contravened the human rights of landlords. We're not finding them guilty of any crime, but we are saying we don't want them in our public houses."

fields.headline: Cameras in court
fields.standfirst: Why that Christine Keeler photo is still posing a problem, and more gavel gazing
fields.trailText: Isn't there a law against filming in court? I mused while watching a preview tape of Partners in Crime, a Channel 4 fly-on-the-wall documentary series starting tomorrow evening.
fields.body:
 Isn't there a law against filming in court? I mused while watching a preview tape of Partners in Crime, a Channel 4 fly-on-the-wall documentary series starting tomorrow evening. It's the nearest we've come to showing the legal parts of the criminal justice system as they really are. The programme I saw (the first of four) was devoted mainly to the depressing story of a minor recidivist with a history of fluffing the opportunities he has been given to reform. His lively, sympathetic but realistic lawyer - Nottingham solicitor Digby Johnson, who is blind - tries to get him one final chance of going straight. The alternative is a long prison sentence. All the conversations between lawyers and clients are real, as are the contributions of the police and others in the system. The pre-trial procedures in court and Johnson's arguments in mitigation are reconstructions, but, unlike most such exercises, they're done not by actors but by the real participants - solicitor, magistrates and the defendant - and it's convincing. Here's the picky but. Some of the filming was done in a decommissioned courtroom in the Nottingham courts complex; but that is still, on one reading of the law, filming within the court's "precincts", which isn't allowed. I mention this only to demonstrate how absurd it is that the ban on televising court proceedings still relies on an act of parliament of pre-TV vintage - 1925 - aimed at banning photos in court; moreover, it doesn't define "precincts". Whatever decisions are eventually taken on the future of filming in court, at least let's make the law clear.

 A few weeks ago I wrote about the copyright dispute over the iconic 1963 photograph of Christine Keeler sitting astride that chair, seemingly naked. Lewis Morley, the photographer, claimed a copyright infringement when publicity snaps for a revival of a Joe Orton play featured actress Alison Steadman in exactly the same pose. Readers have pointed out that the pose had been used often since, to publicise, among others, the Spice Girls, Keith Chegwin (for his naked Channel 5 programme) and a property developer. Now the magazine Amateur Photographer (AP) has revealed a very similar photo that pre-dates Morley's Keeler by five years. AP's editor, flicking through old issues of the magazine, chanced on a portrait of a ballerina called Mimi, by an Italian photographer. There's no reason to believe that Morley saw that snap, but it does raise all sorts of philosophical, artistic and legal issues about the nature of original creativity.

 Here's another typical story of everyday litigants. Chap getting a divorce goes to the firm Mishcon de Reya (once famous for being solicitors for Diana, Princess of Wales). During a telephone conversation, chap asks his solicitor for a quote for the conveyancing work on the sale of the former matrimonial house. When told the amount, the chap goes berserk, making what were later described in court as "grossly indecent, obscene and menacing statements" to the solicitor, in language so strong as to be a criminal offence. Mishcons understandably decides it no longer wishes to act for the angry chap and prepares a request to the court asking to be removed from the official record as his solicitors. The firm provides the transcript of the telephone conversation. Unfortunately, by mistake, it also sends the transcript to the wife's solicitors. When wife reads husband's outburst she wants to use it against him when their court case comes up, as evidence that he's unfit to have contact with their child. Oh no she can't, says chap, it was a legally privileged conversation between me and my lawyer. Oh yes she can, says the appeal court. Chap is now even angrier.

 This is the sad announcement of the end of a campaign. For years, at great cost to my health, finances and personal security, I have fought fearlessly on behalf of truth and accuracy. Alas, after a succession of small disappointments, an event last week persuaded me that I have finally been beaten. There it was, filling the whole front cover of Monday's media section of the country's best daily newspaper. A gavel. The very gavel that I have so often, so passionately pointed out does not exist in English justice. Unlike judges in the US, judges here do not have gavels. Illustrating judicial authority by showing a gavel is therefore . . . I would say wrong, but I don't wish to antagonise the editor of whatever excellent newspaper it was that featured the offensive artefact. I retire from the fray, bitter and exhausted.

webTitle: Unmarried fathers offered full parental rights

fields.headline: Unmarried fathers offered full parental rights
fields.trailText: Unmarried fathers who register their children's birth jointly with the mothers will obtain full parental rights under a clause in the adoption and children bill, which had its second reading in parliament yesterday.
fields.body:
Unmarried fathers who register their children's birth jointly with the mothers will obtain full parental rights under a clause in the adoption and children bill, which had its second reading in parliament yesterday.

The reform will give unmarried fathers who sign the birth register the same rights as married fathers automatically have to a say in their children's upbringing.

Under the current law, if parents are not married, the mother is treated as the child's sole parent and fathers can obtain rights only through a parental responsibility order by the court or a written agreement with the mother that is registered with the court.

The government announced the planned reform in July 1998 to encourage fathers' commitment to the one in three children born outside wedlock.

Ministers believe the distinction between married and unmarried fathers is now out of date.

In 78% of births outside marriage, the father's details were included on the birth certificate. In three out of four of these joint registrations - and in 58% of all births outside marriage - the parents were living together.

But the numbers of parental responsibility orders and agreements are only a small fraction of the number of births. Most unmarried fathers are thought to be unaware of their lack of legal rights.

Jane Kennedy, minister in the Lord Chancellor's department, said: "I am pleased to to bring about this long-needed reform."

 New one-stop shops for people with family and relationship problems are to be piloted in five areas of England and Wales, the lord chancellor announced yesterday.

The family advice and information networks will be accessed through 10 solicitors' offices in the five areas. Clients will be given legal advice, help and information, encouraged to use marriage counselling, given access to mediation services and offered support in talking to their children. Children who need help will be able to get it through expert children's services.

fields.headline: Hidden stories
fields.standfirst: The Whitechapel Centenary show has so many histories to tell - of exhibitions and institutions, visitors and neighbours. But is it trying to cram in too much, wonders Adrian Searle
fields.trailText: The Whitechapel Centenary show has so many histories to tell - of exhibitions and institutions, visitors and neighbours. But is it trying to cram in too much, wonders Adrian Searle.
fields.body:
In his 1973 painting Painting, Smoking, Eating, Philip Guston shows us just that. A man lies in bed. His head is a great cyclopian kidney, unshaven, with a cigarette in his mouth. There's the bare dangling lightbulb and the cord of the blind. A pile of old hobnailed shoes, and paint brushes stubbed out in old paint cans, rear up on the far side of the bed. He looks at all this as he smokes. A plate of chips, bloodied with ketchup, rests like a hideous still life on the counterpane.

The whole scene is in thick pink light, thick pink paint. The palette is reduced to cadmium red, mars black, titanium white, a little ochre on the side for the fries. The paint scuffs the canvas, outlining and filling things in with a slow, remorseless deliberation. The smoke puffs out in a leaden steam-train plume.

A willy by Lucian Freud and a Bill Viola video. What the hell, you say, it's just a bit of a bash. It is a pity Gerhard Richter and Max Beckmann, Jackson Pollock and Arshile Gorky and dear old Ferdinand Léger couldn't come.

This is a rather old-fashioned show in terms of its installation: things on the wall, things on the floor, things on plinths. There are pleasant little conjunctions - a stern Bob Law near-monochrome next to a Japanese scroll; a Mario Merz neon phrase, lit up in a rusty little tub of wax, next to a Robert Rauschenberg 1961 Combine Painting (as though Rauschenberg, in his use of everyday scraps, looked forward to the noble impoverishments of Italian post-minimalism). The Rauschenberg also faces a Bruce Nauman down the length of the upper gallery, as though their shared allegiance to the spare poetry of the commonplace brackets the space. Somewhere between them hangs the Guston, which seems to suck everything else here into the orbit of its enclosed world. Or perhaps I like the Guston too much, or it is just the thing I happen to need right now. The curators (who include artists Anish Kapoor and Rosemarie Trockel, selecting about 20 works apiece) want to tell us a story. But we come to shows with our own needs, our own wish-lists and antipathies.

Patrick Caulfield's gentle, enigmatic 1963 portrait of Juan Gris is placed so that Caulfield's Gris appears to be looking at one of Gris's own late cubist works, hung on the adjacent wall. Jeff Wall's back-lit photograph of a grubby sink, with its wretched bar of soap and grimy Formica, is a play on the modernist aesthetic seen in Gris's work, in Mondrian and in Ben Nicholson. There's a show in here somewhere, about the clean and the dirty, abstraction and the real, but this isn't it.

This kind of curatorial play, with its tiny narratives, little rhymes, dissonances and juxtapositions, attempts to build a coherence where none exists. When this is done with intelligence, flair and sensitivity an exhibition can really take off, and works can enliven one another in interesting ways. But there's too much going on here for that, too many curators, too many old shows and old movements to nod to, too many debts to be paid. Somehow the Whitechapel's geographical position, and the history of the neighbourhood, with its succession of immigrant diasporas (from the Huguenots to Somalis, the Jews escaping the same pogroms as Guston's and Rothko's parents, the Bengalis and Bangladeshis), needs to be reflected. I like to walk along Whitechapel Road, and hear the amplified call to prayer from the mosque wafting over the traffic, to walk into the gallery and find the latest thing from Dusseldorf, or a drug-crazed Belgian artist-poet (Henri Michaux), or a reconstruction of 1970s conceptual chic.

Of course, this show can't tell the whole story of the Whitechapel, though the cata logue makes a pretty good job of its history. Exhibitions also depend on what can be borrowed: there was no way, for instance, the gallery was going to get Picasso's Guernica back, after its fleeting appearance here in a private-hire show in 1939 (although Nick Serota, director in the 1980s, tried to nab the painting en route from New York's Museum of Modern Art, on its triumphant return to Spain). Clement Attlee, local MP and leader of the Labour Party, gave a speech in front of the painting here in 1939. Tony Blair wouldn't even dare a photo opportunity in front of a Caravaggio at the Royal Academy the other week.

Looking at the Whitechapel Centenary catalogue reminds one of the changing manners of exhibition display over the past century: from the clutter of the salon-hang, to hairy-walled hessian and giant's causeways of white-painted plinths, to the more open, less encumbered displays of recent years. These differences mark the change in artists' thoughts about the status of the things they make, and how they occupy and are perceived in space.

There are no neutral spaces, however white and plain the walls, however unobtrusive the lighting, however anonymous and sympathetically tailored the architecture. In any case, there's once more a curatorial tendency to present things not as works in themselves, commanding more and more theatrical emptiness, but as examples of kinds of art, as illustrations to some educative text. Where once galleries moralised, now they try to explain, falling over themselves to be pluralistic, accessible, relevant. What we now might see as the appallingly overhung 1958 Pollock show, with its false, unpainted breeze-block walls and the fussy false ceiling, were, I guess, par for the course in the late 1950s. Although what goes around comes around, and such retro-hangs and intrusive exhibition designs are returning.

Institutions have histories, just as artworks do - and so too do spectators. Going to the Whitechapel Centenary is to revisit previous selves, to hear distant echoes. The Willem de Kooning drawing here looks forward - obliquely - to Thomas Schütte's cast aluminium figures, which once stood near where the de Kooning now hangs. Schütte isn't here, but the de Kooning made me think of him anyway. Then we have Mondrian's tree, a hilarious Arthur Boyd painting of a dog by a billabong, Hogarth's Happy Marriage close by Frida Kahlo's iconic 1940 Self Portrait. Good things and odd things and things that once looked serious, along with the flotsam, washed up on the shores of discarded fashion.

This is the fate not just of most art, but of most curatorial ventures, and of our infatuations as spectators, our little love affairs with artworks. It is impossible to look at a snap of gallery-goers at a 1960s private view and not laugh at the clothes, the Jason King mustachios. Or smirk when we read about shows called Black Eyes and Lemonade or Decorative Art from the Arts Group of Farnham. We will look back, one day, at the souvenir pictures of the artists' party that took place before the Centenary show opened, and laugh some more. Did we really look like that, did we really take this art, and ourselves, so seriously; was there really a show here once called Temporary Accomodation - and who was Philip Guston? But some things will remain, and stay great, and get better with time, and there will be surprises.

· The Whitechapel Centenary Exhibition is at the Whitechapel Gallery, London E1, until May 20. Details: 020-7522 7888.
