webTitle: Neville speaks up for mobile Cole

fields.headline: Neville speaks up for mobile Cole
fields.trailText: England had become stale and Andy Cole moves a lot - it's as simple as that, reckons Gary Neville. David Lacey reports as England prepare to meet a somewhat resurgent Albania.
fields.body:
Albania may still be peppered with pill-boxes, just in case the Ottomans get uppity again, but at least it is a land where sheep may safely graze. Compared to the last time an England football team came here 12 years ago, moreover, it is a clearly a country frog-marching itself forward in an effort to catch up with modern Europe.

Not unlike the present England side, who arrived here last night to begin preparing for tomorrow's World Cup qualifier in the Qemal Stafa stadium fervently hoping that they are about to add another three points to those gathered against Finland at Anfield on Saturday.

The nervous, nailbiting aspect of that win, along with the lateness of Albania's 2-1 defeat by Germany in Leverkusen on Saturday evening, when they held out until the 88th minute, does not entitle Sven-Goran Eriksson's players to think that the Albanian experience will be anything but tricky at the very least.

Eriksson's team is likely to show just the one change forced on the England coach by Sunday's withdrawal of Steven Gerrard for further treatment on his back problem. Nicky Butt is set to come into midfield alongside his Manchester United team-mates, Paul Scholes and David Beckham.

It is already clear that Eriksson does not intend to be pressured by media criticism of Andy Cole's failure to score in 12 England appearances, albeit five of them as a substitute, which was heightened by his shooting wide from eight yards on Saturday when he had only the Finland goalkeeper to beat.

"I still think Andy Cole is a very good option," was Eriksson's response after the match. "I'm happy with the way he is playing and not worried at all that he didn't score. All right, so he hasn't scored for England over six years, but he hasn't been playing for them every Sunday."

Last night Cole received predictable but reasoned support from another United colleague, Gary Neville, who made a point of mentioning the extra movement up front that the striker brings to England's attack. "This is something that the team has not had over the last two years," he said.

Alan Shearer's lack of mobility was mentioned more than once when England flopped in last summer's European Championship. "I'm not criticising Alan Shearer or saying that Andy Cole is a better striker," Neville insisted, "but we haven't had enough penetration in the last third of the field. Andy's pace is useful when people want to play off him or get down the sides."

Uncritical of Shearer Neville may be, but he was at pains to emphasise that in his opinion the injection of youth by Peter Taylor, who when put in charge for the friendly against Italy in Turin last November limited his choice of squad to players of 30 or under, had not come too soon.

"It was time to have a clear-out of the Euro 96 squad," he said. "Good as it was and much as players like Alan Shearer and Tony Adams might be missed, that squad had gone a bit stale. David Seaman and Teddy Sheringham still give us the experience we need but now I feel there is a better atmosphere because the young players coming in have no fear.

"They're refreshed, they're young and they just want to play football. Kevin Keegan wanted to do this but he only had time to start the process. Peter Taylor and Sven-Goran Eriksson have carried it on," said Neville.

Gary Neville is 26 and for the first time in his international career is finding himself playing for the oldies against the youngsters in training sessions.

 The England Under-21 game with Albania today has been switched after the rutted pitch at the Selman Stermasi ground was declared dangerous by the Uefa delegate. The match will now be at the Qemal Stafa stadium (kick-off 2pm BST).

webTitle: Fear is alien to Albania's plucky foreign legion

fields.headline: Fear is alien to Albania's plucky foreign legion
fields.trailText: Albania's side is now made up of players who earn their corn in the top leagues in Europe. Roy Collins identifies the men who could make life difficult for Sven-Goran Eriksson.
fields.body:
The mentality of the Albanian side that lines up against England in Tirana tomorrow will be totally different from any of the teams that have faced England before. And it will be unrecognisable from that of the team beaten 5-0 and 2-0 by England in 1990 World Cup qualifying.

Albania then had a team drawn exclusively from their poor domestic league, which left them not only vulnerable to top-class international sides but suffering from an inferiority complex that left them beaten before they began.

Now Albania's side is made up of players who earn their corn in the top leagues in Europe, which has sharpened their skills and, more importantly, hardened their attitude. Their captain Rudi Vata, who plays for Energie Cottbus in Germany, says: "We used to be afraid of teams like England. Now we go into those games believing we can win."

Vata, 32, sadly for the Albanians, is suspended tomorrow but that will not lessen the belief in the dressing room that they can achieve victory.

They will take heart from the form and experience of the midfield playmaker Bledar Kola, 28, who has 34 caps and plies his trade at AEK Athens.

Kola produced a wonderful performance against Germany on Saturday night, at times dropping off to break up attacks just in front of Albania's back three and at others moving up to join the attack.

The Germans never really managed to pick him up and it was no surprise that he was the man who scored Albania's equaliser, arriving when the ball broke free just outside the box to volley home.

If Kola plays as intelligently in Tirana and England fail to pick up his runs, Sven-Goran Eriksson may have a more nervous 90 minutes than at Anfield at the weekend.

Altin Rraklli, 30, who may return to the side in the absence of the suspended Edvin Murati, is another who has been educated at a high level of European football.

Rraklli, capped 44 times, is currently with Unterhaching but previously played for Freiburg and Hertha Berlin. He says: "We used to be a soft target but when we lost 2-1 to Germany in 1994 in Kaiserslautern, it was a turning point for us. I think we saw evidence then that we could be a side that could compete with the bigger countries. We showed that again on Saturday."

The German press referred to their opponents as the auswahl Albanians, the assorted Albanians, a pretty accurate description since they play for teams everywhere but Albania.

The striker Igli Tare plays for Brescia in Italy, the defender Arjan Xhumba plays in Greece, midfielder Fatmir Vata for Mannheim and sweeper Geri Cipi for Gent. The goalkeeper Foto Strakosha, the second most capped player with 45, is with Ionikos of Greece, while Besnik Hasi, a right-sided midfield player, is at Anderlecht.

They are the best crop of players ever to come from Albania. Vata admits that their biggest problem is that the players are so widely spread across the globe, which does not make for a close-knit side on the field. He says: "We have got a lot of good individuals now but we have to get to know each other more as a team, to play more as a team."

Despite the sickening nature of their 2-1 defeat to Germany, conceding what seemed an offside goal in the 88th minute, they will be more than up for it against England.

As Tare says: "We want to give our people something to enjoy. Wednesday will not just be about football but a celebration, something to take the people's minds off the troubles."

fields.headline: Eriksson: I won't make changes
fields.trailText: England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson will keep faith with the team that beat Finland for the World Cup qualifier against Albania tomorrow.
fields.body:
England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson will keep faith with the team that beat Finland for the World Cup qualifier against Albania tomorrow.

At a press conference today, Eriksson hinted that he will resist pressure from the press to drop Andy Cole. Instead he is likely to only make one change to the team that won on Saturday, with Nicky Butt replacing the injured Steven Gerrard.

"Steven Gerrard is not here, so we will play another player," said Eriksson. "But it will be more or less the same team. I will sleep on it for one more night. We shall see, but there will not be a big revolution."

Asked about Andy Cole, who has yet to score in 12 internationals and missed an easy chance against Finland, Eriksson said: "Andy had a very good chance against Finland and was unlucky but he played well. It is not a problem who scores the goal - it is that we win. The right movement is the main thing.

"If a centre forward does not score a lot of people say he can't play. For me Cole is a very good player. I spoke a little to him yesterday and today. He seems very calm and relaxed."

England have arrived in Tirana full of confidence, but Eriksson has warned his team not to expect an easy ride.

"I was surprised by the way Albania played against Germany," he admitted. "Maybe the Albanians deserved to draw, they had good chances, were well organised and defended well. They had many good individual skills and many good players."

fields.bodyText: England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson will keep faith with the team that beat Finland for the World Cup qualifier against Albania tomorrow. At a press conference today, Eriksson hinted that he will resist pressure from the press to drop Andy Cole. Instead he is likely to only make one change to the team that won on Saturday, with Nicky Butt replacing the injured Steven Gerrard. "Steven Gerrard is not here, so we will play another player," said Eriksson. "But it will be more or less the same team. I will sleep on it for one more night. We shall see, but there will not be a big revolution." Asked about Andy Cole, who has yet to score in 12 internationals and missed an easy chance against Finland, Eriksson said: "Andy had a very good chance against Finland and was unlucky but he played well. It is not a problem who scores the goal - it is that we win. The right movement is the main thing. "If a centre forward does not score a lot of people say he can't play. For me Cole is a very good player. I spoke a little to him yesterday and today. He seems very calm and relaxed."
